22oz bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a two finger off-white head that leaves thick lacing. The aroma is malt forward with sweet and bready malts, raisins, overripe orange, and booze. Taste is very smooth with caramel, bready malts, some alcohol heat, cherries, raisins, and figs, along with burnt toast and roasted malt. The boozy heat hides beneath the hop bitterness up front but slowly intensifies through the middle to the end. Finishes with a soft, slightly dry feel with lingering pine hop bitterness and lots of boozy heat.

22 oz bottle. Aroma: boozy, woody, and very malty, with hints of toffee. Taste/Palate: thick, crisp, and very sweet; finishes with a long bitterness. Incredible and over-the-top hop/malt balance. Another perfect beer from Stone!

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2015 650 ml bottle  Pours a clear mahogany with moderate head. Aromas of dark sweet fruit, toffee, and sweet malts. Flavors are same with a big dose of bitter dry fruity hops. Good but still over rated.

This rating replaces previous tap rating. Bottle is much better...
On draft poured into a tulip glass..copper pour with fluffy white head..aroma of hops,citrus,caramel,pine..bitter,dry taste with caramel,citrus notes..boozy but top notch.
Tap from Maltitude. Pours cloudy amber with white head. Aroma of floral hops. Flavor of bitter hops, caramel, and more hops. Bitter hoppy finish. Very tasty.

Bottled 10/08/13. Pours a cloudy amber with a subtle off-white/tan head. The nose is a bit sour with a hint of ash. If you inhale through your mouth at the lip of the glass before you sip, there is a very hoppy floral nose. The flavor is unexpected .... a hoppy, smoked caramel .... A hop bite that carries through to a smokey, charcoal, caramel finish. Lovely. 

I would let this get closer to 55¬∞, the flavors are much more pronounced ....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

66 cl bottle @ home (2013 vintage). Pours clear reddish amber with an off-white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma and flavour are caramel, sweet malt, pine, and resin - with a slightly bitter finish.

Draught. Malt forward, caramel, hops follow, piney and resiny, lots of alcohol. Mostly clear, reddish brown color, white head. Quite bitter, resinous flavor, some caramel malt character, lingering bitter finish. Bitter overpowers any malt complexity, meh. Good thing it¬ís high boost.

650 ml bottle bought from Systembolaget, shared at home. Light hazy orange amber-reddish color with small to medium beige nice head. Aroma is malty, caramel, bready, fruity. Taste is sweet and light bitter, malty caramel and fruity again. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
33cl bottle from Bottledog London. Dark gold color. Medium head. Medium to high sweetness. High bitterness. Hoppy and malty aroma.
Bottle. Color dark amber with medium white head. Aroma malt, caramel, hoppy, fruits. Taste sweet, hoppy, caramel, spicy.
A bigger version of the little bro Arrogant Bastard....something for a beer wizards...but bigger...bigger malt, bigger hops, bigger aroma, more caramel...

"I¬ím a huge Stone fan, not a big fan of Arrogant Bastard, so I didn¬ít know what to expect from this one. Stronger, but smoother, than it¬ís little brother, and significantly better. Big hops and malt all around. Quite hoppy/bitter for a barleywine. thoroughly enjoyed several vintages at Stone."
{retty killer big ass brew...loads of malts hops and so big. Every flavor imaginable. Balance on the big end...couldnt drink a ton...but It is a great brew

Aroma: intense grain malts, heavy, ripe fruits, caramel, alcohol. Appearance: hazy, dark amber, small, beige head. Taste: light sweet. 
Palate: very sweet malts expanding, intense overripe fruit, alcohol, turning very bitter and slightly dry in the finish. Overall: very nice IIPA, excellent aroma. Pint at Stone Brewing, Escondido.

Eh it¬ís okay. It¬ís a strong beer for sure and lives up to its name. All the things about not being worthy etc it¬ís not that tough. Aroma is syrupy sweetness. Lots and lots of malt. Like a ton. Not bad just don¬ít expect something else. The taste is alright. I heard from people it has a really subtle alcohol burn and that¬ís true. For how high ABV it is it definitely doesn¬ít show which is good. Realllllly bitter, and sweet. Some hopiness but definitely takes a backstage to the sweet malt. It¬ís not bad just in my opinion kind of average. I couldn¬ít really pick out something i really liked about it.
Pours a hazy copper color. Caramel citrusy taste. Hoppy flavor. Thick on the palat. Low carbonation but the head retention is very good. Alcohol warmth is noticable but not overpowering.
Mikon luona. Really thick, complex, roasted malty taste with well balanced drying aftertaste. Wonderful.
Very hot in the alcohol, hurt palate a little, and somewhat sweet. other wise great brew great use of hops, so big of a brew so big. I did like it.

From bomber. Pours a copper red with a big fluffy head and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is toffee and caramel and pine. Taste is the same, with a big malty sweetness and an even bigger hoppy pine bite. This is Stone, after all. This is like a big hoppy barleywine. Alcohol is present, but not as obvious as the ABV would lead you to believe. Bitter finish. A delightful BIG beer.
had the 2012 at a bottle share. even that many years removed, was still too hot for me.
Bottle at home. Sweet toffee and caramel, not as bitter as expected, juicy pine.

Look: pours a dark copper color. Light tan/ off white head. Hazy with slightly large pieces floating in it. 
Smell: sweetness. Caramel. Alcohol. Oak. Toffee.
Taste: slight bitterness on the back. Very sweet up front. Hot alcohol. Oak. Vanilla. Caramel and toffee.
Feel: leaves a thick film on the mouth like an IPA. 
Overall: ok beer. Very hot alcohol. But still good. 
First drank: home 8/23/14

Bottle from brewdog bar, Sheffield. Misty copper ale with no head. Figs and raisins, sweet treacle aroma. Taste is slightly sour tangy fruit with lingering bitterness. Quite prickly carbonation, lots of oil!

0.65l bottle from 2d2dspuma. This is a deep red near cola brown looking one with a small beige fading head. On the nose this one has lots of sweet vanillaish wood, thick sticky caramel, lots of beefy smoky nuances - nor overpowering though just really nice. Lots and lots of flavor and it has this extremely smooth velvety feeling in the mouth. It¬ís not hard to identify the heating alcohol in this, but it¬ís never disturbing. Really okay and almost barreled. Subtle smoky tones from the start to the finish. Nutty snickers caramel, sweet vanilla and it¬ís just one of those that¬ís absolutely loaded with flavors and impressions. Highly enjoyable. 12.08.2014

Bottle: Thanks Hackobock: Served in a shaker:
Medium sized creamy head. Almost clear amber body.
Aroma is a delicious mix of hops, yeast, wood, toast, some fruits, some herbs deliciously balanced.
Flavour has tones of bread, toast, bitters, malts, herbs, some caramel, dried leaves, hay/grass tints and some spice/alcohol.
Aftertaste is strong bitter with malts, some caramel, herbal toast, dried leaves and hay/grass.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, full bodied and a creamy sticky texture.
Touch of alcohol, nonetheless great beer and quite an easy drinker for 11.2%ABV.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
I poured a 22oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was dated as a 2010 release and cost $6.99 ($0.32 per ounce).

Appearance: An ugly rusty brown/brick red hue over a completely opaque body. Pours to a three-finger, ivory, frothy head which laces and retains very well.

Smell: Extremely sweet aroma of confectionery flavors and some alcohol.

Taste: I¬íve never been a big fan of Stone¬ís ¬ìBastard¬î series, as I tend to find them too abrasive for their own good (except Oaked Arrogant Bastard, which is perfectly balanced). Double Bastard tends to be the beefiest of them all, not surprisingly. I set this bottle aside in the basement nearly four years ago and had forgotten about until recently. With some age on it, this beer has become quite different from the hop bomb I remember. It¬ís very sweet, but not cloying, and is now well-balanced since the hops have faded.

If I were drinking this blind I could confuse it for a strong English-style barleywine. Huge confectionery notes are present right off the rip: toffee, caramel, peanut brittle, and butterscotch. Additional complexity through the middle with notes of red and black cherries. The hops still maintain some bitterness, but are not nearly as dry and astringent as they are fresh. Slight earthy/smoky/piney flavors through the middle with just a touch of bitterness. It finishes as it starts, but with some warming (and complementary) alcohol flavor and sensation. Overall, it¬ís a delectable beer, though not quite a mind-blower.

Drinkability: One of the reasons I¬ím not a fan of fresh Double Bastard is because it¬ís difficult to drink it in anything bigger than a tiny sip. With four years of age under its belt, it¬ís a different world. The mouthfeel is thick, calm, soft and smooth. The alcohol is subtle and leaves a gentle warming sensation. There¬ís a residual aftertaste of malty sweetness and minor dry bitterness, but it¬ís easily tolerable. Even at 11.2% ABV, this is no longer a beastly brew and I can handle the entire 22oz bomber myself.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 Glass, 4-ounce, bottle, during the Mondial de la bi√®re, savoured on June 11 2014; eye: mahogany, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, light lacing; nose: malt, resinous hops, caramel, fruity, orange; mouth: malt, resinous hops, caramel, astringency, fruity, orange, finale in malt with good presence of hops, full body, below-average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine

FRAN√áAIS

Verre, 4 onces, bouteille, lors du Mondial de la bi√®re, savour√©e le 11 juin 2014; ¬úil : acajou, limpide, pas d¬íeffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : malt, houblon r√©sineux, caramel, fruit√©e, orange; bouche : malt, houblon r√©sineux, caramel, astringence, fruit√©e, orange, finale en malt avec bonne pr√©sence de houblon, cors√©e, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement am√®re, l√©g√®rement sucr√©e, texture l√©g√®rement rugueuse; en r√©sum√© : bien

Bottle date 10-06-2013. Craft beer shit talk on the back of the bottle is about as long as the bible, so tldr that either. Clear chestnut brown with a medium sized diminishing beige head. Nuts, caramel, booze, brown sugar, sherry, over ripe banana, grapefruit astringency. Full body, oily texture, medium carbonation, medium/heavy sweet and bitter. Hot finish. Rough and clumsy. Not very pleasant and no sense in paying for this.

At Justin¬ís house warming party. Pours murky brown with white lacing. Aroma is cardboard, nice molasis figs, on the complex side. Taste, is as expected. It¬ís a very nice barleywine, just not my style.

Bottle from Brewdog, Sheffield. Big, boozy, chewy, sweet, toffee malt. Overripe orange. Light, spicy herb. Taste is orange sweet. Spicy dry. Burnt bitterness. Big, chewy toffee palate. Finishes big. With added bigness.

Lovely ale - properly layered brilliance best to savour on a sunny afternoon with a BBQ. Rich initial caramel malty texture, not too much alcohol for the strength but it is there hiding, slightly smokey with a with a small hop kick. Just Devine!

2013 Bottling. Another night, another Rocky Patel Edge Lite and now a Double AB added to the equation. Pour is a thick dark amber with a thin ring of suds that stick to the goblet as I sip. Malt and slight orange peel aroma - nice! Alcohol not as forward as one would expect for an 11.2. Lingering bitter finish. Just reward after an out-n-back overnight backack/camping trip. Will be adding three to cellaring stock for annual reviews. Yum!

2013 bottling
Aroma: Thick dried fruit, plums, raisins, slight caramel.
Appearance: Deep cherry amber. Very little head. Tiny bubbled lacing that¬ís edging towards brandy.
Taste: Dried fruits, lots of sweetness to go with the alcohol, some piney hops, caramel. Every sip seems to reveal another layer. Cherries slipping into the picture now.
Palate: Medium/full body, carbonation is more lively in the mouth than the glass. Starts off syrupy/stick and then slightly dry finish that bitters.
Overall: This is a world tour of flavor and aroma. It really hides the abv well. I may prefer the oaked version for a more regular occasion, but this really knocks my socks off. Outstanding.

This is such a badass beer. To me this tastes pretty much the same as Arrogant Bastard, just with more alcohol and perhaps a bit more character. I appreciate its complexity and its brazen character, but I can¬ít say I really enjoy drinking it. But at the same time hell yeah I¬íd drink it again.

Stone¬ís Bastard releases never fail to blow my mind. For me, Double Bastard proved to be every bit as enjoyable as the other releases that I¬íve, well, enjoyed (Arrogant Bastard and Oaked Arrogant Bastard). The malty caramel note that this brew starts off with is sublime. The spicy, herbal hop kick that comes after that is even better. Did I say better than sublime? I suppose that doesn¬ít make much sense. Yet, I do indeed consider Double Bastard to be twice as good as Arrogant Bastard. Admittedly, that¬ís a paradox. I consider Arrogant Bastard to be perfect. How can something be two times more perfect? Exactly. Infinity times two still equals infinity. That¬ís the nature of the Bastard series. Every beer is better than the last... even though the last one was perfect. Shit, maybe I shouldn¬ít drink so much before I post these reviews... Anyway, Double Bastard has a gorgeous amber-red color with a lovely off-white head. Aroma has boozy sweetness, dark fruits, and pungent hops. My bomber was bottled on 9/01/2013 which meant I was a mere 2 months and 1 day away from a year-old bottle. Oh well. The hops were still plenty aggressive but a bit refined. One thing¬ís for damn sure: the body was thick and the mouthfeel was warming in the best possible way. Okay, so I guess that was actually two things. Sue me. At the end of my tasting, I couldn¬ít find any gripes with this beer. I also fully enjoyed reading the bottle notes. Any brewery that uses the word "masturbatory" when talking about their ale is okay by me. Double Bastard made my night by giving me balls-out flavor with a healthy dose of class. I wouldn¬ít expect anything less than that from Stone.
Bottle at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated 30122011. Colour is cloudy brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, sweetness, caramel and malts.
Pours a deep amber color with off-white head. Caramel malts, floral notes, and some citrus on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more malt.

His one is really easy to drink. Not very hoppy and a rad but malty. Pours reddish in cor with a white head. Had at haymarket. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2016 Bottled. Pours hazy, amber with a small lacing, tan head. Aroma of caramel, citrus, floral notes and wood. Sweet flavor that ends slightly more dry and nice bitter. Full to medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. An excellent brew.

Transfer from BA reviewed on 6-3-12- 
Poured from 22 oz bomber into snifter

Appearance ¬ñPours a hazy brown mahogany color with a small off white head. The head fades fast to leave a very persistent white foam film on the top of the brew. 

Smell ¬ñ A bready base aroma is mixed with huge hop aromas. There are big smells of bitter-resinous pine and citrus hop with other aromas of earthy nature. Mixed with all these are lighter fruit aromas and a good bit of alcohol aroma as well; rounding out the aroma profile well.

Taste ¬ñ Throughout the taste there is a massive bready malt flavor. There is a light amount of caramel and light fruit sweetness at first mixed with a citrus hop flavor. The hop flavors at the beginning, while average for an IPA, then really start to gain strength. Citrus and pine hops start getting strong and start to bring some bitterness. The caramel sweetness is largely lost, but the citrus is still there. While the pine and citrus get stronger, they get huge and other hop flavors of a resinous earthy taste come to the tongue. All the hop flavors mix quite well and take the taste to the end, where they are greeted with a warming and lightly burning alcohol flavor, which oddly in some ways complements the hop quite well.

Mouthfeel ¬ñThe body of the beer is creamy and chewy with all those flavors really coating the mouth in all the wonderful flavors. The lower carbonation only accentuates the creaminess with it also accentuating the hop and booze burn as well.

Overall ¬ñ Very heavy and tasty. Its mouthfeel is fantastic and it has a nice blend of hop and booze taste. A great brew for sipping nice and slow.

22 oz. bottle aged two years. Deep amber color with still a nice level of carbonation. Aroma still shows a good hop presence, floral and fruit. Malt is here for sure as well, caramel and thick toffee.
The flavor still displays the hop presence as well, the signature Stone pine hop shows in the finish of the beer with the toffee, caramel and hints of dough. The ABV has mellowed out a bit and shows just a slight warming after the sip. With the age, the flavor has the malt taking over with the hops now complimenting the beer with a nice balance. Nice drink.

Good beer. Very malty. Strong. Thick head with a great brown color. Starts and ends strong. Like a loaf of bead. At 11.2% it gets your attention.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark red/brown body with a medium head. Aroma of barrels and a rich taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

10oz draft. Pours very thick with a thick lasting white head. Pours a murky reddish brown color. Aromas of sweet caramel, vanilla, and citrus. Bold flavors of pine, syrup, sticky hops , and raisins. Mouthfeel is very syrupy and thick . Finishes with a dry sweet hopped profile.

Slightly hazy glowing amber brown with a light ring of head. Very sweet sticky hop smell. A big semi sweet hop bitter syrup taste. With a bitter dry finish. That mild bitter last long after the sip is gone.
DRY BEER. I had a PBR after drinking just one of these and I couldn¬ít taste anything at all. Not for the weak.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2016 Shared 2011 bomber, poured to snifters showing a hazed to cloudy, copper color, with an off white/light tan layer of head foam, and spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was dank, with a bit of earthiness & greenery, dried fruit, and sweet maltiness. The taste was boozy, and quite bitter in it¬ís earthy & rind-like way, but mellowed just a bit by the complementary malt sweetness. Medium+ bodied, and quite Barleywine-ish.  Recently shared a current 2015 bomber, and showed a little more clarity in the appearance, with similar aroma notes, moderate carbonation, and the same, pleasantly even tempered, earthy & rind-like bitterness that lingered well with the alcohol warmth. +.1

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2014 Draft is 2006 vintage. Pours a hazy copper brown with sponge lacing. Aroma is earthy, with hoppy oxidation. A certain mild aged hop complexity. Flavor is "brandy sauce" with a slight note of rust, suggesting faded hops. I will revisit this review with a fresh bottle. From Stone event at Brickskeller 6/1/09.

The aroma of this is pungent of oak and whiskey barrels the head is beautiful and the ale itself is dark amber red and the taste is strong and a balanced bitterness with its hop blast also it has strong caramel,oak and leather with a strong ale taste and surprisingly sweet by far my favorite brew it?s a very intense ale i feel like i should be wearing medieval knight armor while drinking it. Definitely should have this with bbq/smoked meats maybe some good pretzels definitely awesome with a grilled burger.

14th March 2014, large bottle at a barbeque in Newport Beach, bought and took the bottle myself and didn¬ít share it!

Aggressive little bugger isn¬ít it. Hops full on in the mouth, yet it has a sweeter maltier nose: bitter in flavour with a definite Barley wine undertone. A fine beer in all aspects.

Bomber:
Pours reddish-brown, cloudy with a creamy tan head.
Caramel, coconut aroma.
Flavour is syrupy..bitter fruit...
Very thickly malted, caramel, woody bitter.
Prominent alcohol burn at the back of the throat.
A bit rough around the edges.

pours amber with a thick tan head. aroma is malty sweet. burnt sugars and tropical fruit. flavor is sweet, followed quickly by burst of hops. mouthfeel is syrupy. huge presence of alcohol. finish is very dry. big, bold and beautiful. great beer.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2014 This brew is for those who thought Stone couldn¬ít improve on their Arrogant Bastard Ale. They can, and they did.  This is an absolutely superb beer (by any reckoning).
Got a new TV today. Nothing fancy but when you've eaten ground chuck for almost a decade a flat iron tastes like manna from Heaven.

Flaska hemma. B√§rnstensf√§rgad och lagom grumligt tr√∂gflytande med en maltighet och beska. Mycket angen√§m liten sak.

Hazy dark amber pour on draft at Republic. Thick off white head. Malty nose. Big sweet taste, lots of hops and a big bitterness in the finish. Really nice. Big and kick ass for sure.
Bottle from systembolaget enjoyed at home. Pours dark ruby red with a nice head that dissapear quickly. Smells heavy. Tastes heavy malty, heavy alcohol balanced bitter.
Tap. Bold and flavorful malt front with a noticeable hop finish that is not overly bitter. Spicy and strong flavor.
Almost like an unsweetened barleywine. Strong malt flavor. Some bitterness. Strong alcohol heat. Good.

2009 Bomber - Maple ruby pour with off white head. Nose and taste are malt bombs with plenty of dark fruit, sweet malt, and raisins. Some residual hop bitterness present. This stuff ages real well as evidenced by this 5 year old bottle. If it were a little sweeter I would have thought it was a BW. Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ah, Stone descriptions: the Steely Dan liner notes of beer.Tap. Orangish amber with a small pale beige head that lasts well. Aroma of very ripe apricots, vanilla, mandarins, grapefruit. Just short of syrupy. Sweet hay and apricot, grapefruit, pine, kumquat, a little pepper. Main finish is brief, then grapefruit and pine linger. Compressed flavours but punchy hops - sweetness doesn¬ít really get in the way. Unsubtle but good.

Bottle. Dark clear ruby with a 1 finger off white head. Aroma is melted Jolly Rancher, burnt caramel and slightly plasticky. Taste follows suit but adds some floral hops and slight alcohol burn. Caramel/butterscotch takes center stage. Big sticky mouthfeel. Certainly big.

Deep red-Brown color with a nice tan head. Aroma is citrus, pine, caramel. You can taste the alcohol from the first sip. Also has a citrusi, hoppy flavor with a sweet hint. Did not like it because Of the alcohol taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Oh! What a knockout. Sturdy body, heaps of malt and hops and flavor, deep steady aroma underlined with enough alcohol to give justice to every nuance. Warming, cherishing, smooth yet harsh, rich. Yes - rich. If there is any flaw it should perhaps have been a tine bit less sweet. One of the best beers I¬íve made the aquintance with.
This is a hell of a beer. It has a great warming effect without being boozy. Wonderful bitter after taste makes you crave more.

@ Havregatan. Flaska fr√•n Systembolaget (94:-). Fruktig och humlig, ganska s√∂t, karamell, alkoholv√§rmande, medelfyllig till fyllig. Avslutningen √§r fruktig och ganska torr med en vis alkoholv√§rme.
Pours a ruby color with a off white head. The aroma is sweet and full of fruits, biscuit, earth and sugar. And the flavors really hits me, pine, grapefruit, caramel malts and raisins.

Amazing brew. Aroma is surprisingly very sweet. Drinking straight from the deuce-deuce so the bottle looks nice. Flavorful with a very bitter finish. Nice!
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text:
Ap: Quite clear, red/ruby, white/yellow head.
Ar: Just amazing. "Dat malt"...tons of caramel, toffee, some dark fruit, some pine, some alcohol as it gets warmer.
T; Massive toffee, lovely high bitterness. 
O: Really nice brew!

Bottle 9-16-13
Amazing raisiny brown sugar aroma. Thick mouthfeel with a hoppy finish. Phenomenal beer that tastes like a well-balanced barleywine

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A slightly hazy ruby color with a small amount of white head that sticks around the rim. Smells of sweet honey, malt, honey biscuit, a little pine. A nice smooth sweet taste, honey biscuit, a mild bitter, good mesh of tastes. A good representation of the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from drinkstore
Dark amber with beige fluff head and punch of pine on the nose. Full bodied, heavy, sticky, resinous toffee, warming boozy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2014 22oz bottle poured into a Stone specialty IPA glass (a hybrid between a flute and snifter). Where to start with the nose on this one ... well, I guess, at the start. The first aromas I picked up were that of vanilla and caramel primarily. After a little bit, some dark berry aromas start coming through followed shortly thereafter by a hint of nuts, figs, and plums. There¬ís also some licorice tucked away in there. The next round of aromas had a bit of a musty and damp smell to it, but it was also accompanied by a hint of pine, wood, and honey. By the end of the drink, I was also picking up citrus, cuacao, as well as banana & clove notes. It pours a clear honey orange color with a thick, beige, sudsy head that¬ís in no rush to recede. A healthy, rocky lacing is left behind on the glass. A medium-high bitter (fairly moderate by Stone standards) combines with a medium malty sweetness. This full bodied beer is creamy going down; aided by an abundant, yet mellow and soft carbonation. The malty front end is a toasted caramel and roasted nut flavor with some hints of dark, meaty fruits (figs / plums). Mid mid drink, this also takes on a woodsy quality as well. Notes of pine, resin, and citrus combine for a full, but mellow bitter finish with a nice touch of bourbon-caramel alcohol warmth; it a mildly dry finish  The aftertaste left behind is a balanced blend of smokey caramel, grapefruit, and resin with a touch of licorice.

From the giant bottle! Poured into a shaker. Ruby colored with a tan head. Aroma is pretty much all malt with a little bit of earthiness. Flavor starts off malt forward with sweeter notes like a red, but finishes with some earthy and piney hop notes. Fairly creamy and smooth for the ABV. Overall this reads like a nicely balanced strong red ale.

Poured from the 3l 2013 release. Very creamy thick head. Aroma has a nice balance of malty and hoppy. The malt character is biscuit y. It tastes like red malt s were used. The hops are a nice blend of slightly citrus but mostly dank and bitter! It¬ís bitter and I love it!

A great beer, considering how high in alcohol it has, still taste lots of hop bitterness and malty. The kind of beer you bring out when you have wine drinkers over, who think they know a lot about wine, except you may not want to share it.
Aroma is hops, fruits, caramel. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet, bitter, caramel and sweet. Very nice.

Appearance: Clear copper/ruby with finger thick ivory head.
Aroma: Pine, resinous, liquorice, dried fig, plum, woody, spiritous, musky, grapefruit note and treacle/caramel.
Taste: Medium/high bitterness, medium sweetness and low/medium sourness.
Palate: Thick grainy texture, medium body, average carbonation, astringent lingering bitterness follows an initial sweetness. The finish is fruity, spiritous, liquorice, burnt caramel and has alcohol warmth.
Comments: Very tasty and glass lace. 2012 release.
2011 edition. From notes. Big beer, sweet fruit, plums, cherries, caramel. Lots of hops, but strangely does note destroy my palate, just kidding. Gotta love the DB.
Backlog, 2011. Caramel, syrup, brown sugar and raisins. The alcohol comes through together with some dried fruits and a long afternote of sweet-soaked hops.
maltig, karamell och n√∂dig ton och tydlig humlebeska. Alkoholstinn s√• man f√•r ta det lilla lugna. En alldeles f√∂r stor flaska, 25 cl hade r√§ckt!

A kind of strong alcohol note and warm aroma of dried fruits. Deeply burnt orange/red appearance with off-white lacing.
Very sweet and bitter taste and a very long-lasting hop bite. Noticing the 11.2%. Leaves an oily palate. Great beer but such a bastard!

Pours a unique reddish brown color with some sediment. Has more head than I was expecting for 11.2% ABV, but it recedes quickly. Great looking beer. Smells strongly of alcohol, more of a sweet stout or barleywine smell than an ale. The aroma and appearance are near opposites of one another. Taste is hops up front, alcohol in the finish - that¬ís it. Not much of a malt presence that I could detect. Mouthfeel was fairly smooth for such a strong beer, but the aftertaste is way too boozy. You couldn¬ít eat anything with this beer; it would dominate the taste of any food. I was hoping for something more complex. I¬ím a big Stone fan, but I would recommend just about any of their IPA¬ís or stouts over this one. This beer is good for getting drunk (which does have it¬ís place), not for savoring.

2011 bottle pour..medium caramel color with decent amount of carbonation..nose is controlled by sweet malt..molasses..brown sugar..mouthfeel starts out fairly medium bodied with just an ok mouthfeel that has traces of teriyaki-spiked soy crossed with maple syrup..kind of a lot going on here..lingering boozy heat comes through at the end..

650 ml bottle. Copper color with off white head. Aroma sweet, raisins, marmalade, toffeee and caramel. Taste is very boozy, caramel, pepper, dates, dried fruit but the alcohol is overpowering. Way too boozy
Looks like a beer smells like a beer, tastes like Kestrel. Awful in everyway, and even worse for pretending to be a beer.
Flaska fr√•n @Peter_L. M√∂rk B√§rnstensf√§rgad med beige-r√∂tt skum. Doftar m√∂rk sirap och v√∂rtbr√∂d. Stark smak av malt och m√∂rk(?) humle. V√§l dold alkohol. Lite f√∂r kraftig f√∂r mig.
M√∂rk b√§rnstensf√§rgad, Krona som ligger kvar l√§nge. Doftar s√∂t blommigt med lite godis i, Smaken har en perfekt blandning av s√∂tt och beskt. l√•ng eftersmak,
0,65l bottle from the flagship Alko. Pours murky dark amber with a low head. Aroma is malts, dark fruits, hops and alcohol. Flavor is malts, fruits, alcohol and plenty of hops. Pretty good stuff.

.65l bottle from Alko Flag ship
Pours murky amber with medium, stiff off-white head. Aroma is alcohol, sweetish, dark malts, fruits, some nuts, caramel. Flavor is malts, alcohol, nuts, syrup, dry hops. Nice dry and hoppy palate. Swell!

Bold and flavorful malt front with a smokey and noticeable hop finish that is not overly bitter but just right... Truly great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Slight retention with good lacing. Smells of molasses and brown sugar. Tastes of brown sugar, vanilla and hops. Medium bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This vicious brew punched me in the mouth and offered no apologies. Appearance is amber in color, bordering on dark brown. Whatever head there was quickly dissipated and left off white lacing on the sides of the glass as it was carefully consumed. It¬ís significantly more aggressive than say it¬ís more timid associate (Arrogant Bastard), thanks to the elevated alcohol content. Weighing in at a healthy 11.2 percent it could be used in a pinch to power lawn equipment or remove rust. Though the intense flavor and backdrop does an adequate job disguising the elevated ABV. In my opinion the Double Bastard seems to have ironed out all the perceived shortcomings of Arrogant Bastard Ale however insignificant and delusional as they may be. The taste is well balanced for something as visceral as it is. The taste lies somewhere between being to hoppy and being overly malty. Flavors are reminiscent of roast caramel, heavy malts and rich aged leather, all accompanied by a steady backbeat of bitter and aromatic hops. As far as I¬ím concerned Stone can do no wrong. This is a tasty beer meant to be enjoyed on a crisp winter evening accompanied by the warm harmony of a fire¬Ö or as a sleep aid. All joking aside, it¬ís a very good beer.

Appearance: Hazy amber color with a off white head. Ok lacing.Aroma: Sweet malty, a bit hoppy and fruity.Palate: Medium to full body. Ok bitterness and a bit sweet. Soft to average carbonation.Taste: Malt and dried fruit syrup.Overall impression: Powerful tasty evening sipper.Personal stats: Bottle from Systembolaget in Uddevalla, Sweden.

Pours a deep amber with a little off-white head and average lacing. Aroma is sweet with hints of dark fruits, toffee, vanilla, oak and a little brown sugar. Taste follows the nose with a mixture of everything from the aroma initially but then the hops try to shine through but it is a futile attempt. The malt is running the show here but that is to be expected with such a high abv. Medium to full bodied with low to moderate carbonation and a somewhat dry finish. Alcohol is noticeable but not in an off putting way. Having said that, be careful because this beer packs one hell of a punch. Next on the agenda is a growler of Stone¬ís Espresso Imperial Russian Stout so my liver is going to take a beating.

Pours a clear caramel with a slightly tan head. Aroma is a big sweet malty. Booze, dark fruits. Taste is on the sweet side. Raisins, syrup. Medium-full body and low carbonation. Syrupy texture. Overall a huge beer. Best shared. Cheers!

A pretty dark amber beer with a foamy white head. Smells of caramel and hops. This is a very intense beer, with an overpowering caramel flavor, almost like burnt caramel, with a syrupy feel. The bitterness starts light, but then quickly grows stronger. Like Stone¬ís Ruination IPA, I found this a bit too much, but at the same time I really enjoyed sipping this over a two hour period. Not for the faint of heart, that¬ís for sure.

rusty amber color with a few tan bubbles; smells like whiskey, raisins, toffee, leather.... Nice alcohol warmth blending with intense caramel, vanilla, dark fruit and toasty bitterness; lively carbonation, full flavored with just a bit of syrupy mouthfeel. Brash bastard.

640mL bottle bottled on 10/18/13
Deep copper body, holds a dense off-white head.
Serious aroma; substantially woody/piney hop presence, cooked citrus, dried fruits, rich grainy malts and caramels with a spicy alcohol note.
Big thick oily palate, medium carbonation, seriously long palate.
A brutal assault on the palate follows... 

Lots of woody hop spice, lots of caramel malts, lots of bitterness, lots of alcohol.
Lacks subtlety, alcohol on finish is a bit too obvious and warm, probably the lesser of their big name beers...still good though!

This beer (2013) doesn¬ít hide the alcohol but that isn¬ít a big point. It looks great and tastes even better. The aroma is hard to pin down as the alcohol kinda masks the hops a did and you get thick bready malts. So far so good. The taste is earthy hops and beautiful candied caramelized toffee and a roasty nuttiness. along with a good doses of hops. Delicious beer. well done. (again)

22oz bottle dated 9-26-2013, just over 4 months old, aged at cellar temp as instructed by the bottle. Pours a clear reddish amber with lasting foamy head and great lacing. Aroma is ripe fruits, candy sweet malts, earthy, cherries, and cheesecake. Taste is very sweet and malt forward for a few seconds until the hops come around and balance it out. Hops and alcohol burn mildly in the end. Ends bitter and dry. I have been burned by over-aged beers that turn into malt bombs and this is leaning towards that side of the taste spectrum. I suspect fresh this would be much better. Alcohol is appropriately evident for the ABV, with a mild burn and taste.

22 oz bottled over 4 months ago from Evergreen Discount into my NBB globe glass. Dark amber-reddish and hazy appearance with a large, light tan head, slowly diminishing, moderate lacing. Aroma of alcohol, caramel, toffee, pine, earth, bitter hops, toasted malts and light fruit. Similar flavor, strong hop bitterness, medium malt sweetness and lots of alcohol. Pretty full body with a dry feel and a boozy, lingering, bitter finish. Pretty good, a little too much alcohol coming through.

Bottle shared with a friend. Color: nice clear amber beer with small carbonation and medium white foam. Smell: hoppy explosion and domination. Floral and herbal nose with herbs and grass. Taste: oily sensation on mouth, with hoppy explosion with amazing bitterness. Really tasty beer with good bitterness expression. Aftertaste: strong bitterness with a dry sensation.

...alright, I¬íve drank this beer for years and for some reason I never rated it. Had it on tap in California. pours a dark red to brown nice foamy head. Nose is insanely bitter, almost astringent with huge pine oil bread. Taste is just waves of assault. IBUs to the limits, boozy, bitter, bread, pine, citrus finish.

A wonderful aroma of caramel malts. It has a deep amber color with a light tan head. The taste of caramel, with cherry notes and a pleasant malt kicker to the palate. It has a special blend on malts that I could drink all day long. It is well balanced.

Light burgundy with thin head. Pungent malts and spices on the nose. Profusion of flavors, cherries, prunes, candied citrus rind, cinnamon, very boozy followed by very dry and insistent hopping .After taste just keeps on going. Will probably be tasting this in the morning.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours an opaqque bright ruby with a medium off white head...nice lacing. aroma has fruity maltiness and earthy hop notes. flavor is very earthy and bitter...almost medicinal...very resinous and piney. mouthfeel is medium and silky with a very dry resinous piney/earthy bitter finish. i can see the allure but i find this too bitter to be enjoyable for an entire glass.

Truly great. Strong hop aroma and sweet malt background, maybe a little spice. Dark amber color with a medium head that dissipates quickly. Decent weight and the carbonation held up nicely as this was the 2011 edition. Full of flavor as it seems very close to an imperial IPA but with a fuller malt presence. I also detected a fruit essence on the back end, maybe tropical fruit from the hops. A truly fine beer.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish brown with a white head. Taste sweet, pine, hoppy. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Elite in every way. Straddles that perfect middle ground between a maltier Imperial IPA and a hoppier Barley Wine. Age-worthiness accentuated by a pinch of yeast that grows over the years. Beyond criticism.

22oz bomber poured into a pint glass. Appearance is clear, dark amber with a modest two-finger cream-colored head that settles to a thin ring. Some lacing, which was surprising considering the ABV. Aroma suggests barleywine with lots of sweet caramel, brown sugar, alcohol, pine, cherries, and orange peel. Taste is a two-pronged all-out assault from sweetness and bitterness. Lots of caramel sweetness with dried fruit and orange. Bitterness features pine and floral notes. Alcohol is prominent, too, but complimentary not derailing. Full body, sticky, chewy texture, softer carbonation, bitter and warming on the finish, plus drier than expected for a high gravity beer.

On tap at fatheads. Pours a medium copper amber with thin light tan head. Smell is hoppy, with a little caramel. Taste is a lot more hoppy than I thought it would be, some sweet malts on finish. Really drinkable for 11%. On tap is definitely better than bottle. A great hoppy strong ale to judge others by.

Draft at BrewDog, Shepherd¬ís Bush on 7 December 2013. Poured a very dark brown with a thin, beige head. Aroma of brown sugar, grassy hop and some iodine. Pine needle hop bitterness hits the tongue with some straw and dry grain. Finish is very dry hop resin balanced with dark fruit sweetness and oaky hints.

On tap at Special Brews, pours a slightly hazy copper color with a thick tan head that leaves good lacing. Smells of pine, citrus, and dark fruit. Tastes of the same things in the smell. Mouthfeel is slick and oily and well carbonated with a dry finish. This is a great strong ale. Good flavor with a good amount of sweetness. Better on tap then out of the bottle.

Bottle from 16 Tons Taphouse via Jakeb, 2012 vintage. Pours a cloudy brownish orange. Little to no head, aroma big and broad, full of candi sugar. Body full and thick, still very hot, finishes hoppy and strong, lots of malt.
I thought this was phenomenal. Aromas are sweet caramel malts, melon, bubblegum, and resin. This beer tastes like someone dipped a pine cone into honey. So good. Lacerative mofo indeed.

Bottle to tulip
Smells of spruce, pepper, pine, and booziness.
Slightly reddish amber and a tan head.
Bitter, orange, grapefruit, and black pepper.
Mouthfeel is silky and oily, with an alcohol burn.
Bottle - Malty caramel sweetness with a bit of earthy hops. Clear copper with a decent white head. Bitter sweet malty notes, more like an american barley wine. Another nice showing.

Bottle. Red copper pour. Aroma - sweet hoppy american barley wine smell a cross between a double IPA and a barley wine. Taste - hoppy, sweet, lots of caramel malt character with a bitter IPA finish. Good stuff.
From a bottle. Very strong and very bitter beer. There¬ís quite an amount of malty sweetness there too. Maybe a bit too much.

Bomber from world beers. Pours dark amber. Thin white head. Scent of malt and caramel. Smells pretty boozy. Surprisingly hoppy. Would probably be even better if i give it 6 months. Still pretty tasty.

I am not in love with Stone¬ís Brew. Often than not they can have too much hop when it would be best to play up the floral aspects. Their smoked porter was too literal and therefore lost me. I did enjoy their Suede. It is an America Strong Ale. Foamy head. Dark amber hue. The spices seem to be lost in the boziness of it. And the dim body does nothing to support the overwhelming taste of alcohol. It seems like with their beers they try way too hard to get a point across with a hammer when a more approachable taste would serve better. Sometimes the overstated brew is, overstated...

Not sure that this really deserves the 100 rating. It¬ís very tasty, with big caramel bread malt flavor, but unlike most other Stone brews, there is not much hops in evidence. The high alcohol content is evident in the mouth feel!

Dark amber color with a nice head. Great bitter flavor of hoppiness from heaven! Love the aftertaste of yellow grapefruit but without the fruitiness of many west coast IPAs. If you're a hop fan this is definitely a must for your list. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours into snifter with reddish brown hue. Sugared candied pineapples, apples and raisins in the nose. Complex flavors and really a lot going on as this opens up. I taste some prunes, pineapples, sour apples, caramel, brown sugar¬Ö Slight alcohol burn and oily on the finish. Immensely sweet and bitter. Really a hell of a beer.
bomber from hyvee, aroma is of dead fruit, and raisen, alcohol, some mocha taste with strong alcohol, awesome beer overall

This is a very complex beer, it's a beautiful deep mahogany color that has a rich, robust aroma and explodes with flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Maybe I¬ím not worthy this beer was perfectly clear excellent aroma but just too oily this goes and oily green grassy hops way too over-the-top.

I AM worthy ! This is deep rich double malted chewy full beer. The beer is rich and filling. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Bomber.  Crystal clear copper appearance.  Aroma is almost like a IPA past its age.  Tastes sweet and moves to a somewhat bitter finish. Hides abv well but I didn¬ít find it overly enjoyable to drink.-- rated with beerbasher

22oz bottle (2012 release) given to me as an anniversary present from my wife last year (11/29/12). Pours a hazy dark amber color with a finger of frothy tan head. Lots of floaties. Aroma of old citrus hops, apricots, grapefruit skins, and lots of caramel malt. Taste of bitter grapefruit, pine, old rotted citrus, burnt caramel, and a nice toffee and roasted malt aftertaste. Solid stuff!

22oz bottle into tulip. Minneapolis. Bottled 09.06.2013

Appearance: red/copper in color. mostly clear with a slight haze. Small tan head.

Aroma: Caramel and brown sugar is most present. Citrus and floral hop notes  back it up. Slight alcohol. 

Taste: Sweet at first, but evolves into a bitter, long lasting finish. The bitterness builds as you continue to drink the bottle.

Palate: A full body and mouthfeel. Light carbonation. Long bitter finish. 

Overall: Strong ale indeed. Nothing subtle about this beer. The flavors are upfront and intense. More bitter than I expected, but still very nice. For me this beer is less about complexity, and more about straight forward, strong flavor.

Appearance: deep clear amber with a silky, creamy, dense, near white head, poured into a snifter. Aroma: caramel and roasted nuts, toffee, plums in syrup, a hint of woody booze	.  Taste: brown sugar, raisin, caramel, candied nuts, a big wash of resinous, piney hops toward the back end.  Finish: slowly building boozy warmth grows over a lingering malty caramel and brown sugar thread, balanced by the lingering hoppy dryness. Notes: Definitely a big, strong ale, but it maintained a good semblance of balance and was surprisingly drinkable for an 11.2% beer--the alcohol was reasonably well-hidden.  Beerdvent 2013, day seven.
Tap at stone brewing, escondido. Clear deep amber color, white head. Aroma is malts, oak, cherry, fruits, hops. Balanced malty body, big hops, some oak, fruits and some berries.

Pours a murky orangish-red with a decent off-white head. Aroma is slightly boozy, nuts, dark fruits, brown sugar, and some hops. Bold flavor that kicks you right in the taste buds. Roasted nuts, malts, a hint of sweetness, and a surge of hop bitterness to keep you humble. This beer packs a punch at 11.2 percent and they do not hold back with the flavor profile. There really is not mistaking that you are drinking a very strong beer. Sometimes, that¬ís exactly what you need though.

2011 bottle, pours a deep murky brown with no head. Aroma big on malt with slight hop bitterness. Taste is caramel, brown sugar, toffee, pine and slight grapefruit. I¬ím amazed that the hops stuck around this long. Not
Bad

Bottle pour dark amber copper. Nose sweet malt, dank hop. Hint of earthy spice. Taste sweet malt, spicy hop. Bitter starts in mid palate and lasts through a long finish. Reasonable mouth feel. I once drank a 3L of this for New Years.

Draft at jungle jims: pours a dark, orangish red color with a healthy tan head. Aroma is toffee and pine needles... You know it¬íll be bitter before you try it. Taste is a bit of caramel and sweetness, but that gets knocked out by the bracing piney bitterness. Lovely.

Deep copper, very yeasty, no head, strong lacing, sweet, flowers and alcoholic, candy sugar, intensely sweet on the palate with a long lingering harsh and strong bitterness, almost medical in its bitterness

A 3rd of a pint in Brewdog Glasgow (¬£4.25):
An alright beer at best and I felt that the beer was only about loading the flavour with a mix of hops and alcohol meaning the balance was poor and the beer was a hard on to drink with everything in your face and to the extreme. I¬ím glad I got to try this one but I don¬ít think I¬íll be giving it a go again.

Bottle into snifter. Dark red color, dense small head. Aroma is toasty, resin, earthy, caramel, honey, banana. Flavor is powerful, with plenty of hops, roasted coffee caramel. Full bodied, sticky, lots of carbonation, extra bitter finish. Doesn¬ít live up to the diatribe on the back of the bottle, but pretty good.
Keg at Brewdog Brum. Nice lacing. Big, rich flavour, my old beauty. But pointy and glassy, like a posh Christmas tree decoration. Obviously lovely.

Wundersch√∂ne farbe, bernstein, feine weisse schaumkrone, malzig fruchtig und etwas hopfiges aroma, sehr gehaltvolles mundgef√ºhl, malzig und leicht alkoholisch im geschmack, stark gehopft, bitterer abgang welcher lange anh√§lt

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good beer. Honestly reminds me a lot of regular arrogant bastard. Another solid creation from stone.

Keg at Brewdog Edinburgh.Pours dark hazy orange. Nice head. The aroma is rich citrus hoppiness with sweet malts. And yes this is hoppy and bitter. That said, comparing this with many contemporary west coast US style ales, not so unusual these days... actually nae, This is one rich hoppy bastard ! What I particularly like about this is the way that the relatively massive hop bitterness doesn¬ít in any way derail the wonderful malts and hop flovours. It just works. They got this spot on, as they did with Arrogant. Had this a few times now and certainly will again.

Pours burnt orange with some red flames amongst it. Large, impressive robust tan head - its like bubble-bath foam on bath water.
Heavy hoppy aroma. Bitterness is invasive even in the aroma. Some toffee malt, heavily piney. Reminiscent of an even more brutal American DIPA. 
Heavy and strong mouth-feel. I should have worked out my jaw before chugging. Hop-forward pine strangles the wimpy citrus. Heavy sugary malt. Some caramelised fruit. Consuming, evolving and evolving bitterness. Wow, that has pummeled my taste buds. Does it NEED to be this bitter? No-one enjoys a mouthful of flies, surely?
HOPS! Fancy meeting you here in such a lovely cold bottle. Every time I drink this beer, my poor taste buds feel like they¬íre being brutalized, and that is NOT a bad thing.
Bottle from Binnys. Poured amber with yellowish head that hangs. Aroma of pine and malt. Stings. Quite smooth med body. Slight bitter taste thats pleasant.

On tap at Prefunk, 2013 version. Dark brown with small foamy beige head. Aroma is nutty, roast grains, some alcohol warmth plays out in the nose. Flavor is strong, sharp hop bitterness, heavy malt, tingly palate and plenty more alcohol warmth. A real winter warmer.

Vintage 2012, 
Pours copper, light tan central dome and rim with some confluent etching. Smells of alcohol, hops (weed, resin, grapefruit and some tea) plenty of crystal malts, some more tea some more booze, a bit of nougat and vanilla and banana. Flavor is bitter, boozy and sweet. Lots of malt, lots of bittering hops, plenty of alcohol character. Medium bodied with moderate carb. I don¬ít think I care for this fresh. Not at all.

vintage 2010- 15AUG11 - 2/4/3.5/3.5/4-3.63
A: Pours a turbid copper ale with less than a single finger of light peanut foam. This dissipates rather quickly to a mirror surface and a central cap of foam. No lacing. Surprised at how turbid this is.
S: Caramel malts, toffee, richly blended. Really nice smell, and for some reason, when I take a good long hit of this, I get candied and mulled orange smells. I dig it. Reminds me of a well aged barley wine.
T: Sweet and bready with a midline transition highlighting the alpha acid in here. Then an additional mutation to a slightly oxidized and metallic grain bed. Above average for sure.
M: Medium on heavy for the style with moderate to lo carb. Transient slick on the palate falls dry at the end.
O: Good beer. Look foward to reviewing fresh.

Serving type: bottle

11-11-2012

on tap at the Provisions market, grapefruit nose with some hops, tasty hoppy beer but nothing too aggressive not the biggest fan of this marketing campaign but whatever floats Stones boat. The alcohol is well hidden tho
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text:
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2013 Catch up rating #godknowswhat @Tria, Washington Sq, PHL 30/11/13 - last beer of this particular stateside trip !
Keg - dark amber with a big ole light beige head dress.
Nose is candied sugars, red grapefruit, toffee, brown sugars, bitter candied orange peel. hint of liqourice.
Taste comprises bitter citrics, candy sugar, grapefruit peel, rich caramel vein running throughout, orange pith, darker warming fruit notes.
Full end of medium bodied, fine carbonation, sweet finale, slightly drying.
Decent American strong - the alcohol is pretty well integrated for a double digit monster !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft at bistro on bridge. Pours clear amber with a medium sized off white head. The aroma is very hoppy. There is earthiness, grapefruit, and some caramel malt. The taste has a huge bitter hoppy kick followed by an amazing many sweet caramel balance. Terrific balance and alcohol is hidden well.

2013/12/01 - Pours a clear, dark, burnt amber colour with a thick, fluffy, khaki head. Tons of lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, pine, hop resin and wood. Taste is citrus hops, malt caramel backbone, pine, wood and alcohol. Thick oily mouthfeel with smooth carbonation and a slight boozy, warming finish. Caramel backbone and alcohol really balance out the citrus and pine hop flavours. A big beer that is amazingly well balanced. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear amber ale with a medium foamy off-white head. The nose is resiny with some grapefruit and floral pine, and a touch of oak. The flavor is amazing with a big malty caramel tone backed with a bit of boozy warmth, some pine and grapefruit resin, and an assertive oak-ed floral hop tone. Very nuanced, deep and lovely. Lots of hop depth but also loads of malt characteristic. Sticky hoppy oak caramel notes. Warming alcohol finish and more hops.

2013 bottle, pours a dark reddish caramel color with a 1" white head. Nose is burnt sugar, pine, caramel, leather, spruce. It¬ís a little hot, but the ABV is pretty high so...to be expected. This is a well balance, very smooth beer.

Bottle sample at Stone tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Pours almost clear red-brown with a nice head and good lacing. Aroma - piney hops, malts, caramel and alcohol. Sweet with flavors of fruits, licorice, malts and long lasting strong hoppy bitterness, alcohol is quite noticeable. Medium-full bodied.

On tap, clear deep orange-brown hue w/ medium beige head. Moderate sweet citrus hop aromas. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a bold bitter finish of long duration. Tastes are pine, caramel, apple, and tangerine. Big bodied, average carbonation, and a dry finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This Ale is so thick and full of flavor, I want to pour it on my pancakes. Tastes of caramel and a lemony hop tartness. A medium off-white head gives to a ruby-orange hued body. Nice lacing. One of my new favorites. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a burnt amber color with a khaki head and beautiful lacing. . Big hop, caramel, malt and toffee aroma with wood undertones. Big hop, malt, caramel, toffee, raisin, plum, pine and alcohol flavors. Medium full body with a thick, syrup like mouth feel. Bitter but other flavors tone it down. Malt and caramel finish. A very big beer.

November 25, 2013 - on tap at Town Hall Lanes. Not sure how I have never rated this before, but here goes. It was dark in the bar, but appearance looked to be a light brown with nice head that lasted. Aroma was big malt and hops, with some dark fruit that came out as it warmed. Taste was sticky sweet caramel, dark fruit, alcohol and piney bitter finish. Nice thick body that was smooth.

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass. Deep reddish brown color, one inch head. Nice soft aroma of fresh hops and citrus. Flavor belies the aroma, however. It is strongly malty with an intense bitter finish. "Harsh" might be the most suitable word here. None of the citrus from the aroma makes its way into the flavor. The abv is everywhere and unavoidable. Still, fairly smooth for 11%, and what saves this beer. Drink two arrogant bastards instead. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin whitish head. Sweet aroma. Slightly sweet taste with a bitter finish. Much smoother than expected. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Collins Pub. Pours dark reddish amber with thin creamy white head. Aroma is syrupy sweet malt, with pale molasses and earthy oaky undertones. Taste is big roasty amber malt, thick and syrupy, followed by sharply bitter hop finish with notes of pine and grass. Sizable ABV is obvious and impossible to ignore. One goes a long way. Just a monster beer by any measure.

Brown with a hint of Amber. White head that dissipates quickly. Strong taste of booze and malt. Citrus including bitter grapefruit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours brown with red hues and an off-white head. Smells caramel, bready, slight spruce. Has a really strong flavor, hot. Borderline barley-wine in my opinion. Sweet malts with a strong, lingering bitterness to it. Good.

Bottle from Bert¬ís 
Pours a brilliantly clear deep copper color with a decent sized off white head that shows moderate retention and lace. Aromas of pine resin and grapefruit pith atop brown sugary caramel and hints of cheery and toffee. The flavor is heavy on the pine, resin and brown sugar. Slight warming alcohol warns of the abv. Caramel, toffee, light plum and prune round out the flavor. Assertive hop bitterness but never harsh. Medium to thick body with a light to moderate level of carbonation and a sweet slick almost syrupy mouthfeel. Very nice strong ale, I enjoyed sipping on this for most of the night.

Draft, Dark amber color with a nice white head. Aroma is sweet with hints of dark fruit and hops. Sticky sweet bitterness lingers for a while. Great beer. Seems a bit smoother than the regular Bastard.

On tap @ Tap25. Cloudy, orange with disappearing head. Very, very light smells of fruit and hops. Tastes of malty booziness, sweet, but finishes with a bitter aftertaste. Seems like a complex beer, changing as it warmed up, but I still wonder if Arrogant Bastard is better than this. A little more malt with an alcohol bite. Would love to try them together.
On tap at the brewery, pours amber with low head, aroma is rich roast and pine hops, taste is bold bitter roast, delisious.
Pours a dark amber. Thin off white head. Lots of maltiness. Somewhat bitter. Some aroma of dark fruits. Flavor is somewhat bland. Alcoholic.

Metallic and boozy aromas with a Chinook hop aroma, though muted by the boozy notes on the aroma. Flavor is like a under-aged barley wine but a bit thinner on the palate than the traditional American Barleywine. Finish is slightly bitter and alcoholic. Overrated at 100pts.
Pours a hazy orange with some sediment. Has a strong malt, butterscotch, and hops. Taste is complex with hints of rum and strong fruity malt and prune juice flavor. Bitter malt and hop aftertaste.

Pours reddish golden with a foamy head and wildly thick lacing. Nose is dark fruit and hop. Taste is bitter to the 5th power. This shit will destroy your palate for a while. Although not really my style, this is a force to be reckoned with. Very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

TAP at Chez Moeder Lambic during "Moeder Lambic Vs. Stone".
Only found back scores, not ratings.

2013 bomber to a tulip glass. Pours a copper color with a big off white head. Aroma is toffee, butterscotch, and alcohol. Taste is toffee, caramel, hops bitterness, spice from the high alcohol and some sweetness. Creamy but acerbic mouthfeel.

Pours a slightly hazy dark copper with an off white head and nice lacing. Aroma is sweet malt with butterscotch and some citrus. Taste is bready malt sweetness with more citrus hop flavor than expected from aroma. Has a prominent but smooth bitterness that lingers in the finish with a spiciness from the alcohol. Creamy mouthfeel and medium full bodied and medium high carbonation. A very big beer with lots of flavor.

Rich, deep copper color with about a finger of tan head. The aroma shines, I get big spice notes, cinnamon, nutmeg, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, butterscotch, some booziness and a nice jolt of hops. The taste is much like the aroma, very sweet, but well balanced with the alcohol. There is a nice citrusy hop flavor in the back end. This is a big beer, but I find it more balanced than Arrogant Bastard. I would like to try this with a couple of years of age on it.

From 22oz bottle to snifter. Pour is a deep amber, kind of hazy with a medium off white head. Nose is complex- caramel, figs, hops, malt, citrus, a bit of everything. Taste is very deep and equally complex, heavy body with touches of sweet, sour, and bitter of course. Finishes sharp, thick oily texture with little alcohol bite. What a beer, love the complexity and the drinkability here.

Hoppy floral with a light malt aroma. Darker amber in color with thick light tan head. Creamy mouth feel with an almost cherry syrup start that fades into a malty and slightly drying finish. Heavy but delicious.

Draught glass at rattle n hum. Hazy dark amber. Ridiculous lacing. Aroma of pure raisin malt, with grapefruit and citrus bitterness. Sweet sassy, I could spend hours smelling this, and just get drunk off the smell. Definite alcohol aroma, but it's only apparent after you pour the beer into a sack vented directly into your nostril. Preferably the left nostril. The taste is strong with prune and rind bitterness. Oh beer lords of lording all beers, this is glorious beyond words.
Very bold and in your face. The taste of alcohol is really present but delightful. Assertive and delicious.

Aroma of sweeet malt, fruit, with pleasing citrus notes. Pours a clear mahogny with a white ring and no lacing. The taste is quite malty initially and then the hops begin to kick in. And, oh, do they ever kick in! There is a satisfying warmth all the way to my stomach. Noticable alcohol in the finish. Medium-full body and medium carbonation. The mouthfeel is lush and creamy. Overall, very drinkable and beautifully crafted.

12 oz. draft at Plan B in Glastonbury, CT. Deep copper amber pour with a thin off white head and minimal lacing. Aroma is caramel, piney hops, bitter orange, alcohol. Taste is very sweet, some bready earthy notes to go with he caramel. Plenty of west coast hops on the finish, with lingering sweetness and bitterness. Nice chewy mouthfeel, alcohol presence is noticeable but warming. Good big brew from Stone. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It¬ís the 2008 vintage on draft at the brewery in Escondido. Pours brown with no head. Not a lot of carbonation but it still has a a lot of citrus on the tongue. Hides the alcohol extraordinarily well. It¬ís interesting in its current state but it, I¬ím guessing, in no way compares to what this would be like fresh.

Bi√®re bien rousse, trouble, avec de larges flocons de levure et o√π flotte un col mousseux laissant au verre une l√©g√®re dentelle. Au nez, du toffee, de l¬íalcool et des conif√®res. Elle est tr√®s am√®re, avec un peu de sucre r√©siduel. Elle est de corps baraqu√©, huileuse, finement effervescente et se termine sur de fortes effluves alcoolis√©es.

2013 bottle at 11.2% ABV. This beer pours a gorgeous hazy color that blends red, orange, and brown, and there is a large off-white head, some fine sediment floating throughout the liquid, and incredible lacing on the glass. The aroma has a mixture of equal parts of each of its components: booze, floral hops, diacetyl, and bread or caramel malts. The taste is not as hoppy as I was expecting, and I must say that the mild sweetness offsets the mild bitterness well. The way this beer coats the mouth is interesting; its oily texture, soft body, and medium body make for an easy trip over the tongue, and the long finish that is both slightly bitter and slightly boozy keeps you wanting more. Quite a tasty brew this one is.

22 oz bottle for 7.99. Pours a reddish copper with a small light brown head. Aroma is heavy pine hops, but also a caramel malt backing. Taste mostly lies in the malt realm with some hops, an extremely strong kick of bitterness and a little alcohol at the end. Body is a little bit above medium, slighty creamy and thick texture. It¬ís an ojbectively good beer but not really my thing. Not something I would drink regularly.

S: Dark caramel malts, molasses, alcohol and brown sugar. P: A dark clear copper with a tan brown head. T: Brown sugar, dark caramel malts, pine bittering hops in the background and a hint of alcohol towards the end. M: Medium body with semi biterness. O: Unique with a good amount of complexity and at a great price.

22oz bottle of 2013 release. Pours a reddy brown color with a small amount of head. Great hop flavor, not too bitter, balanced against a strong maltiness. Not too sweet and only mild hint of the high alcohol content.
pours a lovely dark mahogany with a white head. has a very robust sweet smell of malt and hops. The taste is very malt forward but then the hops hit you. has a very bitter finish that lingers.

An aggressive poor left only a one finger head but it was very persistent. The flavor opened all malt and just when I thought that was all there was a wonderful hop finish appeared, made me a very happy guys. At 11.2 abv the alcohol was present but not overpowering.

On tap at company store...2013. Nice copper color with mostly diminishing off white cream color head. Aroma is pine, citrus, and breast malts. Taste is same but slight caramel in finish. Light carbonation and med body actual hides the abv well. Overall another great year for the double bastard.

Merci √† Boutip pour la bouteille! 

Bouteille de 2009. Bi√®re forte tirant sur le sirupeux. Une touche de houblons vient tenter de calmer le jeu, mais ne vous y trompez pas, nous sommes ici tr√®s loin d¬íune bi√®re facile et d√©salt√©rante. Tout de m√™me, le corps bien vivant et l¬íalcool assez bien cach√©e nous oblige a admettre que c¬íest une bi√®re √† essayer, pour les amateurs du style... Ce que je ne suis malheureusement pas.

aroma: honey roasted peanuts. citrusy hops. appearance: dark amber. lively carb bubbles. foamy off-white head. taste: sweet stone fruit (I know, right?) quickly balanced by bitter and floral hops, peppery alcohol notes. palate: light and dry body. creamy texture, bitter and long finish, but it can keep on finishing.

DB hits hard alcohol notes but makes them tasty and complex in their own right. Whatever yeast they use, and how they treat that yeast, provides a beautiful alcohol flavor.
Stone¬ís rep for high IBU, palate-destroying beer is well intact here. Pine, bread, yeast, funk all make an appearance but it¬ís too hop-forward for my taste.

This bastard is hardcore. Deep opaque red with off-white halo. Friendly yeast chunks. Thick aroma of bread and sweet bourbon. Punch you in the teeth flavor. Tastes of baked fruit and booze. Cherries. Wood. Warm dough and malt. Medium body and a bitter finish. This is a brew to savor after you¬íve been rained on during a long, cold walk to your car after a shit day at work. Prost.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2014 22 Oz Bomber. The beer pours to a deep amber reddish brown color with a very thick off white head. The aroma has caramel, bread & alcohol notes to it. The taste is medium/heavy in body with a slightly bitter finish. Overall a very good Ale,
Bottle. Pours dark amber with slight off white head. Very nice lacing. Aroma of citrus and caramel. Taste of oak and booze.

Cloudy copper, off white head, drapes. Grapefruit, booze, milk chocolate? Heavy bitter, lots of booze, some toffee,long bitter aftertaste. Medium carbonation, rich mouthfeel. It definitely packs quite a punch.

A: Deep Amber/Brownish Hue, Passes Very Little Light, Good White Head, Some Lacing

S: Malty, Mild Piney, Mild Resin

T: Malty, Bready, Resin

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Bitter

Overall, a great strong ale that was almost a heavy pale ale..great beer.

Poured into a pint glass at a local bar. Would have preferred a snifter. Aroma is fairly non distinct because of this. Pours a dark ale color. Flavor is stupendous. Malts and a caramel finish. Palate is long lasting with lots of malt and caramel. Very flavorful beer!

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Clear amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and moderate hoppy - fruity. Flavor is quite sweet and very bitter. Dry and very bitter finish with warming alcohol. 171013

Bottle, 11.2% 2012 version. Clear dark amber with medium tan head. Aroma is malt, fruit, caramel, toasted and hop. Flavour is malt, fruit, caramel, toasted, wood, little toffee, little dark fruit, oak, medium sweet and quite bitter.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are hops, caramel, fruits, yeast and malt. Nice, bitter and sweet. Some alcohol present.
Pours a very hazy dark honey color with a thin vanilla head. Smells similar to a barley wine. Spices. Slightly boozy. Taste is sweet. Boozy finish with a bitter fruit aftertaste

22oz. bottle filled from a 2012 keg. Pour is a slightly hazy burnt orange with a small off white head. Very sweet nose, feels like a cross between a barleywine and a dark belgian. Notes of candi sugar, sweet caramel, dark fruits, very citrusy hops, noticeable alcohol on the nose, and a nice biscuity malt note. Huge citrusy hops that have hardly faded away up front on the taste, then it goes to a plum and cherry sweetness, there¬ís an almost chocolatey taste there, nice piney notes, and a somewhat sticky syrupy taste. Very tasty beer, and even after a year it is still very very aggressive.
Bottle shared. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, light citrus, light floral and wood. Flavour is fairly heavy sweet and bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation.
2012 draft. Pours deep copper amber. Light citrus and sweet malt aroma. Taste is citrus, candi sugar, roasted malt, nice hop bite. A bit syrupy with a big booze burn.
November 2012. 22 oz. bottle. Dark amber color with an offwhite head. Fruit aromas with malt, caramel, alcohol. Very hoppy, caramel flavors and alcohol burn on the finish.

Poured from bomber into tulip glass. Beautiful color...like hazy caramel. Good foamy off white head that faded to a thin ring/layer and left some nice lacing.
Aroma is hard to define. Reminds me of some Belgians I¬íve had. Lots of hops, but also malt. Spice, floral, woody, alcohol, pine. Quite a bit of sweet at first taste but quickly moves to warming alcohol with a long finish. Fairly lively but soft carbonation. There¬ís a lot going on with this and all of it is very good.
On tap. Dark amber with small head. At first taste it is sharp hops which then smooths out across with an earthy malt flavor that also carries a taste of alcohol. A pleasant albeit complex sipper.

Bottle (22 oz) 2011 vintage. From cparles, thanks! Dark amber with a medium beige head and light lacing. Aroma is harsh and hoppy despite the age with caramel, malt and pine. Taste is also harsh and sweet with hops, caramel, citrus, alcohol, pine and moderate to heavy bitterness. Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Sticky and thick mouthfeel. Even with 2 years on it, it¬ís way too harsh and sugary.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2014 Clear burgundy. Large frothy creamy off-white head, fully lasting with drapes of lace. Aroma is loaded - carmel, over-ripe fruit, red fruits, pineapple, syrupy citrus, sweet, alcohol. Full body, oily - so much happening on the palate. Smooth and vinous. Overall fantastic balance of big bitter, big sweet, and alcohol. Long finish. A very, very big beer that really comes together.

2012. 
Aroma- caramel, sweet dark fruit, a little citrus, hops, alcohol.
Taste- sweet, malt, raisin, a little syrup, some alcohol. Bitter but sweet. Very complex, very interesting.

So good. A great amount of caramel aroma. Head is cream colored and leaves a decent amount of lacing. It goes down smooth and has a nice bite at the end. Color is like cloudy coke. A lot of malt, and something I can¬ít quite place, but I love it.
On tap at Harry¬ís Hofbrau. Dark fruit with alcohol and old bread. Slightly hazy copper with full tan head. Rich caramel, viscous mouthfeel. Layers of depth throughout the entire glass.

Bottle 65 cl from Systembolaget. Amber/ruby with a nice beige head. Caramel, raisin, nice bitterness, brown sugar. Full body, smooth, light carbonation, bitter dry finish. Hint of alcohol in the mouth. Nice!

Bottle from systembolaget (a year old). Nice caramell aroma although faint, might be an age problem. Nice dark red colour, Nutty carameal favour with a nice long bitter finish. Creamy texture with a full body. Soft cabonation. 
A nice beer which, if I remember correctly, is a lot better when it is fresh

22oz bottle. Color: burnt orange. Nose: boozy, huge malt backbone. Palate: hoppy, malty, finishes fruity and drying booze.

text: Bottle. Pours deep coppery amber with a decent, yellowish-brown head. Aroma is caramel, a lot of toffee, resinous, stingy, piney, somewhat ethanolic. Some dried dark fruit. Taste is a lot of malts, quite a bit of ethanol is detectable. Resinous and pithy, pine and barleywine-like flavors. Toffee and caramel. Malt rules here. Even some breadiness. Not exactly sweet. Quite dry, definitely not as sweet as you¬íd expect. Dried fruit. Stiff, full, stingy with carbonation, sticky. Good, but not really as good as their other, similar offerings: OG and AB.
Pours red amber with small off white head. Smells of malts, hops, and yeast. Tastes of malts, bitter, and alcohol. Finishes clean with medium carbonation.
One ugly ass beer, has a murky swamp water look to it. But the taste! Phenomenal beer, a step up from regular arrogant bastard, this is my all time favorite.

22 oz Bottle, with a 14 oz pour into a snifter. Pours reddish brown with a nice head that lingers around for quite some time. Aroma was at first nothing but hops with some sweetness, perhaps caramel? First taste was very similar with a very hoppy finish. Very easy to drink. As I continued to drink I could definitely pick up some other sweet flavors, really couldn¬ít pinpoint what exactly they were though. All in all though, an amazing beer that does not seem to be rocking the high abv it has.

Cold bottle. Finally, a Stone beer that hits the mark for me after so many disappointments! This is really nice. Pours a murky brown with a good off-white head that endures. Smell is loads of pineapple with resin in the background. And more pineapple. Gentle carbonation and mid-mouthfeel. Taste is big on the caramel malts, and lots of indistinct hoppy tastes, resin finish but not that astringent. Sweet caramel aftertaste. Big flavours, all in balance. 11%? I don¬ít believe it. Really good beer. And what a beautiful sunny day to enjoy it on.

This beer is huge in every way. Pours deep brown/red, with a thin off white head that dissipated pretty quickly. Huge malty aroma, caramel, dark fruits, with quite a bit of hop presence too. The taste was of dark fruits, cherry, hoppy bitterness, a lot of fairly sweet malt. The mouthfeel of this is one of it¬ís best points, for 11.2% it¬ís incredibly smooth, very full bodied, almost syrup like. Leaves a coating in your mouth and the taste lingers in a good way. My favourite Stone beer thus far and one of my favourite¬ís full stop.
Dark, amber colour with a tan head. Aroma is heavy with malts with slight caramel to it. Very easy on the palate, slight carbonation. Taste is mostly bitter. This one¬ís a very nice ale.

Reddish brown. Aroma is hops and a vegetative smell. Taste is big caramel hops - bitter and sweet. Pretty close to perfect. Palate is totally ruined. Overall, a brilliant hoppy strong ale. Much better than the basic arrogant bastard.

Hmm quite disappointing. Heavy on the bitterness & that¬ís about it. The oaked & burnt flavors are too subtle & don¬ít add any complexity to this one. It¬ís bold & powerful but just not what I was looking for.

Been wanting to rate this one for a while, but I haven¬ít had the desire to purchase a bomber. I had a 4 oz. sample at Tap 25, and was really glad I didn¬ít have to drink more. Not that it¬ís bad, just a huge chore to drink. It pours a dark orange color with a small orangy head. The aroma has big caramel and toffee syrup and lighter notes of cocoa powder and fruity hops. The flavor is extremely bitter and harsh with lots of alcohol, syrupy caramel, toffee, dried fruit and pine sol. Brutal. I remember being more impressed with this a few years ago last time I tried it. I guess this is a testament to how far craft beer has come in the last 5 years or so. This beer is now a relic of the past when brewers felt like they needed to smack you upside the head to make an impression. I¬íll pass from now on.
Bomber pours a hazy copper with khaki head that sticks around. Big caramel aroma. Malt caramel and nutty taste.
Nice red color with a big head a nice lacing. My biggest complaint about this beer is that it has a bitter/boozy after taste that sticks around. But it has a wonderful malt presence

Pours a nice ruby red with a large off white head that lasts long with good lacing. Very nice balance for an 11.2% beer. A little unpleasant bitter aftertaste. Not bad. Cant drink more than 2. Plum citrus and alcohol aroma.
