22 fl oz / 650mL bottle into a Samuel Adams glass. Served cool.

Aroma: Nice pine-y hop aroma, much like regular Arrogant Bastard, but there¬ís also a stronger malt presence here.

Appearance: Dark, hazy copper with thick, foamy off-white/light tan head.

Taste: Wow, heavy, heavy hop presence, but an equally heavy malt presence. It¬ís harsh, it¬ís bitter, and it¬ís got that nice pine-y hop bite. Really great.

Palate: Full body, very long finish. Get used to that flavor, cause it¬ís gonna stick around for a long time.

Overall: Excellent, excellent beer. Really nice contrast.
Take a chance to drink this. Awesome. Thick rich malty but not overpoweringly so or unbalanced in it¬ís deliciousness. Totally great. Drunk with Brian so I was. You¬íre asleep now.

Draft. Pours a deep copperish brown color with a good light tan head. Aroma is very sweet, with caramel and nutty notes. Moderate alcohol note as well. Taste is very big, with moderate sweetness and alcohol lingering on tongue. Palate is full, but not too heavy. Absolutely wonderful.

Boy this is big. Tap at churchkey. Pours amber with a little head and lots of lacing. Big alcohol hit. Nose is fruity and some sugar. Notes of dark fruit, maybe some rye whiskey lots of sweet malt. Tastes are medium sweet heavy bitter and alcohol is in your face.

Dark brown ale with a khaki head. Sweet ripe fruits, soapy hops and wood notes aswell on the nose. Full and round body with bitter and strong hops. Some alcohol warmth. Very good ale with strong hops and bitter finish that leaves you satisfied.
This is a very good beer but it¬ís definitely over hyped. Like many of Stone¬ís beers.
Good boozy stuff. I g√∂r wasted from the First moment. Notes OF caramel boozyness. And what not. Again next time. I really like the strong Notes OF nuttyness but it should be more flavorfol.

bottle. copper amber, clear. strong piny foresty hops, double caramelized malts. body is full, but not barley wine- like. pretty good overall. excellent. piny hops, good malts. clean, not too hot or anything.

A - Pours a clear garnet with a mix of tight cream colored head that¬ís mixed with big bubbles and sticks around. Sticky sheets of lacing 3D lacing make for a beautiful looking beer.

S - Rock candy, fresh pine wood, bready yeast, doughy buttered biscuits, warm caramel, citrus hides underneath the pine.

T - Dense caramel malt with a hint of buttered biscuits. Sugary cherries hide underneath the slab of rich caramel malt. Toffee and sticky raisins follow a creamy sticky malt. Floral, pine, and citrus hops provide excellent balance as well as a soft but strong bitterness on the palate. Has a long finish of pine resin with orange oils floating on the palate.

M - Dense, creamy, sticky, thick body.

A highly crafted beer at it¬ís best! It screams quality and a big, rich flavors! The alcohol is hidden very well. It¬ís exactly what you want it to be. Big, bold, rich, and robust.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2016 Bottle.
Pours dark red/amber with a small off white head.
Aroma is sweet malty and piny, woody, citrus hoppy with passion fruit raisins and earthy notes but not as in-your-face as expected. Some alcohol fumes at the end.
Taste has sweet, doughy, caramel malt but the heavy bitter, woody, piney and citrusy  hops play first fiddle. Malt backs up very well. Not much alcohol shining through, very smooth for beeing at 11,2%
Mouth feel is oily and sticky. After taste is long and bitter and a wee bit numbing.
Well rounded strong double IPA with nice aroma of pine mild cirtus and sweet fruit; taste is well balanced hop-bitterness-malt with pretty thick mouthfeel. Rich and nourishing.

2011 bottle.  Pours a beautiful deep amber, red color with a nice compact off white head. Aroma: caramel, sweet berries, fruits, toasty malts, sweet orange, nice a juicy. Taste: still a huge bitterness with grapfruit notes, a nice solid sweetness with caramel notes and some berries. Notes of caramel, toffee, red berries, grapefruit, honey. A really good brew! I enjoy this alot!

2012 bottle shared - Cheers Steven! Pours a clear dark brown with a big white head, which shortens but lasts. Big aroma! Caramel, citrus fruit, raisins. Taste is the same only more so, with a long, lingering, thoughtful finish - kissing you softly on the cheek after a rough touch-up. A damn well made beer. Which I want more of. Soon.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 This pours like a lot of Stone beers, dark brown, with decent head leaving a lacing. The aroma is heavy caramel malts, , with piney citrus hops. Wow, this is a fantastic beer, it¬ís pretty bitter, but the balance on this, for the 11.2 abv, is just incredible. It is smooth, crisp and goes down nice and easy. The aftertaste is is quite bitter, less bitter than arrogant bastard, quite sweet but great, lovely balance, really tasty. This is just as enjoyable to drink than the also excellent, arrogant bastard ale.

: 2009 bottle 10.5%. Split with my uncle. Poured deep amber with thin head and lacing. Noted of caramel, cherry, vanilla, booze, hops and grains. A little too much alcohol burn for me. Palate was a little sticky with light to medium carbonation

On tap at Crunchy¬ís.  Favorite beer from Stone.  Big and bold.  I imagine if I had this in something larger than a flight glass I wouldn¬ít be able to taste anything for the next couple days.  Not that that would be a bad thing.

A finger and half of reddish head on an almost clear amber colored body. There¬ís a lot of sediment.
The aroma is weak with only a little malt and lemon coming through.
The taste is HUGE and BOLD. Lots of lemon bitterness thrown against tons of malt. It maintains a great balance.
The texture is smooth with moderate carbonation.
A big beer with still keeps it together.

Vintage 2012. (Bottle) Poured Hazy dark amber little off-white head. Strong hops aroma, pinney, malts and booze... Taste is also bitter hops mixed with fruits and malts the alcohol is quite noticeable. A great beer, quite enjoyable; however is no the type you want to use to introduce your macro drinker friend to the world of craft beer.

Wow!  What a great beer!  Stone out did there selves. Arrogant Bastard is a great beer. Double Arrogant is even better. 

MKH---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

For all it's scornful commenting, double arrogant is somewhat subtle at first, only biting back on the palate's backside.  Great appearance and head, pours somewhat on the rust side.  The malty backbone gives this robust ale something to be proud of, but won't give you the sharp citrus or pine notes you might expect of the variety

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours a nice rich dark red with a one inch foamy white head which lasts a considerable while. Lots of hops are seen floating throughout the body. The smell is sweet malts up front and in the beginning and as the beer warms more hops comes out. The taste follows the smell and becomes increasingly hoppy bitter and yet citrusy sweet, becoming very powerful. The palate is about a medium to perhaps heavy, some slight lingering sharpness coming out slightly strong near the end of the beer. Overall, this is a complex beer and pleasing beer that I would absolutely come back to.
2012 vintage. Great aromas of caramel malt, sweet bread and alcohol. Flavors similar. Perfect bitter hop balance. This year seems smoother than others recently. So good!

My sort of 6 months aged one from 2012... Also what is this picture that shows glassware? But I digress...

A: Nothing special here. Smooth, subtle floral note. some malt. like an IPA. I thought this was an IPA? Or can an aged IPA turn into an american strong ale? I dunno... smells fine but nothing special.

A: Appearance is solid. Pours thick and semi hazy. Nice golden bubble head.

T: Some hops, a tinge of malt. Huge alcohol note. Some more earthy notes in there as well. Seems a bit unbalanced. Alcohol is too powerful relative to the rest of the beer.
P: Minor flavor development is overpowered by alcohol.

Overall this is way different than when I had it on tap. It was amazing on tap and from the bottle this is pretty meh. Certainly not bad but it turns into a bit of a boozy mess, losing the hop balanced of the first one of these I had. A lot more earthy flavors come through with the bottle where on tap it was more floral and citrusy. It was interesting to see the differences aging brought but in this case if was for the worse.
22 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a nice biege head.  Aroma of malt, fruit, vanilla, and pine.  Taste is pine, citrus, malt, dark fruit, vanilla, and alcohol.  A big beer for sure.  Nice!

Dark ruby red, strong aroma and strong flavor. Smells like a pile of hops and dark fruit. First taste had a strong bite. Very bitter and earthy. Did not appreciate much of a malt balance. Really dries out the mouth...not very enjoyable to me. Better as it warmed up more but still not something i really plan on getting again.

Aroma: The smell has a coffee, toasty, rich dark 
Appearance: Dark cloudy amber, a brown off-white head, lacy finish that 
Taste: The taste is bitter and sweet with hints of vanilla, toffee, and fruit mango maybe.
Palate: Small bubbles with an appropriate heavy alcohol presence, oily and creamy, the taste lingers on the palate long but extremely well done for a strong ale like this one


Overall: Awesome brew, one of my favorites from Stone. Drinking this on occasion, not for everyone, but definitely a must have!

2012 Release 11.2 % Bottle from Craft Beer Base. It poured a great amber reddish brown, very clear with a quickly dissipating head of foam leaving behind quite a lot of lacing along the rim of my snifter. It had a really strong piney nose right from the start. The flavor is really hop forward with pine dominating with some slight cirtus notes around the edges. It is quite strong at over 11% which is definitely noticeable and I get the feeling this beer is kind of acidic... If you like your beers hoppy then you¬íll most likely like this beer but I find that the flavors aren¬ít so complex. Maybe I am drinking it too cold...  Overall, another solid beer from Stone but not really my thing, I am not so into ultra-hoppy beers.

Good but not as good as Lucky Bastard. The alcohol was too apparent. Tastes sweet and malty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a deep red with very strong flavor and aroma. This one had a very boozy flavor that you could tell it was a double with 11% alcohol. Although it was a great beer a little too boozy for me. Had bomber from beverage world.
Draught at Thrash Zone. Little nose of caramel and hops. Hoppy flavor, cloying caramel, wine, esters, raisins, big hop bitterness. Not very pleasant. Glad I shared this pint.
Overall, this is a great solid brew that is heavy on the alcohol side of things but the malt profile helps keep the flavor in check and not overwhelmed.

Awesome, well-rounded beer with a great kick. Smells super hoppy with aroma of caramel malt. Thick consistency, pours orange with clouds. Taste bitter with a little sweetness. Average carbonation. Bottle.

Aroma: The smell has toffee, raisins, sherry in it. But also tropical mango and grape-fruit peel, and pine needles.Appearance: The brew is clouded deep amber with hints of oranges, a yellow off-white head, that settles slowly, has little lacing but good curtains.Taste: The taste is sweet, crystalline sugar, vanilla, butter scotch, oatmeal, fruits, apples, peaches and mango. Sherry and lemon and grape-fruit zest.Palate: Medium high carbonation, small bubbles, soft, oily and a bit alcoholic. A long dry finish.Overall: This even if a bit young was very good.Note: Bottle 650 ml at a De Klomp tasting. (Vintage 2011) Reviewed 2013-01-26.

Double bastard lived up to its name. Hops upon awesome upon that feeling when a stiff right is delivered to a backstabbing persons jaw is what awaits you for the first taste. Very strong, great taste.

2012 Bomber. Pours a clear, ruby amber with a medium, fluffy white head and some lacing. Aroma is sweet malt and citrus hops. Flavor is camamel malt, vanilla, orange and citrus fruit, piney hops and a bitter hoppy finish. Medium body with medium carbonation and high alcohol masked pretty well. Really good, flavorful brew.

good flavor overall, but a bit strong for me and works as a good sipper, like bourbon. i usually avoid beers over 8% since they tend to be too strong tasting for my taste.  there have been exceptions where i have enjoyed those above 8%, but not often.

Clear darkish amber pour. Medium thick off white head. Aggressive aroma of earthy hops, malt sweetness, and alcohol. Also has aggressive flavors that seem to evolve several times throughout. Sharp hop bitterness and alcohol comes through first. Lots of hop spice. Good amount of sweetness to offset the hops and then comes back to a dry hoppy finish. 

---Rated via iPhone

Bomber into arrogant bastard fizzy yellow beer is for wussies pint.  Brownish red pour.  Aroma is hops like a double ipa.  Taste is unique.  Lots of hops but also a whole lot of malt.  Pine hops very bitter.  Malt is carmel.  Different than the dark malt of a black ipa.  Good stuff, and very different.
Cracked a bottle of this 2012 vintage for the holidays this past year.  Good beer to share with friends and family stuck in the macrobrew scene.

Bomber from pellegjr - cheers Joey! Pours deep reddish/amber with thick off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit, heavy caramel malt, lots of thick resinous pine, some light spice and vanilla. Taste begins with a big sticky caramel hit, then some dark/red fruit, bit of brown sugar, lots of deep resinous pine, some citrus fruit. Heavy pine bitterness to finish, lots of lingering pine, caramel, and citrus. Booze warmth as it goes down. Very tasty.

Bottled. A copper beer with a medium sized white head. Aroma is heavy malty with some fruitiness and hoppy. Taste is malty and hoppy. Strong but very well balanced. Noticeable alcohol. Very dry finish with wood notes. Great beer.

Very smooth double. I wish I had some of their aged versions. Enjoyable from time to time. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bottle, 2012 bottling - pours glowing orange with crimson highlights, medium, tan head, fully lasting with good retention and nice lacing. Big dried fruits in the nose, nice vanilla malt, with some sweet sticky hops. Creamy taste is pleasant with oranges, citrus hops at the finish, long time comin¬í... Bitter ends. Awesome.
Bomber bottle. Pours clear amber, white head. Hops, hops, malt, malt, lots of it.

Bomber poured into an Arrogant Bastard pint glass.  Pours dark amber color with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, candy, malt, citrus hops. Taste is malty and hoppy. Has a familiar Stone hoppiness and taste, but more of it.

It poured a dark amber color with an off-white head. The aroma was of sweet malts and some dark fruits. The taste was of bittersweet chocolate. It had a lingering finish that warmed the throat and the chest. Mighty tasty.

Wow. Very very malty when compared to most Stones. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth. Hops come in mid stream and finish is slightly alcoholic. Appearance cannot be overstated. It's really purdy. Great beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours out a dark red color with a white foamy head. The taste is very hoppy. If is medium weight beer that becomes a little strong near the end of the beer. Overall, not one of my top choices. Scratch that...I will never buy this again.
Bottle from a friend. Deep red color, beige head. Roasty taste with coffee, chocolate, raisins, plum, oak and smoky aroma. Roasty finish with oak aroma. Excellent strong ale.

last new beer for the year - bomber (2012) - pours clear amber with stained ivory head and great lacing.  Nose is citrus.  Flavor adds grapefruit and caramel.  quite bitter with light sweetness to keep the punishment to a minimum.  I expected worse on the bitterness front.  medium to full body.  slowly becoming a sipping beer.

Stone Double Bastard Ale has a thick, creamy, tan head, some streaming bubbles, lots of lacing left on the glass, and a hazy, amber appearance. There are lots of fairly large chunks visible in the bottle. The aroma is of strong, medium roasted malts and oily, piney hops. Taste is of sweet malt and bitter, piney hops. There is a brown bread aspect to it, coming from the barley malt. Mouthfeel is medium and slick, and Stone Double Bastard Ale finishes semi-dry, strong, yet not alcohilic, and pretty-well drinkable. Overall, this is a sweet, bold, and delicious beer. RJT

Reviewed 11/12/2012. 22 oz. bottle poured into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a very dark ruby brown color with very little clarity. The head is nice for 11.2% - a one finger light mocha color with nice retention and a wonderful texture. It looks almost like cream floating on top of the beer. There¬ís a nice sheet of lacing down the glass, as well.

S: Don¬ít know why, but the aroma isn¬ít as explosive as I anticipated. The usual suspects of caramel, toffee, and nuttiness are there along with the piny/citrusy hops one would expect from a bastard, but I kind of expected a little more in general.

T: Well, it tastes just like a stronger version of Arrogant Bastard does; I don¬ít know why i expected something different. Nuttiness is strong from the get go, while the finish is a classic Arrogant Bastard ¬ísneak-up-on-you-with-oily-pine-flavors¬í. There seems to be a slightly brighter presence of citrus near the finish, and - naturally - the aftertaste is fairly boozy. I can¬ít seem to pick up the faint vanilla presence other reviewers are detecting. The lack of complexity given its gravity is disappointing...but the Arrogant Bastard has never been about finesse, balance, subtlety, or nuance, has he?! Not quite as sweet as I expected, luckily.

M: Smooth and thick like a milkshake - right up until the hop oils sneak up on you. I love the feel of this in general; the boozy/resiny linger on the palate works perfectly for what this is trying to accomplish.

O: Every time Stone lets me down (see: 16th Anniversary IPA, SSR, IPA, and IRS to a lesser extent), I have something from them that restores my faith in them (see: 15th Anniversary black ale and Mint Chocolate Imperial Stout). So I guess this is another beer that helps raise my opinion of Stone somewhat? The shameless, heavy handed nature of Double Bastard is what gives it its charm - it¬ís the ephitet "fuck you" in beer form. I don¬ít really like Arrogant Bastard anymore, so it¬ís good to know that someone else in the bastard family can come through for me.

Very malty, bready, lots of grain and dough.  It has spice, barnyard earthy notes.  Slight banana, raisin, toasty ceral.  Lots a flavor here, mostly aid in the heavy dough and malt with backup of hops, which are subtle but shine thru. Well crafted, everything works together well.

Pours with lots of soapy foam head.  Actually smells sweet to me.  Taste is very malty with bitter and caramel on the end.  This one starts off too sweet and malty for me but then the bitterness kicks in a good way with a twinge of caramel on the end which is strange but good too.

Dark amber with a spongy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy malt and huge hop notes.  Floral, metallic, strongly citrusy.  Flavor is initially rich with malty sweetness but then dives into the longest, bitterest hop profile finish I think I¬íve ever tasted.  Lives up to its name I think.

Served in a snifter from the back of the fridge. I¬íd say this bottle is 5 our so months old. 

The aroma is very sweet, caramel upfront with a floral and citrus hop quality mixed in. This is very enticing. Pours a dark amber with a nice half finger white head. It has legs but not a lot of lacing. The taste is not for the meager. Similar to the aroma, the taste is a mix of sweet caramel, citrus, vanilla and oak but the booziness definitely comes through. The finish is bitter providing some balance. I love it and usually have it to celebrate special occasions.
Poors thick and burgundy colored. Big frothy head. Overwhelming but delicious taste. Caramel smell.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2013 Pours a clear dark amber/garnet with a robust thick pale tan head.  Aroma is caramel and butter.  Taste is almost cloyingly sweet caramel malt, buttery biscuits and a hoppiness that almost burns.  None of the characteristic grapefruit or pine taste one would expect, just the bitterness.  High ABV evident in taste and feel as well.  Somewhat outrageous, but I like it!

Pours dark red, two finger think foamy head left a little lacing.  Aroma was hoppy with pine and citrus notes.  Taste was very good and complex with caramel, toffee, dark fruits and piney hops noticeable.  I did get a little alcohol taste at the end of I¬íd probably give it a 10 on taste.  It had a nice moderately bitter finish.  The mouth feel was also very nice, full bodied and creamy.

Appearance: very nice super dark amber almost brown color, thick head that is almost beige in color, can still see thru it

Aroma: extremely hoppy, just intense hops, maybe fruit, citrus?

Taste: light malt smoothness upfront, then an utterly intense hop bitterness

Palate: lingering hop aftertaste, bitter

Overall: this is just too bitter for me. May have to taste again at some point in the distant future if my palate significantly changes

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look: Ruby red body, creamy off-white head. Smell: Sweet caramel malts, fruity, pineapple, pine, brown sugar. Taste: Caramel, slight tropical fruits, earthy bitterness, semi dry finish. Feel: Medium body, tight carbonation. Overall: Agressive hop bitterness with extreme malt sweetness. Nice balance between the both. I wish this were year round. I prefer this vs. A.B. Recommended.

Clear amber-brown pour, frothy off-white head. Toasted malt and brown sugar initially, followed by resin and floral tones. Sweet and medium bodied beer with a bitter finish. Alcohol very well masked, a very drinkable brew.
Bomber to glass mug.  Pours a redish amber, with a small, but thick tan head.  Great hop notes of citrus & pine, but offset by a strong malt backbone.  The ABV is covered nicely.  Great mouthfeel.

Draft at the Khyber. Poured a clear dark copper red with a tight pillowy head that left some interesting lace clouds. Nice aroma of dark red fruit, though the first taste is of strong bitter hops. The powerful aggressive pithy piney hop notes dominate and linger, though seem to jet over a subtler, but gorgeous, deep red sea. Plums. Red grapes. Candy apples. Apricots. Orange peels. Pomegranate. Fresh dark red fruit laced with some sly brown sugar. Again, the hop bitterness is quite intense but some reflection should help bring out the complexities of this wonderful beer. Really surprised at how much I liked this. Tremendous.

Draft. Very good beer,strength is hidden nicely. Deep copper color, decent head.  Balanced and solid all around. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark red, moderate amber-white head. Aroma is sweet toast. Taste is alcohol, sweet with pleasant smooth hops. Spicy notes at the end are smooth also, very pleasant drinking experience.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  This is a hop and alcohol bomb - if you are into that sort of thing than this is right up your alley.

Dark copper pour with a creamy tan head. Interesting mix of aromas, caramel malt with a strong alcohol presence and hops on the end. Pretty much a punch to the mouth with hops and booze, a mix of sweetness and bitterness on the finish. Pretty intense beer.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2016 Bomber poured in snifter.  Pours a mostly clear, dark copper color with a decent fizzy head that quickly fades.  Great lacing.  Complex aroma of different malts and hops, just the way I like it.  Different things I pick up are sweet candy, caramel, bread, alcohol, burnt sugar, apricot, pine, toffee, grapefruit and flowers.  Taste is not as complex as the aroma would suggest but it¬ís still delicous.  Malty up front, like caramel candy and burnt sugar.  Finish is hoppier, very spicy.  Some citrus, pine, and flowers too.  Slight booziness but no burn.  Medium body, oily slick mouthfeel.  Great strong ale.  Well balanced, great complexity, and very easy to drink at such a high alcohol content.  This beer is dangerous.

Bomber poured into a tulip.  Pours dark amber color with a medium white head.  Aroma of caramel, candy, malt, citrus hops.  Taste is malty and hoppy.  Good but very similar to the many bitter, hoppy beers coming out of Stone these days.

Bomber pour.   I love the Bastard family, but sometimes take them for granted and have to stay away from them awhile; I enoy them more when I try them again.  Double Bastard is no exception. Malty, full-bodied and the epitomy of an American strong ale.

On-tap at Roasthouse Pub in Frederick, MD.  Served in a goblet, cloudy dark amber color with off-white head.  Aroma of bread, caramel, huge malt candy sweetness and some citrus hops.  Taste upfront hop bitterness, spices and full body added to aroma.  Hoppier then expected but very good.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 Pours a dark amber. Off white thick and creamy head with thick lacing left behind.Smells great. Malts, breadiness, hops in the background for me, but they are definitely there. Complex aroma, smells the way a beer should.Hits the tongue sweet and hoppy. Substantial body, a little sticky even. Ends with some grapefruit hoppiness that sticks around. Good stuff, definitely could trick some people into thinking it?s a barley wine.

2012 bottle. Big aromas and flavors of rich, toasted malt, cereal, brown bread, caramel, Br√ªl√©ed sugar and rum raisin, with high-toned, citrus, and alcohol highlights. A malt monster, with a solid hop and alcohol backbone. Reminiscent of a big barley wine. Nice mouthfeel, finer carbonation, full body and long finish of big malts, bitter citrus and alcohol.  A good winter brew. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Pours a cloudy amber-copper with a healthy 2-finger toffee head leaving some soapy lace behind. Nose involves deep caramel, dough and yeast notes, big pine hops, some apricot and citrus rind, fruit bread, and a touch of alcohol. Taste is pretty sweet but also quite bitter, big yet fairly balanced. Toward heavier bodied, chewy, big and hearty yet not as thick as I thought it would be. Actually quite drinkable, probably due to the drying hoppiness that brings you back for more. Sort of like a huge, hop-forward barley wine. Really nice brew.

I¬íve had the bomber but this review is of this beer out of a huge 3L bottle split with friends. Thanks Dan! Pours a nice crystal ruby color with an eggshell head. Smells great, very hoppy, piney, spicy, caramel, little toffee, slightly citrus. Taste is serious, very up front bitter and hoppy, earthy, piney, spicy, notes of caramel, roasty malts. Really complex flavor. Heavy on the palate, rich chewy mouthfeel with a lasting bitterness. It¬ís like an American bitter that¬ís super duper hopped. I love it and love the 3 liter bottle. Double bastard rules

Great looking beer. Ruby red, clear with a 1/2 finger head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of sweet candy malt. Not much hop aroma. Bottle I tried was a over a month old. Initial taste was great, but then it started tasting more like cough syrup. I can see why others would think this is great, but the cough syrupy taste was a turn off for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - Pours an almost clear amber-red with a finger of frothy off-white head. Fades at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of grapefruit, pine, grassy, and floral hops with some caramel malts and some booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of grapefruit, citrus, and orange hops with some bitterness and some sweet caramel malts. Through the middle, some pine, grassy and floral hops come through with some caramelized malts. The finish is mix of grapefruit, pine, grassy, and floral hops with some caramel malts and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, bitter, and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Big and bold, but very smooth and balanced at the same time.

Live tasting, 2012 bomber into Darkness Snifter

Appearance; pours a lovely hazy ruby/amber with roughly a finger of dense dirty yellow head that falls after a minute... 

Smell; aroma is of hops, just a pure bombardment of resin, spice and floral notes. 

Taste; spice, subtle citrus notes and a metric ton of sticky, resin flavors...

Feel; definitely on the full side of medium body or light side of full body... Sticky in the mouth with pretty solid carbonation.. Finish is moderate to long and quite bitter but not harsh. Excellent brew!

Bottle poured a solid amber, with a slowly receding light tan head with small bubbles that settle into a strong ring of lacing.  Hoppy aromas and solid maltyness, spicy citrus notes followed by mild oak undertones.  Flavors are of malts, hops, sweet citrus and spicy toffee notes.  The Finish; this is a solid beer in every way...great body, the malts and hops are so  balanced it hides the 11% abv well.
Draft at South Park Tavern in Dayton, OH.  A huge, complex beer with big malt, big hops much to my surprise and a huge body.  Very tasty and hoppier than I would have imagined.

This Bastard pours a dark amber color with a long lasting, bubbly, off-white head. As standard with most Stone¬ís beers the scent is quite hoppy. The taste is smooth, oaky, and amazingly complex. It finishes with an oaky, hoppy after taste. This is a delicious, full bodied brew that is well worthy of its rating.

Poured on tap at Stone Oceanside. Aroma is rich malty sweetness with a generous portion of hoppiness. Taste is toasted malts, raisins and a little plum. Nice hoppiness in the taste with a lingering astringency. Huge fan of this beer.

Pours a dark, clear amber with a medium sized beige head that is long lasting.  The aroma is heavy on caramel malt along with some citrus undertones of grapefruit and mango.  I get some fig and a bit of pine as well.  The taste contains much of the caramel, but it is challenged in flavor with a lot of pine.  Citrus is still noticeable, and it goes along with a resin and alcohol taste as well.  Bitter throughout, kind of sweet, with a piney aftertaste.  Full bodied with a very thick texture.  The alcohol content is apparent right away in this one.  I like this quite a bit, but I think its something that you should be a bit wary of.
On tap. Bright golden amber body. Sweet malts very well played and alcohol is somewhat subtle. Damn good strong ale!

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2013 Location/Date:Bottle split with Bryan on November 22nd, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a brown cloud. 
Aroma: Aroma of caramel malt, pine.
Taste: Medium bitterness, lots of caramel malt, some pine.
Palate:Medium body, little fizz.
Summary: I know I¬íve had this before but never have rated it. And I¬ím aware you can age it, but I prefer it fresh with all the hop gloriousness.

It¬ís a very good beer, actually doesn¬ít really taste like the regular arrogant bastard, it has a much stronger and maltier taste, while the regular AB is more of an almost IPA flavor, this is really an american strong, excellent beer.

Bomber bottle. The aroma is a hint of alcohol with rich malt. The appearance is nice brown, with some lacing. The taste is a nice stone funk with a tingle that rolls into a nice malt flavor. Finishes nicely. Excellent palate. Overall, a great beer. Hides how strong it is exceptionally well. Buy it now!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great beer. A little sweet. For a strong beer, there is no harshness, nor bitterness. Very agreeable.
I am reviewing stone lucky bastard.  Pouts copper amber. Sweet as hell. Like a pile of Carmel.

This is one brew I love to see on the shelves , just want to add I have a few put away for trading through out the new year.
caramel, resin, citrus, come through strong in the aroma.
clear, tan foam, red, appearance is perfect
medium sweetness, medium bitterness, creamy, a true Stone Arrogant brew.
Paired it first with grain crackers that brought out the biscuit and dryness, then a sharp cheddar mellowed out the bitterness so all the florals came through. Finally slated nuts to reset the palate and get back to the big bold punch this brew brings. Amazing.

Bottle poured a deep amber with a small tan head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is huge caramel malt followed by piney resin hops, and dark fruits.  Taste also begins with a wave of roasty and caramel malts, then some nuttiness before palatable bitterness and slight booziness on the finish.  Flavors linger long after each sip.

Words cannot describe this beer. They say that Ruination will ruin your palate, but this is the one that will ruin you. Not much head, beautiful clear dark amber pour. Aroma isn't crazy, but the beer itself is super aggressive, as you'd expect.

Pours a dark amber color, aromas of roasted malt and hop, strong alcohol up front with a bitter finish

Dark orange amber color, off white light tan pillowy head amazing lacing. Aroma is Carmel  citrucy sweet hops roasty slight chocolate malty earthy orange peel taste follows the nose well with some upfront bitterness followed by a sweet roasty chocolate malt backbone. Very smooth drinking! Simply amazing beer! One of the best I¬íve ever had so far. Wow!

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2012 Dark amber looks with lovely head and lacing, although not the best lacing I have seen.  Aroma reminds me a lot of Dogfish Head 90 Minute.  Flavor...words.  Words cannot explain.  ZOMG.  Ohmy.  Nuttiness...candi sugar...caramel malts...freshest hops you can imagine...lingering flavors...alky, but not a burn...heeh.  This is so good.  Upon going to heaven, I imagine God will take the basis of this and make it the best heavenly drink possible.  This is just woow.  Best.  Beer.  Ever.

True to its description this is a powerful presence on the palate. Beautiful reddish brown color and intricate patterns to the lace.  Lots of malts and all kinds of other crazy shit I can¬ít really describe.  

Awesome beer!

If arrogant bastard is a bit one-note, you¬íd think double bastard would be even more so, but this is a trickier beer than the original, not-born-of-married-stock ale that was the beer that got me hooked on Stone and craft beer in general.  This one has some sweetness to counter the harsh bitterness. They is something chemical and off-putting in the aroma that makes this hard to enjoy. It affects the taste as well. The high abv is masked very well. Perhaps I could get used to the off smell, but I am not going to try too hard. Not worth $8 for a 22-oz bomber

Holy crap!!! This one is not for rookies it starts out on the malty side than bitch slaps you with an awesome hop bitterness. Seems to mellow as it reaches room temp. The 2012 model comes in at 11.2% abv so this is no session beer no sir. The complex mix of flavors will blow your mind. I highly reccomend picking one of these up as the tempatures start to dip.

Tap. Pours mostly clear, tawny brown with average, creamy off-white head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is caramel, cookie, and cereal malts, figs, earthy hops, oak, pine, and faint herbs. Flavor is sweet malt initially followed by smooth oak and hops (medium bitterness) with some dark fruit esters; dry, hoppy finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Pours dark copper with a thick orange head. Nose is boozey, citrus, caramel and pine.  Taste is sweet at first and ends bitter but the finish is a slow gradually increase of bitterness ending with a strong punch. Mouthfeel is soft and creamy, body is heavy and the finish is long. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught.  Deep amber.  Tons of malt and hops in perfect harmony.  Very smooth.

Pours a deep, translucent, copper on tap with thin, creamy, tan head and great lacing. Aroma is strong piney resins, booze, caramel malts, and more piney hops. Taste follows, with a bitter, alcoholic finish. Good stuff, not as intense as I expected.

Booyaka! The king of bastards! More malt, more hops, more bastard. Beautiful mahogany with rich creamy head. Great balance of mega malt and hyper hops. No alcohol comes through, just a toasty warmth. As good as expected from easily my fave brewery. Champion

Huge hop nose along with robust malts...veering towards barleywine territory on the nose but not in taste-not sweet at all.  Very aggressive, but not out of whack hop and malt flavors.  Some resin and citrus...clean finish not a dank hop bomb.  One to share.

Bomber.  Amber mahogany with some legs.  Good mix of citrus and pine with roasted malt aromas.  Perfect smooth and well balanced agressive flavors of malts, toffee, slight brown surgars, mixed with strong hop taste and bitterness.  Great!  Big burn in a clean finish.  Its a good one!

Bomber---> nonic.  Pours a cloudy amber with a small-medium thick white head.  Smells of toffee, caramel, dark fruit, and mild alcohol.  Taste is a spicy sweet malt, with a small piney hop bite on the back end.  Semi smooth palate that isn¬ít as sticky as most beers of this style (which is a good thing to me).  REALLY good beer that towers over his little brother.

Clear amber pour with creamy head. Heavy caramel toffee aroma. Flavor is dry with malty sweetness. Alcohol warmth. Big brew. Nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - pours filtered mohogany stain with low off white head, no lacing. S - aromas of soap and pine up front, notes of caramel and vegetal malts. Hints of rhubarb and sun tea, and grains. Doughy aggresiveM - heavy aggressive full bodied, full palate. Very bitter. Sticky sweet. T - bitter grassy piney hops, caramel and vegetal malts on the palate . Centennial hops. O - aggressive standard kick in the pants stone brew. Bitter malt heavy ipa 5+ ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 Fresh from bottle. Great ruby color with nice size foamy head. Hop aromas of both citrus and pine. Mouthfeel and taste are great. Malty and hoppy without too much of either. This drinks like a fantastic American Barleywine.

Bottle. Pours a very dark amber color with a moderate off-white head. Some sweeter fruity notes to the nose of this. Taste is fairly strong and malty with hints of sweetness which give way to a little bitterness. Very bold and interesting brew.

Bomber. Pours a thick deep amber color with a soapy off-white head.  Aroma of sweet malts and dark fruits.  Taste is total Hop Domination with hints of bittersweet chocolate. Lingering finish warms the throat and the chest. Sticky on the palate. Full bodied and very rich. I love this beer it is delicious.  So very hoppy!

Absolutely incredible offering from Stone Breweries! Though coming in at punch of over 10%, the alcohol isn't over powering the overall taste! Though it will sneak up on you! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber at home poured into my NB globe. Appearance is deep crimson with a frothy off-white head and great lacing. Soapy/floral hops, light pine, vanilla, graham crackers, caramel, light spice, and cookie dough in the aroma. Taste is wood, pine, grass, light alcohol, caramel, toffee, vanilla beans, and a touch of spice with a huge lingering bitter finish. Sticky/mouth-coating body with high carbonation. Another nice strong ale from the guys at Stone. Well-done!!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2013 2009 vintage on tap at Kalamazoo beer exchange. Very cloudy orange, sparse offwhite suds on top. Aroma of orange peel, clove, coriander, a bit peaty. Thick tingly mouth feel, sharp alcohol-y flavor, lots of malt. Finish is sweet malt, some bitter hops, pine mostly. Very dry finish, alcohol content very apparent.

On tap at Carpool in Herndon, VA.

Clear, but very dark, mahogany with a large off-white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of dark biscuit malt, yeast, hops and a hint of alcohol. 

Taste of roasted dark biscuit malt, brown sugar, toffee and plenty of bitter hops.  Both the malt and hops are hard to describe.  Alcohol plays a part in the overall flavor gestalt and comes on strong at the finish.  This is an exceptionally tasty beer.  Close to perfection. 

Full/medium body and medium/high carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

caramel, amber, orange, clear, white foam, frothy, very bitter, medium sweetness.

Fantastic beer.

2012 rings in @ 11.2%. Pours a deep amber color with a thick foamy head that coats the glass completely. Aromas are big, boozy, bold, earthy caramel... on the palate its right on target with the nose. Boozy deep brooding notes of cedar, butterscotch and pine. This should be my last beer for the night cause bastard just killed it.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2013 S: Incredibly resinous with a rich malt profile - toasted caramel, butterscotch - pine and grapefruit west coast hop character A: Deep ruby red and dark brown with a khaki head T: Much more bitter than the nose suggested - resinous, astringent, bitter bitter grapefruit and pine, caramel P: Medium to full with active carbonation O: This really is an APA. Big, bad, and beautifjl

Fresh bomber just released earlier this week from Stone, served in a Duvel tulip. Pours a clear ruby amber with a couple fingers of off white to beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, pine, and orange peel up front. There is also caramel, and pepper. Taste is strong citrus up front. Oranges, pineapple, lemons, and pine. It comes in quick with a strong caramel malt with bread and hints of lemon. Mouthfeel is medium and somewhat chewy and the alcohol is very well hidden. Maybe it¬ís so amazing because it is very fresh but even the original arrogant bastard doesn¬ít even hold a candle to this beer. This is amazing.
In my opinion the perfect strong American ale. Strong malt and oak flavors and subtle but tasty hops. I look forward to November every year more so than my own birth month because of Double Bastard.

Drank from a bottle poured into a glass. Subtle and rich hops aroma. Foamy, toasted-looking head. The real treat comes when you actually drink it! Delicious malt flavor with the perfect amount of hoppy bitterness (if you¬íre into that!). My favorite part of this beer is the mouthfeel: very clean on the palate for such a hoppy beer: medium to full bodied with a slightly creamy finish. Overall a very satisfying yet drinkable beer! Highly recommended!

Darnk at home in glass out of 22oz bottle. Aroma- not strong. Light florals but nothing distinct. Appearance dark red. Taste-very smooothe with a little hoppiness. Very drinkable. Palate- very clean palate and mouthfeel. Little floral taste as well. Overall- very impressed! Score does not reflect. I would rate total score as 4.4

Blame it on the al-al-al-al-al-al-alcohol. Nice malt balance.  My mother-in-law who doesn't like "hoppy beers" actually liked this mammoth of a beer.  Thank God (or any other thing you worship) for Stone Brews.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber bottle out of a trade. Pours a clear, dark amber coloured beer with a small, beige head. Flavour has malts and some booze. Hops are present. Smell has a lot of syrup, molasses and burned caramel. Flavour has a lot sweetness with a bitter backbone of some slightly aggresive hops. Flavour carries a lot of liquorice and alcohol.. but it is a great sipper! Full bodied, medium carbonized, awesome brew!!
Wonderful maltiness.  Earthy.  Thin beige head.  Nice kick, but its well balanced.  Expected more bitterness.

When you do flights of Stone beers things can get messy pretty quick especially when this puppy is thrown in the mix.  pours deep mahoghany with malty and fruity nose.  tastes of grapefruit, resin, caramel, dark fruits, dimetap, and piney hoppy finish.  long lingering finish with some alcohol warming
Draft. Pours reddish amber with tan head. Nose and taste of caramel malt, toffee melt and resin hops. Alcohol in finish. Medium body.

Bottle. Pours clear deep amber with a small off white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is strong caramel, alcohol, resinous hops. Flavor is moderate sweet with caramel malts and alcohol out front but balanced by a light bitterness. Finish is lightly bitter and strongly alcoholic.

(Bottle). 2007, 10% ABV.
Aroma and flavor of fresh and sweet floral hops combined with sweet malt, raisins, overripe tropical fruit and alcohol. Hmmm ... can not say I like this, the alcohol is reflected in the taste too much + the tone of stale overripe fruit is also too strong.

Bottle from a recent trip to New York. Lovely sweet hoppy nose which follows through to the flavour. Malty citrus notes  with a smooth bitterness that lingers on the palate. A wonderful ale, almost a liqueur. Great to taste, but don't order a pint!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2016 From a bottle at abc beers den Haag. Hazy copper pour. Not much head. Caramel notes in the nose. Vanilla and raisins complement the caramel. Nice beer. 

Update from a 2008 vintage bottle shared Thanksgiving 2016: ages very well.  Clear mahogany with a generous tan head.  Still some evidence of lingering hops, despite 8 years in the bottle.Toffee flavors dominate.  Smooth and not overly boozy.

66cl bottle shared.
Thick off white head.  Clear amber pour.  Lovely grapefruit bitterness.  An awesome brew!

Dark copper in color with a brief, crackling head.  The aroma is sweet, kind of a caramel apple, glazed pecan thing going on that reminded me of the smell of kitchens in autumn when I was a boy, except, plus booze.  The taste is like Arrogant Bastard to the power of Bastard.  It¬ís rich and strong, with qualities of dark bread, brown sugar, and a bit of apple cobbler in the background.  Oh, plus booze.  And the finish is big, with a bite and vapor that shows off that 10.5 ABV.  At no point during this 22 ounces was I not looking forwrd to the next sip.  Stone¬ís Double Bastard Ale is really a beautiful bastard.

RBAG Summer Session 2012. Poured red-amber with a small, tan head. Piney hops aroma with some notes of yeast and resin beneath. Full body, deep flavors. Slightly thick and oily. Strong flavor of grapefruit hops that lingers on the tongue in the finish. As it warms, the piney notes from the hops come forward, as well as a mild yeasty note.

Bouteille 22 oz. 10.5%. Achet√©e au IGA de Potsdam, NY. Couleur brune, claire, mousse neige. Ar√¥me de vin d¬íorge, caramel, malt. En bouche, caramel, malt, alcool et du houblon. Finale l√©g√®rement am√®re, douce, chaude en raison de l¬íalcool. Tr√®s bonne.

Sweet bready aroma, fruit, some citrus and hops. Appearance is dark amber, iced tea looking with white head, quick fade, some lacing. Taste is very nice sweet malts, hoppy backbone, bread, citrus. Tasty beer.

Bottle, many thanks to my Secret Santa. dark brown color with small white head. Aroma of citrus,pine, caramel, ripe fruit, wood, alcohol. strong hoppy taste, with chocolate, toffee, grapefruit. Long hoppy finish with strong alcoholic feeling. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2013 2011 vintage keg at Breukelen Bier Merchants Stone event.  Pours dark orange and mostly clear but with no head or lace.  Aromas of burnt caramelized tropical fruit, dank hops mellowed to hae some must; also pine notes.  Taste is strongly pine resin and very bitter with lots of sugar just starting to balance it.  It is sticky but dry and spicy on the palate.  This is a powerful beer and the age is just showing.

2011 vintage, Big brother of AB with some more bitterness and maltiness.  It¬ís really good, but I don¬ít recommend drinking a bottle by yourself.  This is a sharing beer.  Pours a dark orange and just kills it with the flavor.

Thanks to Damian and Lona for sharing this bottle.

2006 vintage

The beer appears a russet brown with subtle crimson highlights. The head is substantial in stature and leaves plenty of lacing on the glass. The aroma is of alcohol, malts, and toffee. The hop character of the beer has faded during the aging process, so I am not detecting any of the fruit, hop, pineapple, or citrus flavors I have been told are well associated with Double Bastard Ale. The feel is thick and syrupy, with a strong alcohol presence throughout. I liked this much better than the Stone Old Guardian 2007 we had alongside this. This is a great beer to share a few ways and sip slowly on a cold night.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-15-2010

65cl, Vintage 2011, at 10.5%Vol, exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex bitter brew, bitter/sweet and slightly alcoholic/fruity, heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!

Wow!  Dark orange color.  Nice hoppy and malty aroma.  Taste is of malt and nice hoppy bitterness.  Bitterness lasts throughout from start to finish in complete balance with the malt.  This is a smooth beer for 10.5%.  Would have no clue is is so strong.

Very, very good. Lots of dried fruit here, brown sugar, a hint of grassy hops, and a warming booziness, with a nutty, woody aftertaste. Bigger and better than the original Arrogant Bastard - and I like the original Arrogant Bastard. Stone does it again, I don¬ít think they make any bad beer.
from iphone beerlicious app: Grassy aroma.  Orange brownish color that is hazy with minimal tan head.  Some sour notes that finishes with heavy bitterness.  Medium body with average carbonation.

arrogant bastards nasty big brother apparently. yeah, it is a bit nasty in comparison. where the regular bastard nails it, this one just falls sort. slightly out of balance, nice and drinkable though but not at that abv

Strong aroma and very thick pour with a balanced and smooth taste and warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bigger and stronger yet better than its cousin. Flavours are  more pronounced, and better  balanced

Found some old phone ratings. Deep, clear amber pour with a creamy tan head. Nose is toasted malts, caramel, touch of berries, citrus and pine hops. Dominate sweetness in the flavor of caramel, berries, and some more citrus hops. Big,full body with a touch of alcohol leading to a bitter finish. I remember liking this one more that the regular Arrogant Bastard.

22oz bomber poured into a large Duvel tulip glass. Pours a cloudy brown color with clear golden edges and a one inch head that leaves no lacing. I love the smell of this beer. There¬ís so much going on in terms of the aroma, hops, cherries, malt, dark stone fruits and some alcohol. It is 10.5% after all. The taste came up a little short in my opinion. Even after it warmed up the fruit and malt flavors weren¬ít as pronounced in the taste as did hops and alcohol. Still, this is a really good beer that I think can only get better with some aging.

Great beer!!! Love all the flavours that it produces from each sip. I am a huge fan of this brewery and this beer I have yet to be disappointed with a beer from stone. Double Bastard is my favourite yearly release by far.

tulip. beige color, small head and clean body. Smell of  berries  and warmth alcohol and sweet notes of dark fruits. Taste is sweet caramels with notes of grapes, malts, and slightly sweet. It does leaves you with a dry finish.

Thanks to ¬íol Chipalsa for picking this one up. Nose is plenty of cherry, caramel, marzipan, some nutty (almond?) notes, dark fruits, alcohol, and citrusy hops. Quite a bit of stuff going on here. Pour is brown with a  tan head. Tastes similar too a nice barleywine mixed with a scotch ale. Tons of fruity cherry/plum notes with a good dose of citrus and hops. A touch of alcohol and some caramel malt. Mouth feel is smooth; not unlike a mead. An interesting brew to say the least. Not bad at all.

1 finger beige head that sinks to 4mm, dark amber body. Nose: Caramel, figs, madeira, floral notes, honey, seville orange and oranges. Aroma: Caramel, resin, grapefruit, seville orange, figs, madeira, honey, floral notes, clementines and marzipan. Initially quite sweet with an enormously  dry, bitter ending. I feel like my tounge is getting punished. Unbalanced and brilliant!

Stone is celebrating 10 years of the Double Bastard and I was fortunate enough to have the current vintage (2009) on draft at a local beer bar. Much appreciated treat for myself.

Beer was clear and brown. Formed a thin white head (slightly yellowish bubbles) and has low carbonation. Lacing is high, its an attractive beer.

The aroma is primarily hops and malt. There is some detectable alcohol in the nose, but its not solvent-like at all.

Beer is surprisingly smooth, really high bitterness at the back of the mouth, a little (less than I expected) sweetness at the front. Sweetness in the front is primarily malt based syrup flavor. Its good. There is some alcohol in the midpalate but its not bad and is well balanced by the high hop bitterness in the back. Drinkability is fine, not high, couldn¬ít pound this beer, Mouthfeel is good, nice connectivity throughout the beer, good body, not thin or too thick. Beer gets a little dry after a few drinks but that¬ís OK. A really nice beer.

Whenever I drink a beer like this I wonder how it will age. This is one of those strong ales that I bet would get sweeter with time as the hops fell back and the alcohol warmness mellowed.

Serving type: on-tap

Draught at World of Beer.  Pour is a dark amber brown with a lingering medium head.  This is a great beer.  A little sticky sweet but not too much...dark fruit blending into some nice, sappy hops with solid malts and a refreshing alcohol finish.  A very, very good beer.

This is a near perfect beer, The appearance is really a brown mud-puddle-brown that swirl in a royally evil way. The aroma is a treat, huge malts and some alcohol. Nice hops claiming the balcony. The taste is so damn delicious it¬ís ridiculous. Everything just blends together so masterfully. It coats the palate with a beautiful huge beer curtain.

Pours a red brown, with a nice tan head.  Aroma of caramel, malt, and lots of dark fruit.  Full bodied with notes fruit, but dominated by malts.  Finishes syrupy with sweet alcohol, and some hops lingering.  Well balanced, and very drinkable.

650ml bottle, 2011 bottling.
Pours a deep copper, with a beige head.
Malty, hoppy aroma, caramel, toffee, spruce, cocoa, almond, marzipan.
Off-dry, medium to full bodied, creamy CO2.
Malty, quite spicy taste, hops, caramel, apricot, spruce, yeast, toffee, faint diacetyl, cocoa.
Very rich, extremely well balanced. There¬ís a gowing sweetness, that is perfectly balanced by the bitterness, and a slight acidic touch. Lovely. (2012-06-06)

Pours a deep red with a thin off white head. Aromas of yeast, caramel, and dark fruits. Taste is hop dominated with some berries and caramel sweetness coming through in there. Soft carbonation and an alcohol burn pretty much the whole way down. I¬íve aged this one for almost a year so it seems a bit more mellow than the last one I¬íve tried. This beer is almost like a meal in itself and is not for the faint of heart; this is a big boy¬ís beer.

Dark reddish amber with an off white ring around the top of the glass. Pronounced caramel and hazelnut nose. Medium bodied with a slightly sweet caramel note in entry, but quickly overcome by biting hops. 2011 bottle. Should let this integrate a bit longer.

Big thanks to zathrus13 for this 2006 vintage as an extra! Bomber to oversized tulip. Looks good; thick, brown, and hazy. Smells great! Reminds me of BB4D. Tastes very nice; time has served it well. This is incredibly enjoyable.

Bottle 653ml, 2010 release. A clear amber rubis beer with medium head. Nose is on aromatic hops and red fruits. Aroma is very hopy on exotic fruits and resin very sweet, toasted malt, toffee, relative hight bitterness, alcohol is burning, mint notes, blackcurrant, light coconut.
A very intense beer but on my point of view too hopy to really appreciate the body, color is wonderful.

Pours a thick and rich amber colour, slightly hazy with a creamy tan head. Aroma is of caramel, butterscotch, pine, slight citrus hop scents and a little toasted malt. Taste is sweet and syrupy up front with a strong but not overbearing bitterness through to the finish. Full bodied, average carbonation, and a thick and creamy mouth feel. An amazing beer, this one is one of the best out their in my opinion.

Pouring this beer i noticed a slight sweet aroma followed by hoppy smell.  The color is a dark red almost a brown.  the first taste was very sweet and malty has a medium body.  The bitterness comes in at the end of the taste.  Not an ipa for me, the maltiness is too much for this guy.

Bottle 2011 .... Hazy reddish dark amber pour thin ring of off white head had hardly any carbonation when I opened it ..... aroma of chewy caramel hops, dark fruits, earthy and faded citrusy hops ..... taste is more on the side of a red ipa/strong ale with chewy caramel malts, faded citrusy hops, dark fruits and earthy hops ..... has a nice bitter bite to it ... mouthfeel is oily .... finish is bitter

2011 bottle. It has a darker amber color and a small tan head. The aroma is malty, with some fig and chocolate notes and a bit of spice. The flavor has some chocolate and hops up front with a malty, sweet aftertaste and great mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Initial aroma like boozy banana bread. Lots of caramel and fruit undertones. Not as good as last years release but still one of the best from stone.
Strangely sweet for an American strong ale.  Dark fruits, raisins, even a bit of grapefruit.  Delicious.  Alcohol pungency. Pours cloudy amber with a beige head.

Pours deep amber with thick white head.  Aroma is caramel, dark fruits, booze.  Taste is sweet caramel malts and a good balance of bitterness.  Only knock on this one is that the alcohol comes through pretty strong.  Medium body, creamy texture.
Tasting @De MolenCloudy reddish amber, small creamy beige head. Aroma and taste some rye, vanilla, sweetness and spices. Good body, bit dry.

22oz bomber from Kahn poured into a snifter. Pours a cloudy dark amber with about 2 fingers of off-white head. Aroma of caramel, alcohol, figs, citrus and other dark fruit. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter. Lively carbonation and a long bitter finish. Overall, very good. I would gladly drink this again every day.

Bottle at monthly tasting @ de Molen, hosted by dEnk. Hazy copper pour, thin white head. Aroma of aged hops, fruity and with madeira. Flacor is slightly bitter fruity, old hops, well balanced and smooth. Very nice.

From notes: 2011 bottling.  Poured red-amber with a small, tan head.  Piney hops aroma with some notes of yeast and resin beneath.  Full body, deep flavors.  Slightly thick and oily.  Strong flavor of grapefruit hops that lingers on the tongue in the finish.  As it warms, the piney notes from the hops come forward, as well as a mild yeasty note.
Copper in color with a good sized beige head. Aroma is of tropical fruit, , floral, caramel, citrus and booze. Taste is of hops, pineapple, mango, heavy citrus and rich caramel.

Pours a burnt orange colour with a thin slightly off white cap. The aroma malty, toffee, biscuity goodness perfectly balanced with hoppy, citrusy, resinous, pine, awesomeness, notes of dark fruit and something I can¬ít pin show up here and there. The flavour is more or less a bang on reflection of all that wickedness, ends with an interesting mixture of apple sauce, brown sugar, and pine, finishes with a slightly medical taste that seems to work. Mouth feel is at the far end of medium, heavy enough to let the flavours sit that¬ís for sure, with a sort of dry mouth feel. So flippin awesome, wish I¬íd bought more.

Mahogany, small off white lace. Concentrated fruit aroma, dough, vanilla, wow... Sweet is combined with a strong bitterness. Smooth body. Ends with a solid bitterness. Really challenges the taste buts. Delicious. Stunning. (At the De Molen tasting, thanks PP!)
Bottle, thanks pp! Aroma is huge hops and caramel, very american barleywine like. Nice. Flavour is big and hoppy and very malty. First quite bitter, then sweet then a long lingering bitterness.

650ml Bottle - Copper with a foamy head. Pine, raisins, grapefruit and spicy malt in the aroma. Fruity, malty and hoppy taste with notes of grapefruit, toffee, nuts, raisins and spicy malt. Rich, but nicely balanced.

From a 65 cl bottle at home in Sk√∂vde (2007 years relese). Amber beer with a small offwhite head. Burnd sugar, malt, dried fruits, licorice, alcohol aroma and flavour. A bit too much alcohol taste and flavour. Otherwise a really nice beer.
Bottled. Pours hazy amber with a small white. Smells and tastes sweet nutty malty and abit alcohol with a similar finish.

Bottle, released in 2007. Nice amber color with a beige/yellowish head. Malty vinous aroma, figs, some other fruits, leather notes, some caramel. Hoppy vinous flavor, alcohol, grass, roasted, caramel. A bit too much alcohol.

Big bottle, poured a brown color with medium head.  Big caramel nose and floral hop.  Med heavy bitter.  Ave carbonation,  slightly oily texture.  Huge bitter hop flavors are almost balanced by a decent malt background.  For bigtime hop lovers.  Bitterness explosion on your tongue.

2011 bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a beige head. Aroma is still subtley hoppy with notes of pine, resin and grapefruit/citrus, followed by lots of sweet and caramel malts, toffee, raisins and dark fruit in general. Flavor follows the nose, some subtle hops left of pine, resin and citrus, lots of caramel and sweet malt, brown sugar, toffee, dark fruit, raisins, subtle alcohol and some red berry like notes. The body is on the fuller side of medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a great brew, I love the Bastards!

220z bottle, pours a small to average light brown head, body is light cloudy amber orange. Aromas of floral, pine, pear and pineapple. Body is full with soft carbination; slight bitter on the finish ties it together.

650 ml bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy orange brown with modest-sized off-white head.  Aroma is quite rich with caramel, citric hops and other fruit.  Taste is also quite rich with some alcohol warmth - notes of toffee, fruit and citric hops.  Big finish.  Big body.  Bascially a big beer.

650 ml bottle bought @ Systembolaget. Pours hazy reddish brown with a small bubbly off-white head that doesn¬ít leave much trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, peaches, orange zest, resin, hazelnuts, bread, earthy hops, oily pine, overripe mango and papaya, pineapple and alcohol. Taste is very sweet and bitter with oily pine, overripe tropical fruits, grapefruit juice, bread, golden syrup, warming alcohol and orange and lemon zest.Mouthfeel is slightly sticky sweet and full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet, very bitter and tiny dry with grapefruit juice, orange peal, caramel, pine and resinous wood. Nice and intense but a bit unbalanced...

Dark red cloudy pour. Decent head. Aroma is full of caramel and toffee. Some tropical fruit in there too. Mouth stings a bit. Alcohol is noticeable. Taste is a little sweet for my taste. Pretty complex. I like the single bastard better but this isn¬ít awful.
22oz bottle.  Aroma is distinctly hoppy.  Pours clear amber with no lacing.  Full taste, strongly bitter with an oily texture.  Crisp short aftertaste, clean.

Reddish brown with a foamy head that stays the entire drink. Smell is of sweet nector with that alcohol smell. Taste is sweetness like honey with that strong alcohol finish, this beer is not for the light hearted.

Bottle.

Clear amber with a medium head. This reminded quite a lot of a Barley Wine. Sweet with toffee, malt but also fruit. Pleasantly bitter and really enjoyable.
Gedronken in Brussel bij moeder Lambic, het ruikt fris en hoppig. En het smaak zoet
I just ain¬ít good at all then word usings that most people have. The beer drank pretty good is all.

From notes.  First reviewed 8/6/2011.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a pint glass. 2010 vintage.

Double Bastard is an impressive looking beer. A deep brown color with a cherry amber tint, this has a very full foamy white head that retains well and leaves a lot of lace. Eventually it dies down, which does not surprise me given the strength of the beer.

Lots of sugary sweetness, bown sugar, toffee, caramel in the nose. Tons of grapefruit hops in here as well. 

Brown sugar and toffee smooth sweetness come onto my palate up front, bringing an intensity unlike I would expect to see from anything but Double Bastard. The sweetness gradually turns into an ever-rising bitterness. Grapefruit flavors dominate a huge hop bill. There is a bit of an alcohol bite from the middle of the sip on.

This truly is ¬íone lacerative mother of an ale.¬í Almost immediately, the tingle from the alcohol and hop bite causes my tongue to tingle. The alcohol leaves a slight burn in the throat and warms the stomach. The body is quite full, with carbonation that is creamy but still provides a bit of crisp character.

The only thing that really gets in the way of my pure enjoyment of this is the strong alcohol bite. A very good beer, one that I will savor and enjoy slowly.
A slap you in your face kind of beer.  Subtle nuances and complexities in this one.  A sipper but a nice one.

Tastes a lot like a barley wine. Not drinkable only sippable really.  Poured into a 12oz tulip.  Aroma is alcohol and hop mixture.  Taste is difficult to gulp.  Explosions of pure hops and alcohol are all I can taste.  Absolutely not my favorite stone brew.. blech

This is to me a Barley wine. The alcohol is on top of things. I usually LOVE Stone Beer, but this one is a bit unbalanced. You should share this one with a couple of friends and, i guess, with some strong cheese instead of meat.

Bottle.
Reddish brown, beige head leaving lacing.
Aroma: tropical fruits, toffee.
Taste: hoppy and malty, peaches, grapefruit, toffee, vanilla, high bitterness.
Full-bodied.
Just a bit harsh, would probably be a lot more balanced with aging. Still very nice.

Dark ruby hue and golden-amber at the top, with a good, small, tan head. Webby lacing disappears. Aroma of malts, fruits, breadiness, and hops. Very gentle carbonation precedes a complex mix of sweet caramel, plum raisins, biscuits, citrus, and piney hop carried in a full body.

Pours a hazy dark reddish orange with a pale yellow head that dissipates fairly quickly to a ring. Leaves some lacing.  Aroma is very sweet caramel and fruit.  Taste caramel  maltiness, some piney hops, some earthiness, and a hint of alcohol that warms as it goes down.  Pretty slick on the palate. Aftertaste is earthy and somewhat woody.

My two cents. aroma is licorice and dark molasses. lightly carbonated syrupy mouthfeel. taste is sweet followed by bitter hops and malt. Not the easiest brew to drink but worth a shot every now and then.

On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids, MI.  Clear amber with a foamy head.  Aroma is malt and English hops.  Taste is alcohol, and very bitter, but not in an IPA way.  Similar to an American Barley Wine.  Thick and syrupy palate.  Pretty good, but not highly drinkable.

Bottle from BrewDog bar Aberdeen. It pours deep red-brown, with a thick beige head. The nose is gingerbread, wood, cake, spice and dark fruit. The taste is oak, leather, resin, alcohol warmth, spice, fruit cake and stewed orange citrus fruit, with a decent bitter finish. Full body and moderate carbonation. Well balanced. I like it.

Appearance was clear amber reddish hues with diminishing 1 finger creamy head and no lacing.Aromas where of sweet choco,caramel floral hops and fruity yeasts.Taste where of sweet figs, choco, yeasts of all strains with slight  citrusy hops and hidden alcohol.Mouthfeel was balanced with all malts and hops this smooth velvety carbonation finish.Complex brew...

Pours a murky copper.  Off-white head.  Smells mostly of dark fruits like plum and fig, dark sugar. Strong but smooth.  Earthy, nutty (?)  Alcohol prevalent but warming.  Really nice.  I¬íve had this before but not for a long while.  I wonder why I don¬ít drink it more often?  Could be new addition to cold weather quaffables.  I still wonder if I¬ím worthy?

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2012 A bloody good beer! Pours a thick dark amber with a medium light tan head. The nose is massive, a full onslaught of caramel, syrup, worts, toasty malt AND resinous hops. Taste is bitter up front with a thick malty sweet backbone. The sweetness subsides quickly to leave room for even more bitterness that feels almost solid in the mouth through the looong finish. Mouthfeel is very thick and creamy with fairly soft carbonation. It¬ís a bastard of a beer and I love it for that.
dark amber color, aroma of citrus pine hops, toasted malt, toffee, flavor is citrus, pine, toffee, roasted malt, slight alcohol spice on the finish, full bodied and very smooth, great beer

Pours deep brownish red with a small off white head. Smells of pine, tropical fruits, and toffee with a little booze. This is a nearly syrupy brew with a massive flavor. Pineapple comes to mind with a caramel and toffee malt notes that finishes with a deeply bitter long finish. Massive beer for sippin¬í time.
Super hoppy.  Smells of hops and candy, with some flowering hop essence.  Very good.

650 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Almost clear, deep amber liquid with medium to big off-white head. Aroma of wort, caramel, citrus, piney/resiny hops, tropical fruit and toasty/bready malt. Taste is light sweet, quite dry, medium to high bitter and really nicely malty. Chewy with caramely notes. Medium to full bodied with good carbonation. Really nice one. The combination of the chewy maltbase and the citrusy hops is great.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown with a lasting 1 inch, tan head.  Very malty aroma with caramel and coffee very present.  A little fruity as well, but secondary to the previously mentioned aromas.  Taste is very malty sweet.  Not quite barleywine caliber, but still very sweet.  Most certainly not a chugging beer.  Only the very slightest of alcohol notes, but they compliment rather than hinder the beer.  It does a good job of offsetting the sweetness a bit.  The mouthfeel is quite full and, dare I say, syrupy almost.  The caramel and coffee from the aroma are also present in the flavor and the finish is, as stated, sweet but offset by a slight bit of alcohol flavor.  Overall, another outstanding brew from Stone and one I would definitely recommend to lovers of big beer.

2011 vintage poured int a Kentucky Bourbon Barrel Ale snifter.

Appearance is a hazy dark ruby with a tiny head that fades to a thin ring around the glass.

Smells of fruit but a couple different kinds. I pick up some orange, grapefruit, and pineapple presumably from the hops but then also dark fruit; figs and raisins. Also some wood.

The taste starts out quite sweet with some light citrus coming in next, much like an Imperial IPA. There is then a transition to the darker fruits more typical in a Barleywine. There is some vanilla along with wood towards the finish. A fairly strong bitterness comes in at the end along with some pineapple. Finally there is a somewhat drying bitterness with hints of tobacco.

Overall this is a very complex and enjoyable beer. There is so much going on and it constantly changes as the beer warms. A sipper for sure kind of wish it came in something smaller than a 22oz bomber.

Wow, great beer!  The aroma is good, but not great, feel like the aroma does not do the beer quality justice.  The taste is just great, not sure how else to put it.  Stone has a homerun with this one.  My only complaint is a slight bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bottle, pours hazy deep reddish with one finger off white head. Aroma is lots of malts, dark fruits, some hops and also some alcohol. Taste is malty, lots of caramel, hoppy citrus and bread. Big bitterness, medium-high sweetness, big body. Nice complex over the top beer.

Nice aroma. The hops are there, but not overly so. Surprisingly smooth going down, considering its brother! Balanced bitterness with and underlying sweetness. Pleasant citrusy aftertaste!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fullbodied Ale with loads of floral hops and well balanced bitterness. A hint of sweetness is present in the background.
Rich, well-balanced ale. Strong but still subtle bitterness. Overall a great beer

Uber hoppy out of the bottle, popping the cap fills the room immediately with the pungent grapefruit and citrus smell this beer is so well known for.  Hops are balanced with a ridiculous amount of grain to balance it out.  Three bombers in one night will tunr you into the Double Bastard, no doubt about it.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 pours copper red to brown with medium and thick head
aromas of caramel malts, oak, sweet hops. some bready tones there as well.
starts out quite sweet, almost barley wine style, but in the end lifting it towards a fine bitter ending. alcohol is finely hidden in the bitter and sweet tones. fine tuned hops and malts makes this a very good ale.

esta es supuestamente la chita = mona de tarzan
This is a lacerative muther of a beer. The evil big brother of Arrogant Bastard Ale. It is strongly suggested you stay far, far away from this beer. Those foolish enough to venture close enough to taste will experience a punishingly unforgiving assault on the palate. ¬íCourse there¬ís always the masochists...
Note: 2007 - 10%, 2008 & 2009 - 10.5%, 2010 - 11.2%, 2011 - 10.5%.

Bottle.
Clear deep brownish red with a dense yellowed head that leaves nice lacings.

Big meaty malty aroma at first with tobacco, leather and meat juice. Then comes sweet sugary caramel with ripe pungent tropic fruits, pine and alcohol.

Taste is syrupy sweet with lots of malts with robust tobacco and leather notes, but also ripe fruits and a growing devastating herby bitterness.

Big body with soft tickling bubbles.

Big, bold and tasty.

Dark brown pour with fluffy tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and dark fruit. Taste is dark fruit, chocolate, cocoa and burnt brown sugar. Nice carbonation and a bitter finish. Something a little not right on this one,
The original is absolutely delicious, and this is even better. Thicker, stronger, tastier.  Yes!
Pours a pretty orangish brown color with some lacing. The aroma is very dank. Flavor is very herbal with some smokiness and fruity notes.
Draft at Gingerman. Deep brown pour. Lots of malty raisin raisin flavors to balance out the bitter, dry finish. Solid West Coast hoppy strong ale.

Nose has some raisin sweetness but just a ton of alcohol beating you down; not bad, but too heavy.  Taste is similar, a complex sweet/dry balance with fruity flavors, reminding a bit of Southern Comfort, but not particularly stellar with all the alcohol backlash.  Just a good strong ale, never have quite understood the hype.  Brandy Double Bastard, on the other hand...

Christmas 2010, 3qt btl. Rated on scene "Almost oakey malty IPA flavour.  Positively doubley as good as Arrogant Bastard."  I have a bomber bottle in my cellar that I¬íll break out soon, but just wanted to get this rating down.

Pours a hazy orange brown with a 1/2 finger. Aroma is a carmely sweetness. Taste is very sweet but very balanced with a nice bitterness. Damn smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer is too much for you.  You can¬ít handle the bitter hops which transcend into a lingering sweetness on only a truly arrogant bastard¬ís palate.  

Alas, even the the lone arrogant bastard is too much for you and yet you even look up and consider exploring the double bastard?  FOOL!  Pick up  the Budweiser you have been taught is good.  Do as the propaganda extols you to do.  Do as you¬íre told.  Don¬ít dare to do something different.  Hell you¬íre probably asinine enough to think that there¬ís a difference between Obama and Romney.  You can¬ít think for yourself so don¬ít drink like it.

Swing the TV-beer back like a foolish high schooler bonging her first beer in an attempt to slip it past the tongue to avoid the taste and impress her peer group.  

You¬íre intellectual life has made no progress since then; why should you expect more of your palate.  You¬íll enjoy this book as much as Kant.  You¬íll have no clue what¬ís going on.

Pours cloudy dark brown-ish with thin off-white head that laces on the glass.  Little aroma and taste is huge from the start through to the finish.  Very dry, malty and bitter.   "Double Bastard is not to be wasted on the tentative or weak."

Bottle. Dark amber colour with a small lasting off-white head. Sweet malt, dark fruits and some hops in the aroma. Flavour is sweet malt, hops, dark fruits and notes of alcohol. Full-bodied, some sweetness and bitterness in the aftertaste.

2011 bottle poured into a snifter. Beautiful Deep amber hue,  strong malty aroma, with some earthy but strong hops. Very full body, doesn¬ít assault the palate right away, but finishes with some good bitterness. This isn¬ít a beer I love, or would drink often, but you have to appreciate how well crafted it is

22oz bottle.  This is one of the last surviving beers of Christmas 2011.  I saved this for the NFL playoffs.  The ale poured an amber-brown in color with tan frothy head.  The ale laced down the glass.  It has been on ice for the over 20 days so I have let it warm up.  The aroma of grapefruit and maybe some spruce.  There is a sweetness of grapefruit.  The sweetness may be due to higher alcohol.  This is an ale for pure enjoyment.  The medium body has a lively carbonation.  The ale finishs with a slight bitter taste.

A hazy, amber-brown pour with a big tan head.  The aroma has bread, caramel, some fruitiness, and hop resin.  It has a full body with a slick texture and average carbonation.  The taste is bitter with noticeable alcohol and a very dry finish.

22 oz. Bottle. Pours dark amber, worn leather. The aroma is a sweet molasses with muted hop, which reminded me of those candy orange slices. 

The palate is between a med-full body with a sticky texture and low carb, a bitter finish, and the taste jumps right out at you, big molasses, those candy orange slices, with a bitter sweet lasting aftertaste.

Overall, a winner. I¬íll be putting one of these to rest in my cellar. Curious to see what a couple years will do to the hop/bitter side of it.

22 oz bottle, 2011.  Thick, dark, hazy copper color.  Thin tan head that disappears to a white ring, light lacing down the glass.  Big malty smells - molasses and caramel, muted hop notes.  Full bodied mouthfeel, big malty flavors - again with the molasses, caramel, toffee, oak - and a good dose of piney hop flavor, lingering bitterness for a well-balanced profile.

(Bottled, rated 2011-12-27) Hazy dark red-copper with a small head. Huge amount of different hops in the aroma. Alcohol and high gravity also present, but overall not boozy, and more pleasant than Amager Rated XXX. Instant hop overdose attacks right from the start in the flavor, but it¬ís hard to find any nuances from it. Pleasantly malty body manages to hide most of the alcohol. Quite full body with soft palate and low CO2. A truly big beer, but no more than a glass of this for me, please.

Pours a litghtly hazy copper brown with a 2 finger soapy tan head that has decent retention and leaves pretty nice lacing. Aroma is dark caramel, tree fruit, citrus hops, berries and a touch of pine. Flavor is dark caramel, toast, roasted nuts, toffee, juniperish piney hops, alcohol, light earthy and wood notes and a decent pine and grapefruit finish with a lingering caramel maltiness. Palate is medium to heavy with a creamy entry that almost immediately dries out, enough that it accentuates the hop bite, but not enough to be unpleasant, light, blanketing carbonation. Tasty beer.
