2010 bottle. pours murky light brown minimal head. aroma of sherry and tons of malt. boozy mouth fell and some oaky sherry

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours slightly hazy dark amber with marron highlights and inch high dull off-white head.  Good fine bubble lacing, medium body, resinous texture. and medium grapefruit hop aroma.  Taste is sweet grapefruit & some caramel malt, pine, some alcohol and finishes slightly bitter.  Imperial IPA, not sure why listed as american strong ale.  Not balanced, a little too much alcohol, not a fan.
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2012 Pours a ruby red with a pillowy tan head.  Smells of caramel, citrus.  Taste is smooth, following bitter with a mild sweetness.  Hops and malts are pumped up to a rich flavor.

Bomber. Pours a rich deep copper. Nice off white head. Aroma is powerful citrus and hops. Taste is ripe fruit, citrus and malt mixture, very good with slight alcohol tow. Very rich taste. Excellent night cap!!!
Dark brown colour. Slightly nutty. Caramel, also sweetness due to alcohol. Solid.

Bottled 660ml (Beer Hunters, 2011 release)
Ruby-brown color, tiny off-white head. Dark bready, citrusy, hoppy, salty and salt licorice aroma. Medium to full bodied. Licoricey, salty, bready flavor. Then excessive bitterness, spices and citrus in the aftertaste. Ultimate bitterness. For slow drinking.

65 cl bottle @ Konttori, Tampere.
Pours clear amber colour with small head. Aroma of exotic hoppy fruits, caramel, mild sweet malts and some syrup notes. Flavour of ripe fruits, caramel, malts and sugar candy. NIce and balanced brew with a hoppy bitter bite.
6525

66 cl bottle @ Olutravintola Konttori, "2011 release"
Sweetish aroma has vanilla and hops with some fruits. Flavour is sweet with american hops, some vanilla, resin and fruits. Too sweet for me.
Bottle. Pours awesome clear amber with a small head. Aroma fruity sweet american hops. Bitter and strong palate. Not Bad.

660ml bottle @ Pannuhuone, Kuopio
2011 version - Pours dark reddish orange with a medium foamy head. Strong malty aroma with notes of caramel, fruits and pine. Taste is quite malty with bready, caramel and sweet notes. Finish is quite strong and slightly bitter and dry. Nice, well balanced American strong ale.

650 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone, Kuopio.
Pours an amber colour with a small white head. Aroma of caramel malts, grass and wood. Flavour of caramel malts, quite heavy hops, grass, wood and some fruits. Full bodied, sticky mouthfeel and a long, warming, sweet and malty finish. Works nicely as a winter warmer.
Tap - small thick head, very dark amber color, mild aroma, sweet malt flavor balanced with a fair amount of hops, very flavorful

(Bottle, 0.65 l, at Pikkulintu, 20111228) The beer poured deep copper coloured and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had hops, malts, citricness and sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were hops, malts, sweetness, mild roastedness and medium bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, hoppy and bitter. Very good hoppy strong ale.

Reddish brown and pretty clear with a good head and lace.  Wonderful smell and taste, this beer is just a bomb for your senses in every way.  To say it¬ís "balanced" would be both true and patently false.  The malt and hops bills are about equal, but they¬íre both completely over the top.  So much intense flavor!  There¬ís some fruitiness and a little bitter, smoky wood type flavors too.  The body is so exceptional, it¬ís amazing.  So thick and rich.  Alcohol is warming and notable but not over the top.  My favorite seasonal from Stone, wish it was year round.  It¬ís surely worthy of the name!

This 10.5% alc. content beer made me very naughty and I almost had to sleep on the couch. I think there are  devil "spirits" in the brew that made me copy the arrogant call-out verbiage on the back of the bottle, and paste to Natural Light and Bud drinkers on Facebook. My God though. What a gift!
Deep amber in color with an off-white head.  Super malty sweet aroma.  Strong bodied, almost chewy sweet-matly with a nice malty bitterness that lingers in the end.

Heavily malted in aroma while the appearance is dark amber.  The flavor has notes of syrup and cutting hops as well, with a warming alcoholic finish.  Extremely thick in body, it was very good but very much not an everyday ale.

2011 vintage, kept for about 6 mths, 11.2 listed abv

Very pungent brew, tasting more like a barleywine at this point, hoppy, bitter, strong, and malty.  I have another I will keep for about a year and re-review but would probably get better with age.

All in all solid

Pours an orange color with a medium well retained head. 

The aroma is soapy with some caramel and pinecone. The aroma has a good dose of hops in it but it¬ís also got a lot of booze and honey. I mean there are a lot of good things happening but it¬ís all a mixed bag of good things that aren¬ít balanced or particularly complimentary. 

The flavor is basically the same as the aroma soapy and sweet with a good bit of booze. Plenty of nice hoppiness, some spicy alcohol character, good expression of bitterness. But again it¬ís kind of a mixed bag. 

I¬ím no stone hater but this one just isn¬ít really for me.

What a beer!! What a bottle 3L magnum (2010 edition) I got last year for Christmas from my sister!!!!!! Beer aged one year in cellar was this to long? Did I lose too much of the hop bite? Beer is hard to pour so my first glass is 1 inch of beer with 6 inches of head (insert gay joke here) beer has settled down now and I got a better second pour. Dark brown opaque body with a sticky thick crown. Aroma is thick and sticky, resin, pine, grape fruit, hardy roasted malts, lots of yum, slight hints of warming alcohol. FAWK this smells good. Hominick just got knocked out in 7 seconds¬Ö¬Öthat blows.  Taste is intense, thick sticky roasted malts, caramel, tons of pine, thick resin, hints of alcohol. So happy I five people here to split this bottle with or I¬ím sure I¬íd be hospitalized. Perfect lingering bitter after every sip. The mouth feel is thick it¬ís like softy carbonated cough syrup. The intensity of this flavor is kicking my ass, I¬íll have to nurse my tongue back to health slowly after I¬ím done. A herbal quality is starting appear. Time for glass number three!!!! Head starting to swim, taste buds destroyed, Jeff looking more attractive. Great beer glad I finally cracked it open.

22oz bottle, 2006 vintage. Pours a cloudy red with a dissipating white head. Smells strongly of hops, citrus and and caramel malts. Tastes of medium to strong bitter with caramel and a somewhat harsh bourbon. Texture is creamy. Body is medium. Carbonation is medium. Finish is astringent bitterness.

Its a tasty dark ale / ipa hybrid.
Poured into a snifter; deep copper, with bubbly, thinning head.  Aroma is biscuit, candied fruit and lemon zest.  Taste is orange and fresh baked bread, with a dry, grassy finish.  Great ale.

pour from a bomber, amber brown color. off white head, lacey. settled to an amber orange color. aroma is malty and hoppy with a hint of spice. taste is strong of hop and malt combined. malt gets sweet for a minute in the after taste. great brew

Aroma contains leafy hops, caramel malts, fruitiness, roasted nuts and light choccolate. Appearance is a very dark shade of amber with a pretty large foam head. Flavor is immediate herby hops and choccolate/caramel malts. The finish presents a nice leafy bitterness. Overall, there are a ton of flavors working in harmony together. A fabulous balanced between leafy hops, caramel and choccolate malts, roasted nuts, slight fruitiness, subtle coffee and bread flavoring. This is a big, full-bodied, creamy brew. I¬íd give this an A+ rating.

Pours a cloudy amber with a thin eggshell head. Aroma is caramel, light citrus, herbs, hoppy. Flavor is great, very strong. Definite alcohol flavor, lemon peel, long bitter finish. Really nice; glad to finally have it.

Bottle. Pours a dark orange with small head. caramel, roasty, citrus, spruce, light sweetness, medium bitterness, bitter. Not bad at all starts of a bit like a pine tree mixed with grapefruit finishes a bit dry.

Tap at Pony with E. Dark amber pour with off-white head and no lacing. Aroma is dry and kind of without definition. Palate is dry hop bitterness and a touch of booze. Rich and balanced but not very defined.
Aroma is pleasantly heady.  Not laced with silly fruits or fancy spices.  Comes across with a great balance of malt, hop and alcohol.  Taste follows up on the promise.  I really enjoyed this one.

Bomber pours a hazy, dark copper color with a small tan head.  Aroma is both hoppy and malty, with roasted grains, citrus, and caramel all present. Alcohol is well hidden, so this one sneaks up on you before very long. Not much carbonation, but who cares?  This is a substantial beer with a long finish that is both bitter and sweet.  It reminds me of a double/imperial IPA but without dominant hops   Well done! The only negative is the marketing hype (like a bottle cap that says "you¬íre not worthy"

What an awesome American strong ale! Bold, intense and intrinsically delicious! Caramel, roasted pine nuts, burnt sugars and a light punch of alcohol make for an abundantly smooth, slow-drinkin¬í beer! Starts off malty & spicy and then settles down to a dry malty finish with some long-lasting caramel in the aftertaste. Not too sweet. Not too hoppy. Just right!!
Moderate robust malt aroma. Hazy dark orange color with a medium with a medium Bitter beginning that fades lightly in the finish and gets slightly sweet. Mildly creamy palate.
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 (*2011): Ce qui me frappe le plus fort mis √† part les fruits exotiques et l¬íamertume narcotique, c¬íest la rondeure incomparable qu¬íon doit traverser √† chaque gorg√©e.

Intense. This beer lives up to it¬ís name and description, very complex aroma and super bitter shock and linger to the taste buds. Extremely dry, bitter and alcohol after taste but surprisingly smooth and easy to drink (especially for the 10+ ABV)

22 oz bottle from binnys.  2010 vintage.

Ar. Boozy dried fruits dominate the nose. Hop character pretty mild on the nose. A bit of pine.
Ap. Deep hazy orange pour.  A bit of a head but leaves nice lace.
T. Quite boozy here despite relaxing for a year. Date prominent, the fruity flavor from Chinese black vinegar without the vinegar ness.  That doesn t make sense. Moderate bitterness on the finish.  Nice contrast with the sweetness.
P. Thick body, quite sticky. Mildish carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2013 2011 bomber pours a hazy burnt orange with light tan head. Thin crisp aroma of slightly roasted grain, a sweet apple and some booze. Up front it is robust and grainy but it also carries a big hop kick of pine and citrus, somewhere between orange peel and grapefruit bitterness with the pine. The hops kind of soften the blow of grain and at the same time make it a bigger beer, although it goes down pretty easy with smooth carbonation and a medium body. The hops really dominate as it kind of has an oily palate that quickly turns dry with some grain texture in the bitterness and a touch of wood. It is close to a double ipa but has too much in it for the style. Overall it is a really nice strong ale that doesn?t get too boozy.

Draft at Iron Abbey with Ann, Linh, and James. Pours a very dark shoe polish brown with a nice mocha head. Aroma is only slightly hoppy. I believe i¬ím picking up some mustiness in the nose too. Taste is not overly aggressive as you¬íd believe it to be. Very nicely rounded between a slight bitterness and a nice caramel maltiness. Not extremely hoppy, but a great American Strong.

Got to try some of this at the Brew¬ís Best Beer Fest on my trip to Vegas, fall 2011. Actually, started there (as I really did not want to miss this one). Amber-copper colour with a nice creamy beige head that has great retention and decent lacing. The aromas are mixed between the grainy and roasted malts, with some farm notes (that are not offensive, but different). The taste has this great hoppy feel with medium bitterness and caramel in the background, with a dry-hopped finish that lingers. Quite a nice easy-drinking, heavy alcohol content brew.
Aroma of pine, caramel, and malts.  Pours deep red and thick with a small white head.  Taste is super intense and bitter.  Feels like a hoppy barleywine.  Pine, grass, caramel and alcohol

On keg at The BrewDog Bar. Pours a deep ruby colour with a thin beige head. Aroma of alcohol, passion fruit, grapefruit, sherry and pine. Flavours of plum pudding, sherry and treacle with alcohol quite present. Mild carbonation and a warming alcohol finish. A little metallic right at the end though.
Don¬ít buy this unless you like seriously well built strong ales.  I am proud to be an American, in this age of craft beer.  And this is pretty close to the best of our brewing art.  Meow.
darker orange/brown colour, big carbonation. aromas are all hops. very resinous.tastes are monstrous. it is almost chunky with the hops. very enamel removing. big resinous. heaven.

Keg at BrewDog. Vivid dark red, thick head fades to nothing. Nose is rich resinous tropical fruits with massive honey/caramel notes too. Booze notes. Not subtle but enjoyable. Palate is similar - hits you in the face with crystal malt sweetness, then hits you again with massive grapefruit hops. Er, ouch?

Tap at brewdog. Pours ruby red with off white head, looks great. Big aroma, lots of resinous hops, fruity, sweet, caramel. Taste has dried fruit, vanilla, pine, caramel, lots of hops, lots of malt, tiny bit alcohol. Relentlessly bitter, like fresh grapefruit on the palate, but enjoyable. Still bitter 15 minutes after it¬ís gone. Just wish my buddy TheCametron was here to enjoy it with me, deadbeat.

Caramel, pine, citrus, grapes, candy corn, toffee-like flavor that comes in with raisins. The alcohol is almost completely masked by the complex flavors. Medium to full body creaminess that engulfed the mouth perfectly. Light Carbonation, just a hint of alcohol warmth going down. It leaves the lips sticky and the mouth feeling dry from the metallic hops. A dangerous easy drinking high abv. beer that should be sipped.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EvIpqC9Lwic

Appearance: Clear brown/amber, 3-finger head dissipates to layering, excellent lacing

Aroma: Pine, orange citrus, celery, bready malts, grassiness

Flavor: Full body, hop astringency, pineapple, bready malts, earthiness, resin, buttered popcorn, black pepper, orange candy, green tea, hint of smokiness, celery + cotton candy residual, mild carbonation

Pairings: Pizza

UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 in taster at urge.  Looks red.  Smells a little red and some hops.  Tastes like the smells but engulfs the palate.  Oakiness really comes through after a good gulp.  I remember this beer once destroying my palate now it just tastes great.  Overall 8 of 10.  

4/9/12 edit.  Shared a 2008 vintage bomber from Corvallis brewing supplies.  Fantastic beer!  Big red malts with still powerful hop balance.  I was very impressed with this aged version of this beer.  9.5 of 10.

Im not a huge "stone" fan, but I did enjoy drinking this bomber.  It pours a crystal clear amber color with white head.  The aroma is caramel, bread, citrus, floral.  The taste is medium sweet with a heavy bitterness.  The maltiness shines a little too much in this one but its pretty good.

Dark brown pour with fluffy tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and dark fruit. Taste is dark fruit, chocolate, cocoa and burnt brown sugar. Nice carbonation and a bitter finish. Something a little not right on this one, slightly overrated in my opinion.

2005 bottle aged 6 years.  I¬íve had the 03 as well, but since this is one I do not drink fresh, I figured the best DB I¬íve ever had should get reviewed.  Pours a wonderful darker amber hue, slight reddish hint.  Big malt aromas, loads of caramel, toffee, some darker fruits, very complex.  Hops have faded to the point that they are only noticable on the outside edge barely.  Sherrified like conditions, malty, smooth, slight anise, it¬ís really big.  Does this have more time?  Sure, but it will be tough to get better than this.

Unique color. Dark amber with hints of brown. Almost pinkish in some spots. Nose is super complex. Dark fruit, sweet malts, citrus and pine. Taste is also extremely complex with similar flavors. Medium to heavy feel. Overall a great brew.
At a beer dinner in Highlands. Huge beer served in a Stone snifter. Assaults all the senses with complex aromas and taste. Paired with a bone marrow burger on a rosemary bun it was perfect.

Aroma of sweet clean fresh fruit maybe dark fruit, some vanilla/coconut,heavy hop resin flavor/bittering, piney some with some citrus,dark toasty roasty roubust malt with vanilla notes.Robust dry roasty bitter finish with mild sweet malt/fruit notes,can detect the alcohol presence some.Better creamy mouth feel as it warms.Alcohol notes are stronger too.
Hazy dark reddish brown with light  creamy head and  some lacing

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 22oz bottle.  I¬ím not the biggest AB fan, but the Double is great.  Pours reddish-brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is pine, grapefruit, vanilla.  Taste is similar but sweeter, maltier, bigger; not overwhelmingly bitter at all.  Very well-balanced.  The abv definitely gets you, though.

22oz bottle. Pours a deep, reddish-brown color with an off white head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, fruity, a bit of pine hops. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, nutty, pine hops, with a bitter hop finishes. A very complex, tasty beer.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is somewhat of citrusy hops with a bit of nutty malt thrown in.  Mildly bitter hop flavor with some caramel maltiness.  Long bitter finish with a bit of alcohol burn.  Pretty good.

Pour is a deep deep amber with decent white foam head. Smell is pungent very robust deep fig currant dark floral that Im not sure (hibiscus) molasses and pine sorry the smell is big and all over the place to me. Taste is hop bitter front sweet really sweet figgy and alcoholly finish that kind of depletes a lot of other flavors. If this hid its alcohol a little better it would be the perfect beer.

The brown gutter appearance pours from the tap with a thin cream head. The citrus Cascade hop is traditional of a Northwest beer. Heavy caramel and alcohol fills your mouth with a thick body and carbonation. Acidic black malts and a roasted dryness complete the package. Not a session beer but glad I had one.

Better than the original bastard but still kind of off. Aroma is malt in a slight hinty kind of way, bits of chocolate, roast, toffee nothing really present kind of like whisps. Appearance is reddish brown, dark. taste is sweet. Palate is thinner than I expect every time. Overall impression is MEH.

Bottle purchased at Premier Gourmet in Buffalo New York. Pours a cloudy orange/ copper colour. Huge whitish head, and not bad lacing left behind. Aroma is sweet, with a little citrus hop in there is also some sort of butter tart smell in there as well. Tastes bitter and smooth. It doesn¬ít wallop your taste buds, but I kind of prefer regular Arrogant Bastard better from memory. I¬íd like to try them both back to back some time.

draft ¬ñ sampled @ Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas: one of many Stone kegs that acquired during/for the Stone vs. Moeder festival \ They keep still putting up a different Stone beer every week or so, I wonder just how many more they have got left \ My strategy of getting the rarer ones at the festival and trying the more common ones latter on as they put them on has really paid of, either way I may have tried maybe more Stone beers now than some Stone fans in the States, it is possible \ I have tried this one before with Chipotle but the Chipotle obliterated pretty much most if not all flavours of the base beer, although I did half-recognise this, this one is pretty much new for me \ Caramel amber with the typical Stone red hue \ Sweet with a strong berry & caramel malt fruit base, hints of wood, spices and syrup as well, toffee, on top of the malt base you get plenty of American hops, the malt  dominates here by 60 ¬ñ 65 % or so, floral & slightly lesser but not much grapefruit hops as well \ Medium body & carbonation, very drinkable \ Pretty nice session, standard beer,  nice,although I am not entirely getting the love for this one

Pours a copper-brown with mid-sized head. Roasted malt apparent in both the aroma and flavor. There¬ís an underlying sweetness under the mostly bitter combination of hops and malt flavors. Quite a strong alcohol component as well.

Bottle to snifter. Pours clear dark caramel color with a soapy kahki head. Aroma pine grapefruity hops and malty alcohol. Taste is straight bitter alcohol with pine hops and caramel. Palate is medium to full with a chaulky hot finish. Sorry this one is not for me, the alcohol is very noticable, but at the same time the amazing hop bitterness could be enhancing the alcohol on my palate.

2006 vintage. Quite turbid and very little head. Looks and smells like a liquid carmel candy. Also raison, port and an old woody aroma. Mouthfilling malts quickly followed by a still (after 5 years) substantial bitter whack. Even the bitter hop flavor tastes of age and toffee. Smooth, rich, complex, strong -- barleywineish.

Opened up one of my 2009 and 2011 bottles with friends. This years is still the amazing beast it has always been. Nose is heavy on the grapefruit and citrus notes. Taste is sweet caramel upfront that quickly fades in a sea of citrus hop goodness. Just a great beer. The two year old bastard is quite different. The hops have dissapeared from the aroma. Instead the caramel dominates. Flavorwise the beer has morphed into a malt monster. The hops are still present enough for balancing, but their flavor is quite diminished. Almost reminds me of some belgian strong ales but without the spice. Interesting to have the two side by side.
Bomber. Impresive brew. Sweet at first, then turning to hops and bitterness. Lingering bite at the end with a nice alcohol burn.

Cloudy burgundy pour with a thin ring of tan bubbles. Sweet aroma, very grainy with notes of plum, toffee, molasses, cereal, and something else I cant quite put my finger on, with a load of piney hops. Taste is sweet toffee and grain, bready with some dark fruit notes. Sticky and resinous. Very sweet up front, but very bitter on the finish. Carbonation level is pretty average, medium-heavy body with a lasting bitter tongue coating. Good, but not great. The front and back ends of the taste are night and day, and I find it a little disconcerting to have something so sweet end up so bitter.
(22 ounce bomber - snifter - 2011 release)  Pours a ruby brown color with little head.  Tastes of caramel, toffee, and floral hops.  I drank this bottle too early should have aged it more.

Bottle pours medium brown with garage tint and brief white head.  Aroma pine hops and caramel.  Taste sweet malts and caramel/toffee with pine hops arriving quickly.  Palate thick and a little syrupy  Finish prolonged hops.  Alcohol well hidden.
Improves as it warms.  Shows the limitation of the "American Strong Ale" style indignation, really it seems to me an American-style or hoppy barleywine.  Too hoppy for me, maybe it would be better with some aging.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint, but then I switched to a Snifter for the second pour once I realized this is essentially a hoppy Barleywine.

Appearance: Hazy orangish-brown with moderate light tan head and some lacing.

Aroma: Semi-sweet caramel and toffee backbone, with light citrus and pine. Somewhat fruity and spicy. Aroma is Barleywine-like.

Taste: Much more bitter and hoppy than the aroma indicated. Loads of pine and citrus overwhelm the malt backbone of caramel, toffee, plum and cherry. Wait a sec, that was the review when it was 45 to 50 degrees. Once it hit 55 or so, it becomes much more malt driven.

Palate: Moderately low carbonation, pretty full body with a very dry finish. Slightly creamy texture.

Overall: If I didn¬ít know that Stone made Old Guardian (which I have not yet reviewed at this point), then I would have assumed that this was their Barleywine. Kind of reminds me of Bigfoot or Old Ruffian with some age on it (maybe like six months to one year), but better!

Poured from a draft into a goblet or tulip glass. Color was caramel reddish. Maybe ¬æ-inches of head. Fairly light lacing on the top. Semi sporadic film on the sides.

Smelled of eucalypts, citrus, roasty malts and vanilla.

Smooth taste on the start. Strong taste, yet smooth alcohol bite. Somewhat fruity taste as well.

Medium body. Average carbonation. Smooth and consistent taste.

Thought about a 4.0 or a 4.5 and went with a 4.5. Really good beer!

Bottle.  Pours orange/amber with a large, off-white head.  Aroma of heavy caramel malts and citrusy hops with notes of orange and a hint of dark fruit.  Flavor is similar with a nice balance between sweetness and bitterness.  Alcohol in the finish with a nice bitterness and a hint of earth.

Draught poured into a snifter at world of beer, Tampa Palms. Pours a deep reddish brown with a full finger head. Aroma is of malty sweetness and pine with hops coming in strong. Flavor is similar with a good hop coming strog followed by a dark sugar or caramel malt. Pine is definitely noticeable as well as some dark fruits on the backside. At 11 percent, it¬ís not hidden. The body is a nice medium which lingers and while lacing isn¬ít an imperial stout, it¬ís nice for what¬ís at hand. Overall a nice drink.

Intensely malty and heavily hopped, although not overly bitter. Flavor is not complex, and there is nothing unexpected or surprising either good or bad here. To me, this beer is essentially a barley wine, which is not a style I¬ím fond of. Would probably age well, but not a beer that I would pick again, as it just is not very interesting to me.
Bottle.  Amber pour.  Aroma of pine and grapefruit.  Taste of pine, grapefruit, and a little bit of sweet malt.  Medium carbonation.  Medium body.  Not as bitter to me as Arrogant Bastard.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2011 2011 Bottle.  A hazy reddish-brown beer with a medium white head.  Sweet aroma of berries.   Taste is very sweet, of berries and hops.  Very syrupy and malty, full bodied, with a sticky mouthfeel.  Quite bitter on the finish.

Bright red.  The nose is heavy with sweet malt, raspberries and acetone booziness.  It¬ís rich, heavy and incredibly full on.  Hot alcohol,  sweet brown sugar malts and a decidedly wicked hop bitterness in the finish.  A real fiend.

Amber with a cream head, hazy.  Aroma is pineapple and some citrus (I¬íve noticed the pineapple before in the oaked bastard, perhaps it¬ís from a specific hop used in this line of beers.)  Body is rather light for the style, unexpected, not syrupy really, light silk feel from the carbonation.  I nice change of pace from other syrupy ASA¬ís.  Flavor is more of a pine flavor with some citrus, huge bitterness, light caramel, but really just the right amount to keep the hops in balance.  Cool
On tap at Rattle n Hum bar in New York, NY. A slightly hazy amber coloured pour with a medium off white head. Malty, hoppy aroma. Tastes hoppy, malty, bitter/sweet. Another big beer from Stone.

Like once before, I found the last bottle in stock!  Pours a nice bubbly brown, not much of a head though. Smells pretty malty with some fruit (cherries?), hops and a hint of alcohol. Flavors are all over the place, LOTS of hops and caramel assault the tastebuds, but not before an aggressively spicy and malty aftertaste. The burn of alcohol is pleasant and warming, I¬íd say it even taunts you to drink more. If you are taking on a bottle on your own, watch out for the ABV, it punches you in the face.

2010 vintage. Pours brown with a white halo of head. Smell: Citrus, lemons, grapefruit, caramel malts and a ton of them, pine and toffee. Taste: Caramel, some chocolate, pine, grapefruit and a touch of molasses. Mouthfeel is thick and the finish is malty but long and bitter very good!

Bottle kindly shared by Plovmand thanks body.. ;) 
Pours hazy amber with a off white head. 
Aroma is sweet caramel, fruity hops and a hint of peach pine and alcohol. 
Flavour is sweet caramel, fruity hops, peach and pine with a long strong bitter after taste..

Draught @ Moeder Lambic during the Stone vs Moeder Lambic event. Hazy orange colour with a small white head. Smells very hoppy and grapefruit. Tastes very hoppy, sweet, fruity. Good carbo, medium body.

Bottle. Thanks Secret Santa. Pours hazy amber with a creamy beige head. The aroma is bread, barley, fruity hops, sweet malt and light chocolate. The flavour is highly fruity with notes of barley, biscuits, fruity hops, caramel, sweet malt almost syrupy and the it kinda explodes in your mouth. Very long duration. Great!
nice soft malty aroma,amber, light hazy,light brown foam,light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, a lot of tast and nice finish.

Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Brown coloured and hazy. Has a light brown head, fully lasting. Heavy malty aroma, dark bread, cerials, chocolate. Great flavor, sweet and bitter, heavy bitter finish. Long duration. Creamy texture and soft carbonation. Light astringent.

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas during the three day Stone Event, 16-18 september 2011. Hazy dark orange / amber color, small white head. Smell hop, some bitter and somehow a lot of wood. Taste pine and wood. Good carbo, full body.

My favorite strong Ale, I¬íve heard it ages well, but its so good fresh it usually only last about 6 months in my cellar. Pours a deep mahogany red with an off white head. Its a big beer and is a bit hot but it is a great malty sipper. There is a strong hop profile but the malt really balances this beer out nicely.

22oz bottle. Mildly hazy dark ruby red color, Light khaki head fading to minimal and leaving some lacing. Honestly, at 11.2%, I was fully expecting this to taste like shit. I¬ím pleasantly surprised. First impression I get is a nice, creamy, woody aroma. Peppery aftertaste. I like the resin flavor that the hops provides. Really complex, I keep discovering new impressions with every sip... Gets better as you go. Of course, alcohol warmth all the way through, but there is no bite or burn - it actually works pretty well, as long as your sipping. The palate is great, too - texture isn¬ít too syrupy, and the carbonation is subtle but present. Just enough so that it goes down smooth. Taste is a mix of bitter, little sweet, and mild warmth. A strong one that manages to not taste awful.

Had a year and a half old bottle. Simply incredible. Aged, the hops weaken down and leave more pallet for the smooth body. Not much hop aroma but the aroma that it does have is all malt and delicious. Cant beat it.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Mahogany body with a thick offwhite head. Good lacing.

S: Mixture of pine and caramel malts take center stage. Some citric hop bitterness as well.

T: Nicely balanced as caramel malt and pine bitterness. Again the citric notes ride in here as well and highlight the complexity of the brew. Booze shines through.

M: Medium-full body. Good carbonation. Clean, bitter finish.

O: The 10.5 creeps in by the end and starts to dampen the drinkability of an otherwise good beer. Will have from time to time when I see it.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2012 En flaska fr√•n 2011. B√§rnstensf√§rgad, klibbig v√§tska med kompakt h√•llbart l√•gt skum. Doften p√•minner om besk grapemarmelad med toffeedrag. Munk√§nslan √§r n√•gonstans mellan kr√§mig, oljig och sockerklibbig, men alkoholen och humlebeskan g√∂r att det inte k√§nns f√∂r s√∂tt. N√•got str√• vassare √§n Bigfoot p√• alla plan och en riktigt god american barley wine.

Nice beer.  Sweet with the hops... as a double IPA should be.  But stronger on the hops side.  Strong sweet... strong hops... many times the hops drops off, not here.  Smell is strong of molasses or dark sugar.  Very enjoyable to sip.  Use the correct Glass!
2010 version. Intense flavors of both hop and malt. Could tell it was very bitter at release. Way better than the regular AB; though a bomber is too much for one person (good thing I shared).
Bottle; clear orange with small beige head; aroma-caramel, roasty, alcohol, floral; taste-medium sweetness, very bitter, long-lasting, warm feel. Delicious
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 Love at first drink and I think I am still uncovering details in its taste. Perfect for those refined who like dense taste and a mild buzz.

2010 bottle.  Pours an opaque caramel color with minimal head leaving a lasting ring.  Smells is big on raisins, caramel malts, sugar and a little booze.  Taste is heavy raisins, ripened and dried fruit, heavy caramel, hopsl and light booze.  The taste is much lighter than one would think with the 11.2 abv.  Overall, a very mature version of the original with a more known alcohol aspect.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2011 2010 release, some age on the bottle. Sweet malty body hop bite is subdued. Some lingering bitterness on the finish. Not much hop flavor but that could have diminished with age. Decent brew
Much like its bastard brother but with a sweeter finish.  Head the warning as worthiness does not come cheap.

On tap at the ACBF. Murky brown pour with almost no head. Big citrus and resinous hops with an equally heavy caramel backbone and an almost woodiness. The palate is almost identical with a big grapefruit hoppiness backed up with caramel maltiness and that little woody hint. Finish lasts days with a long bitterness and slight warming.

The bottle says it all, "You are not Worthy," and to be honest I don¬ít think I am. Very pungent to the nose, lots of hops there. Poors a dark red with a small head. Hops HOPS hOpS. Very complex citrusy and resiny onset with a huge malt backbone. Cant put my finger on what I taste but it¬ís a little roasty with a hint of espresso. Very good, very strong awesome in a bottle. Cheers

On tap at Flying Saucer. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a thick beige head. Looks delicious! Complex mix of hops and malt in the smell. Hoppiness gives way to alcoholic sweetness layered with fruit and roasted malt flavors - more akin to Old Guardian than Arrogant Bastard (it is "Double" after all). Overall, spectacular, especially for the first half of the beverage (16 oz was a bit much for me).

Bomber from 2008. Light hazy orange brown with an off white head. Muted hops, sugar, plums and caramel. Nice carbonation, touch boozy, sweet but still some hops to balance things out. Like this much better with a couple of years on it.

22 oz rocket, cellared 6 months. Pours a cloudy copper with a medium off-white head. Some lacing. Good malty character. Somewhat boozy aroma. A certain resin/hop flavor present that would have been more pleasant if cellared for 1 year or more.

I have yet to find something by stone that disappoints and this was not the first. Hops, Malt, caramel, and cherries were what came through to me the most. the 11.2% abv came through but was not overpowering. Fantastic beer. Real treat.

This is definitely a beer I want to keep on hand. It is joining the normal rotation of beers.

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma is very malty, quite sweet, lots of cherry, very boozy, not terribly hoppy.  Flavor is much maltier and sweeter than Arrogant Bastard and, oddly enough, less bitter (although the hop quotient shows in the finish).  I assume the Stoners have upped the hops but have really added a lot more malt.  The result is one of my favorite Stones.  The palate is slightly oil but also a bit astringent from the alcohol perhaps.

Tasted on 5/12/11 from a 650mL bomber bottle purchased at Sun Devil quite a while ago, 2006 vintage.  Pours a murky light coffee color with amber tones and an average off-white head that slowly recedes to a nice collar of lace.  The nose is tons of malty caramel, roasted nuts showing some oxidation, and light bitterness that smells both resin hoppy and burnt malt.  The flavor is once again, dominated by malty caramel, along with light roasted nutty oxidation, and burnt bitterness with some underlying hops resin as well.  The body is full, thick, and somewhat sticky with average carbonation and a long caramel malt and burnt bitter finish.  Even at this age, this beer has plenty of life left.

Deep amber beer with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet amber malts and hops.  Medium to heavy body and almost chewy with malt and caramel.  Loaded with hops but not excessive.  Mostly just a heavier Arrogant Bastard.  Pretty good stuff.

Dark amber, slightly cloudy, tan head.  Sweet malt and pine in the nose.  Taste is bitter with slight hints of molasses or brown sugar.  Finish continues with bitterness and the feel of alcohol.  Lots of flavor in this one.

10 May 2011, tap. med red orange, slightly hazy. raisiny alcohol and hops on nose. med body and fizzy. raisins or plums and bitter, astringent hop stems. hops dominate but sweet alcohol is great. neat contrast.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2011 a bigger bastard. way thicker mouthfeel, higher alcohol that is well hidden. not to much different that the regular, just heavier and gets you drunker. great malt and hop. seems to be double malt but not quite the double hop. great though...
still on tap at foundry. its a 2010. pretty great sort of barleywine thing going on with the hops changing, not as sharp with the age. toffee.
Shared from I believe a 2L bottle from some nice guys at DLD. It had a nice bitterness and good harshness but it really wasnt for me, it kind of reminded me of a barley wine. Overall good offering
Yep this beer made me a bastard times two for sure. Hahaha. It hits you early and is worth every moment.

Poured from a bomber into a snifter.

Pours a burnt-umber color with the head being a lighter version of the same. Respectable head which dissipates fairly quickly but leaves decent lacing.

Smells of butterscotch, butter and raisins.

Very decadent in the mouth, full-bodied with boozy caramel, dark fruits and vanilla backed up by a nice bracing bitterness. Finish is long and dry.

Overall a very nice beer to be enjoyed almost like a cognac, sit back, sip and enjoy.

Bottle pours orange/red amber with an off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel, berries, cocoa, and a good dose of citrus hops.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of cherry, pine, and a touch of red licorice. Overall body is relatively malty and the hops are aggressive.

22 oz. bottle 2007 vintage.  I have had this many times fresh and aged and for me, aged is the way to go.  Pours hazy amber/copper color with a medium sized off white head.  The nose shows signs of a mildly oxidized English barley wine.  Sweeter caramel malts, citrus fruits with peels and cherries, some earthy notes and plums.  The flavor presents with sweet caramel malts, dark cherries, plum, grapefruit peels, vanilla and an earthy bitterness.  Time calms the hops down and makes this more enjoyable.  I still have a fresh one from time to time.

A: Dark copper with a nice wheat head and a good deal of lacing.

S: Tropical hops and some roasted malts that bring on a good deal of sweetness.

T: Quite sweet with dark sugars and caramel in addition to the tropical and citrus hops. Slightly earthy with some wood notes.

M: Full body with good carbonation and a bready mouthfeel.

D: Pretty drinkable. This is definitely a bastard of a beer. I had this pretty fresh, and I¬íd like to try aging a bottle of this to see what sort of complexities comeout.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009

Dark copper pour from bottle with a nice head.  Aroma is pine.  Taste is wood, pine, booze, fruit and the rest of the kitchen sink.  Man, the entire "Bastard" series of beers is just excellent.  Congratulations to Stone.
Dark copper clear soft carbonation small white rim that last. A: Caramel, licorice, fruity some citrusy hops. F: Full body finish is bitter and long O: Great maltiness well done.

Deep reddish copper color with a puffy cream colored head with nice lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, wood, raisins, pine and floral hops. Very rich, sweet malty and fruity flavor with an extremely well blended, tasty and slightly bitter, hop profile. The alcohol is well blended as well, but you definitely know it¬ís there. Full bodied, smooth and a little sticky. It finishes a little bitter. Very good. Too bad it¬ís not cold outside...

Bomber bottle from Majestic in Addison.  This beer pours a deep mahogany/red with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly.  The aromas are musk, light cherries, oak, and bread.  The mouthfeel is bitter, sticky and dry with a heavy body.  This was an outstanding beer!  Cheers!

Bottle.....big, intense, warming, tasty brew! Pours somewhat hazy dark, dark amber with rich tan head. Aroma of aggressive malt, some hoppy pine, spicy, notes of fruity esters, burned caramel, pepper and seems a bit woodish too. Flavor is the same with a great malty sweetness and hop bitterness. Heavy mouthfeel with low-medium carbonation. Impressive!

Pours clear reddish brown with a thin tan head.  Sweet, complex aroma of caramel malt, brown sugar, and citrus and pine hops.  The hops take over on the palate.  The sharp bitterness of the citrus hops is balanced very nicely with loads of sugary malt.  The alcohol shows through on the bitter finish.  This is a very big beer that makes even it¬ís smaller brother seem timid by comparison.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2017 Tap, Berlin version. Roast, honey roasted nuts, good hops, hazy red brown, off white lace. Sweet finish. Old rating bottle. 6 3 7 3 13 Bottle. Light honey aroma.
Dark amber, lacing head.
Quite grassy notes, over the tip hoppy, gets soapy after a while.
Metallic finish.
Had quite a strong scent of hops and quite a bitterness taste to it that lingered in the mouth. Rather smooth for a 10% beer.

22oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours deep ruby/brown with a a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of caramel and cereal for the malts, but really strong citrus/pine hops overpower the malts.  The malts are present and there to balance, but the underlying bitterness/sharpness of the hops are what are most noticeable in this beer.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.

Pours cloudy dark amber with thick creamy off-white head.  Very complex aromas including brown sugar, marmalade, dried fruits, and a bit of heat.  Tastes don¬ít disappoint.  Burnt sugar, musty ripe apple big all around but with a nice hot/malt balance.  Medium-thick mouth-feel.  Candied apples, and hop bitterness echo back and forth playing tug-of-war for my attention in the finish.  Like many big Stone beers; very good, but not something I would be interested in all the time.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Tap. Murky amber pour with an off white head. Wonderful aroma - almost barleywine like. Some oak in there. Creamy body, nice hop kick, maybe a little citrus.

This bastard pours a very dark copper almost amber, that is pretty clear. The head is very nice rising about 2 fingers and lasting for awhile. It is medium tan with good lacing. 

The aroma is medium in strength and dominated by hops only. I can¬ít pull anything else out. 

The taste is pretty mild, I was expecining a big explosion of flavor. I get mostly hops with alcohol. The aftertaste is very bitter.

The feel is good, drinkablility suffers a tad.

Overall, prett decent. Its like an ipa on steroids not totally my thing but I see its mass appeal.
Aroma has lots of malt and rotten fruits, mostly apricot. Taste is very bitter like dark chocolate or lemon peel and also has frutiy characteristics of apricot.
EVIL + EVIL = Double Bastard.  Ok, back to reality. A very nice rendition of a ASA. The alcohol is palatable as well as the hops, not for lightweights.

Treated ourselves to a growler of this from Bert¬ís Market at Folly Beach.  Pours a beautiful dark amber with a generous head.   Medium slightly creamy body with a solid mouthfeel.   Aroma of sweet caramel malt, spicy hops and some fruit.  Hops come through in the taste and then sweet malt, caramel, some citrus and spice- in that glorious order.  Finish is slightly dry with some alcohol.  Really amazingly balanced for a "big" beer- not overly hoppy or malty.   If you like real beer- you will like this.   Tested it on some non-craft beer drinkers who found it a bit much for their palate.  Probably wouldn¬ít want more than one pint at a time, but really exceptional.

Huge malty body. Stone must use three times the amount as a lot of places. And hops...anyway...this is so awesome, so balanced. It¬ís slight hot but the nose let¬ís you know its gonna be sweet and delicious. Nothing more to say really.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, spicy hops, & some fruit; Flavor of intense hops, sweet malt, caramel, citrus, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter with some alcohol; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, an explosion of hops - I enjoyed it.

popped a bomber at Thursday Night Football kickoff

poured a dark cloudy brown into the glass, not a clear beer. opaque.

Smells of extreme Grapefruit rine of the first nose followed by heavy wafts of grain and malt. This thing smells like i¬ím in a grain bin squrting grapefruit at my face. slight pineyness but way more grapefruit. 

Tastes similar to the smell with heavy hits of grapefruit hops and a massive load of malted grain. this is by far the maltiest/grain-laiden beer I have ever tasted. some small bits of caramel all over in this once you wear through all the hops. 

nice over the tongue and way more drinkable than I thought it would be at around 10% ABV.

I think roasted chicken or even Pork roast with onions and potatoes would do well with this. Big hearty meal. nothing spicy though, simple tastes to keep this beer on top.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours dark brown with a offwhite head, leaving laces on the glass. Strong aroma of caramel, oak, brown sugar, bread, pine and resin. Taste is bitter hops at first, grapefruit, pine, followed by bready and caramel malt, bitter finish. Medium body, soft carbonation. Nice and complex brew, plenty of different notes in here to keep it interesting. 010311

22oz bottle, 2010 batch, bottled Dec 1 if memory serves.  First half served cold, second half left on the counter to enjoy at a higher temp.  Pours hazy red/copper with a small tan head that leaves a few small spots of lacing and holds a wispy cap and ring.  2nd half pour produces a much nicer head and leaves better lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt, toffee, raisins, apples, pine, floral and earthy hops, touch of citrus, bread.  Good to very good strength.  Flavor opens with citrus rind and pine hops, very strong caramel malt in the middle along with toffee, molasses, a bit of chocolate, some fruit, finishes with sharp bitterness to contrast the sweetness, along with noticeable alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium to full, oily, medium, sometimes prickly carbonation.  A monster of a beer for sure.  I have an ¬í09 that I will crack very soon for a comparison of not only age but the tweaking they did to this ¬í10 batch.
Pours a brown red color with a little head.  pleasant caramel and hoppy aroma. tastes of caramel, hops, sweet fruits and malts. Long lasting taste, overall a flavorfull and refreshing ale
Picked up a bottle at Graziano¬ís with Pizza.  This is a really nice beer, with full mouth, I would call it a double ESB, with lots of both malts and hops.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Draft at Jerry¬ís. Caramel colored with big, creamy, beige head / Earthy, sweet nose of caramel, cooked fruit, coconut, and hops / Full body, chewy, malty but with big, biting, hop kick, and with very bitter finish / Flavors of brown sugar, caramel, cut pine, grapefruit, orange, turning apple, nuts, and coffee / Hard to deny the quality of this brew, and here a lot going on, but the ultimate flavor profile is somewhat dull and ponderous.  Call it a triple ipa.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 2009 release. Comes in the usual Stone bottle with a bunch of hogwash on the back. Served around 50.

Pours into my American pint glass with a dark brownish red with a short lived white head that leaves some lacing.

Smell is like floral hop candy. Hints of sugary caramel blend with some doughy, bready malts. The hops are very floral and perfumey. There is some fruitiness in there too.

Taste is huge with smooth malts and good bittering hops. Theres so much going on with each, the malts are slightly chocolaty and roasty, sweet, and a bit caramally, the hops are nice and bitter with a touch of pine. The alcohol is more prevalent as you go.

The mouthfeel is decadent and the drinkability amazing the style.

Overall this is a big beer that is worth challenging, because it is highly drinkable and smooth, not an alcohol bomb like it could have been.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-28-2009 00:24:16

Pour is a light mahogany color with a small off white head. Nose is of some dark fruits and caramel. Taste is remarkably similar to the nose. Very thick and heavy in the mouth, with a twinge of alcohol, a good sipper.
2009 22 oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber color.  Aromas of bread, malt and light hops.  Very heavy yet smooth, a sipper.  Another delicous beer from stone that ages incredibly well

On Tap at Craftheads in Japan. The highlight of the day came suddenly after drinking Stone IPA. The man sitting next to me bought 2007 Double Bastard Ale and share to me to celebrate our reunion. What an experience.
In 2007, it seems a little touch of thinner color but stands with elegant figure. We close our face to the glass at the moment, and we all looked at each other with grinning. It maintains a superb sense of balance. Port wine atmosphere and the nuances of oloroso sherry gradually. A little zesty hop flavor is still marvelous, and I found the hop protected beer ageing quietly for sure. So cute. I felt that this time is kind of peak ¬ëactive¬í aging point for this beer. Off course may still keep on, but it will be calm another 3-5 years from this point. I am interested in what is going on, but it was a very good timing to have it now after 3 years of bottling. 2007 bottle and 2010 tap connected with beautiful line certainly. Incredible. Beer aging world? like wine? No¬Öno warehouse for everybody drinking beer world. Do American people know how small country Japan is?„ÄÄ...Experience like this all the way across the sea in Japan, what a wonderful world, wonderful US-Japan relationship, Cheers to Craftheads owner who store this beer in this small country.
Sorry my English.

Pours a light brown red color with a light beige head.  Nice sweet caramel and hoppy aroma.   Flavors is again of caramel, hops, sweet ripe fruits and light malts.  Long lasting in mouth of hops and caramels.
Nice ballance of sweet and bitter, flavors.  A nice easy and flavorfull, refreshing drinking ale
Pours amber with a medium head. Has a fruity bannana aroma with a semi sweet burnt caramel taste that finishes bitter with a dry pallet..
Another great one from Stone.  Strong palate with dark cream maltness to big pitted fruit flavors.  Smooth!
Sampler at Big Dog¬ís Brewery. Strong citrus in the nose and sip. Starts sweet then moves bitter on the end. Nice!

Damn!  Where to even start....  Smells sour, fruity and piney - lots of pineapple.  Thick beer that just fills your mouth.  Flavor is just damn full of hops and malts -- complex but balanced.  Tons of bitter aftertaste with a nice alcohol burn in the nose.  Very good stuff, even better than the original bastard.

Double Bastard. You evil fucking cunt.  It¬ís a hop monster, it¬ís a malt monster... it¬ís a little sweet, but then it kicks you in the junk for calling it sweet. I love this fucking beer. This is a tough bomber.

Hazy amber beer, orange tints, and an off-white head. Floral hops aromas, some vegetable type smells as well. Tastes of caramel malts, a bit of sugar, fresh pine, and some complex hoppiness. Smooth, and creamy mouth feel. Very tasty, and surprisingly drinkable.

Bomber poured into snifter. 2010 release. 11.2% ABV. Pours a hazy orange with a large light-beige head with nice retention. Leaves some Rorschach-like patterns of lace on the glass. Aroma of caramel, cinnamon, fresh vegetables (???); could be more assertive. Taste is bittersweet and very smooth; a bit brandy-like. It tastes a bit fruity and has an unidentifiable flavor that sets it apart from any beer I can think of. Very good. Carbonation is medium-low, mouthfeel is creamy, body is medium-full. Much better than less-evil little brother, Arrogant Bastard.

Pours an opaque dark amber with orange hues.  Aroma of brown sugar, caramel, citrus, wood.  Flavor is molasses, caramel, alcohol, sugar, dried fruit, wood, peat, citrus.  Quite nice and smooth with a sweetness up front and a bitterness that lingers.

It¬ís funny, I¬íve had Oaked Arrogant Bastard, but still haven¬ít had straight Arrogant Bastard. Now here I go trying the double version still without a frame of reference. Oh well.
2010 Release, consumed 2/1/2011

Pours clear, deep and dark copper with a moderate head. Nose is burnt caramel, resiny hops. Tons of resiny hops.  Sweet at first, lots of caramel/toffee malt character, and then transitioning into some pretty strong alcohol warming, very bitter resin finish. Hints of leather too. The balance of cloyingly sweet with intensely bitter is interesting at first, but makes it hard to drink more than a few ounces of this bad boy. I could handle this in a nip bottle every now and again, and I¬íll be curious to see what this is like with a year or two on it, but count me among those not crazy about it fresh.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2011 On tap and 22oz bottle.
Deep, dark amber color with lots of creamy head and lacing.  Wonderful aromas of pineapple and roasted malts.  Crazy smooth and robust - so much flavor it¬ís hard to nail any one thing down.  One of my favorite Stone beers, period.  I love this beer!

Bottle. Pours a nice mahogany/rust color, deep amber whatever you want to call it. Head doesn¬ít last long. Moderate light lacing. Aromas of caramel, malt and hops. Pine and resin, some citrus hops too. Lots of sweetness as well. Taste is the same as aroma. Lots of pine and citrus hops. Lots of malt and sweetness in the finish. Some resin and alcohol as it warms. Just like the arrogant bastard but stronger.

A: Poured into a snifter. Rich, reddish mahogany, with a nice tan head. Low retention rate, with almost no lacing.

S: Nice mild hoppy aroma, more of a sweet citrus. Some sweet apple tones as well, with a hint of fig.

T: Strong flavors overall. Malts up front with a nice well-balanced hop flavor. Strong alcohol esters. Some smoky hints too.

M: way too smooth for 10%. very well-balanced. not too thick, but not light either...this one was just right. Mild carbonation.

D: not sure if I could handle more than one, but this was definitely a treat for my first time.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Simply amazing. Huge beer ! Pours a hazy caramel colour, almost red. Small off white head with some nice lacing. Smells of caramel, hop resin, grapefruit. Good nose. Tastes of caramel sweetness with a huge bitter kick. The hops play a big part throughout the whole beer. Palate is immense, thick and creamy. Love it. Very big beer that deserves this rating
this is really hoppy. but it smells pretty good. i¬ím too tired and not sober enough to give this a real rating, but this is super sippable.
Bottle 650ml. Great beer. Aromas of caramel, coffee, grass, and a hint of alcohol. Taste has a bitter kick, with smooth sweetness. Palate is creamy, and full bodied. Brown, with a frothy white head.
Sweet citrus and malt aroma... Notes of grapefruit... Deep reddish color.... Flavor is sweet and citrusy, definitely notes of candi sugar, nice bitter finish... Phenomenally well done.

Poured from the bottle into a standard pint glass.  The initial pour produced an thick, opaque caramel-colored body, topped by a nice head of off white foam.  This is a seductive-smelling brew with a generous sweetness to it, with some tell-tale whiffs of alcohol and hops.  This is heavy-bodied and smooth, though not for the faint of heart, as the hops are quite assertive from the outset, followed by a light sweetness to mildly balance it off.  While the bitterness is at the forefront, Double Bastard is a very drinkable ale (at least for those that like their ales to drink like a meal)

22oz bottle poured into a tulip. 2010 vintage. Pours a cloudy reddish orange with one finger of foam and good carbonation evident. Good lacing. Nose is sweet and malty but not so rich as to be syrupy. A little nutty but mainly it just smells like a massive beer. Very nice mouthfeel for such a big beer. Full bodied but the carbonation doesn¬ít let it sit too heavy on the palate. For a beer with no evidence of hops on the nose it is surprisingly bitter on the palate. A malty sweetness comes on smooth and is balanced out by a mouthful of resiny hops. The finish is hoppy but not overly so. The malt balances quite well here so the finish is light, long, and very enjoyable. Not as clean a finish as the Lucky Bastard but similar in character. One of the best beers over 10% abv you will find and worth every penny.
Nice creamy head.  Dark brown color.  You definitely smell the malt and the hops.  Great taste.  Bitter.  Aftertaste lingers.

Poured into a snifter. 2009 vintage.

4.5 A: Hazy amber-brown color. Two fingers of thick, creamy yellowish white head that retains well and covers the glass in lacing.

4.5 S: Sweet caramel and toffee malts. Hops are intense, especially given the high gravity here. Aromatic and citrusy hops centered around orange and to a lesser extent, pine and peach.

4.0 T: Tasty brew here. Strong toffee and caramel from the top. Raisin and tobacco to some extent alongside a peach and orange fruitiness. Healthy hop bitterness which works well to balance the malt onslaught. Hops lend the citrusy taste as well as a bit of astringency. However, regardless of all the good qualities, there is just too much booziness. If I were to guess without knowing the ABV beforehand, I would put this brew at 16%.

3.5 M: Thick, viscous body. Bubbly carbonation, maybe a bit too much. Alcohol brings down the smoothness, but does give a nice warming on finish.

3.5 D: Really tasty brew. One of the few brews that manages to get lots of malt flavor AND lots of hop flavor, and do both well. However, it¬ís simply too boozy, especially for only 10.5%.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-06-2010 01:40:01

12th February 2009 Very full on Barleywine. Immediate malt with a ¬íwee heavy¬í chocolate profile. Leads quickly in to an almost salty hop finish. Despite the extremes this beer never loses control and holds together well.

Draft at Taco Mac Prado. Opaque amber with zero head and a small trace of lacing. Aroma was rich caramel malts with heavy booze overtones. Light pine hop. Flavors had a bit of sweetened caramel malts however bitterness overpowered this slightly. Good hop presence of light pine matching the aroma. Reminiscent of a barley wine. Quite good.
Dictated, but not read, by ratebeer member

I¬íve been looking for this beer for years, and looking back it¬ís been almost 5 since I had first tried its little brother Arrogant Bastard.  I¬ím not really feeling like describing every specific little flavor in this beer...cause frankly I want to get back to drinking it.  It¬ís obviously very, very similar to Arrogant Bastard, but tastes a little smoother and with a little less bite (which is the opposite of what you¬íd expect).  Perhaps that¬ís due to the weight of it...feels very heavy.  I certainly wouldn¬ít call it twice as good as its little brother, but a formidable beer for sure!

New Beer Distributors, NY 650ml ($6.80): Pours a really nice reddish color with an off-white head. Aroma is of plenty of fruits, plenty of hops, and plenty of malts. Obviously when you drink this you get way too many hops in your mouth. Obviously, there is plenty of aftertaste. Perhaps less obviously, there is balance with the malts and enough fruity flavors to call it a fruity beer. Is it really good? Yes. Is it what I expected? Yes. Is it my favorite ASA? No, not really. Am I glad I had it? Yes.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Big malty nose, caramel with a big punch of bitter pine notes as well.  Pours a reddish amber with a thick white head.  Bitter earthy hops upfront with some pine resin with caramel malts holding their own as well.  It feels messy though, loads of malts and hops with no direction?

Intense long ride.  Initially a strong kit of barley, chocolate, citrus, hazelnut, slight cherry and floral notes then as it passes the back of your tongue a high gravity hop mist creeps up and eventually double bastards your mouth.  Just take sips.  Hilarious speech on the back of the bottle.  World class brew strictly for the gangsters.

The aroma is somewhat malty, faintly fruity. I would testify in court that there is a Tootsie roll in here somewhere. Peanut hued head is fluffy for awhile and then settles a bit. Laces slide back into the lightly foggy amber brew. The flavor is vibrant with roasty malt and bitter hops, the two forces tangling fiercely with neither winning out in the end. The palate is assaulted with the brew¬ís thick oily-ness, but let¬ís be honest, it was asking for it. Brilliantly fun and tasty ale with a mighty punch.

Bottle (2010); Pour is a dark copper, amber highlights with a frothy off white/beige head. Average retention and lacing in this glass. Now this one was a pleasant surprise. I haven¬ít been a fan of t he bastard brews; until now. This one really does it for me. Toffee, Citrus, piney hops on the nose, and the alcohol was noticeable. Pineapple, Toffee, Caramel Malts, Piney Hops, and slightly boozy. Sweet, Bitter, finishes slightly bitter - this is excellent!

Bottle. Hazy coppery red pour with a lasting foamy tan head. Aroma is quite hoppy but also has powerful chocolate and toffee notes mixed in with the orange, grapefruit and pineapple. Flavour pretty much mirrors the aroma with some added hazelnuts. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a lingering, powerful bitter finish. Obviously not a session beer, but for this sort of strong ale this is actually quite an elegant sipper, restrained even.

Aroma: Lemon and citrus with some roasty malt
Appearance:very dark amber red
Taste:almost like a grassy hop flavor, and then semi sweet malty flavor with a touch a creamy and finshes with a mild bitterenss

Double Bastard Ale. If you are worthy enough for Arrogant Bastard, you¬íre going to love this one. It pours our a dark red color with a small white head. It doesn¬ít have very good retention but it does leave some lacing, but not too much. The aroma is primarily of hops and strong floral hits. The flavor is similar to the aroma. Hops hops and more ops with floral notes. The strong hoppiness of the brew is well balanced with the slight caramel malts hidden beneath everything else. If you¬íre a Stone guy like myself, you will definitely enjoy this beer through and through.

Bottle (in NZ). If you have survived 3 days hiking across the Sahara, this would not be the beer you would be wanting waiting for you at the oasis. Dry as buggery! But bloody delicious!! Lots of chocolate orange. But man it is dry...
This Beer is not for the regular beer drinkers. It is amazingly complex but simple one of the best I¬íve had I would defiantly look it up again.

Bottle. Pours amber with a biege head. Flavor is malty with a big pine hops bite with some citrus in there. This is a big beer that hides the ABV well but was very malt/hop forward and not much else there.

Poured into a snifter. Dark copper with nearly no head. Lacing is a beige and disappears relatively quickly. Aroma is malty and chocolate. Taste is like a malt barleywine with a hop took at the end. Finishes slightly bitter, but not too much so. I can¬ít say I¬ím too impressed.

22oz from BevMo in Laguna Niguel, CA. Pours amber with a small white head, with a little lace.  Smells of pine and hops. Tastes carmel with loads of hops. Not nearly as bitter as their other offereings, very nice complexity.

22 oz bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a tulip. Pours hazy mahogany with a moderate frothy tan head. The head fades to a thin cover but leaves lots of fine lace. The nose has huge notes of pine and resin, along with flowers and caramel malt. The flavour starts out moderately caramel sweet but quickly becomes intensely resiny bitter. The finish is long, lingering resinous hoppy bitterness. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is a nicely balanced strong ale with a huge resinous hop character. It has a good dose of nicely rounded malts, but they are totally overpowered by the hops. The hefty ABV is surprisingly well hidden. This is a very well constructed ale that is definitely worth another try. 2010-12-28

Notes of caramel, bread, licorice and hops in the nose.  Pours a dark amber with an off white head that did not leave much lacing on my glass.  Not as much hops as I expected, more heavily balanced towards the malt side in my opinion.  They are right, this is a mother of a beer.  Big and boozy.  Warming all the way down.  Decent.  May seek one out again.

22 oz bottle. Very excited to be able to pick up both this and Lucky Bastard at the same time; thinking it made more sense to have the Double Bastard before Lucky though. Pours a bronze/brown color (reminds me of a dark apple cider) with a small light tan head. Smells of light citrus, dried fruit, a bunch of hops, a bit of caramel, and a little alcohol. Taste emphasizes the hops, dried fruit, with the alcohol being more cleverly disguised near the end. Very heavy body to it, and definitely packs a punch. Very impressive, and makes me excited to try the Lucky Bastard.

Wow.  Without question the strongest, angriest, beer I¬íve ever tasted.  I had been waiting on this one for a while since I¬ím from a backward state when it comes to "malted beverages."  It¬ís piney, citrus-y, hoppy, bitter, and was thoroughly enjoyed with a bowl of chili (the first time).    Color was deep gold, head was light and dissipated moderately.   Even as an IPA lover, this one wouldn¬ít be a daily drinker -- more of a special occasion one to pull out.

Big.  Bold.  Bastard.  It tastes like what it is!  A double version of the amazingly well known Single Bastard.  Malted up, hopped to bits, and fairly carbonated.  I usually enjoy this one the most with about a year of age.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 (bottle) 2010 release - clear dark orange colour with small brown head; aroma of citrus, spruce, fruit; slightly oily palate, strong complex flavour, on the dry side, with long medium bitter finish
(tap) 2014 release -clear, bright honey amber colour with a small tan head; aroma of stewed fruit, citrus; somewhat thick palate; rich, balanced flavour with a long, medium bitter finish

Pours a deep amber with a creamy tan head.  The head lasts and laces.  Very malty on the nose, pine hops, and some alcohol.  In the mouth, the beer has a full body and the alcohol is not hidden and remains through the after burn along with the bitterness.  The taste is complex malts. sweet, chocolate, dark fruits and bitter pine hops, all accompanied by the alcohl presence.  While I know this is not a bad beer, it is just a little over the top in my estimation.

Bomber from my bro in Illinois who can still get this stuff - thanks ck1!  Pours a reddish brown with lots of fine bubbles, including an interesting grouping on the bottom of the glass.  1/2 inch head of very fine foam.  Aroma is pineapple and caramel.  Taste is overripe fruit, caramel and hops with a longgggggggg bitter finish.  Somewhat alcoholly.  Lots of strong bitter flavor.  Very yummy.
(bottle)  The alcohol of a Belgian Quadrupel with less subtlety.  Mildly sweet.  Lingering flavors or prune and dark fruit.  I feel somewhat overrated, as are most selections from this brewer.

Deep Red Pour with tan head.
Nose is grassy hops and big roasted malts.
Roasted Malt front with spicy bitter hop finish.
Full bodied.
Strong beer yet totally quaffable

Garnet pour with a big tan head.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Full bodied with a good level of carbonation.  Thick, resinous mouthfeel.  Strong and hoppy with a pretty good balance of sweetness.  Dangerously drinkable for the abv.  Great brew.
Very well balanced start to finish... begins with hoppy tones transitioning to whiskyish finish.  Overall, a very drinkable beer.
Bomber...poured into pint glass, nicely hoppy, great looking beer, a bit boozy definitely a sipper and shouldn¬ít be enjoyed at too cool a temperature
Hop-fusion in my mouth right now. Aggressive hop flavor which so smooth to finish

Great tan and long lasting foam head with a dark brown cloudy body. This one has a long aftertaste and a bit bitter, but definitely not overwhelming.  I¬ím a big fan of this brewery, and this is another great selection.

bomber from Archer Liquors. Wow very aggresive and hot! The hops were extremely aggresive, way too bitter and acidic, rather than highlighting aroma. Very malty nose and flavor, strong alcohol presence. A good beer, but a little "too much," though I guess that¬ís the point. Tastes mostly like a hopped-up english barley wine.

One mother bruiser of a beer.  Solid aroma on the pour highlighted by bright citrus and freshly baked bread.  Beautiful ruby coloured body with a velvety tan head.  Sweet and warming up front featuring citrus and pine hops backed by caramel malts.  The mouth is very full and filling.  Bitter, bitter, bitter finish!  As it warms, the ABV becomes more prominent and the background flavours of anise and whiskey cask present themselves.  This is a sipper from start to finish.

A strong ale, high alcohol content, with a flavor to match. Fierce bitterness is complimented by an almost chocolaty, deep matly flavor. There is a slight funkyness to the taste, right at the end. All in all, very pleasing.

Tasted from a 22 oz bottle purchased in Denver, Colorado.  Pours a dark red/purple/brown body and a thick brown/purple head.  Amber malty with a strong alcoholic aroma.  Creamy and tingly mouthfeel.  Amber malty flavor combined with alcohol is quite strong.  For the alcoholic content, the beer is fairly smooth.

220z 2009 vintage poured into a pint glass.  Pours a murky reddish brown.  Aroma is very malty with a hop nose.  The taste is way BIG...with notes of caramel, nuts, and alcohol.  This is a VERY BIG beer, but one that has a nice finish.  The abv is very high, so it is hard to drink as a session beer...but a lovely beer nonetheless.  A great big brother to the Arrogant Bastard itself.

Amber with a medium beige head. Not much lacing. The Aroma has floral hops with pineapple citrus, also a strong caramel malt backbone. Flavor matches aroma. Thick and creamy, with soft carbonation. Bitter finish. Not bad, alcohol well hidden when cooler.

Pours medium brown malty aroma.  Huge bitter beer, I found myself craving cheese about 1/2 way through to help balance it.  For such a big beer I was expecting more complexity.  Thick mouth feel and very one dimensional, finishes with bitter hops.  Not bad, but not impressed.

Stone
Double Bastard
Had this many times, but never got around to rating it. Pours medium brown with an orangish tinge. Medium tan head and ok retention. Aroma is bittersweet rye with big floral hops and lots of booze. Flavor is big boozy bittersweet floral hops and an assload of malt. Good to drink, good to drunk. Bleh Bleh Bleh. Urp!

2009 Release.  Bomber poured into a wide mouth chalice.  Cloudy to murky amber with foam swirling across the top and a ring around the edge.  Malty nose of caramel with bubblegum and the fruity/sweet citrus side of hops.  Malty rich in the mouth.  It¬ís kind of woody and has a tobacco taste on the sides.  It is sweet as well, like maple syrup.  Very robust and rich and takes over the swallow.  This is goodness.

Pours a really nice deep amber color. Smell doesn¬ít give enough away of the flavor. Taste is a very sweet, caramel malt and finishes up with a strong hop bitterness. Hops are piney and grapefruity, mouthfeel is excellent ant the bitterness is perfect. Tons of tropical fruit and citrus in this beer, nice compliment to the malt sweetness. SOOOOLIIIIIDDDD

Poured into pint glass, Dark amber to ruby color, heavy with generation of a small amount of off white head.  Nose of candied fruit and malt. Initial flavors of alcohol and buttery hops, turning malty/sweet and finishing with a slightly bitter hoppiness.  Very good, perhaps much better with age.

Wow!  great beer.  pours a dark amber.  minimal head and carbonation.  strong alcohol flavour that is tempered with plenty of roasted malts.  finish is relatively smooth considering the style.  a must-try beer for sure.

Bomber pours an amber/brown with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, sweet malts, caramel, citrus, and slight pine. Taste has an all around sweet candied fruit flavor, immediate hop bitterness smooths into sweetness with a little alcohol warmth. Good all around balance, very nice.

basically a  yeasty aroma with a sugary smelling malt presence yet some resiny and fruity hops present themselves too,you can tell its gonna be strong..appearance is a reddish clear brown with a tan off white head that thins but leaves plenty of lacing..taste is not subtle even for a double ipa a very bitter hoppiness battling with the big malt backbone and finally overtaking it in a surprisingly dry and lingering finish..also surprisingly drinkable slightly slick and oily but tingly too good stuff well worth the price  I will be buying again

Poured into a pint glass as a dark brown/ruby red liquid with a small frothy off white head. The nose is strong on hops, dark fruit (raisin, fig, dates, plum), some smoke, and chocolate. The palate matched the nose with an initial bitter hop taste, followed by darker fruits, chocolate, and some anise. The end is hops and bittered chocolates. Mouthfeel was medium bodied, a mix between smooth velvet and water. Pretty good but over rated.

Tame and timid . The most Arrogant thing about this beer is the pedantic prose.  Hops?  Could have had more.  Flavor? Meh. Abv? My liver just chuckled patronizingly. If this is a bastard, maybe we don¬ít want to know who the father is.
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 Dark fruit aroma. Dark amber appearance. The 11.2 ABV is completely masked in taste. Very good high gravity beer!

OK...so I popped the cap on a bomber and got hit with some serious fruit, alcohol, and floral notes. Very strong aroma from the bottle. Nice off-white head, cloudy redish brown beer. To-be-honest, it really didnt¬í taste like an 11+% ale, at least not in the beginning. As it warmed up, I started to taste more ABV, hints of wood, hops, and citrus. Very tasty, but it seems a bit over-rated IMO. Nonetheless, a very nice strong ale. tasted @ 55F.

2008 vintage at Richo¬ís. Nice lasting head atop a clear red body. Nose still a little hops but mostly malts, cramel, wood, nuts, prunes, cooked peaches, and other various fruity esters. Taste is sweet and malty with more hops in the flavor than the nose.  Is sweet but still very bitter. Hard to believe it¬ís an 08. smoothe creamy and sticky with some sticky lace. Very nice so far but not all that complex.
UPDATED: NOV 14, 2010 Nice medium head.  Aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate, alcohol, pine, lemon and pineapple.  The pineapple, pine and chocolate malt flavors come forward in the taste.
Pours brown with little head. Nose is citrus and pine. The palate is certainly hoppy, but not overly so. Great smoothness to this beer.

Stones Double Bastard ale

Had for game six. Pour is a hazy brown.  The color of the bottle. Little off white head. Aroma is rich malts, alcohol and hints of Bourbon. Flavor is nice malts, bit yeasty. Some hints of alcohol and bark.

Bottle. Clear yellow medium foamy cr√™me brul√©e head with good retention and beautiful lacing. Aroma is caramel, alcohol, citrus, pine and sweet malt. Flavor is fruity with citrus, raisins, caramel, pine, lots of sugar well balanced with a ton of hops. Full body with and oily mouthfeel.

Pours a bit murky red brown with small tanned head. Aroma of sweet fidges, raisins, malts and citrus fruits. Flavor is very hoppy with notes of alcohol. Full bodied and very tart on palate. Finishes very dry and very tart-bitter hoppy, lasting very long after.

2003 vintage, on tap at the RnH Stone Takeover. Mahogany pour with a frothy beige head. Aroma is warm, melted toffee, grass, and bourbon. Flavor starts off very bitter of pine and cardboard but is backed but some really sweet malt quality. Odd moutfeel: I wrote "hard" and "stiff"; wasn¬ít being sexual. Stale pine box finish. There things about this that told me it used to be Xtremely sweet, but now its best qualities have been masked by cardboard and bitterness.
Draught at Churchkey.  2003.  Lots of plum and apricot flavors, strong and syrupy. overall a nice brew.

Had this one on tap at the Fort Worth Flying Saucer Fall beerfest. 2008 vintage.

The beer pours a dark amber color with a white head. The aroma is very nice. I get a ton of citrus hop character with a lot of caramel malt and alcohol. The flavor is pretty bitter with a lot of juicy orange citrus and pine notes. The caramel malt is present in the flavor but doesn¬ít cut the bitterness too much. The alcohol is also present. The mouthfeel is medium to thick and is very sticky. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Year Zero (2011 Vintage): Denser than your average Arrogant Bastard, you can tell this is more syrupy and heavier in alcohol than Stone¬ís average fare.  Excellently sweet, alcoholic and beefy with grain and hops.  A strong aroma.  For such a seemingly-heavy beer, though, this is light in the mouth and the sweetness balances out the alcohol presence nicely.  A high-class beer with an interesting bittersweet bite at the end.  

Year Four (2006 Vintage): Sampled at Falling Rock Tap House in Denver on September 16, 2010.  Very cloudy, deep-dark-dark amber color and an extremely fine off-white head.  Aroma is hoppy, malty, and sweet yet dark. You can tell this is a strong beer by its smell... and I¬ím not just talking about alcohol presence.  Heaviness comes to mind.  Flavor reminds me of an Arrogant Bastard, but aged, oaky (yet not woody) with a wood-grain character.  This puppy is strong... hardcore.  Thick, rich, alcoholic, grainy, hoppy strong ale goodness.

Bouteille de 22 oz, √©dition 2009. Ar√¥mes de malt caram√©lis√© et de fruits rouges. Belle complexit√© malt√©e. Robe rousse fonc√©e et trouble, l√©g√®re mousse et effervescence assez faible. En bouche, le caramel est tr√®s bien exprim√© et d√©veloppe des notes fruit√©es et fum√©es. Le houblon est moins aromatique que dans la Arrogant Bastard (ou peut-√™tre est-ce l¬í√¢ge ?), mais montre tout de m√™me des notes r√©sineuses. Amertume tr√®s prononc√©e coupant efficacement dans le caramel sucr√©. L¬íalcool est pr√©sent mais demeure bien int√©gr√© au profil de la bi√®re. Une bi√®re agressive, √† d√©guster tranquillement.
