The color out of the bottle is a glorious reddish-copper with a fizzy half-inch head. The aroma is bursting with hops, with notes of grapefruit and pine being most prominent. The flavor is likewise overflowing with hop bitterness, eliciting the feeling of eating a ripe grapefruit at a small table in the middle of a pine forest after a rainstorm. Not content to just be a hop bomb, though, this one also has a substantial malt backbone, with big flavors of caramel and toffee. Nicely carbonated and having a texture that is oily but also somewhat creamy, it should go down smooth, but it is just overwhelming with the combination of high alcohol, dense malt sweetness, and big hop bitterness.

Bomber, shared with my buddy-in-brew Zach. Pours a cloudy amber-brown, small tan head, slight lacing. Nose is hop-centric, with pine, orange, toffee, burnt sugar, leather, wood, and tobacco. First sips are bracingly bitter, but not sharp. As it washes over the tongue, the bitterness transforms into a funky sweetness. Caramel, hops, light smoke, and pine. Finish lingers. Check and mate.

2009 release drank Feb 2010.

hazy amber with a dense beige head, full bodied with medium-high carbonation.

aroma: lots of candied piney and somewhat herbal hops, some bready malt.

taste:
T1: pine resin.
T2: pine resin, crisp carbonation, a bit of bready pretzely malt.
T3: resinous pine, long.

piney sharpness really clings to the top of palate, very one dimensional.

Bottle pours dark amber color with off white head.  Aroma is aggressive grass hops and malt.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is very strong malt and bitter hops.  When fresh its real hot.  With some age its still got the bitterness, just not as brutal as when fresh.

Pours red-brown with some head.  Aroma with malt and wood.  Flavor kind of bourbon-like with lots of caramel malt and burnt wood and noticeable alcohol.  Hops just in the background.  Very full body.  Lots of interesting stuff going on here, I would have it again for sure but somehow a little less than the sum of the parts.

In the description of this beer, it tells me to stay away.  Why a beer would put this on it is beyond me.  You would think they would want you to drink it!  It pours a dark brown color with a tint of red in it.  Has a light brown head associated with it.  Smells of wood, hops, earthy tones, plums, and cherries.  Aroma is fairly complex.  At first taste, I get wood and a creamy texture.  The hops roll in next, with some sweetness that tastes plum like.  There is a bit of a bitter finish to this drink.  Overall, however, I like it quite a bit.  Would have this one again.

(draught at Moto Stone 14th Anniversary release).  Pours mahogany with off-white head.  Aroma of pine, citrus, and cooked banana(?).  Taste is sweet followed by bitter.  Medium bodied with oily texture.  Finish is bitter and dry.  Very nice beer.

With all the hype associated with this beer I was expecting it to be a lot better. It has a boatload of flavor, and does scare away the average-joe, but isn¬ít particularly special as far as flavor profile goes.

2009 version. 22fl oz bomber. 10.5% ABV. Pours clear copper ruby on the first pour with solid light cream/tan head. Second pour being alot cloudier in the goblet with the light residual sediment - no big deal as there are no offensive off flavours throughout. Sweet caramel malt aromas overpower distinct citrus fruity and grassy hop aromas. There is more complexity to the aroma in this beer than described. Some alcohol notes are evident, but coupled with the abovementioned; work quite well to add to the complexity of the nose. Sweet burnt toffee and caramel malt notes with bitterness exceedingly prominent regardless of the medium full body. Flavours not as complex, but worthy nonetheless. Carbonation medium light, accentuated by the bitterness. Finish is burnt sweet and lingering bitterness, but satisfying given the complex nature of body and aroma of this beer. Great Job.

22 oz bomber from Casanova.  Deep red pour, fluffy tan head.  Fantastic lacing.  Sweet caramel aroma, some big hops as well.  Absolute onslaught of the taste buds.  Big malty backbone with massive hops.  Leaves your tongue whimpering from a severe ass kicking but wanting more.  The bottle states it very accurately, not for the tentative or the weak.

2009 release. Poured from a bomber into a pint glass.

Appearance: Pours an almost opaque dark brown with hints of ruby and a fluffy tan 2-3 finger head. Very nice lacing throughout.

Smell: Very nice mixture of pine, citrus, caramel, dried fruits and malts.

Taste: Sweet malt flavor up front followed by a very nice hoppy bitterness. Aftertaste is mostly and grapefruit and pine.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with very light carbonation. Very smooth from the beginning. There is a definite alcohol bite at the finish.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability despite the very high ABV. This is one to savor. It gets better as it warms and also gives you a nice warming sensation. I¬íd recommend stopping after 1 bomber if you know what is best for you.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. I would highly recommend trying this. This is one monster of a beer. One of the best I¬íve had in a while.

Serving type: bottle
Well, it¬ís quite a bit like regular AB, but with more malt backbone obviously. More chocolate-good. Malty goodness.

06 vintage on draft at the Stone kick off party.

A: Pours a nice golden hue with a solid one finger head. Good retention and lace noted.

S: Wow have the malts come out with a bit of age. Nice sweet caramel undertones with strong notes of burnt brown sugar. The hops are there no doubt but not overpowering. They are now a nice combination of tart citrus, sweet pine, with notes of pineapple.

T: Holy malt, I like this one. Very similar to aromas. Nice brown sugar sweetness up front which turns to sweet pine. Hints of citrus poke thru but the finish is nice and sweet with tones of pineapple and peach.

M: Full bodied, thick, and clingy.

Bomber. Red brown color. Smell of caramel, resin, alcohol, vanilla. , Medium bitterness, heavy  sweetness. Taste of alcohol, candy and resinous bitterness hops. Some butterscotch and vanilla. Good but not that good.

Holy hops Batman...the flavored text is more enjoyable then the beer.  Too over the top for my tastes.  I could totally sip the liquid equivalence of a  highball glass but more than that and I¬íll pass.  You may grow hops on your teeth after drinking.

Poured from 22 oz bottle, luckily found this while at a liquor store in Escondido (they didn¬ít have it at the Stone World Bistro, this was the last one at the liquor store).  As the marketing description suggests, this is one "mutha" of a beer.  Aroma is like caramel and honey, as malty as it is sweet, like a syrup but it doesn¬ít smell syrupy to me.  Appearance is a dark caramel with a white head that expands as the ale settles in the glass.  Taste is just fantastic, it hits you with that caramel malt.  There are also a lot of other things going on with it, but you don¬ít realize it with every sip as that high ABV hits you without you even knowing it.  I¬ím impressed by this, one of the best I¬íve had.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2010 Massive hops on the nose, alcohol and leather notes.  Pours cloudy amber-red with a nice white foam on top.  Very sweet with a blast of resiny hops and alcohol warming immediate, quickly followed up by bitterness and a woodyness, possibly a symptom of overwhelming of the tastebuds.  Full bodied with a sticky texture that paste bitterness on all surfaces of the mouth.  I bet this stuff would take paint off.  It never backed down, never mellowed, sometimes too much is simply too much.

The beer pours deep orange hued mahogany.  The head s small sudsy and yellow.  The aroma is syupry sweet, honey and fruit.  Many many small bubble rush to the top, I hope this is not too carbonated.  The flavor is very robust big hop, citrus and pine.  The Big malts are matched with big caramel malts.  the finish is not completely dry/sharp, but for the beers character it is pretty clean.  The high alcohol is masked almost completely.  Very good.

22 oz bottle. Dark deep amber with dark red hues thick covered head with great retention and lacing. Big malty aromas of pineapple, caramel, toffee, with citrus hops, slight whiskey, brown sugar.  Flavors of slight alcohol, caramel, toffee, light pineapple, brown sugar. Sweet, bitter, malty. A great strong ale.

I¬íve seen this one just about everywere I go now. Finally decided to try and rate.  Pours thick and has a lingering head. Dark brown in complexity with plenty of carbonation showing. There is a sweet malty aroma with hint of hops. I also get hint of leather and mushrooms. Starts off sweet on the pellet and wham you get hit with the hops and the alcohol. In a good way. Taste like a barly wine. Very enjoyable   09 version

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 Deep reddish brown color with a tan head. Heavy flavors of malts, aged fruit, and alcohol. Complex. Strong. One to sip and savor. Enough of a hoppiness to the bitter finish to tilt the balance.

Poured a hazy golden brown with very little head. The smell was amazing, very resiny, with some fruit. The taste was nearly overwhelming, and I find I can only compare it to the original Arrogant Bastard. The alcohol was well hidden, but snuck up rather quickly after I¬íd finished the 22 oz. bottle. Overall, this is a loamy, mulch of a beer, a walk in the woods, kicking up some leaves.

22oz at a tasting.
Appearance : Hazy amber small head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Quite sweet and very resinous. Lots of fruits (dry peaches). Some alcohol as it warms up.

Taste : Very resinous and bitter. Quite sweet. Very fruity. 

Overall : Very resinous and bitter beer. Alcohol is quite well hidden considering its 10%. Quite complex and very rich. Quite powerful and even a bit overwhelming. Very good overall but maybe a bit too much bitterness. Solid stuff.

Bottle.

A - Dark cherry oak amber color with a small bubbly off white head. Goes down fairly fast leaving some patches of lace.

S - Rich caramel and butterscotch along with a large amount of fruity aroma (apple, cherry, and citrus fruits). Strong amount of floral, citrus and pine hops.

T - Strong caramel and brown sugar malt base. Big hop presence consisting of floral, citrus and pine hops that are extremely strong given the age. Nice fruity liqueur type presence with citrus and cherry along with some apple flavor. Alcohol comes out a bit as well. Great mix of hoppy bitterness and caramel malt sweetness.

M - Medium to full body with a little less than average carbonation. Fairly creamy and smooth.

D - Great balance (don¬ít know how it would be fresh) between sweet and bitter. ABV is a little high but it is a pretty drinkable beer given what it is.

Notes: Vintage 2007. A very enjoyable beer to drink with flavor jumping out and being very strong, but the balance between malt sweetness and hop bitterness was nice (again not sure how it would be fresh). I would definitely recommend trying this, very flavorful beer.

Has a light reddish color that is a little hazy. The aroma is hoppy and spicy . I thought with ABV being 10% it would pack a little bit more of a punch but it is still surprisingly very easy to drink.

I just love really hoppy beer and this gem certainly qualifies.  The aroma warns you that the hops are coming and the color is very pleasing to the eye.  The care taken in production is evident from the first taste to the end of the bottle.

Pours medium brown and translucent with an off white head. Like standard Arrogant Bastard this beer is an exercise in balancing out overwhelming and very bitter hops with a strong and heavy American ale malt...and it does a damn good job. The doubled malt allows the hops to be upped on this one....the combined effect of the hops, malt, and high alcohol is quite powerful but worth the initial shock to the tongue. Great beer.

Poured with a huge foamy frothy light tan head and lots of lace. Color is a clear copper amber. Aroma is malt hop roast . Flavor is like aroma with big hops and bitter over sweet. Good body and carboantion. Huge tang on the tongue from bitterness. Ditto for the finish and some alcohol warming. Pretty good beer, but a little overdone on the bitterness. Not a session.

The aroma is delicious.  Thunder aged this sh!t for 3 years (btw...this sh!t is Krauss).  Me and Thunder liked this more than both the arrogant bastard and oaked aged arrogant bastard.  Vlad is the only hold out.  He thinks the oak aged arrogant bastard is a little better. Sometimes he can be an arrogant bastard!!!  Regardless, we all loved it.

~3 of 13

I had this beer in a bottle that had been on the shelf in the beer store for at least 7 months.  I put off trying it because it was pricey and there were so many other glorious stones to try.  I eventually bought it because it was almost out of stock at the store, and I¬ím so glad i did.  It is excellent and deserves the praise it has received.  The color and thickness of the pour let you know how intense your drinking experience will be before you even take a sip of the beer.  I made sure to take a good whiff and savor the hoppy ale aroma before I began to indulge in the brew.  Finally upon sipping both my friend and I agreed that it was truly an excellent beer and yet another offering from Stone that did not disappoint.  If you love the original Arrogant Bastard you will definitely adore this beer.

Brown with slight red tint and a small tan head, very good lacing.. The aroma is very well balanced and includes hints of raisins, plums, yeast, hops, and flowers. Almost smells as if someone mixed in sugar with a bed of flowers. The taste isn¬ít nearly as sweet as the smell would have hinted to and overall its just a well balanced ale. There is a slight sweet maleness in the beginning which leads into a bitter hop finish. Good beer.

A red and very cloudy pour typically beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with powerful hops. The flavor is totally dominated by hops but also has hints berries and roasted nuts...stronger and wilder than it¬ís little brother...outstanding.

Served from bottle into a Spaten Mug.  Poured a nice amber color with a one-finger off-white head.  The aroma was comprised of slight hops with subtle malty notes. This brew was big on flavor with nice malt, nutty, and a small amount of hops with a nice crisp flavor upon swallowing.  It also had a nice medium feel on the palate with mild carbonation.  Maintained very nice lacing throughout.  Overall this is an awesome beer from Stone.  Then again, this shouldn¬ít be a surprise.  Brew is similar to the Arrogant Bastard in my opinion but has a lot more complex flavors and aromas.  I will definitely be buying more once I get the chance locally.
Overall great carbonation and hops.  Bitter. Nice malt flavor. Will drink again.
UPDATED: SEP 22, 2010 too bad this is a seasonal. I stock up with a case or two when it hits the shelves. And I cry when my stash is gone.

Stone makes some of my favorite beers, and this one is certainly on the list. The intensity of this one¬ís flavor rivals most IPAs. This is a whallop of flavor that will leave you shocked and satisfied.

This review pertains to the very best Double AB that I can recall having (on tap at Breakwater) in November of 2009.  Brown/red color with a healthy slightly off-white head.  Hops, caramel, and a dominant, clean pine smell.  The freshness of the beer really took it to another level as compared to many other Double ABs I¬íve had.  Never had it like that since.   Good stuff.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Poured with a decent white head, that dissipated quickly. Hazy copper-brown color. Nice, but not overwhelming hops and a good deal of maltiness. Huge hop smack up front (burn baby burn), and some warming alcohol pops in before a malty end. Thicker MF, and near creamy. Very light on the carbonation. Almost viscous. Despite the whack of hops, this is surprisingly balanced. Alcohol was almost not noticeable, which helped with the drinkability. Overall, I thought this was fantastic. Definitely takes all the elements of Arrogant Bastard and ratchets them up several notches.

Bottle at the dogpark, 2010-05-01, G√∂teborg, 2009 edition!
AP: amber clodied body, ofwhite rockey big bubbles organic head
AR: rasins, scotsh toffee, heather honey, malts
F: rasins, scotsh toffee, heather honey, malts - a very good ale the alchol is extremly well hidden - buy!

Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with an offwhite head.  Very impressive looking.  Very malty with a sweet backbone but bitter up front.  Caramel/toffee in the scent and taste.  Perhaps some cinnamon as well.  A spicy bite, but somewhat sweet at the same time.

Holy cow this thing is strong.  Nice and malty (my type of beer) with a dark amber pour and small white head.  Nice thickness and body.  Glad I only had one.  I could feel this after just one pint.  This is a bit on the sweet side and bares a passing resemblance to a scotch-style ale.  If you like Stone¬ís Arrogant, or any of Founders various Bastards, then Stone Double Bastard will be right up your alley too.
On tap at Ginger Man Houston.  Reddish brown in the glass.  Malty aroma with a slight hint of dried fruit.  Bold hops mix with a strong malt backbone on the palate.  Very, very nice.
Uh oh... Monday night, game 6, do or die, and I¬ím in the grasp of a double bastard.  Yikes.

2007 bottle that I am finishing as I review.

A-Great appearance on this brew. The body is a beautiful transparent deep mahogany color. Moderate pour produces an aggressive 3 finger light beige colored head. Head slowly fades to 1 finger with a smooth and creamy look (in a standard glass) and has great retention. Plenty of lacing is left behind.

S- Nose is promising with aggressive citrus and piny hop aromas fighting for dominance with a harsh spiciness. A big presence of alcohol looms in the background. No malt detected in the nose.

T-Initial taste is almost sweet. Caramel and chocolate malts are present with an accent of citrus hop flavor. A big spiciness bursts forth for the finish and the flavors present for the initial flavor vanish and are replaced with a big hop bitterness and a large kick of alcohol. A slight alcohol warmth lingers with nothing to accompany it with the exception of an aggressive (of medium strength...nothing too powerful or overwhelming) hop bitterness that lingers on and on and never goes away. The taste is wonderful at the beginning but ends slightly below average. Overall an average taste.

P- Medium to high stinging carbonation that temporarily vanishes but reappears for the swallow (very interesting). Body is thick and sticky-loaded with hops, caramel malt, and alcohol...but still has a pleasurable smoothness.

O- Drinkability gets an "above average" score from me. The taste is average but this brew screams "American Strong Ale" in almost every category. Its slightly more enjoyable than regular AB but is nowhere near oaked AB (which seems to take everything arrogant about the AB lineup and make it more smooth and mature). I enjoy reading the long-winded arrogant description on the back of these bottles but this honestly does not stand out to me as a superior ASA. I¬ím glad I was able to sample this bottle-but my choice from the AB lineup is still oaked AB.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-27-2007 06:02:39

bomber from glouglouburb. 2009 vintage. its exactly what you think it will be. a bigger bastard. red with a tan head. minimal carb. balanced yet huge. the malt profile is classic "double red" and a disgusting amount of american hops went into this one. i dont really need to "review" a beer with almost 1600 "reviews: so instead ill say this; if there ever was a prototype american strong ale this is surely it. classic.

This was thendouble hopped version on Draft at Blind Tiger . 
Piny hoppy nose. Poured a light clear mahogany with a thin off white head. ¬†Strongly hopped (amarillo) with some nice bittering hops. ¬†Really good.

Double Bastard is a smoky red-amber ale with a big foamy head. The head really foamed up nicely in my tulip on the initial pour. The nose is sweet with white grape juice and spices. The flavors are strong and bold. There¬ís spot on bitterness from citric hops. The hop flavors are almost reminiscent of Stone¬ís Ruination, a phenomenal beer in my opinion. Double Bastard comes out and hits you with a healthy alcohol bite on one side and a huge bitter hop note on the other.  The beer is smooth and well-carbonated and keeps a clean feel with a high abv. It¬ís quite drinkable for its strong flavor profile, but it¬ís definitely not easy on the tongue or mouth.

Bottle. Pours a hazy burnt red with a brown head that laces a bit. Aroma has a strong alcohol note with a strong caramel note as well with undertones of hops. Flavor has notes of caramel and nuts and the alcohol is a nice undertone.

Copper colored, can¬ít see through, beige colored decent dense foamy head.  The smell is fruits, hops, dried fruits, malts, caramel, and toffee.  The taste is fruits, hops, malts, caramel, alcohol, sweet, and toffee.

Strong, dark, hearty, with a taste of caramel, coffee, and nasty goodness.  Poured dark and hearty from the bottle.  The aroma was at once strong and inviting, like that dude who always steals your chick at the party.  Mean afterkick.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 650mL bottle, pours dark amber with a white head. Aroma of caramel malt and sugar. Flavour is similar to the Arrogant Bastard (toffee, caramel malt, brown sugar, nuts), but more sugary / malty, and therefore balanced. Excellent.

Pours deep clear red-brown. Small off-white head.
The aroma is imressive and complex. Loaded with floral hops, caramel malt, toffee, burnt sugar, nuts and a hint of chocolate. The taste is filled with sweet caramel malt, bitter hops, nuts and some dark fruits. Palate is warming and rounded. Once again Stone delivers a highley recommended beer.

(draught at plano gingerman) pours deep orange brown with creamy white head and great lace. Nose of citrus, bread, alcohol, ripe banana. Taste of banana, alcohol, bitter citrus oils but creamy. Medium oily body that¬ís very creamy.

Drank this bee while watching the gold medal hockey game with savvy1982. Pours an impenetrable orange with a small head. The aroma is very sweet and malty. Honey, butterscotch, caramel, soft fruit, flowers, and a hint of chocolate. The flavor is sweet, floral and bitter. Butterscotch, pecan, chocolate, flowers, fruit, honey, brown sugar, and a nice bitter finish. Chewy mouth feel. Again, Stone does not disappoint.

3 litre bottle of 2005 shared courtesy of MilkManDan:
Poured dark amber with a medium tan head.
aroma was warm malty toasted marshmallow, cherry wood fruitiness.
Caramel flavour,some earthy/woody tones and some bright lemony bitterness through the middle and then raisiny sweetness and a warming alc in the finish.

22oz bottle. Poured a murky dark orange brown color. The head was two fingers high and light tan with an orange tint. Good retention and lacing. Great looking beer. Nice aroma that included citrus, pine, caramel, pineapple, and toffee elements. Medium to full bodied and sweet. The sugars gave way to mild bitterness at the end peaking around 3/10. As with the aroma, there was a nice mix of balanced malt and hop flavors, particularly caramel and orange liqueur.

A hop head I am not, but still I can appreciate the craftsmanship in this beer.  It certainly was close to perfection in appearance and it¬ís nose was well balanced.  It¬ís persisting bitterness overwhelmed my palate and exhausted it quickly.  It left a bitter, metallic aftertaste.  Nevertheless, the bready, toasted, sweet malts made their presence known.  This beer surely gets an A for sophistication.

This is quite possibly the best beer I¬íve ever tasted. Or will ever taste. Immensely strong in palate and alcohol content with a generous balance of malt and overwhelming hop character, this is a brew for the ages.

Pours a dark amber, slightly cloudy. Small fluffy head that fades to lace quickly. Aroma of caramel, malt, hop, floral, spruce. Bubbly mouth feel. Lower carbonation. Taste of hops, caramel, spruce, resin, dark candied fruit. Full bodied. Bitter and sweet hop caramel finish. This is a very good brew. Smoother and a bit sweeter than the Viscosity¬ís,(to me, that is a good thing).

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2016 Additional notes Stone Double Bastard, really nice. Bold and mellow all at once.
Damn, it reminds me a bit of a serious Belgian Tripel or something with the complex hop flavors, solid body, and marmelade citrus layers. It could be a De Dolle brew of some kind.  Original rating:
Rusty deep golden amber with solid tan white head. Barley wine like aroma of malt, malt alcohol hops and malt. Flavor cleverly replays aromas with a lightly pleasant stinging bite and some drying hop bitterness. It demands the whole palate. It¬í is delicious. Raisins and burnt toffee and lemon and some dewy grass. The best Bastard so far, hedonistic and wonderful.  MARCH 2010.  4.0
On tap. Clear red orange pour with a small tan head and great lacing. Aroma is caramel, malty and floral hops. Flavor is cinnamon, pine, malty, very bitter.

Appearance: 5/5
Hazy dark amber liquid with a medium sized dirty beige foam that left a nice lacing on the side of the glass.

Smell: 7/10
Fairly mild smell of hops, malt and caramell.

Taste: 8/10
Caramell, malt, hops, grass and pine needle.

Mouthfeel: 4/5
Dry and medium smooth mouthfeel with a thick body.

Comment:
It almost felt like a barley wine with allot of malt and a bit wineous. The alcohol was well hidden and it was really easy to drink. Having a pint of this wouldn¬ít be a problem but the effect of the alcohol afterwards might be.

All in all a very nice beer. The oaked version is slightly better in my opinion but it definitely holds it¬ís ground.

Tap at Burp Castle. Pours a beautiful, amber-red with ruby highlights and a firm, white head. Nose is potent with pine and citrus hop aromas. Flavor is deep and layered. At once sweet and bitter, notes of dark fruits, caramel and candy abound. A pretty thick beer, heavy, with mild carbonation. Finish is sticky sweet and somewhat bitter. Super beer.

Pours a nice dark/cloudy amber.  Aroma is deliciously thick with hops, resin, caramel and a little bit of toasty earth.  Taste is smooth, but full with floral hops, caramel, a little malt and some spruce.  The hops character does assault the palate as claimed, but well balanced and so delicious.

Appearance is amber with white head. Aroma of citrus, caramel and prune. Taste is very bitter, behind the aggressive bitterness there¬ís a fruity and sweet taste of prunes, caramel, toffee and raisins. Overall a nice beer that¬ís, in my opinion, a bit to aggressive in it¬ís hopyness.

22 oz bottle from my celler. With a dark Carmel pour this ale comes alive and fills the room with it¬ís aroma. Fluffy tan head reduces to a thin foamy film that seems to cap in the flavor. Bitter sweet full roasted hopps keeps your pallett remembering this brew!

At a tasting, thanks Shahar, pours red with a nice cream color head, intense aroma of marmalade, orange and toffee, flavor is extremely bitter, piney hops, notes of orange and cherry, full- bodied. Very Nice
Pours copper with a white head. Aroma is caramel, fruity, raisin and plum. Complex. Flavour is caramel, medium hop bitterness, raisin and plum.

Bomber from Party Source (Syracuse), served cold in a tulip glass. 19FE10. 
App.:  Deep ruby-mahogany with a so-so light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Deep woody, fruity, sticky toffee with some alcohol, pine and grapefruit hops, brown sugar, a meaty-brothy note, a touch of tang, a hint of butterscotch; I¬ím having trouble describing all the malt notes.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body with soft, silky effervescence, syrupy.
  
Flav.:  Tons of C-hops, toms of malt, fruity, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, some licorice, still a touch meaty, dark rum, pine, wood, grapefruit, huge and over-the-top; sweet with plenty of bitterness and a lingering finish of malts and hops.

Hmmm...too much?  Would 1.5 Bastards suffice?

Like fireworks!
Red, brown with a small fading head. Aroma is sweet and nice. Flavor is nice, dark berries, hoppy with a sweet bitter end.

On draft at the Midtown Broadway Brewhouse in Nashville, TN. This stuff is not for a beer beginner. It does assault the palate with brutal waves of malt, hops, and alcohol explosions. This is a BIG beer. My style though. Velvety and rich. It has a great mouth feel. Alcohol wasn¬ít nearly as overwhelming as I remember it being. Nice head and menacing in appearance.

Bottle, huge thanks to Glouglouburp, a generous soul to say the least; Thanks Dany! Pours hazy copper/red, spotty lacing, thin head. Nose is spicy, sticky hops atop a massive toffee-dominated malt base, notes of caramilk bar, peanut brittle, redfruit, citrus. More toffee (burnt-sugar dark toffee), cappuccino, barley sugar, spicy/sprucey hops, mild non-specific citrus, surprisingly dry and balanced considering the sweetness. Excellent!

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.
Pours a deep copper color with a dense off-white head.  Lots of pine notes in the nose mixing with a good amount of caramel.  The hops really come out in the taste.  This one is surprisingly bitter with lots of pine and resin notes.  The caramel notes are still there but well behind all of the hops.  The alcohol is virtually undetectable.  The mouthfeel is well balanced with a medium feel to it.  The carbonation is medium and the finish is long and bitter.  This one is very well put together and is certainly worth seeking out.

Bottle. Pours copper with a massive beige head. Nose is caramel, toffee, ripe fruit and hops. The flavour is toffee, fruit, caramel and hops. Very smooth balance. Chewy mouthfeel with a fruity hop finish that lingers for some time in the finish. Very tasty stuff. Thanks Jonno for cracking this!

Bomber (2009) from Beverages 4 Less.  I¬íve had this on tap numerous times around San Diego, but finally getting around to rating this one.  Pours a clear deep red-brown with one finger of off-white foam with good retention.  Aroma is light with sweet caramel and a muted hopiness.  But the hops emerge stronger in the flavor (fruit mainly) and are perfectly balanced by the big malt flavors which are not overly sweet.  Really, this is a lesson in how to amp up both malt and hops to create a giant (but balanced beer).  The high ABV is very nicely hidden.  A giant beer, but still highly quaffable.

At a tasting, thanks Shachar, smallish head, hazy light reddish colour, malty aroma with notes of jam and orange, flavours of orange marmalade with dried fruits and oxidised notes, bitterness that is not upfront but comes to the fore after the malty flavours and becomes strong and empathic, big bodied but not oversized. Very good
UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 2009 bottle. Aroma is nuts, caramel malts, earthy and does resemble the aroma of a boiling wort! Taste is medium sweetness, earthy, complex with a good bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 On tap, deep ruby/amber pour with a ring of cream head.  Nose is hops, dried fruits, rich malts and sweet alcohol.  nice thickness, flavor is citrusy hops, alcohol, and dried fruits.  Light alcohol finish but very warming for the weather.
Pours reddish brown with small off white head.  Moderate carbonation.  Aroma of prune and hop.  Flavor is spicy hop with raison.  Perfect feel and body.  Powerful ale.  Awesome.

Bottle from Utobeer, 2007 release. Cloudy copper brown with a medium tan head. Caramel, raisins and citrus aroma. Cellar dryness, caramel sweetness, raisins, some citrussy hoppiness, complex nuttiness. Full-bodied. Accomplished bastard.

Bottle at a tasting: in the aroma strong kumqat oranges, butter, honeycomb and a bit of hops, in the flavor lot of malt and then later good dose of hoppy cirtusy and herbal bitterness, some caramel as well, very good but as great as i expected.

Such a nice beer.  Pours a garnet brown with a very small trace of a white head.   Aroma of raisins, hop and purple fruits.  Taste is very complex,  so many flavours coming out.  Raisins, hop bitterness.  Tastes almost like a barley wine, really nice sipping beer.  Very, very nice.

2009 bottle.

A: The pour is a clear, dark copper color with a lot of red notes to it. The head is about a finger¬ís worth of cream colored foam.

S: The nose has a nice sweet caramel, toffee, and fruit background. A lot of raisins and oranges, and a touch of floral hops.

T: The flavor is very interesting and while it has the trademark Stone hoppiness, there¬ís a lot more going on. The flavor starts off very sweet with caramel, toffee and perhaps even butterscotch. The raisins and oranges again make an appearance in the middle and are followed by a bitter, piney finish. The biggest flaw is that the beer is a bit hot.

M: The body is fantastic. Very full with an almost chewy texture and a moderate level of carbonation. The finish is surprisingly dry.

D: As I mentioned before, the biggest flaw with this beer is the alcohol presence. And as the glass warms up, it comes out a bit more. This is a big, big beer, and one you can¬ít drink too much of in a sitting.

On tap at the Saucer on the Lake. Dark amber with a tan head.  Excellent lacing on the glass.  Huge amount a hop bitterness and fruity aroma that lingers on the palate after the first sip - and everyone thereafter.  The alcohol level is noticeable which is a good thing.  nice chewy finish.

Pours a cloudy amber with big, lasting head. Smells of malt and a hint of fruit. Taste is interesting, starts off with a bit of malt moves on to a slight hint of fruit and finishes with a slight bit of bitterness and alcohol. Mouthfeel is syrupy and pleasant. Overall, it doesn¬ít seem to be as powerful as the description on the back but still a good beer.

I hate to be a naysayer, especially with an offering from Stone, who I really admire.  While this is a reasonably complex beer, it presents the high alcohol content (10%) front and center. I¬íve had plenty of high ABV beers that do a much better job of masking the booze. Flavor is of alcohol, orange peel, malt, with a dose of hops in the background.  I think this would be a prime candidate for some bottle aging.  All of this being said, I still enjoyed this bomber and do want to try it again.
Pours great with a creamy, tan head. Aroma has strong oak, pine and fruit undertones. This beer is incredibly smooth to drink and finishes wet, leaving you ready for more.

bottle, pours brown with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is sweet with strawberry and maple syrup.  Flavor is alot sweeter than the original, with a metallic notes and faded hops in the finish.  Not impressed, but not dissapointed.

22 oz 2006 bomber poured into a snifter. Nice red-brown with a small white head. The smell is hoppy and floral. The taste is also very hoppy, floral with a little caramel (from the malts?). The alcohol makes its presence known but is not offensive. As it warms it gets better and better. Another outstanding beer from Stone.

04/12/08 2005 vintage

Dark, brown-red, smells sticky, tastes bitter, somewhat piney, the hops are still definitely alive and kicking. The beer isn¬ít as sweet as I expected it to be either.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-26-2007 18:57:47
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 Stone¬ís just killin me with all these hop bombs, ipa¬ís, bastards, doubles, damn and there all delicious, whose brew-en this stuff? give him a trophy please...

2006 Double Bastard.  Huge props to BeerNinja for opening it.

22oz poured into a pint glass.  Aroma caresses my nostrils with an aggressive, fruity, malty, caramely scent.  Pours a deep, dark, chocolate with a creamy cappuccino head.  Hops, caramel, resin, malt, and more hops.  This thing is sweet, aggressive yet pleasant. You can tell its gonna buzz you up, but it doesn¬ít taste boozy.  Very special indeed. This ale is indulgent...just a creamy, sweet, full bodied dessert beer, like a liquid glass of alcoholic bread pudding. Well done Stone.  Hope I happen to be around when he opens his 2003 bottle.

This is one great brew, poured a reddish brown into snifter.  Nice head forms that dissipated quickly.  Taste is hoppy and sweet.  You can tell that this is 10%, but it tastes great.  Excellence in a bottle.
Had this at Stone¬ís Winter Storm 2010.  Pours a dark orange.  Soft floral aroma but then the taste is big and citrusy.  powerful bitterness.  alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010 22oz bottle. "Welcomed by a thundering absence of" NOTHING !  Very aggressive taste, as I like those wicked crazy out-of-control beers.  Full-bodied slighlty sweet maltiness, with notes of vanilla and fruits, with a kick-ass mainly citrusy hopping domination.  A hophead wonder and an overall tremendous brew.  Sorry, I have to: "You¬íre better off empty and blank, then left with a single pathetic trace of this..."  I finished the whole bottle by myself without any effort, praying I would taste it again as soon as possible.  I love Stone. And LOG...
Bottle. High creamy and long lasting head. Hazy dark brown body. Caramel spicy cocoa aroma. Alcohol dominated malty caramel cocoa flavor. Pretty spicy. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste.

Bottled. 
Dark brown colour with pale brown head. Rich nose, where almond paste, grassy hops and chocolate dominate. Thick, sweet and malty flavour, like a Barley Wine. Almost syrupy. Chocolate. Lots of hopiness. Really sweet. I don¬ít know. According to my score, I think I liked it...
Bottle pour.Dark brown with a good beige head.Nose is all hops and malt with citrusy hints.Taste was a malt/hop punch in the mouth.Very strong but drinkable.Like this very much.

22oz bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver (Thanks Chris!). Pours a translucent dark reddish brown with an off-white head that lasts a fair time and shows some lacing. The aroma is strong and complex with caramel, cola, citrus and hops. The flavor is hops forward with bitter hops being the first taste sensation you notice, rounding out the sides are caramel, toffee and cola. The mouthfeel is full, creamy and satisfying from start to end; the carbonation is lively and prickly. The alcohol is well hidden, perhaps a touch shows on finish, but because of effective use of hops it is not distracting. The finish is dominated by more lingering bitter hops and caramel. Overall: I love this beer. Gotta¬í stock up the cellar, this is a great year and it should age very well. Recommended.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2013 2006 Release. Pours an opaque rosewood with plenty of head. Complex, sweetish nose with furniture polish and herbs. Very punchy on the palate with a long finish and a pleasant phenolic, smoky bitterness.  Proof positive that hoppy beers age just fine.

Here we are again Stone, "Hello."  What did you bring with you in that case of yours?  A bounty of hops I¬ím guessing.  Really, how could you asume anything else.  Stone does always say, maybe just a little more.  I appreciate their bold persona and their beers.  The beer is full of heady Northwestern American hops - Tomahawk, Chinook, Warrior, Cascades and alcoholic laden malt bodies, oh that oily hoppitude.   The beer is a dark orange-brown color with a thick rust head.  Sexual lacing along the side of the glass.  I¬íd describe this drink like handling a ram in your mouth.  It¬ís not for beginners, in fact your likely to cave in from your mouth making a unique spectacle.  The beer is like a smoking hop being ground into your mouth.  When along comes an alcohol medley via fortified malts.  The beer is unapologetically full, oily, with soft carbonation.  The finish is abruptly bitter that cools and yields to the alcohol.  Rygar stone, rygar!!!
bitterness limits of my tongue was busted tenfold; fantastically balanced for a hopbomb
holy crap.  very intense.  well-hopped, strong yet balanced taste.  lives up to the name.

Clear dark reddish-brown with a thin head. Heavy sweet malt aromas with a dose of bitter hops.  Aggressive pine, grapefruit, vanilla and molasses flavors. Complex and thick, with a sweet start leading to a bitter hoppy finish that wasn¬ít overpowering. Extreme and balanced.

Bottle. Pours a deep, hazy red with an off white 2 finger head. Aroma Is citrus, floral, gingery. Had a medium to heavy mouthfull. In my opinion, the alcohol was well hidden, Had thick texture, cabonation was normal, finish was extremely bitter. Over all taste was exellent. Perfect for winter.
Great sipper. Drank a bomber over a couple of sittings.I couldn¬ít really pick out any particular flavors, but the overall experience was pretty nice.
even better than the wonderful arrogant bastard! it¬ís like they took that recipe and just kicked everything up a notch. a wonderful brew.

1 pint 6 oz. bottle.  This is a BIG beer!!  Lots of flavors.  Big malt presence on the front followed by a hoppy bitterness.  Great looking beer in my tulip.  Great feel in the mouth, thick and chewy.  The alchohol makes itself known too.

Bottle, pours dark red with a big tan head.  Aroma of massive hops and a lot of malts.  Taste is immediate powerful hops with some malts and fruits.  Very aggressive beer not for the feint of heart.  Enjoyable but be ready for it.

big flavorful beer!  Tons of variety of hops and malts...I cant hardly explain all the flavors, plus it¬ís super strong so i was lit by the time I drank this and everything else that night.  I¬íll say this, if you like stone¬ís stuff, get this one, it¬ís one of their most complex and interesting
Pours maple syrup brown with durable head, aroma is hops and hot metal. Mouth is heavy, hint of alcohol, nicely fizzed carbonation. Taste is grapefruit and coffee syrup. Lasting bitter finish.

2007 release, at home, 9th Jan 2010. Hazy tawny brown with a bit of head. Soft, light caramel flavours delicately mixed with hoppy dryness and resinous notes. Fruitiness is slightly glac√© - sweet but not too sweet. There is a burnt hint to the aftertaste, settling in the corners of the mouth. Hops & alcohol on nose. I feel that I¬íve had this in better condition (on draught at the Rake) and leaving it for 18mths+ was probably a mistake.
on tap - orange amber beer with not much foam. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavour is also hoppy but well balanced with maltiness.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2010 22 oz. bottle- Pours deep red with minimal head and perfect lacing, aroma is malt and hops and some alcohol. This is one of the best Stone beers I¬íve had, complex and powerful, yet subdued and subtle. Stone beers are overwhelmingly aggerssive in a good way, they are unlike any other brewery out there, but this beer is different, it¬ís special and is just really well made.

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a chalice.  Nice deep dark brown color with hints of red. A heavy and robust beer with a sharp hoppy bitterness. Overall, a great beer that I¬íll certainly drink again.
1pint 6ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL Excellent!

Stone Brewing Company	Double Bastard Ale	2001	22 oz.	Yes	10.00%	4.75 / 5.0	Barleywine	Clear rich dark amber color.Smooth malty hoppy frontRich malty bodywithout excessive fruit sweetness.Rich caramel base and doughy notes.Smooth rich malty balanced hoppy light EtOH finish.	2/15/2002
Stone Brewing Company	Double Bastard Ale	2003	22 oz.	Yes	10.00%	4.75 / 5.0	Barleywine	Hazy dark copper brown color.Mild lacy head.Rich floral malty hop front.Thick rich smooth toasted black cherry caramel bisquit dry mild fruit body.Clean balanced rich hop EtOH end.Edit 12-29-04.Hoppy!	4/9/2004

Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany color with a thick beige head.  Nice residual lacing along the side of the glass.  The pungent aroma of floral/piney hops, alcohol and pineapple gets your attention.  Then the first sip with its brutally hoppy flavor hits you like a ton of bricks and leaves a bitter mess on your tongue.  Finally the warmth of the alcohol runs down your chest and deep into your stomach.  This beer is not for the faint hearted, but it¬ís oh so delicious and rewarding if you¬íre a hop lover.

bottle hand delivered from california thanks to bman1113vr.  poured hazy dark amber with a beige head and lace.  aroma was malt, pine, ginger root, and maybe some root beer like qualities.  flavor was caramel malt, raisin or plum, and pine bitter.  body was mediumish with low carb.  this was exactly as the name says.  taste like arrogant bastard only doubled.  i really enjoyed this one.
Bottle on 7/27/09.  Pours dark amber with frothy cream head, good lacing.  Toffee, pine and resiny aroma.  Nice sweetness then a bitter balanced toffee finish.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2010 Bomber. Appearance is dark amber with a thin layer of dense, oily head. Aroma is floral hops, caramel malt and rum. Flavor begins with toasted caramel malt sweetness and alcohol followed by resinous hops, vanilla and rum. It finishes bitter and boozy with a slightly malty aftertaste. Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy and full-bodied with low-to-medium carbonation. Overall flavor is powerfully boozy and concentrated with a nice blend of resiny hops and caramel malt.

Bomber. 10.5%. Pours a dark amber with a small, yellow-tan head. Aroma has huge citrusy hops, big sweet malts too, slightly floral, with a pinch of candy sugar. Flavor consists of generous bitter hops, ashy, tarry malt. Lasting sulfuric finish, in a good way. Sticky mouthfeel, thick viscosity, medium carbonation. Definitely a big beer, slightly bigger than regular Bastard. Nice all around with bold, delicious flavors. Overall, very good to excellent.

What a very large beer in every way.  Pours hazy deep orange with white head, aroma is full of piny and citrus hops with a large caramel sweetness.  Taste upfront is hoppy but moves quickly into thick caramel sweetness and goes into a bitter finish.  Over the top in every aspect!

bomber poured into a tulip, really strong aroma that is unique to Stone beers, especially their ASA¬ís, IPA¬ís, and DIPA¬ís. took my time with this one just to make sure i wasnt "unworthy". originally i was worried that it would get annoying and be a chore towards the end, but it continued to taste amazing and i highly recommend using the tulip, definitely made a difference.

Not for the faint of heart. Big in every way. The sweetness really stands out. Too strong to drink everyday. Accept it for what it is and you will enjoy it a lot more. It¬ís best to slam it and let the alcohol take effect. Then appreciate the after burn. Sipping it is kind of like Chinese water torture. There are other beers that are similar that i enjoyed more. Possibly would buy another one to age for years.
Pours out a darkish opaque brown with a small tan head that lingers a bit. Very big smell and bigger taste to this beer. Starts out malty with a pretty hoppy finish.
cloudy  brown in color, big frothy off white head. Pineapple dominates the nose with a hint of caramel in the back round.  A Big Hoppy flavor with a trace of Malts. Not as balanced as I remember it.

Pineapple nose. Opaque copper, thin yellow head. Full bodied, resinous mouthfeel. Extremely hoppy pine flavor with a fair malt backbone and grapefruit accents. Pine and plum finish. It is what it is: a hop bomb, but a good one. Alcohol almost unnoticeable. Do not pair with anything sweet, it will clash.
An ale lovers dream. Better for your first round. This beer is strong and should be enjoyed with a fresh palate.

this beer is big in every way. murky brown color. malt and alcohol smell with resin hoppiness as well. the flavor is a deep malt and a hop linger afterward. Alcohol notes permeates this but is used well.

Bottle: Poured a murky copper color with a fluffy off white head. The aroma is full of hops and roasted malts. The taste lashes your tongue with piney hops, there is also a nice malt and alcohol warming to sooth the pain.

On tap at The Davis Graduate 
Appearance: Dark golden with a small white head 
Aroma: Pine, citrus, spices and grapefruit 
Taste: Lots of malt and citrus hops 
For as big a beer this is it is well balanced, very good.......

Resinous piney aroma.  Pours a dark brown with a billowing tan head that fades to sticky lace. Heavy thickbitter start with a hop explosion that just coats everything.....so over the top but lovely. Full long finish.
Wow! Tastes like candy... at least to me.  Probably the best beer I¬íve ever had. Wow!
Copper & golden with a nice off-white head. Malty and bitter at the same time. Lovely, but honestly, the words on the bottle are worth the purchase price alone!

Pours cloudy brownish color with tan head. Aromas of pine hops, toasted malts and molasses. Pine hops bitterness is the dominan flavor with sweet malts, molasses and some alcohol. Medium body with average carbonation. Mouthfeel is resinous and syrupy.

Bomber, first off this beer is complex if you rate it and its slightly too cold you get one experience too warm another, that in mind the rating is... aroma when cold is of burnt sugar almost sickening sweetnessas it warms the hops come alive and the citrus and pine prevail. Taste- Wow. when cold like the aroma very sweet initially hthe the hops turn your tongue inside out as it warms goes sweet to creamy to hoppy and bitter dry finish makes the tongue tingle. I like this beer.

Dark reddish brown, hazy, cloudy, murky pour, Foamy tan head dissipates after a few minutes, leaving a tan film and nice lacing. Aroma of deep roasted malts, heavy caramel malt, burnt sugar, and some spice and pine as it warms. This beer is huge!!!! My tastebuds are jumping! Big malt, molasses, brown sugar, caramel, vanilla, burnt sugar, piney hops. It begins a little sweet but dries throughout each and every taste as the hops build and shine. It starts sweet, gets creamy mid-taste, and then turns my tastebuds inside out. My tongue is tingling, not sure if it is the hops or the alcohol, but I like it!

From a 22 oz bottle into a pint glass.  2009 Vintage.  Pours with 1-2 inches of thick head which dissipates in a couple of minutes, leaving plenty of lacing.  Smell is of pine, alcohol and brown sugar.  Taste is of piney hops (bitingly so), molasses, alcohol, skunk and a little bit of smoke.  A good strong ale, bordering on an IIPA as well as a barleywine.  It¬ís a good blend of all three.

holy crap- really long lasting caustic syrpupy flavor and mouthfeel. Cloudy dark amber color with a smell of dying flowers, like a funeral home. Maple syrup flavors, too. This made my stomach hurt- I should have eaten something beforehand.

Bottle. Pours very dark red, with a thick white head and creamy lacing. Nose is big on pine and sweet malts, caramel and dry resiny flavors. Flavor is big on fat, juicy malts and a lovely pine element. The hops and malts balance out quite well surprisingly. This was the first craft beer I had, and it¬ís quite an experience to see how much my palate has changed since I first had it.

2009 Bottle pour. Strong hoppiness that quickly gives way to sweet almost creamy maltiness. Finishes with another blast of hops with alcohol traces mingled in. Kinda makes the tongue tingle. Still developing palate so basic reviews for now. 2 thumbs up. Will be getting another to cellar.

Bottle.  Prune/apricot, caramel malt, lemon hops and alcohol aroma.  Copper color with small head.  Sweet caramel malt flavor that is quickly overwhelmed by a dry grass hops finish.  Medium body.  Okay but seems to be trying too hard to be extreme.

Bottle. Caramel malt and light lemon aroma. Poured copper with a small off white head. Sweet caramel and molasses flavor with a strong hoppy finish. Medium bodied. It¬ís a good beer and the marketing on the bottle was highly entertaining, albeit a bit over the top for the actuality of the beer.

Pours a medium brown with an off white head.  Aroma of pine hops and grain with a hint of citrus. Flavor of toffee, pine hops, and a slight alcohol warmth at the finish but is still very smooth. A very deceptively strong beer that is a pretty darn good.

Aroma is tons of grains and hops.  I¬ím not even sure.  Flavor is rather sweet in spite of voluminous amounts of hops I suspect are brewed in this.  There are plenty of earthy hops to it though.  Body is red with a decent sized head.  It just feels like too much on all fronts.  Perhaps Stone¬ís "too much for you to handle" marketing has finally succeeded in giving me something that I think is actually too much for me.

On tap at Underground Bluz. This beer can be quite the kick in the teeth. Especially in the morning.  Hops!  Fantastic pine flavor, probably my favorite IPA. Goes down unbelievably smoothly for the high ABV.
tasted at stone tasting event at the ice house, smelled of alcohol grain and bread.  tasted was alchol at teh end but dramatically smoother than expected.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2010 Poured an orange brown with a fluffy, lasting beige head that left a moderate amount of lacing.  Very hoppy aroma with lots of floral, almost rose petal notes and citrus.  Some gentle brown sugar sweetness.  Flavor is complex and sweet with a long, dry, bitter hop finish.  There¬ís some toffee, brown sugar, and vanilla sweetness and a bit of fruitiness up front.  The bitter hops at the end are floral and citrusy, with grapefruit having a strong presence.  The alcohol is hardly noticable considering the percentage.  I didn¬ít think I could like this more than standard Arrogant Bastard, but I do.

Aroma: Very malty, caramel, dark fruit. Appearance:  Cloudy reddish-brown with a head that all but disappears too quickly without much lacing. Taste: Very carmel malt tasting, pine resin, citrus. Palate: On the flatter side, thick and viscous, very nice long lasting finish. Overall: This is one ¬ístout, in-your-face¬í beer. It¬ís got to warm up to get it¬ís full effect. Hides the ABV very well. Awesome beer and a definite treat. If you like Arrogant Bastard than this is a must!

Ruby copper with a medium tan head that leaves a ring of lace.  Aroma of over-the-top hops, resin, citrus, orange, alcohol and caramel malt.  Taste of heavy hops, citrus, caramel, alcohol and a touch of diacetyl.  Overly aggressive that fatigues the palate quickly and finished up with moderate bitterness.
big malt and hop goodness. a truly unique brew.  more malty than its little bro. scary how drinkable it is. scary how bad your headache is the next day if you drink too much

Bomber from my local. Pours a rusty brown with a minimal head that recedes quickly. Aroma isn¬ít very strong, picked up some citrusy hops but that was about it. Hops dominate this big guy but also has a nice malt backbone with a bit of pepper at the end. Lemon and alcohol linger  through the finish  but it¬ís not overwhelming. Good shit.
This beer has a sweet raspberry aroma.  The flavor is malty with a light aftertaste.  It has a very different flavor from the regular Arrogant Bastard.

Pours amber/ruby, almost tea-like, with a medium- to off-white retaining head from the 22oz. bottle: A heavy crystal malts bill on the nose. Flavors are oven-baked bread, toffee hard candy, toast, caramel, spruce hops, vanilla, and finally some alcohol, which stops shot of being overpowering. Significant bitterness plays with a large, multi-characteristic palate. Drinkability: So dangerous, so deceiving, it¬ís truly epic. Rebuy: Definitely. #239 on 06122009, DG.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2010 One of the best IPA¬ís I have tried so far.  Love Dogfish 90 Minute, and love Rogue Imperial IPA, but I would place this close behind both.  Great body and perfect balance with the bitter.  Love it.

Gift Bomber via the Bonster.  Nose is thick with hops and a funky alcohol fume. Some malt sweetness appears in nose as it warms. Thin tan head from start to finish. Body is evenly moderate and just a skoash waterish at the finish....or that could be me drooling. Hops are omnipresent and quite tart.

.66l bottle. Murky brown pour with little head. Nice american hop aromas, some pine and grapefruit some sweetness. Quite bitter, lots of american hops in the taste, a short sweetness to balance it all and well hidden alcohol. Thick and heavy mouthfeel.
On Tap. Subtle Pine Aroma. Golden amber body with a Medium sticky head.  Sweet candied flavor is well balanced with pine and floral notes.  Strong bitter finish.  Hides the alcohol content well

Bitter, uncompromisingly bold, and a truly visceral experience. The Double Bastard is a malty, meaty, beastly ale that is chalked full of earthy flavors and bark-like undertones. Potent with it¬ís wopping 10.5% alcohol level, Stone delivers a brutal liquid with the consistancy of milk and the burnt chocolate notes of a full bodied beer. Fantastic as a sipping ale. Salut!

2008 release. Bomber served in a snifter. Deep ruby-brown, slightly hazy, small off-white head. Big sweet and heavy malt aroma. Barleywine-esque. Caramel, nuts, molasses, fruit cake, and pit fruit. Big flavor, little carbonation, heavy body. Malty and alcohol flavor. Rich finish that later shows bitterness. Nothing small about this bad boy.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a deep amber color with a rich cream colored head.  Aroma is of banannas, caramel, floral and citrus.  Taste is strong with the hops throughout, but carrying a sugary undertone throughout, with a hint of roasted malt in the long finish.  Full bodied, with a thick texture.

"Strong" ale is right!  This one¬ís full-bodied, and sort of thick feeling.  Definitely packs a punch on ABV, and has a nice blend of hops and powerful malts creeping in.  Nutty brown in color and taste, but with a lingering bitterness that I kind of like.  Pretty good.

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in a pub glass.  The beer pours a medium to deep amber color, with a medium white to slightly off-white head.  The nose initially brings a strong character of west coast hops, followed by moderate to heavy notes of crystal malts and perhaps some continental character malts.  Finally, some alcohol is detectable in the aroma, but it stops short of being overpowering or unpleasant.  The palate is large and full, again first showing a significant level of bitterness, especially given the beer¬ís gravity and the undoubtedly heavy malt bill.  Flavors then transfer to toffee, fresh baked bread, and some depth added by the alcohol on the back end.  Overall, the lightness of the beer was decieving, as it deftly hid its abv.  Very nicely done, another very well-crafted beer from Stone.
A great brew that doesnt taste of the alcohol content is has. a fantastic dinnner or cigar beer. great lingering aftertaste.

22 oz bottle of the 2009 batch poured into a snifter. Hazy deep amber with a sticky off white head that leaves lots of lacing. The aroma is lots of PacNW hops, pine resin, citrus and floral and lots of caramel malt. The flavor is sweet caramel malt with lots of bitterness that comes in slow and finishes strong. Medium to full body with average carbonation and a thick syrupy mouth feel. Finally got around to rating this epic beer, totally extreme and totally Stone.

Nice pine and citrus aroma from a cloudy brown pour with a good off white head. Flavor is well balanced with the malt sweetness complimented by the hop bitterness. Finish is very dry and clean. Got to have more.

Aromas of toffee, fruit, dough. Thick and chewy, this brew is huge. Alcohol is hidden by giant malts, toffee, caramel, white raisons, all sorts of good stuff. Overall, a little too much ass-whooping for me...

Pours a medium to dark golden brown color. Three-finger head of light tan foam. Great retention and sticky, clumpy lacing.

Not a whole lot in the smell department. Light hints of sweet malts and some floral and citrus hops notes. Light caramel presence, but mostly hops.

Hey, what do you know? A beer from Stone that¬ís actually getting close to being balanced. The hops still dominate, as usual, but it¬ís closer.
This has an underlying sweet malty profile that, for once, is actually putting up a good effort to get noticed. 
Mild caramel and sweet malt taste. Pine and grapefruit notes. Slight bitterness.
Not nearly as harsh as Arrogant Bastard.

Smooth and basically creamy. Just a slight touch of sharpness. Nice lower medium level of carbonation.

I have to say that, being from Stone (who I actually like, despite how it may sound), this is a pretty darn drinkable beer. I find most of their brews to be way out of balance, but this one goes down pretty smooth.
At this point in time, this would be my ¬ígo-to¬í beer from Stone.

on tap @ Jakes Bar and Bistro steilacoom, yeah this beer is massive, so massive that I think it deserves a little time out in the cellar@! at least it¬ís telling you the truth, not watering it down for ya... recently did a vertical of 06-07 at a Stone Beer Dinner at Jake¬ís and the 06 was my favorite because it had finally mellowed down so you could taste each flavor... 09 is still too young for me! 07 was pretty damn good too!!

2009 Bomber.  Beautiful rich, dark red pour.  Minimal head allows for full appreciation of the sharply pungent pine and pink grapefruit cirtus hops that pervade the nose.  Wow, what a beer.  Flavor is strongly of pine and carmal-combined-with-citrus.  There is a pleasant smoky quality in the later palate that balances out the impossibe-to-hide booze.  Beautiful

2009 bomber, drank fresh. Pours a murky dark amber with a thin off-white head that lightly laces the glass. Nose of hops (tropical fruits, citrus, some pine), toffee and caramel malts, some brown sugar. Flavor is mildly sweet with strong resiny hop bitterness, some hints of tropical fruits, a bit of grapefruit and pine on the finish, some toffee. The hop bitterness helps cut the malty sweetness, medium carbonation.

22-oz bottle opened at local beer tasting (Underground Bluz). A beautiful brew. The only beer all night that everyone at the table liked: hopheads and malt lovers alike. Sweet and tasty up front with roasty malt flavor. A very nice hop finish. This beer can do some damage because you won¬ít want to stop drinking it!
All the goodness of bastard...just more of it.  Dark reddish pour, thin tan head...lots of citrus, malty sweetness, but nicley balanced by hop bitterness

Oh joy, I¬íve finally found the time to post!  My journal needs some online alleviation.  For my first post, we¬íll start with this exceptional brew.  When the 09 DB came to my favorite beer shop, I decided to buy an 08 vintage as well and do a side-by-side.  

The 08 poured mahogany with a light tan head into a snifter.  On the nose I smelled a rich barley wine (love that smell); toffee, malty, slight raisony wonder.  Taste mimicked the aroma.  Fantastic upfront taste of toffee with a slight lasting bitterness, a little odd, but not unwelcome raisin/pineapple taste detectable, fairly nice balance of sweet and bitter.  Finishes rather bitterly with some nice warming alcohol present at the back of the throat.  This brew warms exceptionally well; hop bitterness fades, replaced by more alcohol and toffee sweetness.  Marvelous finish.  

The 09 poured the same as the 08.  As can be expected, this did not live up to its predecessor.  More of a candied sugar aroma with a hoppy presence.  The taste holds with the aroma; more pure sweetness than rich toffee, more prevalent hops (probably due to the lack of sweetness with age compared to the 08).  This was more or less a weaker version of its predecessor.  Still damn fine, but I firmly believe this brew should be aged a while.  The 08 was astounding, I did my rating on that vintage.

22 oz Bottle -- Pours a rich cloudy amber with an off-white head.  Very complex and balanced.  Malts are strong providing caramel, dried fruits, and some roasted flavors on the back end.  Hops are there for sure bringing some citrus and pine.  A little salty and the alcohol is very present on the palate.  Flavors last long for a long finish.  It¬ís arrogant bastard turned up a notch with some more sweetness.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a  thin tan head. Served in the stone double bastard glass which was a nice touch. Aroma is citurs and pine hops with sweet malt. Alot going on here...hoppy with heavy malt, wood. Warming alcohol finish and more hops. A big beer to be savoured and enjoyed.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2011 Pours deep red with a lasting off-white head and some lacing.  aroma is woody hops with plum, raisins and spice. taste is very hoppy at first but the fruit characteristics soon take over and what started much like a barley takes on more of a Belgian strong dark ale character.  the finish is distinctly Stone in its brutal bitterness. a fine, formidable beer.

Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a clear brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness and notes of berries. The flavor is hops, roasted and berries. The palate is bitter. Overall a great beer.

2009 bomber. This one pours a dark reddish brown color topped by a large, foamy light tan colored head that slowly settles to a thin film. The aroma is very hop forward with grapefruit, citrus, and pine hop bitterness to go with a big dose of sweet caramel malt. The flavor follows suit with huge amounts of grapefruit and piney hops balanced out by the big and sweet caramel and toffee malt backbone. The bitterness is quite striking from all the hops. It is certainly one monster of a beer. Full bodied, thick, and a touch syrupy as it warms with ample carbonation and a lengthy bitter finish. There is touch of alcohol heat on the finish as well. This one packs quite a punch with all the flavor and hops. Good beer.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market in Columbus, OH. Dark amber color with a fluffy tan head. Wonderful aroma of hops, citrus, and more hops. Great caramelly, malty, fruity flavor with a thick mouthfeel. This beer is big and beautiful.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2011 Draft at Catskeller on the UC campus.  Pours a cloudy brown/orange/amber color with a small tan head.  Aroma of floral hops, citrus, caramel, alcohol, sweet malts, and a little grassy earthiness.  Flavor of sweet malt, alcohol, caramel, citrus, pineapple and tropical fruits, and wood.  Sweet and fruity early, but big notes of pine hops in the middle and bitter and alcoholic late.  The aftertaste is also bitter and alcoholic, and satisfyingly so.  Medium bodied.  Spicy, warm, bitter alcohol mouthfeel.  Excellent. Re-Rate, 5/3/11: We did a 2005-2009 vertical at The Royale in honor of Stone night. This beer is so consistent over time, moving from more hoppy, full-bodied, citrusy, and boozy to lighter in body and in color, sweeter, and maltier as it ages. I liked them all and people could blindly tell which one they were having because it¬ís so consistent. Very cool.

Appearance-great dark amber appearance with a wonderful head.
Aroma-very good. Slight alcohol smell with plenty of hops.
Flavor-Very complex taste with alcohol finish. Not for the weak.
Palate-Smooth. Leaves the bitter taste but not like Runination.
Overall-Good. I don¬ít know if I could drink this all nite. I think after one bomber, I would be done.
Overall a very good beer. I like the Ruination IPA better but this is good.

Presentation: 10.5% ABV from Bottle, ¬í09 Vintage. Clean red and white screen printing. 

Aroma: Very light aroma, but if you really sniff you can detect pine & alcohol.

Appearance: Murky copper/walnut with big bubbly light tan head if aggressively poured, otherwise none.

Flavor: Highly alcoholic with a big hop kick. Caramel and malty overtones and a solid yeasty spiciness too. 

Palate: Silky smooth, slightly syrupy. 

Overall: Gets better with every sip, by the time your done, you will probably be feeling it. 1.375 pounds of beer @ 10.5% has that effect.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2015 You bastards at Stone have done it again!  Wow!  I like Arrogant Bastard just fine, but this ale comes with a bit more punch.  Poured from a 22 0z bomber.  I¬ím really starting to like these American strong ales.

Initial rate 11.09 : Revisiting this thing after a few years.  Double Bastard still has it!  It as if the malt and hops are turned on the highest maximum setting available!  Double Bastard is a lesson in balance--even when things are turned up.  Not adjusting my score from initial.  Still excellent.  2009 / 2012 vintages sampled.

Another re-rate: 11.2.15 :  Sort of off on this vintage.  Little hot.  Still enjoyable at 11%.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2010 Dark but glowing red-amber pour with a thin off-white head.  Huge caramel malt aroma laced with fragrant hop notes.  Taste is thick with spicy hops, candied ginger, preserved citrus rind, all carried by a sweet malt-wave.   A moderately ¬íheavy¬í mouthfeel carries the bold flavors beautifully, and the hop onslaught cuts the sweetness for a nice, dry, bitter finish.
Well, this seemed a tad boozy to me. However, the more I drank the more a liked. This stuff is thick! 2009 version. at 10.5%
Light aroma but has elements of rich malts and slighted hops. Taste is dry hops and bitter flavors. Has some sweetness on the finish but mainly sits with bitter dryness.
On tap at the Flying Saucer Fort Worth.  Malt aroma and a little hops.  Sticky sweet taste with pine and hops.  Great mouthfeel and aftertaste.

This past week Stone Brewery released their tenth edition of the Double Bastard Ale, a doubled up version of their popular Arrogant Bastard Ale. I have loved the Arrogant Bastard for many years now and the Double Bastard is just that much better. It pours are golden copper color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly. The nose is kind of sweet with notes of caramael and cane sugar with a slight bit of citrus from the hops. At first taste the Double Bastard comes across well balanced between the sweetness of the malts and the bitterness of the hops, but as the beer lingers the hops really start to show through. I get flavors of caramel, dark chocolate, anise and citrus and since this beer is 10.5% ABV the flavors are intense and dominating.

Pint on tap with thortheviking after devils/islanders game. Pour is maroonish brown with slight suddy white head atop.  Sticky with plenty of piney and citrus hops, malts, and sweet dark fruits...then some more on top.  Palate is tingly and spicy.  Indications of alcohol but amazing well hidden, like a troll under a bridge.   Made my soar throat all feel better. Maybe the cure for swine flu

This is the best Ale of it¬ís type I¬íve had.  It boasts a dark amber color with a brownish white micro foam head.  The second you lift the glass to your mouth you smell the spicy citrus tones that also make the flavor of this brew so unique.  It also leaves a pleasant aftertaste on your palette.

pours out murky brownish amber in color with a slow forming off white tannish head that is some what bubbly.  the body is a deep mahogony some what brown amber.  the aromas are in your face and i am picking up merlot grapes, roasted malts, some sugar and alcohol.  there is also a decent amount of lacing forming in the glass.  the taste is very smooth and reminiscent of the original brew.  there is a strong comanding hoppiness all the way across the palate.  it is medium bodided and a very nice amount of carbonation that has good mouth feel.  and dare i say this, this brew in my opinion is a lot smoother then the original and enjoyable.  i could drink this all night.  also,  the aftertaste is very strong and unforgiving and alcohol is very prevelent on the tongue and i feel it burn as it goes down.  a really nice beer from the masters of stone brew.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a reddish brown with a white head. Nutty nose with aromas of caramel, plum, brown sugar, chocolate. Flavours of figs, malts, dark fruits, raisins. Finishes malty and hoppy with a warming alcohol feel.
Bottle.  This beer pours a nice dark, rich color.  I enjoyed drinking this beer and I will definately drink this one again.

2003 Vintage:
After 6 years, the super-hoppy nature of this beast has taken a backseat to the brown sugar and dark fruit.  That doesn¬ít mean that it has lost any of its quality.  Pours a deep red, almost black, with a thin lasting head.  The aroma is brown sugar, banana bread, and booze with a hint of hops.  The flavor is very complex, including chocolate, maple syrup, dark fruit, etc.  The hops serve to give it a nice dry finish, and complement the beginning.  The alcohol is there, but not overpowering.  This one was worth the wait.

2007 Double Bastard
Dark Red hue when poured in to a Dogfish head Snifter.
Hoppy with some heavy malt character. it lives up to its name.
Dak copper with a lasting off-white head. Sweet malty aroma with fruit and caramel and plenty alcohol. Sticky sweet malty flavour with lots of citrus hop and bitterness, and again, plenty alcohol
Bottle. Trade with Baggio. Pours cloudy amber/reddish with a small creamy head. Nose and taste is sweet and matured. Dark fruits, alcohol and hops. Vinous , smooth and hoppy. Lovely.

Bottle.  Pours a murky hazy brown with a large taupe colored head.  Big pineapple and wet pine, malt, plum, and caramel.  Creamy, medium bordering on thick bodied, big malt and caramel.  Finishes with a touch of alcohol, some slowly developing grapefruit bitterness and a little bit of prune.

Bottle. Light brown in colour with off white head. Rich aroma of hops, malt with some chocolate character too. Quite a complex beer, deep and rich flavours, with lots of malt fruitines and quite a bitter finish. There is alcoholic warmth but its not over powering. This is not a beer for the faint hearted or those that consider Crown Lager a "good"beer. Definately a beer for the beer geeks among us, thank god for Stone!

22-oz bottle Ò¢âó) - Aroma: alcoholic, raisin or dried fruit (malt or esters) , and caramel (malt) Appearance: cloudy brown, tan head; Flavor: very complex of low to mod sweet and salty, high bitter and floral (hops), caramel (malt) and raisin (malt or esters), alcoholic; Mouthfeel: full (heavy) bodied, mod carbonation, alcoholic warmth; Overall: complex beer with a well balance of malt, bitter, and alcohol (wish I had a keg of this instead of 22 oz).

Dark brown, beige head.  Aroma has a bit of hops, swedish fish, and alcohol.  Decent bitterness, a lot of sweetness, brown sugar, caramel and alcohol.  Dryness picks up toward the finish.  Not too sticky for the full body, but there¬ís a fumy alcohol that I don¬ít like.

Bottle. Pours deep, deep brown, nearly black, with a beautiful, creamy tan head. Aroma of bitter coffee, hints of chocolate, malts, and a bit of hops. Body is solid with a sturdy, crisp finish. Outrageous, epic brew. Truly epic.
YUM - had the 2006 in 2009!  Big Beer - this one will set the palate for a while.  Stays with you.  very good.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 this is a great beer if your a dry mouth hop head which I am not brown in color with an off white head aromas of hops and caramel taste is almost unbearable with very bitter, astringent, long finish, thank god I shared this beer on labor day with neighbors there was no way I could drink all of this or would want to

Bottle form 07. Pours a nice dark brown color with just a little bit of a off white head. Has a grain smell to it. Has a caramel flavor with a some hoppy bitterness to it. Possibly a little chocolate on the finish there as well.
Dark redish brown with a small off-white head. Malty and some fruity notes. Malt, hops and fruit. Full body with a balanced bittersweet finish.

A beautiful cloudy dark cherry red. The head dies down quickly. The rose color seems to glow from within.

The smell is sweet-but-dark cherry and grainy barley. Just this side of a barley wine aroma. A very mild citrus/floral hop.

The taste is deep, roasted-yet-sweet malts. Cocoa and cherry cordials. Liqueur like a dark brandy. The hop is mild and flowery by comparison. Malts are deep, rich and bittersweet. Dark and rich. As it warms, bitter hops really push through.

A chewy, thick feel; lingers on the tongue. This baby is a sipper; might as well be a barleywine. A real thick choker.

22 oz. bottle. Vintage 2008. 10.5% ABV. Pours a thick long lasting off white head with extensive lacing, over a very slightly cloudy reddish amber (SRM 17) body.....nose has brown sugar, toffee, citrus (grapefruit primarily), resin, alcohol.....taste initially toffee,caramel, honey, then balancing heavy lasting, hop bitterness swings in, with grapefruit tones......mouth feel is thick and chewy, with carbonation adding a lovely creamy texture. When I got the  first bit of the nose it was reminscent of a Barley Wine, the taste is not that of a Barley. I would prefer a more complex hop profile, than what came through in this bottle.

A dark red to brown beer with little head. Aroma is strong with sweet, alcohol, & hoppy. Taste is sweet, hoppy, & a strong alcohol presence with port like qualities. Can get you drunk & is not for the weak.

2008 Release. Reddish nbrown pour with a light tan head. Nice malt aroma.Great tasting brew. Malty, semi-sweet. Alcohol is present but it is not overbearing. Well-balanced beer. Another great beer from Stone that I am glad to have met.

22oz bomber obtained at the liquor shop in Tyngsborro, Mass. Pours a brilliant translucent dark red with a persistent inch of off-white head. Grassy and citrussy hops dominate the aroma, though the aroma could be stronger. Caramel toffee malt and citrussy American hops share the flavor, and both have strong presences, with some grassy and minty character also showing from the hops. Creamy smooth mouth feel with ample but not overpowering carbonation that helps to clear the palat for the next sip, adding to the drinkability. Fairly drinkable considering the abv and flavors. A solid ASA and for a buck more than Arrogant Bastard, you really can¬ít go wrong.

Pours cloudy brown with contrasting white head that doesn¬ít retain too long.

Nose has brown sugar, miscellaneous candy, black tea, and dry brown paper bag smells.

On the palate is a strong malt presence that is syrupy and reminds me of caramel or other similar chewy candies, but the hops and alcohol kick in to balance it out. Overall it is a big, chewy, savory beer that is surprisingly easy to drink.

Well, well, well. I just bought a selection of Stone Beers and it would be an understatement to say I was highly anticipating the new experiences I was about to have. I had to dive straight in at the Double Bastard, as it was the original Arrogant Bastard that blew me away in the first place. Appearance is just lovely. Copper, amber glow, rust, and at times just red in appearance, with an off-white/tan head that has rapidly shrunk, lazy carbonation just about struggles to the surface. The aroma is very inviting, mellow but definite hops, good soft malt with abundant fruitiness backed up with ripe strawberries, an aroma similar to damp or wet concrete, orange zest and assorted citrus notes and caramel. Well the flavour is intense but remains balanced, both the alcohol and hops get you at the back of the throat rather than clogging up your palate. There¬ís something almost wine like about the beer, not vinous but it reminds me of the beer equivalent of a big Ozzy Shiraz, thick, dense and complex. The malts ooze over your tongue hiding inside a deceptive bitterness that unleashes itself at the last moment with an almost earthy feel to it. The hops are floral, perfumed and very tasty, there is an acridness to them but not a soapiness, and the acrid nature is not too full on as its contained deep within a coating of thick semi-sweet caramel malt.
