The flavour is so big I¬ím almost at a loss to pick it apart, I almost don¬ít even want too. It¬ís like an experience, you have to try it to really understand it. The beer itself is somewhere between a barley wine and a double IPA, although leans more to the latter. I¬ím going to shut up now because I don¬ít think I have the vocabulary or even desire to capture this beast, it¬ís like meeting a wild Lion, you just have to be thankful you walked away intact, you wouldn¬ít want to cage such a beautiful monster, allow it to be wild, untamed try not to pin it down too much or the magic is lost. Just one thing though, the palate is to die for, it¬ís like thick velvet caressing and coating your tongue and warming your throat. The only draw back is the slightly untamed alcohol which does ride quite high in the mix, but as the bottle warns: only fools dare, so I can¬ít complain. Stone are truly Demons among men, and I¬ím beginning to love them for it.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2014 I smell lots hops in there yummy and a touch of maltsPours a dark coppery red with a huge fluffy beige headThe taste is not as enticing as the aroma would lead you to believe the alcohol shows through too much fairly good hop taste

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2009 Source: Bomber from KnB

Glass: Bordeaux wine glass

Aroma: Powerful, huge caramel mixed with american hops.

Appearance: Amber and murky

Flavor: Sharp. Tons of caramel malt flavor with sharp bitterness. Really enjoyable.

Palate: Smooth mouthfeel, with a long finish.

Overall: I like Stone

2006 vintage: Sweet and still delicious

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2009 Bomber into a snfiter.  Aroma is hoppy with a touch of pee. Flavor is sweet and ends with a combo of hop and roasty bitterness.7 4 7 8 14
Just had a vintage 2007 sample at brewfest Tallahassee.  Still some nice citrus and a bit of hop on it, and I really enjoyed it - much better than I remembered my old rating.
8 4 9 4 16

22oz 2008 bottle enjoyed 8.5.09.  Pours a clear medium-dark red with a nice dense fine frothy light tan/orange head.  Aroma of American Barley Wine, dry pine, earthy, bitter, warming alcohol, richly oxidized caramel, a touch plasticy.  Of course flavor is quite assertive at first, mellowed just a tad by age, odd play of dark bitterness, almost ashy/burnt against the sticky caramel, reminds slightly of Central Waters Y2K ale, dry bitter pine, earthy, some hot alcohol, plastic dullness, light fruit, definitely a Stone beer, has several similarities to Old Guardian.  Some lighter notes of cotton candy, dough and brown sugar as well.  Medium bodied, nice viscosity without being sticky or syrupy, soft smooth ubiquitous fizzy carbonation.  Much better as it warms, definitely a BW now. [Huge thanks to drewbeerme for sharing 02 - 08 bottles with me in a sickening vertical tasting... still gathering my notes from that though.  If I remember right I liked the older bottles the best]

Stone Brewing is one of the newer highly anticipated California breweries that are now available in Florida. By the time she made to my shelves late last year though, I had already missed out on most of her special seasonal releases, the Double Bastard 2008 release being one of those. Thankfully, the folks were on a trip and stopped in a liquor store to pick me up some goodies, beer and sake, and the clerk hooked them, and thusly me, up with some nice rare beers and sake.


Burnt amber and garnet with a hazy brown murkiness which adds a mysterious aura. Not much of a head to speak of while she sports a thin collar that also threatens to fade into oblivion. Her head may have been nothing to write home about, but let me tell you about her nose. Grass, lots of grass, flowers, green leaves and sticky hop oils lead into more green hops in their whole entirety, picked fresh from the vine as their presence permeates the air around them. Sweet grass mowed with fresh morning dew finishes with a dry punch of dry hay and crunchy honeycomb. No, not the cereal, real honeycomb dripping with the fruit of hundreds of hard-working bees. Obviously the head knew better then to get in the way of this Mack-truck of a nose barreling its way to wherever it durn well pleases. Like a beer geek frozen in its headlights, I throw caution to the wind and dive right into her path. What¬ís a little danger, right? Dry and herbal, like a gourmet rub to tempt and taunt and seduce my tastebuds. Green leaves, hops and grass scrub also center on top of my tongue for a tasty palate cleansing experience. Her dryness is balanced by a sweetness slowly swells in the background thick with honey, honeycomb, and burnt sugars. Hop oils continue to coat while further fields of grass and hay dry at the same time. I always enjoy the playful interplay of dry and wet at the same time; it only serves to quench one¬ís thirst while adding to it at the same time. It¬ís no wonder then that my glass is quickly diminishing in volume; thankfully Double Bastard comes in large 22oz bomber bottle. A pleasant warmth slowly starts to blossom in my chest before spreading throughout my body, a testament to her higher ABV which also adds a nip of spice at the back of each quaff. Mmm. From start to finish, a big hoppy, grassy, sweet and yet dry, woodsy and warm brew that I look forward to quaffing this year, also.


What can I say about Stone Brewing that I haven¬ít already said and probably will say again later. Great brewery, great beers, and they make no apologies for being big, bad, and doing exactly what they want. If you don¬ít like their beers, tough. They aren¬ít brewing it just for you, but for those who will enjoy them, especially the folks at Stone Brewing. After all, don¬ít we all want to brew what we would like to drink?

Poured from a 1 Pt. 6oz. bottle. into my Guinness pint glass.

The color is a dark orange/red and a little amber and gold at the same time. Not clear but cloudy with a thick off-white head.

The smell is very hoppy. Is a bit floral and a bit sweet with malt but also has a bastard of a smell that I can not place. It is the signature smell of the Arrogant Bastard brew.

The taste is strong, it is at first sip a little citrusy, has a great hanging aftertaste that is reminding me that this is a true to form craft beer. Is very creamy and is a bit flavorful than the orignal bastard.

This beer has a nice finish. It has a nice bite but is not overwhelming in it¬ís texture. It is just right is it¬ís combination and is very mush the brew worth the wait..

Poured deep red with a medium head.  Great hops smell and carmelly malts.  Taste was very smooth, rich and balance with carmel and brown sugary sweet notes. Just as good as the Arrogant Bastard, but with more punch. GREAT BEER!

Hazy, red/brown, yellow firm head, good lace. Very sweet, very very bitter, grassy, fruity, floral, heavy flavours. Sticky, warming finish. Very flavourful, powerful, complex yet not over the edge. Nice stuff.
Noogfest High 5. Sample from a bottle thanks to brentfeesh.  2008 Vintage.  Dark red, thin off white head.  Aroma is caramel, big berry fruits.  Taste is alcohol, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, fruit.

Bottle, 65cl - Hazy red amber beer with a fine head. Aroma is very malty with hints of cranberries, dried fruit and red berries. Flavor is very sweet with hints of roasted malts, caramel, ripe fruits and spices. Very full bodied beer and beautifully balanced.

Bomber. Small head of off-white, a little boozy, doesn¬ít hide it¬ís alcohol well. Overall a beautiful looking beer, with explosive flavor, that really packs a punch... better than its little brother arrogant bastard ale. anther great beer from Stone who never produces anything but exceptional beer!

2008 batch. Deep brown color; silky, dark tan head that disappears fairly quickly but can be brought back briefly with some swirling. Aroma caramel, orange and lemon, raisin, and some piney hops; note of alcohol evaporation. Big flavor: Caramel sweetness and heavy, lingering hops; some peppery spice; dark fruit; some alcohol but doesn¬ít taste nearly 10%. Really nice mouthfeel; smooth and silky; moderate stickiness on the lips. Maybe a tiny bit overrated, but very good.

(on tap at Trinity in Colorado Springs). Pours a cloudy amber color. Medium off white head which is lasting. Strong hop aroma.  Strong spicy hop flavor with alcohol and light bitterness. Long duration. Oily texture. Fair lacing. Moderate carbonation.

Bottle, Amazing beer! Pours ruby red with minimal head. Nice hoppy notes, sweet caramel, with some mild citrus. If you could match the nose of the arrogant with the taste of the double you would have a wicked brew!
Pours hazy ruby brown with a foamy tan head. Ripe fruit, alcohol, anise, pine, and citrus aroma. Bitter pine and molasses taste with some roast. A kick right in the face.

Very strong and complex. Pours a reddish brown with small ring of head. Mostly hop aroma. Tastes syrupy, malty and sweet. Notes of caramel, toffee. Hop flavors come out towards the end. Dry, slightly bitter finish. The best I¬íve had from Stone
Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a nice white head. Nice caramel and hop aroma. Boozy taste with a hop bite. Wicked good. It¬ís a perfect double.

Very strong hops flavor and bitterness with some malt.  Pours a dark copper color with white head, and the aroma is very hoppy like that of a double ipa.  This is a great beer if you like very hoppy and bitter brews.

Strong  caramel aroma, hops a little skunk. Amber colour with a good frothy white head. Syrup like texture. Tangy bitter hop flavour. Sharp and cuts right to the palette. Grapefruit lingering around afterwards. Very tasty ale. Should have looked at the ABV. Wondered why I woke up with a wee hangover.
Now this is beer!  Great looking and tasting beer.  Deep flavors and a richness that is hard to find in a beer this strong.

2007, 22 oz bomber. Pours a clear, dark orange-brown colour with a cream coloured, frothy but quickly disappearing head. When I say quickly disappearing, I mean quick!! I turned my head for a minute and it was gone when I turned back around. Aroma of pine, malts, citrus, grapefruit, nuts, hops, caramel and alcohol. I started to smell the aroma before the cap was completely off. Flavour is the same as the aroma with a tangy sort of aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 Pours a lovely dark brown with a small tan head that lingers. Aromas of alcohol, raisin, caramel and malt. Strong anise flavors. Very bitter. Burnt toffee and caramel. Medium body. Soft carbonation. I think I prefer regular bastard better.

[2136-20090509] 1pt6floz bottle. Sweet malty syrup aroma has very heavy syrup hops. Clear, dark red amber body with a quick foamy light tan head. Super boozy heavy malty hops flavour. Medium-full body. Big beer, big booze.
(Vintage 2008)

Bottle 650ml. @ home.Clear medium orange amber color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, dark berry, moderate hoppy, orange. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. [20090206]
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2015 Bottle. I believe this is much better than the "normal" bastard. Smoother and even has a higher alcohol content. What big beers should be.

Amber colored beer with white head.  Strong hoppy flavor that is well balanced with the overall malt.  The alcohol flavor is a bit strong at first but tapers away.  It is a great beer and I think I prefer it to regular Arrogant Bastard.  I just couldn¬ít drink it every day at 10%.  I look forward to Double AB every year!!

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2009 Pours a amber-orange color with a thick tan head.  Aroma of grapefuruit, pine, and carmel malts.  flavor is similar with grapefuit, pine, carmel, bourbon, but also has some other fruit flavors.  mouthfeel is heavy with a slight but not overpowering alchool note.  overall, a very complex and tasty Strong Ale.

Yuck! I had high expectations for this one, given it¬ís rating and reputation. It pours into the glass llike syrup. Very unattractive. Very low carbonation. Taste is excessively sweet, like cotton candy. Not enough hop balance. This doesn¬ít taste at all like beer. Will not be buying this one again... highly overrated!

Bomber.  Pours an amber body with an off white head.  Chewy hoppiness with a nice grass y feel to it.  Moderate malt and fruity etoh warming with sugar sweetness.  Then my notes says F.Drunk.  Great beer. A big beer for big bellies.

Pours an orangish brown with thick tan head and a lot of lacing.  Aroma of hops, pine, and grass.  Flavor is similar, but it¬ís almost as if they just threw tons of ingredients in without a lot of attention paid to if they actually make sense in the proportion.  It gets easier to drink as it warms, but I am just not impressed.

22 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet, 2008 release.  Pours a thick, brownish-orange color with a very thin off-white head.  Aroma of peach, apricot, wet grass, and pineapple.  Tastes of grapefruit, caramel, apricot, and apple.  Extremely complex.  Moderate alcohol burn but not nearly as easy to detect as when this was fresh or especially on tap.  Another excellent offering from Stone.

Bomber purchased at The Keg and poured in glass. Aroma is of hops, pine, grapefruit, with a hint of sweet molasses. flavor is very similar with a slight alcohol bite at the end. Still the beer is smooth and very drinkable. The large flavor of hops makes it taste a lot like an Imperial IPA but it contains some unique attributes. Great beer.
2008 Release. Poured cloudy brown. Thin head. Pine and grapefruit aroma. Very thick and sweet with soem malt and caramel notes. Hoppy bitterness as it warms.

Pours dark brown with a ruby tint when held to light. Faint off whit to brown head that disappeared quickly. NIce carmel smell with mild cirtus raisins pine and hop aroma. Flavor had chocolate , molasses hop flavor , light cherry , and some vanilla flavors

Pours a nice mahogany with a light tan head that leaves a perfect lacing down the glass.
Smells of badusy and awesomeness.
jesus mary mother of god this is fantastic. far better than expected. Far better balanced than I expected. Hops are in the background and keeping this from being too sweet.
Alcohol is far more hidden than expected.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 Bottle shared at Butter¬ís Big Cellar Blowout.  Semi-hazy reddish pour with good white head.  Muted citrus hop aroma, with malt sweetness. Tons of malt and caramel, bourbon, and earthy hop note Moderate alcohol warming on the back  Awesome label.  Just overated imo.

Also tasted a ¬í03 to ¬í08 vertical at Noogfest High Five.  ¬í03 was my favorite vintage and is holding up nicely.
Butters Big Blowout - Pours a dark amber with white head. Fruity, malt, hops and alcohol present in the aroma. Smells like a barley wine. Same in taste, burnt finish. Nice stout.

Bottle at Butters Big Cellar Blowout.  2008 bottle.  Pours a beige head with lace and a copper amber body.  Smells of fresh hops, malt, and brown sugar.  Tastes the same.  Candi sugar, roasted malt, and hop finish.
2007 bottle from mspindler. Very good sweet taste with caramel smell. Good hoppy taste. A little bitterness at the end with taste of alcohol.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009 Pours a hazy brown/orange color with a thick dense cream head.  Smells of sweet citrus and caramel.  The hops are very strong, giving tastes of citrus fruits like orange and grapefruit.  Medium body with lively carbonation.  Finishes bitter and lingers.  A little astringent.

Inviting sweet aroma.  Very thirst quenching, caramel and sweet malt.  Hops not in the forefront, with a slightly bitter finish. Sessionable, but with that ABV (that you don¬ít taste!) it would slow you down :)
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2009 Inviting sweet (slightly citrus?) aroma. Finish seems hoppier, more bitter than Arrogant Bastard. Great carbonation in the bottle I got. Definitely hugely alcoholic.
The nose is very soft and elegant,vanilla,and mild tamarind. It pours a dark hazy copper with a nice head. Taste is Mild vanilla,caramel,great body and very mild hops.06 vintage very nice!
Flaske, drukket sammen med klubben. Uklar r√¶ver√∏d, stort set intet skum. Dufter og smager af m√∏rke t√∏rrede frugter, karameller, noget gran og godt med humle.

Bottle  Pours a murky brown with a decent tan head.  The head is creamy, lasting and seems to lace well.  Has an aroma of malts mixed with hops and some straw.  It is a total mix depending which hits you first.  Wow this has a lot of flavors hitting you.  It sweet, but yet that changes to tangy and hoppy within a second.  Has its own presence about itself.  Has light carbination, good mouthfeel.  Has a strong finish.  Has a heavy body.  The textureis thick like you could eat it with a spoon.  A solid kick butt beer.
Bottle...  Poured amber with an off-white head.  Herbal aroma.  Thick, creamy palate with tangy fruits, a little bit of hops, and a big malty finish.
Sampled at Blind Tiger Very Special Keg Night 11/19/08: Ruby-red color. Strong on both the malt and hops front; a great beer kicked into overdrive. Well balanced.

A bronze-hued brew. Off the nose, rich maltiness, belgianesqe sweetness, and a depth that can only be attributed to the copious amount of alcohol. Wow. A strong punch of woody barrel flavors and heavy-handed maltiness with a slight bitterness toward the end. Hits your gut with a ¬íthunk.¬í Hits your brain shortly thereafter. It¬ís certainly not a casual sipper or a grab and go but its got a lot of character, and I¬íll give it due credit for that.

I had this after having an Arrogant Bastard and I was shocked to find that I liked the Double Bastard a bit more. It has a cloudy appearance where as the Arrogant Bastard does not. It¬ís a bit sweeter and has less of a hoppy bite. It goes down smoother. The inexperienced beer drinker will be more likely to dig this beer than Arrogant Bastard.

The bigger brother of the Arrogant Bastard and more intense in every way except for harshness. It is actually smoother than the regular one, but that alcohol rating will sneak up on you. Great beer that really shows the talent of Stone Brewing Co.

22oz bottle. Pours a clear, but dark ruby-brown body with a off-white to beige head that leaves more of a swirly surface than the Bastard and thicker lacing on the glass. The body is more red than the Bastard. Aroma is chewier than the Bastard. Thicker and sweeter berry malts. Almost like a barley wine, actually. Much bigger than the Bastard maltwise. Lots of sweet caramels. The hops are just as in your face as the Bastard, but these seem brighter. Much more noticeable citrus and definitely not as earthy. The booze is noticeable, but blends more with the hops rather than berries. The flavor is much more aligned with my tastes. Big! Lots of malts, lots of hops, and a warming booze. Starts with a sweet, but somewhat earthy bitterness and licorice malt taste. The bitterness quickly grows in the middle, but never becomes quite as earthy or dirty as the Bastard. Despite that, the hops remain ample. Stays more along the lines of a heavily hopped barley wine. An intense sugary citrus hoppiness. The malts grow and the caramel becomes fuller. Some dried fruits, raisin, grainy rye, and booze come in before the finish. The finish is a mix between barley wine and strong ale...but mega-hoppy. Sweet, but bitter and stong/bold, but fruity. Dryer than the Bastard. Flavor doesn¬ít linger obsessively like the Bastard, but definitely sticks around for awhile. Slightly earthy, but more of a piney hop linger. Not quite sharp, but on the edge. Sugary sweet maltiness, but not as resiny as a barley wine. Overall, I guess what I¬ím trying to say is that the hops are intense, but there is a lot more going on besides the hops in this one. Much better balance IMO than the Bastard. I can¬ít help but think this is a mix between a typical barley wine and strong ale. Really nice stuff right here!

Bottle. Dark brown with small whitish head. Intense taste of malt and raisin. Strong on alcohol but not too much. The bottle is maybe a bit too large though.  Low on bitterness. maybe a bit one dimensional since it focus on malt.. When it gets warm it is slightly too much alcohol.
tons of malt and hops. just as arrogant as its little brother but just more arrogance to spread!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2009 I have had this on tap before, but this one was bottled.  The aroma is strong with roasted malt and hops notes of darkfruit and yeast dance around in the aroma.  The flavor is the same, but the hops really stand out in the finish leaving a nice alcohol burn in the back of the throat.

2007 bottle consumed earlier this week. Maybe I¬ím losing my edge, but this beer was definitely not designed to be drinkable for atleast a few years. The point of this beer seems to be a beverage that just destroys your tastebuds. Tons of malt and hops....wildly out of balance. Plenty of alcohol and bitterness. Dark fruit, alcohol and hop flavor/bitterness DOMINATE the palate. Needs way more than 2 years to mellow.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2009 One of my favourites. Always work for me. It¬ís pretty damn huge with allot of everything yet very well balanced. Lovely malt profile and a perfect amount of hop-bitterness balancing it out. The taste is full of nutty, nougat character.
Just like the regular, but more - and better - one of the better balanced big beers that I¬íve had the pleasure to try, lots of hops, lots of maltiness, supremely well-blended, and just wonderful.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2013 bottle.   pleasant tropical fruit hops.  tangerines.   some grapefruit.  backed by a toasted nut and caramel malt backing.  not too bad.

Heavenly malt,  sweet,  light hop aroma. Pours a deep cloudy amber with a 1 inch off-white head. Flavor is perfectly balanced sweet smooth mild caramel citrus hop, medium heavy malt and spring fresh mineral. Starts out incredibly smooth, then turns to a slow burn several seconds later. Mouthfeel is pure bliss. 
Aromatic and tasty smooth hops. This is the king of winter warmers. Thank God its 50 degrees today in Texas. Lacing is something to be jealous of. Enjoyment factor is high. To be used in only the highest quality company of friends.

So happy I finally picked one of these up.  After a string of so so Ales, this one really pops.  Great aroma of sharp citrus hops and sweet candied fruit.  Burst of flavor that  matches the aroma well with a good, paste your tongue to the back of your throat citrus bite that I like so  much.

Poured from a 22-oz bomber into a snifter. Appearance was a dark amber color with an off-white head. Nice lacing on the glass as the beer went down. Spicy hops and candi sugars are on the aroma. This has a creamy mouthfeel as it leads to the taste of caramel malts with a finish of peppery, spicy hops on the finish. I felt this was much better than the Arrogant Bastard Ale.
Had this many times, last from giant bottle at Tiger. Always good, rich and smooth with wonderful hops and malts. Caramel and molasses sweetness. Alcohol well hidden, I bet would age great.

D√©gust√© avec Agaguk et Pyrozoid.  Apparence orange fonc√© nuageux avec une belle grosse mousse beige tres collante.  Aromes de caramel, butterscotch, nougat, dates, prunes, cassonade, zest d¬íorange et pamplemousse.  Incroyable amertume crisp√© et piquante au d√©but finition sec et cr√©meuse.  Quel experience au niveau du palait!  Super belle rondeur en bouche, parfaite √©quilibre.  Gout de cuire, caramel, malt√© et bien houblonn√©!  Superbe experience sensorielle!

Bouteille de 600 ml. D√©gust√© avec french tickler et Agaguk. Bi√®re de couleur rouge caramel brumeux avec un bon collet collant. Ar√¥me de sucre brun, vanille, un peu d¬íalcool, semblant de l√©gume, senteur tr√®s fraiche. Saveur de sucre, un peu d¬íalcool, pamplemousse, citron et √©pices.
Poured dark amber with a fluffy white head. Aroma of citrus and sweet caramel. Alot going on in this. Lots of everything... malt, hop, and some citrus. Good stuff.

had on tap @ The Flying Saucer in Houston the day theWick and I watched the Man Utd victory over the spurs in the Carling Cup ... lots of sweet malty aroma .. honey molasses, syrup things like that .. fantastic lacing .. good foam head .. good abv, not lots of heat ... a classic, worth the praise ...  happy i trekked around and found this ...

Shared by afire-thanks Waylo. I continue to enjoy the beers from Stone and this Strong Ale was another well done experience.  Cloudy and mead looking copper pour with simmered beige head.  Toasty and malty with a blend of aromatic hops.  Caramel and roasted smooth quality with the alc mixed in making this a strong and bold flavorful body.  Good stuff and will buy and cellar some for future feasting.  Cant wait to savor again!
tasting at lake las vegas..reddish pour..very strong drink..not easy to drink but an interesting beer..but like most say the 10abv you cant even feel..

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 On draft at Teresa¬ís.  Poured ruby in a tulip glass.  Rings of lacing.  Spicy, citrus bomb.  No alcohol noticeable (beer menu at Teresa¬ís had said only 7.5% ABV).  Very smooth and dangerously sessionable regardless of the alcohol content.

On tap at Flying Saucer Austin. Glad they were able to get this one in. Amber or almost ruby in color, with a foamy off-white head. Astringent, sharp, bitey and citrusy bitterness in an almost harsh way, but yet it¬ís an excellent flavor. None of the 10% ABV shows up, either. It¬ís lots and lots of hops, but maintains some balance and ends up a lovely beer.

Bomber. Pours ruby with a moderate tan head. Aroma of grapefruit hops, alcohol, caramel malt, wood, and some fruit. Flavor is a strong combination of similar elements, with lots of hops and malts, heavy on the grapefruit and toffee. Both the hops and malts contribute to a thick, syrupy/resiny character, and there¬ís quite a bit of alcohol present too. It all pulls it off surprisingly well, though; something like this could very easily have turned into a rough mess.
This is a very, very good brew!  Excellent aroma and flavor!  Pours a nice amber color with a whitish head.  Al lot smoother than I was expecting.  A definite must try!

Overall Impression: 
Amazing beer, absolutely top notch blending of flavors, hops alcohol, etc.  I haven¬ít had this one in a few months, but I like this one a ton.


**I will need to re visit this ranking in the future, as I don¬ít remember all the intricacies of this beer well enough to record them at this time.
Best beer, incredible for the ABV is is the smoothest thing you¬íll ever taste

Bottle from Utobeer. Deep amber/red with an off white head. Pungent aroma of quality ingredients and alcohol. Rich sweet malty base perfectly balanced by intense rounded oily resinous hops. Not cloying considering it¬ís strength. A truely delicious sipping beer from a brewer that I worship.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a beige head. Caramel, toffee, frutiness, grape, spicy hops, nuts, pine, alcohol. Full bodied.

10.5% nose of some pine but overwhelming malt stickiness, plenty of toffee. no alcohol detected. appearance is clouded rust that gives way to opaque rust. flavor is huge malt sweetness, none of the crunchy nuance found in the nose. some hops but huge bitterness seems to be more attributable to fusel like alchol that burns even the nose like ammonia. palate is somewhat dry, when actual flavors are gone the sour bitterness hangs like acid.  while arrogant bastard is one of the most well balanced beers ever and hugely enjoyable, this is just overkill. far from undrinkable, i think its execution was as planned but i dont see that this is that enjoyable, just intended to be ¬ílacerative¬í per its description, but i dont know that that is at all positive.

Pours a cloudy ice tea like color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt, some bitter hops, and a little bit of alcohol.  Taste is strong.  Sweet malts, spice, alcohol that lingers in the aftertaste, but not unpleasantly.  Interesting, strong definitive beer.  You need to be ready to drink this one.

2008 bomber in a pint glass. Pours with a one-finger off-white head that sticks to the upper third of the glass. The aroma is all hops - piney and floral with a juicy grapefruit bitterness. The sweetness of the caramel malt doesn¬ít show its presence until you taste the beer, providing a nice balance to the strong bitterness of the hops. The mouthfeel is sticky, like light syrup. Be careful - the alcohol sneaks up on you quickly - it started going to my head only half-way through the first glass. This is an excellent beer - highly recommended.

From a 22oz bottle this Ale pours a ruby amber with a very nice, thick tan head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma jumps right out of the glass at you - citrus hops and sweet malts with lots of spice and alcohol.  This big beer comes right after you on the first sip with the malts, bitter hops and spiciness - but the alcohol is never overwhelming.  I was actually surprised how different this beer came across than the Arrogant Bastard.  This is a fantastic beer that I would certainly drink again (and again).

On tap at Flying Saucer. Has a cloudy copper golden color with a large frothy light tan head that lasts awhile. Good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sweet pine hops and citrus. The taste is a sweet caramel not as hoppy as i was expecting, alchol is present but not too overbearing. A very well done American strong ale from Stone.

Pours a deep brown in the glass with a tan head.  Smells sweet with a huge piney hop aroma in the glass.  The taste is not much different from the AB, but has a bit more alcohol burn and hop bitterness.

deep reddish-brown in color with a beautiful creamy beige head that leaves sticky sheets of lace in the glass. Strong hoppy aromas of grapefruit and candy, citrus, bready and fruity flavors kind of like pineapple cake. Full bodied with a thick almost syrupy mouthfeel, alcohol is very well hidden
Unassuming pour, weak ipa scent, but tasty, closer to a hop centric barleywine but not a dipa.
Wow.  I expected this to be super malty and bitter, but I was wrong.  This beer is well balanced, with a nice mouth-feel and gentle after taste.  I got this at Woodland Wine Merchant in Nashville.

Pours a nice dark orange with a big off white head.  Aroma is big pine hops and some nice sweet malt.  Flavor is more of the same, but a really nice balance of the two.  The malt sweetness is really well balanced with the hops bitterness.  A lot less assertive than some of their beers, but that¬ís not necessarily a bad thing.  Nice beer.

22 oz bomber (2008 release) purchased from Frugal MacDoogal¬ís in Nashville.  Poured a beautiful, clear amber/orange color with a half finger of off white head.  The aroma has significant notes of caramel malt, citrus and floral hops and some fruit notes.  The flavor was amazing.  A very solid caramel malt base, with a earthy/citrus bitter finish.  The alcohol shows up in the finish as well, and gives a nice warming sensation.  I absolutely love this beer.
goddamn a great beer, in fact the most balanced and best tasting beer i have ever had in my life

Cloudy, copper appearance with an average size beige head and good lacing.  Full on citrus hop aroma with some caramel malts and ripe fruit in the background.  Surprized by the balance.  Was expecting a super aggressive, hop dominated taste, but there was a good malt backdrop to help showcase the the hoppiness.  High abv shows up quickly and makes me glad I drank this at home.  Full bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel.  The finish lasts forever (poetically speaking).  Well crafted and worth the high ratings.

22 oz. bottle - Poured reddish brown color like a dark iced tea. with medium head that faded quick.
Aroma - caramel malt, alcohol and plums.
Flavor - rich creamy toasted caramel malt with nice hop taste on lips. Tastes like original with small alcohol burn in throat.
Palate - heavy mouthfeel with average carbonation. Spicey on tongue with definite alcohol taste in finish. Reminds me of drinking a Captain Morgan rum with coke, has similar aftertaste.
Overall - Another great beer from Stone, same taste as Arrogant Bastard with more kick! Prefer original just a bit.

650 mL bottle.  Auburn, with a thin head.  Powerful aroma, largely dominated by hops and alcohol, with a little malt underneath.  Flavour is much the same, with the addition of pineapple and toffee.  Nice, biting finish.  Very full.  Brilliant.

Copper colour, cloudy, small tan head, creates a lid, lacing. Aroma is sweet, dark fruit, honey, jam, almost vinous, noticable ABV, reminiscant of belgian quadrupels. Flavour is more hoppy than the aroma indicated, dark fruit, spices, hops. Mouthfeel is lively but quite smooth. Very complex but yet easy to drink. My second beer from Stone and they impress me again!

Serving type: bottle

2007 Release. Poured a light hazy copper/amber color with a tall creamy tan head. The head lasted throughout the glass and left good lacing. There was a good aroma of sweet roasted malt with an alcohol scent and a hint of hops. The beer had a nice creamy texture and started off with a sweet taste of toffee and dried fruit like raisins. There was a good bit of alcohol in the initial taste. The flavor built to a good strong hop bite on the finish that lasted for awhile. There was a good underneath sweetness to balance out the strong hop bitterness.  This is an excellent beer, full of flavor.

Taste 2/9 Bottle. Looks: Deep caramel body with a nice full foam. Aroma: Nice citrus a heavy malt. Taste: Very strong malt and floral/citrus hops. Full bodied. Too sweet, maybe toast more of the malt.

Bottle.  Hazy orange/copper color.  Small whitish head.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy.  Citrus hops and honey to be exact.  Flavor is sweet but not sickly so.  Some notes of honey, caramel and great malt backbone.  Then the hops come into play.  NIce citrus hops balance this beer beautifully.  Very nice.

750ml Bottle.  Pours a bright and deep golden hazy ale with a huge white head which lasts the duration.  A thick syrupy palate, very sweet and strong with huge hop smell and taste and bite.  Very heavy and great with some spicy nachos and chili.  This beer will kick you in the butt

2004 Release!!!

A- Pours a murky dark amber hue with a watery off-white head, lacing is excellent throughout

S- Rich, strong hops, tones of pine and citrus, considerable alcohol presence

T- What can I say other than Amazing! I like Double Bastard, and this is the longest aged bottle I have ever had. Initial taste is dominated by piney/citrus hops followed by cherry and honey sweetness. Aftertaste is a brief hoppy bitterness balanced by sweet malts. Alcohol is fairly evident, but not entirely overwhelming.

M- Full bodied with light carbonation, thick and oily mouthfeel.

D- What a treat! Pulled this gem from a co-worker who had to give away his beer due to medical reasons. Didn¬ít realize it was 2004 until I started drinking it!!! I am a big fan of AB and am more partial to Oaked than Double, but this was great!

2007 bottle.  Poured cloudy dark copper with a beige head, no lace.  Aroma of big sweet toasted malts, caramel, piney hops.  Taste is very malty with big hop bite, a little like an imperial red.  Body is sticky.  Finish is very bitter.  Overall, very enjoyable hoppy brew.

Pours a deep cloudy copper brown with a glowing red hue and a mid sized off-white creamy head. Aroma is very fresh and pungent citrus hops with a lot of grapefruit and pineapple. A solid caramel malt backbone gives the aroma a nice roundness. Flavor starts with a creamy sweet toasted malt character with a little buttery and a slightly tart fruitiness. Gains the powerful bitter edge from the hop resin. Can detect hints of the alcohol. Becomes very floral and spicy in the swallow and finishes with a bite but keeps its nice malt sweetness. Medium to full body and moderate carbonation. Very well balanced and rounded. Nice fresh taste.

Poured a dark brown/copper with a tan/beige head.  Aroma was very sweet with notes of toasted malts, and caramel.  Palate is medium with strong flavors of toasted malts.  A decent amount of hops in the flavor as well.  Some alcohol is present.  Finish is slightly bitter.  Overall very good, but the balance was a little different.

You can¬ít consider yourself even a well-informed novice until you¬íve drank your own birth year in beers, so here goes. 650ml bottle. Deep copper pour with a dirty diminishing beige collar. Specks of lace, ample legs. Plenty of sweaty resinous hops in the aroma, notes of tangerine peel, blackcurrant even raspberry, pollen, toffee malt richness, dab of Marmite, phenolic heady apple, almond, butterscotch,raisiny choc hints and thyme after an hour,loads of alcohol. Quite an integrated, English-like combo of house yeast fruitiness, caramelised malt and floral/citrus hops that reminds me of Fullers, White Shield, Burton Bridge... every now and again a waft of pure hop joy. But it¬ís not enough. Alcohol and hop astringency in the mouth. Alpha floral and tanging with soapy citrus but overwhelmed by booze, shampoo and quinine. The punch of hops without the promised aromatics. Aftertaste utterly drenched with retronasal alcohol, if no burn. Slick and full but losing its lace and head. Tipping some into Octo¬ís glass. Delicious smelling ale but the least balanced and enjoyable of my US box, and by the pint+ measure a bit of a struggle.

22oz bottle, 2008 release, dark copper color, with a thick beige head, leaving a veil of lacing, sweet toasty, caramel malt, minty, herbal, medicinal floral hop nose, with some resinous, leafy piney accents, with a toffeeish, hint of cookie dough, and a light lime citrusy aroma follows though on medium-bodied palate with a warmth, sweet toasted, caramelized malt, flowery hop resinous, spearmint character, with a hint of fruity elderberry accent, with some piney, leafy, cedary flavors, within smooth malty background, and some light zesty, lime, lemon peel, citrusy notes, leading towards a warming, toasty, citrusy, intense resiny, piney, grassy hop bitterness finish.

I¬ím a bit torn over this one. On the one end it is a strong drink that bites hard. on the other, it bites very friggen hard. This felt like a fistfight in my mouth. Not very pleasant to drink, very friggen bitter, probably to bitter. I¬íd give this one more shot, but most likely i won¬ít change my opinion much

I liked this beer.  Unlike its counter part arrogant bastard this double actually tastes like something besides hops.  In fact when I ordered the large bottle at Highlands in Kennesaw, the bartender sent over a sample glass with it because I was tasting it before him.  This beer is excellent  and I suggest you try it and add it to you list.  I got the 22oz bottle, and that is MORE than enough though, not an all night drinker even for the fanatic.

See Bastard, Arrogant. I didn¬ít think this stuff was much different, just slightly stronger with a little more intense flavors.  Orangish-brown color with off-white head.  Aroma is hops and sweet malt, typical of West Coast hoppy ales and Stone in particular.  Flavor is more of the same, very citrusy, heavy on Amarillo hops with a sweet malt backbone.  Sticky, full mouthfeel, a lot like a West Coast barleywine.

Bottle, pours a hazy orange amber red brown beer with a creamy off white head.  Arom a is sweet and hoppy.  Flavor is sweet fruit, pine and citurs hoppieness.  Very bitting full body beer with a bitter as hell finish.  Taste like an American style Barley Wine but better.  Bottle reads 10.5%.  Awesome

2005 bottle at the Bistro on the first day of Winter Storm 09.  This is the first time I¬íve had an aged bottle of this one and the years have served it well.  The fresh bottles that I have had were harshly hoppy and bitter.  I am just as big of a hop head as any of us, but it really masks the complexity of the beer.  This aged bottle is more like a great barleywine.  Pours a cloudy reddish orange with a thin white head.  Lots of caramel and dark dried fruits in the aroma, although some floral hops are still there even after all this time.  Flavor is alot of buttery caramel or toffee, a bit earthy and piney hops.  Still quite bitter but definitely not harsh.  Full bodied and sticky with medium carbonation.
Bottle.  Pours a murky copper color with a thin off white head.  Smells of malt and bitte hoppyness.  It tastes similar to how it smells and is well balanced.
Roasted malt and hops aromas.  Reddish brown colors. Rich malt flavors with an equally rich bitter hoppiness.  Creamy palate with good bitter duration.

Very powerful. Lots of sweet malt flavor, balanced with an extreme amount of bitter hop flavor. Not a floral/herbal taste, but just straight bitter. Strong malts remind me of a barley wine. No shortage of flavor in this beer. Delicious and strong. Only complaint is the bitterness is perhaps a bit too overpowering.

Sampled during MN Gathering II in Maplewood, MN. We tried a side by side comparison between 2004 vintage (MilkmanDan) and a 2008 vintage (Badgerben). Both poured a hazy reddish amber brew with the 2008 had a decent off-white head and the 2004 quickly dissipates to a film top. The 2004 had a sweet raisin and caramel aroma while the 2008 had more hops with caramel. I liked the 2004 vintage which was quite smooth and even had a powdered caramel flavor that was easy drinking. The 2008 had its extra hop character. The 2004 finish hid the alcohol while the 2008 had a slight alcohol bite to it. Since I liked the 2004 vintage the most, my rating reflects off the aged version.
Comlex but rough with a completely unhidden grainy alcohol burn. Sticky stale bread and leather.

22 oz bottle

This has been cellaring for about a year now.  Of the 2006 vintage it was a bit of a letdown.  Going big for the sake of going big is not always a good idea.  It could have been this particular year or maybe it is better fresh but the overall impression was only redeemable because of the price paid.

Aroma / Appearance - A delicate one finger head rested above a creamy opaque maple colored body.  Malty and dense it reminded me of caramel apples, chocolate truffles, and wood residue.  Overall it was not unlike bread pudding.

Flavor / Palate - Caramel bites attack the throat as the alcohol is evident from the start.  A delayed bitterness slowly unfolds on the back of the tongue.  An oaky finish wraps up a reasonable experience but nothing that you do not find in other big beers.  Balanced but a little stale it might have slid over the past year.

Date: 12/2/2008   Source:Capital Ale House - Downtown   Citrus and floral hop aroma with lots of caramel. Clear amber golden with frothy white head. Moderate spicy hop bitterness, grassy citrus hop flavor. Caramelized malt backbone. Finish is slightly sweet and quite bitter. Alcohol warming is quite evident.
Pours a dark red orange with an off white head.  Great strong aroma of hops.  It¬ís Arrogant Bastard Ale with tons more hops.  The hops flavor is excellent.
Bottle.  Muddy very dark brown beer with a reddish hew.  The aroma is well hopped and the flavour very, very, very hopped and dry with a deeply malty and whisky/rum finish.  Overall a good beer.

(22 oz. bottle (2008) from Rum Runner)...Pours dark reddish amber with one finger of lightly amberish biege head that recedes to a thin lasting layer. Aroma of sweaty hops and pine. Some traces of caramel and vanilla underneath. Mouthfeel smooth, lightly sticky. Flavor is just big over-the-top hops - sweat and pine resin with a little bit of malt that is really buried. Just like regular Bastard, except the hops are even bigger and harsher. Big bitter finish with lingering pine and sweat. I¬ím a Stone fan on most things but not these Bastards.

A vertical tasting of vintages 2003, 2004, 2006, and 2008.
The 2003 and 2008 were sampled together, and the 2004 and 2006 were sampled the following evenings.

Vintage 2008 bottled on on 9/12/08. 

Pours dark amber with a ruby hue. Clear body with a half inch head of off white. Some light rings of lacework after the short head fell, and a partial skim coat remained on the surface for the duration.

Aromatics lead off with jammy malt, red and tropical fruits, and warming alcohol. 
Peaches, apricots and melons lead the way for shadows of red grapes, cherries, and bourbon-spiked honey.
Sweetish and quite juicy.

On the thick side of medium bodied. Sticky and chewy mouthfeel. A bit light on the carbonation.

Sweet crystle malt, ripe fruit, fresh caramel, and a resinous bitterness start the palate. Warming alcohol steps forward as well as hints of caramel-candied apple, spruce dew, and candied figs.

Finishes with a lingering warmth, sustaining bitterness, and drawn-out sweet fruit. 

A classic American strong ale that dances along the lines of a Barleywine. 
Next up, a mini vertical with an aged example.

Vintage 2003:

Pours cloudy, dark amber, with a half inch head of off white. A slow retreat revealed some spongy lacework and a few whisps on the placid surface.

Aromatics are heavy on the malt, with lots of wet leather, rotting cedar, wet paper, and Sherry. Very earthy and oxidized. Hops are not to be found, and the nose rounds out with hints of cocoa, cardboard, and dried earth.

Medium bodied, but very syrupy and chewy. A slick, tacky mouthfeel with subdued carbonation.

Stale malt, wet and dusty boards, worn leather, and earth-dusted chipped toffee start the palate. Oxidized Sherry steps forward as well as a warming boozy note and tannic caramel.

Finishes with a lingering dried earth note, dusty leather, stale malt, and old wood tinders. 

Not a fan of the five year old DB.

Side by side with the 2008 freshie:

Wow, I wouldn¬ít believe that they were the same beer unless I poured it myself. The freshie is cleaner, infinately hoppier all around, and much brighter. The peaches and apricots really shine though when sided with the oldster DB.

Vintage 2004

Pours clear, dark amber with a two inch head of off white. Retention is moderate and theres some decent lacing after the fall.

Aromatics lead off with ripe, red fruits, sweet malt, and alcohol. Significantly more boozy than the 2003 or 2008. 
Slightly vineous with hints of bourbon fusels, cherries, figs, and sherry.

On the thick side of medium bodied. Slightly syrupy and plenty slick.

Dark fruits, cherry-infused malt, and bourbon-spiked toffee start the palate. A mild throat burn quickly steps forward as well as a peppery warmth.

Finishes with lingering alcohol, sweet malt, and fading red fruits.

Hardly a trace of oxidation in the 2004, which makes it pretty amazing how quickly this beer goes off the deep end. Looks like four years in the cellar is the max for a Double Bastard.

Vintage 2006

Pours murky dark amber, with a one inch head of off white. A partial skim coat remained on the surface for the duration, along with some spotty lacework.

Aromatics lead off with dry, papery malt, caramel, toffee, earthy cedar, and a trace of cocoa. Warming alcohol follows through along with wet cardboard.

On the thick side of medium bodied and chewy. A creamy and somewhat syrupy mouthfeel.

Drying malt, caramel dust, and hints of cocoa, nougat, and wet boards start the palate.
Dark fruits, warming alcohol, and an approachable biterness follow through.

Finishes with lingering cardboard-infused malt, stale chocolate, and a drying bitterness.

Concensus:

The 2004 was remarkable and somehow far superior to the 2006. Zero oxidation and was clearer in the glass.
I¬íd like to think that the perfect amount of time for DB in the cellar is four years if you use the 2004 as a benchmark. The 2006 disproves this though.

Vintages in order of best to worst:
2008
2004
2006
2003

Note: All were stored in the cellar on thier sides for the duration, and the 2006 was very close to the 2003 in last place.

0.66 l bottle at Akkurat, Stockholm. Slightly hazy dark amber color with creamy head. Sweet, hoppy and fruity aroma with flowery and lemony hops,  prunes and caramel. Strong bittersweet flavor with caramel as well as massive lemony and flowery hops. To my mind there is too much everything and the overload of hops make this a bit soapy. I prefer the original.

Bomber.  Pours a clear dark amber with a 2 finger creamy beige head that leaves spotty lacing.  The nose is caramel malt and floral hops.  The taste is sweet toffee, caramel and ripe citrus with a lasting bitter pine finish.  Medium creamy mouth feel.  Good ASA.

Bottle from Jonpol at AJs.  Pours a murky amber color, almost like a barley wine, with a creamy tan head.  Smells and tastes of slightly overripe apples and citrus, with balanced amounts of yeast, malt, and hops.  Finishes hot with alcohol and a trace of wood.  Nice.
Doubling the bastard was a fantastic idea.  Sweeter and thicker, the more subtle flavors of the bastard come out fully.  Very interesting mouthful.

2007 Bottle, aged one year.  Pours a dark murky reddish body with a loose off white, almost tan, head.  Huge vineous alcohol scent with sweet sticky bready notes beyond what must have been a hop overload.  Sensation is still hot on the pallate with lots of alcohol soak and dry puckering bitterness.  It feels disorganized on my pallate like the malts are all boozed up and don¬ít know how to act.  Flavors are deep and complex with citrusy hops, caramel malts, boozey vodka like alcohol notes, and some sweet woody malts.  Still not sure what to make of this one, but I know not to mess with it.

Dark reddish brown.  Sticky sweet caramel/sugary initial flavor, incredibly smooth.  Full body.  Almost buttery in it¬ís mouth feel, but not syrupy thick.  Moderate carbonation.  The initial caramel/roast/malt sweetness almost overwhelms but after a moment a hop bitterness kicks in to balance things out, then all the flavors blend and it fades into a warming sensation as the alcohol makes it¬ís presence felt.  Notes of dark chocolate, the aforementioned caramel, mixed fruits were all detected.  Finish is warm, slightly tingly, sticky caramel sweetness still very present.   Too bad it¬ís not readily available year round!

An 04 and 08 bottle sampled at Skyview¬ís tasting.  This rating is reflective of the 2004 bottle, since this beer was much better with age.  Pour was a hazy dark brown pour with medium carbonation.  Aroma was mild hops and malt.  Flavor was excellent, mellow hops, wood and and a little fruity on the finish.  If trying to acquire this, get an aged bottle if possible.

Pours a murky, rusty brown with a small beige head. Very sweet caramelly aroma, much fruitier then the arrogant bastard. Pineapple, orange, citrus, and spices. The flavor is so massive, combining flavors of sweet fruits, cherries, wood, massive hops, and lots of spices. Take a large sip and just savor it to take in the huge flavors over time. Even better then its little brother.

Brazen darkly opaque brown body with a thick off-white head that clings reasonably well to its snifter... nice, spooky, ghostlike lacing as its body drains... spruce and spice rush to arrest the senses... fresh fruity esthers bolster the rush with an engaging connection... the alcohol is noted in the heat at the throat... teeth rattle as Double Bastard is chewed... otherwise, body behaves as an IPA should... upon first sip, one wonders the IBUs needed to make this run... second sip brings a sweetness to the lips and a bitterness that lingers minutes after... difficult to gage the effects of this, as the expectation and the affectation blur in the experience.... I just feel I am drinking something important here, ignoring the rather silly "diatribe" on the bottle... a shout-out to brother Jer for gifting me with three (3!) of these for Christmastime...
bottle, reddish caramel colored pour with some slight foam, aromas of piney sugarcane, flavors of sweet grapefruit, caramelized sugars, some alcohol with a metallic bitter finish

Bottle. Pours dark orange. Huge aroma of canned pineapple with hints of marzipan. Big bodied and sweet malty flavor balancing on a big bitterness that lends the beer a dryish finish. Big vanilla malt flavor. Nice Barley Wine.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2011 Bottle from CaryTheDude, crushed with CaryTheDude and JakeBra. Pours deep red with a thick white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt with a huge shot of hops. Flavor is a hard hit of hops, with sticky caramel, citrus, fruitys. Double Bastard is absolutely awesome. 

Rerate: alcohol, generic bitterness, thin flimsy malts.  Gross, drain pour.  Original rating was a 4.4.  I averaged this rating and the last one.

Finally rating this staple brewski. Pours a glorious crimson elixir with a late forming beige head that leaves rings of lacing. The nose is pungent, dusty, citric hops and caramel malt. The flavour is brutally, yet tastefully hoppy, with sharp grapefruit citrus, peppery spice, ripe red fruits and zesty citrus. The palate is slick, medium-full bodied and drying. The finish is long and warming. The booze is present, but not severely for 10.5%. I feel this is a bit overrated, but still great.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 bomber (2008 release) from grape and gourmet poured into a stone arrogant bastard pint glass. pours a beautiful and slightly syrupy dark amber with a half inch light tan head and very solid lacing. aroma is deliciously sweet with big, juicy hops, orange zest, raisins, caramel, rich toasty malt, and hints of vanilla and bourbon. taste is nothing short of spectacular. flavors are rich and very well balanced with a hoppy sweetness and touches of citrus and molasses blended perfectly with toffee and roasted malt. the hoppy bitterness lingers nicely after the swallow. palate is amazingly smooth with just a slight alcohol warmth and perfect carbonation. just another awesome brew from Stone that truly lives up to the hype.

22 ounce bottle split in Chimay glass.  Hazy deep red with lasting ring and lace.  Hoppy port brown sugar aroma.  Toasted brown sugar and ripe dark fruit with wood and hoppy flavor and bitterness.  Well-disguised warming alcohol.  Full body and medium carbo.  Very complex and delicious.

1/4/09 notes: bomber for $6.99.  Given how much I loved Arrogant Bastard the first time I tried it, you can imagine my excitement at getting to try its older brother.  Aroma full of juicy hops, red fruit, and a certain assertive spiciness.  Appears murky red, with a creamy head.  Flavor was very full-bodied, of strawberries, lemon, sweet malt, and some minerals.  Another excellent ASA from Stone, Double Bastard was well-balanced with the high ABV hidden tastefully.  This is simply an awesome brew.
Bottle. Dark bown/orange. Smells vinegar and raisin. Big taste! Caramel hops dominates. Bitter aftertaste. Complex beer in all ways. Has a thick feel to it.

Bomber->tulip: Pours a large, frothy, light brown head that exhibits good lacing atop a cloudy dark amber body.  Aroma of overripe fruit, caramel, and light hops.  The body is full, texture creamy and the duration is long, being lightly sweet.  A great beer for sure!

(Bottle, Akkurat, Stockholm, 1 Jan 2009) Reddish amber colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty, vinous nose with dried fruit, caramel and lots of earthy hops. Malty, fruity taste with notes of dried fruit, caramel, black-currant and lots of citrussy, earthy hops in the finish. Full bodied and chewy, vinous and warming. Very nice balance for such an extreme beer. Excellent stuff!

Been waiting a long time to try this beer and it was well worth it. Pours a slightly murky and thick deep amber color creating a creamy and dense off-white head. Head retention was a bit weak with only some spotty foam and little lacing. Just fantastic complex aromas of balanced malt and hop contributions with notes of dark roasted caramels, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, citrus rinds and spice. Palate was perfect; big, full, round and smooth. Very fine carbonation bubbles keep the beer velvety slick. Flavor is just immense and rich with a nice balance struck with the sweet malts and hoppy bitterness. Flavors start out with notes of sweet dark brown sugar, raisin, caramel and toffee. Gradually slides into a medium - bitter hop contribution with crisp, fresh notes of grapefruit, orange and pine. Alcohol is fairly muscular but not hot or intrusive. Just a FANTASTIC brew in all aspects.

Pours clear, amber-brown, with a thin tan head, good lacing.  Smells of molasses, fig, caramel, pine and grapefruit.  Thick but crisp body.  Tons of hops, tastes of alcohol, grapefruit, plum and spice.  Very bitter, and a lasting aftertaste.

22 oz. bomber poured into a pint glass. Pours an opaque, amber-brown color with a foamy off-white head that diminishes to a thin layer but lasts throughout. Good lacing.  Aroma is a strong malty sweetness, some caramel, and noticeably hoppy. Flavor starts off with a strong, sweet caramel maltiness followed by a grapefruity hop bitterness that carries long into the finish. Spicy. Slightly warm. Very full  bodied..
Bottle at home ... Copper brown ... light sweet toffee malts ... deep and quite bitter malts ... deep roast  malts ... quita a lit of vanilla ... bit rough.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2009 Strong, big, thick, rich, luxurious, malty, hops, sweetly balanced, smooth, and palatable.  What more is there to say?  Awesome.

This is one amazing beer. I got the 101.4 fl oz bottle. That‚Äôs right, 3 Quarts and 5.4 oz.

Look - Has a great cloudy amber color to it with a beautiful amber/tanish cream.
Smell - Fruity, Alcohol smell def. Amazing, like heaven.

Taste - Has an extra bitter taste def.Has a big alcohol taste but fruity and sweet also. Amazing. That‚Äôs all I can say.
Pours amber with thick tan head.  Aroma of caramel, floral hops, and alcohol.  Taste is creamy, caramel malt and grapefruit hops.  Nice, thick mouthfeel.  Better than the regular Bastard.  Excellent!

Pours a clear amber/brown with a minimal grey head. Aroma is lightly sweet with grapefruit, cherry, flowers and caramel. The flavor is floral hop, grapefruity hop, cherries, toffee, orange and light cinnamon. Medium body, very pleasant light creamy texture.  Finishes very hoppy and dry with a warming alcohol burn.

Pours a thick red/brown.  The beer is completely opaque with a good amount of carbonation and a small white head and good lacing. This beer looks like a meal in a glass. The first thing you taste is a thick caramel malt with maybe a hint of orange peel  and honey then hops, lots of hops! The finish is immediately bitter but quickly backs down leaving a deliciously bitter taste on the palate for 10-15 seconds and a sticky honey malt flavor on the roof of your mouth. Alcohol is hardly noticeable. Excellent beer to be enjoyed with friends on special occasions.

2008 12 oz.  Disappointing.  Beautiful looking beer.  If it tasted how it smelled it would be a wonder.  Very one-note bitter hoppiness, not fruity or flowery or balanced with any full, roasty or sweet maltiness at all, just bitter, bitter, bitter hoppiness in the flavor.  The only saving grace of this beer is that it seems to smooth out as it warms, thank the beer gods for that.  Sorry Stone but you and the rest of the west coast may have to come to grips with your hops obsession (Ruination!!!!!!  Great brewery but off key with this guy.

Bouteille de 22 oz partag√©e lors d¬íune d√©gustation Ratebeer Montr√©al chez MartinT. Ar√¥me: Odeur d¬íhoublons avec une pointe de c√©r√©ales et de fruit√©. Apparence: La couleur est ambr√©e. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de caramel fruit√© et d¬íhoublons. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Pr√©sence de caramel en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #2053)

Bomber bottle. Aroma is really sweet with lots of fruity notes and plenty of caramel. Taste is hoppy and fresh with lots of caramelcandy,fruit and some malt. Really well balanced. Nice and creamy mouthfeel. Certainly a treat!

Dark pour with a minimal tan head. Huge hops, a little malt, smoke, and fruit aroma. Huge hops flavor. A very big beer. Nothing subtle at all with this. The high ABV is unsociable at the finish. Great brew.

Style and Glass: American Strong Ale, Snifter; trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 10.5% in 22 fl oz. estimated at 400 C
Purchased at: Canal¬ís Lawrenceville, NJ for $7.99

Having this on Christmas night to finish off an amazing day. Merry Christmas and happy holidays to all of you.

Aroma: amazing, sweet, flowery, hoppy, grassy, heavenly, malty, earthy, mold.

Visuals: nice label design, what seas might look like in hell, menacing deep red, brilliant, clear, thick white head, sticky tight lace.

Taste: wow. very malty, deeply hoppy, sugary, not syrupy, crisp, heavy, molasses, smoke, strong.

Palate: Of the highest visual and taste quality, rigid, sandy, rough, long bitter finish.

Overall: An absolutely amazing DIPA, though not classified as such. I¬íd have it again no question. Perhaps one of my top ten. A favorite. Great value. High craft.

I love this brewery.  What a hopslam in my olfactrory and taste sensations.  I wish i could leave a lengthy "diatribe" here but all I could taste and smell were powerfully but superbly blended hops and roasty toast caramel , juicy with sugared fruit and candiesd raisins and malts to help me enjoy this bitteringly refreshing and palate shattering brew.  A powerful brew, stronger than you would think  and a warmning brandyish quality is also there.  This beer evolves with every sip and takes my palate into different dimensions of experience...is there anything else you could ask???

This beer is phenomenal, plain and simple. Perfect cloudy color of amber and caramel with a ruby glow. Huge flavor of floral hops, alcohol, caramel malt, with a bitter-sweet, but smooth finish. Aroma matches much of the flavor with a bit of an earthy sweet smell. Sticky, full-bodied mouthfeel. Excellent.
Bottle.Brown and clear.Sweetness dominates making it a single dimension beer.Powerful alcohol presence but nothing else going for it.

Aroma is fairly hoppy and has a strong fruity overtone. It pours a deep coppery reddish brown with a fairly thick off-white head. As to flavor, WOOOOO! One sip of this beer, and you will know what it is like to have an angry puma in your mouth. It is FIERCE, not for the faint of heart! Bitterness is strong, but not unpleasant. Taste is mainly hoppy with some malty and sweet tones and hints of Coca Cola and caramel. Texture is satisfyingly smooth, and aftertaste is bitter yet with a sweet fruity undertone. Like no other beer I have ever tried.

[2007 Bottle] Pours dark amber with a small head. Aroma is hops, caramel and marzipan. Sticky, oily mouthfeel. Flavour is really intense, really bitter hops. No refinement at all, its all straight in the face, but I liked it somehow.

Dark amber/ruby.  Not much head.  Tons of grapefruit/piney aroma.  Delicious flavor of sweet malts, dried apples??, huge hops....I freaking love this beer.  It is everything its smaller version promises and more.

Bottle.  Ruby pink and amber with a small head.  Aromas are peppery pine with smoky, woody notes.  Some sweet toffee with not too harsh alcohol.  Flavours are toffee and chocolate malts with sweet caramel.  Some dark syrup.  Pine hops with peppery notes. Very smooth despite its strength.  Very good.
22oz bottle, 2008 release. Pours a dark amber with a large white head. Big hops with hints of caramel and malts. Smooth drinkability with nice alcohol burn. Very good.

2006 vintage on tap at Oldsmar Tap House (Tampa, FL) for Stone opening. Pours a dark reddish brown/mahogany color with an off-white head. Aroma is very hoppy with a floral and spicy note as well. Some sweet malt hidden among the hops, but the citrus-grapefruit hop aroma comes through strongly even after two years of aging. Flavor is much of the same--floral and hoppy with a balancing maltiness. Generally medium body with a hoppy finish.

22oz bottle.  Had this once or twice before and could not wait for this batch to come out.  Pours a deep amber, almost light brown, with a huge off-white head.  Lots of hop in the nose, but a good amount of caramelly malt too.  Tons of hop flavor up front, followed by a slight alcohol burn and a carmelly malt finish.  Alcohol sticks around for the aftertaste.  Superb stuff.

22 Oz Bottle.  Poured a somewhat cloudy amber with a small tan head.  The aroma was compelling and the taste did not disappoint.  This is a big bold ale which doesnt rely on a lot of fruity or chocolate notes to get the job done.  Stoneworthy!

Deep Murky copper color. Huge pine, and earthy hop aroma, with sweetness and slight alcohol notes. WOW. Almost a huge DIPA character. Extremely thick on the tounge and an awesome wood flavor on top of the MASSIVE hops. The alcohol it very noticable but it finishes unbeliveably for as wicked as this shit is....Superb.

I have been looking for this beer for the better part of a year, and I finally found it. Pours a deep, deep ruby that makes the beer look as badass as advertised. The foreground of the aroma is hops, but oh so many different styles- grapefruit, sweet pineapple, pine, and floral aspects blend into an assaulting beautiful hop smell. This is coupled with a marked malt presence, with sweet and sticky dark fruit evident. Flavor is incredible- the hops remains massive, and the malty side contributes to a gorgeous palate that covers your entire mouth with waves of flavor. This beer is phenomenal.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 First rating, Initial Rating Date: 12/14/2008 8:26:10 AM65 cl bottle thanks deft. BB March 2010. Hazy orange to copper color, orange to tan head. Sweet, hoppy scent. Bitter, a bit sweet, grainy, dry taste. Alcohol aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/3/7/4/15=3.6RerateDraught at Moeder Lambic, Brussels, for the Stone beer festival. Sampled on September 16, 2011Had the 2005 against the 2010 vintage, both from draught2005:Hazy copper color, big tan head. Sweet, hoppy, bitter, malty, alcohol taste. Bitter aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, high to very high bitterness. Malty, caramel, sweet, ocean scent.7/4/7/5/15=3.82010:Hazy copper color, big tan head. Fruity, sweet, bitter alcohol, dry taste. Medium to moussy mouthfeel, high bitterness. Sweet, hoppy scent.8/4/7/3/14=3.6RerateTwo bottles, one fresh and one older, both thanks to Johan K (not on ratebeer), sampled on March 18, 2013.Bottle 1:Hazy brown color, tan head. Malty, sweet, tobacco scent. Malty, bitter, alcohol taste. Alcohol aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.8/3/7/3/14=3.5Bottle 2:Hazy copper color with floaties, tan head. Hoppy, citrus, tobacco scent. Hoppy, bitter taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Noticable allcohol.7/2/6/4/13=3.2RerateOn March 15, 2014. Thanks to RobertGBG and thomat! Bottle 1 pt 6 fl oz, BB 2010, marked 10% ABV.Hazy copper color, small tan head. Sweet, caramel, malty, alcohol scent. Malty, sweet, wood, dry, yeast taste. Dry, ash aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, dry finish.7/3/6/3/12=3.1

Fiery amber with a yellow head. Fruity nose has a lot of grapefruit, hop rich stuff, and some dank caramel. Flavor is similar but less fruit, more caramel, and a lot of alcohol coming on with warmth. Quite a lot of bludgeoning here.  Body is oily and syurpy. Not incredibly refined, it certainly is abusive.

This beer pours a reddish brown with hints or orange.  It is a nice looking beer.  The first thing noticed about the aroma is that it is very hoppy.  It may also have some sweet undertones to the aroma.  This beer drinks like an IPA with a really heavy body.  It has a ton of hops without being overly bitter.  This beer is velvety with small bubbles in the mouth.

I just poured my bottle of this brew and igotta say it looks great Its got nice contrast between beer color and head color. The flavor on the hand could be a little more balanced  but thats just me. It does have a wonderful smokey sweet start followed by a hint of raisins. Its definitely not my favorite from Stone but it is up there and I would most likely get this again. Cheers

aroma is strong with grapefruit, some pine and a balance of malt adding some caramel and dark sugar.  pours dark amber with ample white head that leaves some nice lacing.  Solid beer with lots of character from hops and malt.  spicy, bitter, resiny, with some caramel and a general fruitiness as it warms.  medium full body.  a good brew.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 22 oz bomber. Pours a murky dark orange with a small yellow head. Aroma of hop resin, grapefruit, pine, and spice. Taste adds tons of brown sugar, molasses, maple syrup, and hop spiciness. Much smoother than I expected and not as punitive as say the Ruination IPA- closer to a barleywine.  Usually these super intense beers are unbalanced but this is absolutely perfect. Incredible.

To make the long story short, this is an over the top, super hoppy version of the Arrogant Bastard.  The extreme hoppiness takes this one closer to a barleywine for me.  An incredibly smooth brew for 10 percent.
2008 22oz bomber.  Pours a mohogany color.  Aroma is strong citrus hops, lots of sweet malt .  Flavor is bitter then ripe fruit and sugar, with a bitter finish.

Bottle. Dark amber, medium head. Vinous smell of plum, spice and some hoppy grass. Sweet, thick mouthfeel, rather intense flavour. Sugary flavour without really much to it, but which finds redemption in the nice spicy hop-bitter finish.

Bottle, poured into a Duvel tulip. Pours deep garnet topped by a receding beige head. Big nose of tangerine and grapefruit with a hint of sweetness. Deep penetrating bitterness is peppered with tangerine, resinous pine, grapefruit, and chewy bready malt flavors. Lasting finish. Very good.
Crushed with Jakebra.  One of the best Ive ever had.  Perfect balance and awesome hoppy finish.  Have nothing else to say.  One of my all time favorites right away.  Knocked me out.

The big brother to the oh-so-Arrogant Bastard. Never tasted the two side-by side, but that is OK because this beer is fantastic. Smells heavenly and hoppy. First taste warms you up right quick with a fairly bitter alcohol-flavored finish. Absolutely ruinous on the palate but I kind of like that. And now I am done because my post needs to be shorter.
22oz bottle. Beautiful mahogany color with a nice white head and good lacing. Nice deep hop aroma, with some nice malty balance. Very rich flavor, well balnced and delicious.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle from BMan1113VR. Brilliant and clear red colored pour with a yellow head. Nose is passion fruit, caramel, slight banana and dark candi sugar. Taste is sweet, with many of the same components from the nose mixed with a dark tree fruit taste. Smooth and balanced mouthfeel, with a decent back end bitterness that is not overwhelming.

Mmmm. FINALLY! I have looked yonder mountains and in the wee shops of whoville for this stuff and alas! the search is fruitful. I feared the bottle would implode and cease to exist once I opened it. But nay. Mmmm. Double Bastard. This really tasted like a barley wine to me. Except sweeter. Which was bizarre. But it was great none the less. Lots of flowery bouquet notes with a definite dark raisiny cheek watering bite. Well worth the wait.

Savannah, Georgia - Habersham Beverage Warehouse - 22 oz bomber. Pours a medium to dark copper with a thick sticky off-white head that produces nice lace that clings to the glass for the entire time.  Resiny aroma with some nice mountainy Scotch pine accents and a wee bit of alcohol. Succulent flavor with some sticky grapefruity hoppiness, some nectarines, pomegranates -  you name the fruit  it is in there.  Nice malty backbone with some maple syrup notes, molasses, brown sugar. Sticky rich thick mouthfeel. Excellent -  best beer I have had in a long time.

22 oz bomber poured into a pint glass. Two-finger head that stayed strong and left nice sticky lacing. Caramel and citrus were strongest on the nose, which also held a background of dark fruits and malts. Wonderfully balanced caramel malt sweetness and slightly citrusy hops bitterness on the palate. Complexity seemed to increase as the beer warmed, and additional flavors of spices, ripe fruit, and carmelized sugars came through. Medium to full mouthfeel, good carbonation, and a pleasant aftertaste. Alcohol is warming, not overpowering. Excellent beer.

Bottle.  Pours with a white head, rather small.  Body is a dark amber color with excellent lacing.  Aromas of hops, mainly citrus, roasted grains and malts, and some casket-like port or wine. Flavor smacks you in the face with a bold initial taste followed by a very nice bitter aftertase.  Texture of sticky and carbonation almost perfect.  Well worth the wait each year.

On tap at ‚ÄôGinger Man‚Äô in NYC. Dark ruby red, tiny wispy pancake colour head. Deathly still. Aroma: Alcohol, some allspice, hops and then alcohol again!  Flavour: HUGE, just huge, alcohol, some distinct hops, very very bitter finish, long brandy in the finish too. A lot of alcohol. Woah.

(22oz bottle) Deep amber w/ off white, mostly diminishing head.  Aroma of toasty malt and fruit cocktail (a la Del Monte), specifically pineapple and peach.  Seriously resinous and syrupy - not for the faint of palate - w/ plenty of bitterness and alcohol burn.  Malt is distinguishable w/ caramel being prominent throughout.  Lingering bitterness and syrupy stickiness.  Good stuff.
Reddish body, tan head.  Has some sweetness to it.  Pine, spices, hops.  Smells clean.  Maybe a bit more malt than the average strong ale..
This is a brown-colored ale with a hint of red and a small head. Good lacing. The flavor and body are both full. The high IBUs are countered with some solid malts.
This tasted nothing like Arrogant Bastard, which is a dark and smooth and sexy beer.  This was just a typical barleywine style ale.  Too sweet and medicinal for me.

Bomber.  Missed this both the last two years.  Huge lacerative nose, strong alcohol but that¬ís nothing compared to the massive citrus and pine hops, powerful gritty caramel malt, and warm lemony biscuits effusing from the neck.  Woody, earthy, but all about the hops.  Deep copper-mahogany pour with a thick, rocky tan head.  Taste is punishingly bitter but moreso alcoholic.  Malty, sticky, chewy caramel taste, earth and wood with an overabundance of pine but less resin and far less grapefruit and lychee.  Lemon citrus and a little orange rind, very high-pitched fruty notes.  Fresh leafy green hop leaves, sugars are pretty well done but still sweet (and the thing laces pretty well).  Medium body, perfect for a session, helps to hide the 10.5%.  Big mutha, worth splitting and enjoying once a year, but there are four or five from Stone I¬íd rather go to on a daily basis.

Bottle from Systembolaget (temporary)

Where to beguin the description? Read somebody elses and I¬¥ll give you a tip that if you like this try to get hold of Nogne Imperial Brown Ale

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2008 Pours a beautiful reddish-brown color with a huge chunky tan head that lasts and laces throughout.  Aroma of citrus and pine hops, ripe fruit, sweet caramel malt and a whiff of alcohol.  Flavor is much the same, very hoppy but not enough so to mask the other elements.  Thick, full and a bit sticky on the palate.  Lingring bitter finish.  Seriously good stuff!

[Bottled]
Hazy reddish amber.
Loads of sweet fruitd an bitter hoppiness. Some smoked notes.
Thick mouthfeel. with some caramelle.

Dark amber/mahogany pour with an off-white head. Aroma is like a hop-bombed barley wine. The mouthfeel was very thick, maybe the most viscous beer I have ever drank. The flavor was the stereotypical Stone hops, caramel malts, and dark fruits.

Bomber.  Pours reddish amber with thick off-white head. Aroma is powerful hops, citrus pine and caramel malts. Flavor pascks big hop punch with strong citurs and pine notes. Big caramel malt back bone with some dark fruits. Big ale done in typical stone fashion.  Good stuff
Dark amber, sweet, alcohol, Piney,  spicey, citrus, hoppy, little caramel, little dark fruits, long bitter finish.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 (Bottle).  Strong fruit and cinnamon aroma.  Red body, light tan head.  Flavor is fruity and spicy, with lots of alcohol warming.  Bitter finish.

650 ml bottle (2007) shared with Bananaman.

Dark red color with a mediumzised beige head.

Aroma of dark berries, fruity candy, sweet malts... well actually I think it‚Äôs like smelling into a bag of candy or something... not that wrong. Some american hops there too.

Flavour is fruity with a big bitterness. It also got notes of fruit candy with a sweet, pleasant aftertaste. Lots of american hop-notes with a obvious taste of grapefruit. Very good. Some warming alcohol in the taste.

Very filling, fullbodied and nice in the mouth. The carbonation is average and very nice. A bit sticky, but not in a bad way.

A very nice sipper. Reminds me a little of american barley wines, but it has some other characteristics as well. My next bottle will be standing for a while though.
This beer leaves a long lasting impression and shouldn‚Äôt be treated lightly for it will put you on your rear end.  Strong ale with an everlasting palate and texture.  Only for the strong ones.

Bottle from the Winehouse in West Los Angeles
Pours with a deep red/brownish hue that sits below a light brown head that is mostly diminishing. 
Extremely hoppy taste all the way through, with some bitterness at the finish. 
Medium Texture with lively carbonation.
all i can say is wow!!! amazing - stone succeeds yet again!

‚Äô06 on tap @ OTH, Stone FL release party.
Pours orange, beige head.
Aroma is fruity (grapefruit) and hoppy.
Taste is thick and hoppy. Caramel malts with light chocolate notes. Hoppy finish with light lingering bitterness. Very drinkable with the abv remaining very hidden.
Deep red burgundy color, soapy lacing; thick tan head. Soapy hop aroma. Creamy. Very hoppy, herbal. Borderline abrasive in a good way. Soft texture. Very much in the American BW style.

Since the site went down, I‚Äôm having a hard time remembering this beer. I didn‚Äôt take notes at the time and I consumed three or four similar-but-different brews on the same night. It was served cold from a 22oz. bottle. From what I recall, it was amber-ish in color with an off/white head. Very complex. At first I was convinced that I didn‚Äôt like it, but the more I drank I started to really enjoy it. Maybe next time I try it I‚Äôll re-rate with more specifics.

Pours a murky brown in color. There was a small amount of head on the pour, but it is completely gone before I can find my seat. Smell is huge malt and a good amount of hops. Everything seems to be amped up a bit.
Taste is a bit more hops than I was expecting and a whole bunch of spiciness that caught me off guard. Very enjoyable, but nothing to mess around with. Good amount of caramel malts and to a lesser amount some toffee. This is a good beer fresh. I‚Äôve had an older bottle that was amazingly good, but fresh, this stands up there with the rest of them. Good beer.

Beer is Hazy Amber with thin  tan/white head.  Wonderful Hop aroma.   Hops bitterness perfectly balances alchol and malt sweetness.  It¬ís hard to believe that this is a 10.5 Percent beer.  Hop Bitterness is initially very forward but subdues substantially as drinking progresses.  Spicy piney dank hop bitterness.  Flavors are sharp with a  Sticky/full mouthfeel.
