UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 On tap @ Stone Release Party at Oldsmar Tap House.  This stuff is a liquid that attempts to live up to its name.  Beer pours hazy orange-copper with a wicked white head.  Aroma is syrupy sweet with hop notes composing a symphony, both sweet and sour.  There is awesomeness, sweetness, grapefruit, and malt.  Finish is crazy.  Smooth, yet pow-er-full, boozy as hell yet interesting events that the hops take part in.

Poured from bomber, awesome reddish orange color pour with a off white head that dissipates quickly with not much lacing on glass. Smell is wonderful hops,fruit,pine. Flavors found are hops,caramel malt,fruity sweetness,earthy plants,herbs and a perfect bitterness that sticks on the back of the tongue. Abv is hidden so well as beer is so smooth and very drinkable.

On tap at the Brasserie V here in Madtown. Holy smokes this beer was too good to be true! Poured a SICK cloudy orangeish copper colour with a thick sticky white head that seems to be temporarily out of control. Aroma is wonderful- so hoppy you want to punch yourself in the face. Pine,pine and more pine- fresh hops, and lots of grapefruit notes. Spicey on the palate, chewy dank herbs and earth. black licorice and soft oak as well. Overall an amazing beer for a hophead.

22oz Bomber.  Pours a beautiful reddish amber with a nice 2 finger off white fluffy foamy head.  Not much lacing for me, otherwise I probably would have given it a 5/5 on the appearance, really a beautiful beer.  Aromas of hops, pine resin, pineapple and/or grapefruit, and some caramel malt.  Flavor delivers a dominating hop profile, with some fruit, and a nice malty back bone. I really didnt catch much heat from the alcohol.  This beer went down fast and smooth.

Very delicious beer. This beer had a big everything. I really liked it! Wish I had been a bit
more sober when I was writing down my notes. The beer was caramel red. Had a nice red look to it like 
Terrapin¬ís Big Hoppy Monster. Nice tight head that stayed around for awhile .The head was not fully
white either, which I loved. The head a nice off-white color to it. The beer was very aromatic. Loved
the dominating hop aroma. The beer had a nice range of aromas. I loved the sugar aroma. The beer smelled
very sweet, and really hoppy. Of course, the hops dominated. I smelled grapefruit and pine hops flavors. The
aroma was extremely pleasing. The beer was very good as well. It had a nice and smooth palate. The beer was
very sweet and hoppy. The alcohol was well hidden, and I loved the ABV. I also was tasting grapfruit and pine
in the flavor as well. This beer was pretty good. I like other imperial/double IPAs but I must say this is 
one of the best out there, just not my favorite. I would definitely try again.

Tap @ Blind Tiger.  Pours a hazy reddish brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy hops with citrus and light fruit notes.  Flavor is the same, with light fruit dissolving into heavy hops with an ever-so-slight alcohol burn.  I agree the balance on this beer is much better than others in the style.  Another excellent beer from Stone.

cloudy reddish brown under a large foamy beige head.  ASA style hoppy aroma.  also some pineapple and light fruit.  flavor is hoppy with light fruit(pineapple).  alcohol shows in the finish.  citrus hops dominate.  good but not amazing.  seems more balanced than other ASA‚Äôs.

Bottle (bomber) from Systembolaget. Clear copper, medium yellow-beige head. Dark berries, caramell, and piney hops in the aroma. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. The caramel sweetness is well balanced by surprisingly restrained bitterness. Well done.

Draft at Brouwer‚Äôs in Seattle. My idea of an archetypal Big American Ale. Big malt-hop bomb, intense alcohol warming and thick and sticky. Lots of caramel, touch of sweet, citric hoppiness. Long finish, very rich. Yum

Bottle: Clear red colour, with nice creamy head. Aroma a mix of caramel, lots of malts, viny, lots of hopy fruity nose. Flavor is medium to full malty/citric,hopy/caramelly mouth feeling, medium to long fruity/malty,caramelly finish. Abit Viny in the end here .  Werry nice beer. Whow!

Pours deep garnet with somewhat small veneer of a head. Aroma is riddled with every hop facet imaginable- resinous, grapefruit, citrus, pine, grass. Malt character is full and undeniable- dark sweetness melds with the powerful hop blast seamlessly. Flavor is like getting hit by a freight train made of hops. Malt character is deep and foreboding. This delicatessen is far more lacerative and aggressive than its regular ABA counterpart- still wholly drinkable though. Palate is rich full and smooth with a punishingly hoppy finish. Simple incredible beer- at the forefront of its style.

Deep dark red color with off tan head.  Heavy malt in the nose mixed with some hops and flowers.  It almost punches you on the first taste, heavy hops with grapefruit    covered in honey.  Almost leaves your tongue numb.  Heavy mouthfeel, great flavor, very bitter.  Extremely solid, like this one better than last years, very aggressive

Pours a weird rusty red that can‚Äôt be seen through. The head is thin with off white coloration and a slightly yellow tint.
The smell is very hoppy yet malty at the same time. Heavy nose of citrus, pine and potent malt. Wow the taste is rather boozy and quite a cluster F@$# of flavors. Im getting a heavy hop grapefruit bitterness one minute than a sweet malt flavor the next. The alcoholic flavor is very noticeable and I don‚Äôt think stone had the intention of hiding it. Anyways this is my beer rating done after rate beer came back online so it was a good choice in my opinion.

2008 Release.

Appearance: Pours a clear, reddish amber body with a well-formed, sustaining, off-white head. Copious amounts of lacing on the way down.

Smell: Aromatic hoppy nose, some sweetish hints to it, and smelling of fresh orange peel, exotic flowers, pine resin, and a splash of pomegranate liqueur. Caramel-scented maltiness underneath. Very, very minor wafts of alcohol.

Taste: Sweet caramel-laden maltiness with a pinch of light brown sugar and a quick drizzle of simple syrup brace themselves for the impact of hops. Quick montage of fruit flavors - oranges, grapefruits, pomegranates, even sweet cherries. This precedes a solid jolt of straight-up citrus and pine hoppiness with a full, sturdy bitterness. Definitely a warming beer, but not quite hot or bracing for me. Drying finish with a touch of booze and more than a touch of bitter hops.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Recommended! I‚Äôm ashamed to admit it‚Äôs been more than a few years since I‚Äôve had a bottle of this to myself, but I‚Äôm more than pleased to be having a fresh bottle and am happy they‚Äôre finally, at long last, distributing to the state of Georgia.

mine was the 2008 release, 10th anniversary with silver ink instead of white... not bragging... just letting you know you should hold onto those bottles and when you have a trip out to Cali, Stone fanatics will pay MAD cash for the bottle. the beer itself, was alright compared to other Stone beers.

bomber ($7) from local market into wineglass.  Murky dark amber/honey brown pour with a big cream colored head that lasts and leaves great lace as it slowly recedes down the wall of my glass.  The aroma hits my nose upon uncapping this one - beautifully fresh juicy citrus (grapefruit) hops with a very sturdy malt character to balance the hops.  The flavor is the same but with a more pronounced alcohol presence sneaking through.  The grapefruit hop character fades into a bitter earthy and pine character on the finish.  Though the flavor is very solid, the hotness of the alcohol detracts from its quality.  It is medium to thick bodied on the palate with soft subtle carbonation.  Overall: very solid but a bit rough.  A big beer.

Pours a deep, transparent ruby amber with a thick, pillowy head. The aroma is so powerful it practically hits you in the face ¬ñ a delectable balance between tons of bright, citrus hops and sweet malts. Spices and booze also abound ¬ñ this is certainly a winter warmer. At first sip you can tell this is a big beer. The bitterness of the hops lingers, but is never overpowering. Not very smooth ¬ñ there¬ís no hiding the alcohol in this one. It¬ís just a tad on the wet side, but the flavor is fantastic. This would be dynamite with a steak.

On tap at Stone for the release party.  I love living in San Diego.  The 2008 is hot.  Way sharp and full of alcohol flavors.  Still was great.  However... the tap that flowed the ‚Äô06 was the tap for me.  It mellowed and blended and tasted so effing good.  I‚Äôm rating this on the ‚Äô06 just because I can.

Bottle@home

Finally i managed to chase down a bunch of bottles of this, very hyped, brew. 2007 vintage!

Apperance: Dark red with a yellow/beige lace that looks quite creamy.

Aroma: Malts, Caramel, Dark fruit, Citric notes, Hint of pine, Raisin.

Flavor: Orangepeel, Caramel, Bread, Butterscotch, Spices, Ripe fruit.

Palate: Quite thick with low carbonation. Lots of hops but the malts help to balance it out a bit.

This tastes like a DIPA mixed with a barleywine or something. Very heavy and complex and so very different from the Arrogant bastard. This is a good brew to sip on during cold nights. Outstanding!
Until I drank this beer I didn‚Äôt realize that I was such a masochist...I‚Äôm glad that Stone is out there to teach me such valuable life lessons.

Found this gem in a wine shop in Davis, though I didn‚Äôt anticipate to score anything...  I‚Äôm a huge fan of the ASA, and this one indeed put the Bastard in it‚Äôs place.  The sheer hoppiness was similar, but the complexity was clearly superior. This brew had an unbelievable palate for the sheer strength of it.  Excellent, excellent beer.

2007 Bottle - Pours a beautiful amber with a large tan head...aroma is huge - fruit, wood, pine, an insane amount of molassas-y malts, you can smell the alcohol...flavour is as you would expect, sweet, bold hops, yeast, dry fruit...as I expected, a year in the bottle definitely helped mellow the fire (but certainy not extinguished), will continue to evolve...

22oz bomber from a kick ass liq. store you wish you lived by... Pours a dark, clear brown/copper with highlights of dark amber and a large tan head. The aroma is strong - quite hoppy with some citrus/pine, but also very malty (lots of caramel) with a good bit of alcohol. The taste starts complex with a two-edged bitterness: a hint of roasted grains with a dark chocolate or coffee-like bitterness and a large presence of hops. The flavor is quite reminiscent of the "weaker" version - but sweeter and more alcohol. The middle of the palate detects more roasted grains, some biscuity malts, subtle touches of fruity esters, and hops. The finish isn¬ít as long as its lowly "arrogant" brethren and is much more warming. The mouthfeel is heavily carbonated (pour vigorously or swirl in glass to release it and to add creaminess to the texture) and medium- to-full in body. Overall, a good beer that is exactly what its name implies.

Bottle from 2007. Pours murky brown with a fast dissapating white head. Aroma is of earthy hops, strong alcohol, and citrus. Taste was very bitter. The bitter hop flavors are accompanied by the tastes of dark fruits and toasted malts. A burning alcohol bite finishes off each sip. Surprising how balanced this beer is. Despite the bitter hops and strong alcohol presence, it is extremely drinkable.

Hazy brown beer, fine lacing. Sweet, but somehow balanced, until it throws a punch at you. Warming.
Full flavour, raisins, Belgian sourness. One of their very best, despite the boasts this is actually a nice sipping beer where both hops and malt are allowed to play!

Pours a hazy / sludgy off brown with nice tannish head.  Earthy, oaky and alcohol nose.  Coating thick on the palate.  Taste of black tea with an alcohol warming.  Malt for sure with lingering hops not noticed in the taste.  This is a great beer and so much better than Arrogant!

Pour is a dark ruby red that is impenetrable to light, thin light tan head.  Aroma is woody, vanilla, fruity and mild notes of alcohol.  Flavor is much of the same.  Palate is sweet then bitter...wow so not impressed with this, hoping for better.  Arrogant Bastard is much much much better.  This lacks hop flavor and aroma...damn...but i gotta rerate, as much as i was hoping for better, its still good...

Timfoolery and I have been looking for this beer and finally found it at a wine shop in Davis, CA. Poured a copper color with little head. I could smell the hops upon first pour. Got some of the bittnerness, but was backed up with a malty finish. Excellent on the palate. As it warmed a little the alcohol became more present, but still a wonderful beer.

Cloudy copper with thin off-white head.  Huge hop aroma, hints of citrus.  The aroma is a warning for what is to come.  Your first sip is big with hop flavor then the bitterness barrels down.  Malt plays a big part to balance this big brew making it feel think on the tongue but it still finishes dry.  A very satisfying beer.

Bottled@Akkurat. Deep murky copper coloured with small beige head, that stays for quite a while. Aroma is full of fruits, wood, nectar and mild notes of syrupy sweetness as well as some notes of alcohol. Flavour is quite much the same along with some vanilla and mild plummy notes too. Rather sweet for most of the part, but also some bittering notes preventing the sweetness to totally take over. Really pleasant!

Poured into a standard Stone pintglass. A deeper, murky amber pour. About the perfect line of head which rose just over the brim. 

Full of citrus and pine scents. A beautiful, complex aroma of soft and sweet maltiness backbone, moderately toasted, some floral like scents.

Man, this is smooth and rich. The body of this is everything I love in the feel of a beer. Pretty much perfect in the feel. The bitter hoppiness is there, but they are amazingly balanced with a soft, and slightly sweet backbone. I find myself pondering over how wonderfully smooth it is again. Stone has created something of a masterpiece with this beer, with a near perfect blend of flavours. The alcohol is certainly there, but it continues to be quite an easy drinker considering. Thumbs up, and certainly recommended.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2009 overall very nice brew.  reminds me of a higher alcohol version of ommegang abbey ale?  very fruity on the nose, taste is moderately sweet, dried fruits, alcohol is slightly noticeable but not offensive.  Nice finish.  would definitly buy again.  whereas ommegang abbey is more drinkable this has the higher alcohol.  both great brews

UPDATED: APR 14, 2009 2006 Bottle, shared w/ and compliments of danielcurtis81. Simply put: AB Amplified. This was this first time I¬íve tried DB so I¬ím curious to try it fresh and compare to this aging. Got lots of hops and lots of dry roasted malts. Excellent character to please the aquired craft taste.

Pours to a murky reddish brown with a slight off-white head that lingers to about quarter-glass and leaves okay lacing. Aroma is malty raisin with earth scents. Mouthfeel is fairly thick and sweet, with hoppy bitterness creeping in. Flavor is more malty raisin than hoppy citrus (as I had hoped), leading  to a fairly bland, bittersweet finish.

I much prefer the hopped up Arrogant Bastard over his Double relative.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 2006 Edition, bottled. Every time I sample a beer that¬ís been wonderfully aged it reminds me to be patient although it is so hard! The aging added some very enjoyable sweetness. Poured a rich red hue. Filled the mouth with hop flavors and finishes with malt flavors and some dried fruits.
2007 Release: Much the same as the ‚Äô06. This one was fresh and didn‚Äôt have as much sweetness. I need to learn to do vertical tastings to compare.

Draft at Tyler‚Äôs.  This is the biggest bastard of all.  Dark copper pour with a nearly yellow head.  Tons of resiny and fruity hops and caramel and sweet malts right behind in abundance with peaty notes as well.  Surprisingly delicate floral notes somewhere behind the sensual assault.  Sticky sweet palate, and can definitely taste the alcohol.  Good, but certainly not subtle.  But you weren‚Äôt expecting subtle, were you?

Magnificent aroma, fluffy white head with a red tint to it, thick unfiltered body. Tastes of sugars, hops, spices, and dark fruits. Warms you up quick. Unless you are used to this, sip it.  The hop spice goes away somewhat at the six month mark, and evolves into an even more magical brew with time.
An insane brew. Crazy aroma, very dark in color and STRONG! I though the first AB was instense... who was i kidding?! Can‚Äôt wait to score the magnum bottle come New Years Eve!

Aroma is very sweet and fruity, not as hoppy as Arrogant Bastard.  Alcohol aroma becomes more evident as it warms. Pours a hazy reddish-brown with no head; really not very attractive looking.  Taste is sweet fruits, caramel, perhaps a bit of peat.  Hoppy finish with an after taste dominated by caramel, but also a little smokiness.  Alcohol is well-hidden in the flavor.

Number three in my bastard tasting, and by far the best.  Orange-red pour, very hazy.  Thing tan had with nice lacing on the glass.  A sugary sweet alcohol aroma with lots of hops.  Hints of raisin and caramel.  Sweet malty flavor with raisin and caramel.  Hops hit you like a punch in the face.  Very fruity with citrus and grapefruit.  A bit on the harsh side, but a good beer.

Bottle, 22oz. A reddish golden beer with a slight haze. Dense, beige head of low height. Quite intense aroma with lots of sweetish maltyness, beefstock, caramel, piney and resiny hops, and some alcohol. Maybe a bit too sweet on the palate, with a lasting alcohol warmth, but there‚Äôs enough hops to justice it. Piney, resiny bitterness with a citrusy touch. Sweet and bitter finish. A big, bold beer, but very satisfying. (080811)

Somewhat cloudy amber color with a thin light tan head.  Sweet aroma with notes of honey, alcohol and hopes.  Some citrus flavor but mostly hops with a little bit of malt taste coming though with maybe a bit of caramel.  Finishes with a piney-alcoholy bitterness that hung around.  A more bitter and hoppy version of the regular that I think they could have done more with.

Surprising red fruit-punch color. Incredible nose of berries, citrus, passion fruit, faint chocolate, and hop. Flavor goes a bit flat after that nose while showing no subtlety. There is a mildly sweet and fruity start before the wave of bitterness hits and sticks for long finish. Not much betwixt. Not well balanced IMO, even compared to other Stone beers. The result is interesting but smells much better than it tastes.

650ml bottle. Clear reddish orange beer with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, dry fruit, citrus and hops. Flavor is sweet malty, dry fruit, some citrus, some caramel and very bitter with a warming alcohol character. Long and bitter finish. This is a nice and hoppy beer, but a bit too sweet for my taste.

Wow is all i have to say! This is a strong beer. Aroma of hops and berries. Dark murky appearance. Flavor hits you strong but takes it down a notch with semi sweet flavor. A real thick palate. Overall its a really good beer that complements its alcohol level with a taste of sweetness, but I rather drink Arrogant bastard ale then the double.
Super strong, but very subtle.  You would think that a 10% drink would be stronger, but it was excellently balanced.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: Dark murky copper with a hint of red. No visible carbonation. Thick one finger head. Aromas is heavy malt, spices and fruit. Smooth mouth feel which gets bubbly and bitter, followed by a pleasant taste of alcohol. After a few sips the taste gets sweeter and fruitier.

Pours thickly into glass with a rich dark amber color, thin off-white head.  Heavy blast of alcohol and peppery hops, sweet malts hinted at.  Real sweet malty caramel taste, a lot of aggressive citric hops.  The alcohol is certainly there, but doesn‚Äôt come out as much as the aroma lets on.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2013 A true freak of a beer and easily the best thing I¬íve tasted out of the states. At first it was a bit much for me, but the balance between the malts and the hops is otherworldly...one for the ages

Thanks to Rustychiles for this one.

Pours super-dark brown with no head whatsoever. Nose is all malt sweetness, very reminiscent of a Barleywine. First taste reflects that impression. Lots of dark fruit phenolics. Hop aroma is surprisingly restrained, especially for a Stone beer. Fairly balanced, could use a lot more aging. I think this sample was too young for my palate.

2007 vintage
Many thanks to scthaden on BA for this extra.  Pours a dark Hazy amber with little head after an aggressive pour and some spotty lacing.  Smell is butter, oranges, rum soaked figs and raisins, and alcohol.  Taste is much the same with a huge piney sharp bitternes and a buttery creamy rum-raisin flavor.  Lots of toffee in the flavor as well.  One of my favorites and it just gets better with time.

2006 Vintage. On tap at Stone Brewing World Bistro and Gardens. Pours amber/deep red almost purple. No real head. Sweet and spicy aroma of plums and blood oranges, there is also a nice aroma of sugar. Flavor begins mild and smooth, almost like a rich Cabernet/Merlot. The dominate flavor and aroma is alcohol, it really hits you in the sinuses. Even after a few years, the alcohol is still very intense.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2011 2007 release. Now this is one fine beer. I love Arrogant Bastard so I was not only very happy to find a bottle of this on a road trip but I also had high expectations. The Double Bastard didn¬ít let me down! Pours a reddish color, nice clarity, with a thin off-white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, cherries, alcohol and some pine. The flavors are sharp and delicious. Lots of sweet caramel malt, some toffee, with a blast of hops, pine and some grapefruit. Finishes bitter with just a little alcohol showing but my palate adjusted quickly (or bowed down to it¬ís goodness) and this was just so damn tasty. A wonderful brew that I can¬ít wait to have again.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2009 Bomber - Poured a cloudy dark amber in color with a small light tan head that faded quickly.  Aroma was spicy and full of hops.  Flavor was pretty unique with lots of hops and hop bitterness.  Alcohol not that apparent... until you finish... then you know.  Excellent beer... will seek out again!    - Original Rating - Sample at the 2008 VT Brewers Fest - Poured a very dark amber in color with a very small light tan head.  Aroma is of coffee, brown sugar, caramel and a good amount of floral hops.  Flavor is somewhat hoppy and a bit malty sweet to start with the hop bitterness coming in at the end.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Really good!

Now this is a great brew. 22 oz bottle pours amber color with a little head.  Taste is very strong bitterness and hops.  If your love Arrogant Bastard you will probably like this, even though this is his older brother. Can be harsh if you let it get warm, but cold tastes great.  If you like Stone products you will like this.

22 oz bottle, pured into chalice. An amber brown beer with almost no head. Pleasant aroma - coffee and brown sugar, fruit. Great palate with spice, coriander, toast, vanilla, yeast. Long finish- not too dry or sweet. Really nice beer in spite of very high ETOH. Drank this with spicy lamb curry- highly recommended.

Pours a murky orange brown ¬ñ not the prettiest looking pour.  Smells of citrusy/floral hops. First sip is much less hoppy than the aroma indicated.  Very smooth and sweet with a welcomed bitterness to finish.  Slight honey taste could be the beginning of some oxidation as this bottle has been in my cellar for about six months. This puppy is very drinkable as the 10% ABV is hidden.
Maybe the best beer I‚Äôve had. A step beyond the regular bastard which is already a classic.

‚Äô07 bomber.  I would call this a Barley Wine... pours a deep red with very little head which quickly dissipates.  strong aroma filled with a touch of alcohol, dark fruits and sweet sugar.  huge hop profile, especially on the finish, but is well hidden by the dominating malts.  as soon as it hits your tongue, you can feel the huge body character behind this beer.  very full and round.... filled with dynamic qualities of a world class beer.  sweet and spicy on the front, very soft on the sides and thick and malty on the top with caramel, citrus, candi sugar, dark fruits and a touch of oak.  Wonderful strong, sticky hop filled finish that sticks with you.... sticky and sweet.

Pours a dark brownish ruby with a moderate sized tan head.  Aroma of grapefruit, tofee, toast, butter, pine-soaked caramel candies.  Big malty taste hides the hops a bit.  Sweet caramel dominates with brown sugar, grapefruit, and a very Stone-esque earthy hop flavor.  Finishes with buttery hops and toasty aftertaste.  Thick and full-feeling, pretty nice stuff.

Smells a lot like oaked bastard, caramel sweetness and strong hops.  Flavor is much sweeter than regular, almost sticky sweet with big bitter hops on top, almost doesn‚Äôt pull it off, but somehow, it works.  There‚Äôs not much here we haven‚Äôt seen before, though this is well made if not well formulated.  With this current brewing trend of "More is better", sometimes, more is just more.  Good, but not great.

Dark red, maybe a bit brown in color, fitted with an off-white colored head behind some sticky lacing. Fruity smell as well as a smell I can only describe as rotten pine. Taste was good and hoppy, certainly a nice malt base here too. I do have to say some of the bitterness had some harshness to it; harshness does not equal badass. Heavier side of medium bodied and a medium amount of carbonation. Overall, good beer for sure, but I can‚Äôt help but think a different hop choice could make this so much better. Don‚Äôt take the above comment the wrong way, it‚Äôs just my opinion and Stone does a damn fine job as it is. Would buy again.

2004 bottle courtesy the thebeercellar. Thanks Matt!  Drinking this with my buddy Charles and celebrating the 4th in WInston-Salem. This has aged very nicely. None of the hot alcohol flavors that you can usually taste in fresh arrogant bastard or double bastard.  Still a lot of carbonation and a lasting yellow white head amidst a deep red amber body.  Nose has some brown sugar, strong caramel malts, hints of piney hops still kicking around. Flavor is really yummy.  Nice caramel, brown sugar, woody flavors with a bit of bittnerness in the finish. Alcohol is very well hidden.  It‚Äôs been a while since I had this and I was very pleased with this nicely aged bottle.  Thanks for hooking it up, Matt!

2006 Keg on draught at Stone Bistro. Pours with a slightly murky brown body with a small, tight, off-white head that leaves great lacing. Aroma is complex, with currants, raisins, and light oxidation. Tastes is amazing, very rich and spicey with a really long duration, and a nice alcohol bite at the finish. A little bit of sherry and other oxidized notes. Lively bubbles.

22 oz Bomber-Pours a cloudy, reddish color w/no head but good lacing. Sweet aroma. Sweet, sticky, hoppy flavor w/a very rough edge, kind of woodsy & smokey w/traces of dark fruit. Oak barrell taste as well. Alcohol was very evedent, definately a sipper.

~Pours dark red with big creamy off white head. Some lacing.
~Citrus hop grapefruit aroma combined with a malty sweetness.
~Sweet flavor but extremely hoppy. Has hints of fruit in there and smokiness.
~Thick and sticky feel. Alcohol tinge present.
~Great flavor on this one! I cant believe it has 10% alc. Definetly one I will enjoy again.
The back of the bottle gets harder and harder to read with each sip.

On Tap at Bier Tasting event at Boston¬ís Bistro & Pub in Dayton. This is just a more hard hitting version of the original bastard. Tastes like an epic battle between malt and hops, both struggling for control of your taste buds.  What the hell just happened in my mouth?
A lot of malt and molasses in the aroma touched lightly with hops.  Very smooth sweet malt with a small bitter finish going down.  Some alcohol is apparent towards the end.

Bottle, 2007 release.  Pours a hazy, copper-red body with thin yellow-white head.  Aroma of hops, caramel malts, and some fruit.  Thick mouthfeel with a complex profile of flavors: grapefruit hops, caramel malts, molasses, citrus, and brown sugar.  Green floral hops finish with a slight alcohol and aspirin aftertaste.

Huge light brown head, that lasts a long time.  Aroma - heavy malt, dark bread, light hops, resin, and dough.  Also allspice and pepper.Initial flavor is sweet and moderately acidic.  Can really taste the alcohol.  This was good, but not great.  I have a few others that I¬íll keep for a year or so to see what happens.

22 oz. bottle.  2007 vintage.  Pours a dark, leather color.  Small, thin white head.  Aroma of dark fruits, molasses, citrus hops.  Very thick mouthfeel.  Flavor is a wonderful explosion of hop resin, raisins, caramel malt.  Long bitter finish with strong warming alcohol notes.  Outstanding beer, wish we could get it in Atlanta.

The beer pours an amber red with a thin quickly disappearing head. The nose is a thick mix of sweet malts (dark fruit and berries) with a dry hop. The flavor is big but simple. It is defiantly hoppy but with a good balance from the sweet malts. The finish is a sweet hop that last for days.

Thanks to Taverner for the bottle. Pours a caramel brown with a thick tan head. Big hops, caramel, malt, citrus aroma. Sharp pungent hop taste with a thick malty backbone. Medium spicy body. This is not for the faint of the taste bud and pretty much reduced all beers tasted afterward to wimpiness. Awesome brew.

Delicious looking beer. Pours a hazy dark reddish copper with a modest orangy-tan head that leaves lacing. The aroma is a nice combination of sweet caramel maltiness balanced by a fair amount of fruity and piney hops. The flavor of this beer hits close to the full spectrum of tastes I love in beer. It starts with a sweet caramel maltiness which gives way to darker roast barley notes and finishes with a dry bitter hoppiness. The only thing that kept it from a 10 in flavor was the alcohol heat overpowers the hop finish a bit. Regardless, this is a fantastic brew.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 Re-rate 2/24/10: Bottle at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Deep clear amber with a beige head. Aroma of piney and resinous hops, smoky hints, some cookie-ish malt and caramel notes. Flavor is mostly bitter, hoppy, oily and resinous with some alcohol, fruits and light malty sweetness. Full-bodied. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

2007 bottle. Very dark amber color with a big and slowly-diminishing beige head. Juicy hoppy nose with lots of citrus and some pine and some malty, a bit cookie-ish, notes. Flavor is malty and sweet with caramel, biscuits, hints of bread and lots of hops, which are later getting intense, leading to a very bitter finish with some grapefruit and oranges and mild tongue-tickling alcohol notes. Body is quite full and the mouthfeel is oily. This one is nice! 8/4/7/4/15=3.8

22 oz. 2006 release. not sure how i have yet to rate.... anyways. pours deep copper with small dissipating head. aroma is huge sweet caramel malt. mouthful is huge malt that starts to fade to a nice bitterness but then is overtaken by the alcohol. not the best finnish. i had had a couple stone age with big abv finishes... i think i would rate a fresh btl higher cuz i do not recall such an alcohol finnish.

1pt 6oz single from 6-Pack & Subs, Lancaster, PA...pours hazy deep amber, small off-white head...sweet smell of malts, dark fruits (bit of a musty smell as it warms)...flavor of raisins, licorice, hops, alcohol (grape juice as it warms)...smooth mouthfeel...lots going on here...to me, not as good as the AB and OAB (haven¬ít had the ODB yet) but still, really good.

Easily the best beer I have had in recent memory.  It is surprisingly smooth for such a hoppy beer.  22 oz bottle, drunk slightly above room temperature.  Had a very small yet noticeable hint of fruitiness.  Pours a nice deep orange with a very small and thin head.  Great mouthfeel.  Excellent bitter finish.

22 oz bomber. Pours a reddish orange color with a small white head. White lace ings my glass. Nose is hops & malt.  Mouthfeel is heavy with moderate carbonation.  As others have said, a very powerful ale. An absolute assault on the palate and tastebuds. Strong hop presence with a malty, caramel background. Bitter hop finish.

A red beer with a small disappering head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of berries. The flavor is great; totally dominated by hops but combined with berries and roasted notes (chocolate?). A wonderful beer.

Damn this stuff has some punch.  Deep brownish red pour with a relatively thin head.  Almost abrasive hoppy aroma and flavor that really takes a couple sips to settle in.  Full body and flavor with a nice warming touch as you get into it.  After the tongue recovers from the hop assault, it has a very pleasant malty taste to it.  Some age would treat this beer well.  Would recommend for any hop lover...

Bomber poured into a sniffer. Produced a good bit of tan head that turned quickly to lace, all this on top of a reddish brown body 

Aromas of sweet malts caramel and a light hop finish to the nose 

Tastes some what like a barley wine with a nice hop finish at the end but as it warms the sweetness of the malts comes out along with the alcohol warmth

Full body not much carbonation on the tongue

This is a good brew, but defiantly a sipper. Not something I make a habit of but I will drink it again
Double Bastard is some serious business.  If you can drink more than one of these in a sitting you have bigger balls than I do.

Tongue, ouch, tastebuds, ouch... a powerful ale. I¬íve had this at a Stone tasting in DC on tap, just had it on bottle. Too much of a hop wallop. I¬ím trying to get a feel for Stone¬ís beer. They are good, but just a bit overpowering. Poured a little darker than regular Arrogant Bastard, more sticky, less sweet. Thin head (maybe it was just the pour). I drank it VERY slowly... just because it¬ís a beer to treat with some level of respect. Malts can be detected, but the hop bitters it out too much. I remember the tap version being a bit more mellow. Bought it with a few other Stone brews, may try those a bit later today. (Bottle Pour 5/10/2008)

Compliments of DrBayern (Thanks Matt!), pours from bomber, forming small to medium off white head of foam.  Aroma is of mossy wood malted hops with wet forrest hints, caramel burnt oats and plums hint too.  Flavour is of complete smoothness, caramel malts with a hint of hop bite towards the very end.  Jeez, what an incredible beer people, plums and raisins swrill among this lovely beer.  Truly a lovely example of American beer.  Thanks Matt!

Hope to try it on tap.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
i drank this beer out of a tremens tulip.

this beer poured a cloudy (perhaps sediment from cooling it in the rapid beverage chiller) orange-ish brown with very little and and little lacing. carbonation abounds. i should add that the beer cleared up and i didn¬ít see any sediment in the glass, so i am not sure what that was all about, but it was inconsequential. 

this beer smells of raisins and caramel. a bit of spice in the nose as well. i can detect the alcohol, which is not a bad thing.

the taste is consistent with the smell, however it becomes much more complex as it warms. i can best describe the beginning of this beer as very agressive, starting sweet and finishing bitter, however superbly balanced.

the mouthfeel is quite full with hella carbonation. makes me wonder where the head went?

i shared this with barefootbrewer and another, but i think i could drink a whole bomber by myself. highly drinkable in my opinion. quite like a barleywine. actually closer to a barleywine than the last barleywine i had, avery hog heaven.
Not really good at the psudo wine comparisons. However, The Best Stone I¬íve ever had...

Clear red pour with a big head that leaves a nice lacing behind as it settles. Complex aroma with a sweet malty smell with some pear notes and caramel. Taste explodes with alcohol and carbonation, really coats the mouth

Deep mahogony pour with a small off white head that dissipates quickly leaving no lacing and little head retention.  Quite a bit going on in the aroma. The first thing I noticed was a sweet, sugary malt smell with a heavy dose of dark fruit. Definitely a smell of alcohol in this one to burn the nostrils. I didn¬ít get a whole lot of hops in this smell.  Definitely dominated by the initial malty sweetness with heavy caramel and brown sugar yumminess. I got a bit more of the hops in the taste and it was balanced very well given the ABV.  Syrupy but prickly, this definitely coats your mouth but has enough carbonation to tickle the tongue a bit.  This one is certainly an assault on the senses. I couldn¬ít imagine having more than one of these in a sitting. Complex but also in-your-face, this is definitely a unique Stone brew.

copper body, with a good off-white head.  aroma of caramely malt and citrusy hops.  sweet and malty taste, a bit too sweet for me, so i knock o point or two off.  medium bodied, with an oily palate.  overall, an intersteing, but not particularly great attempt.  much too high an abv price to pay for the experience.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 22oz bottle, poured red/brown with very little head.  Aroma of hops, citrus, and caramel malt, and slightly oaky.  Taste is similar to a barley wine, smooth, slightly sweet, and hoppy.  Very good!

22 oz. bottle.  Aroma is excellent, with a strong oak/smoky aroma and a hint of alcohol.  Appearance is dark red-brown, with a small head.  Alcohol is apparent at first, but diminishes after the first couple sips.  Malts balance with hops quite nicely.  Leaves an aftertaste not completely unlike a decent bourbon.  Very nice job here.

A- Pours a deep blackish crimson with light bubbles escaping to the top reminding me of a guiness pour. A small but thick head reins over the top of this monster.

S- Smells oaty, earty, very similar to oaked AB. A little lighter than I would have liked.

T- The taste is sharp with huge alcohol notes interspersed with sweet malt, coffee, mixed dark fruit.

M- Thick with ample carbonation.

D- This is definitely a sipper but for how much it lets the alcohol through, I am surprised I am able to drink so much.

Another winner from Stone.  Pours a ruby red with a tan head that dissipates to a thin layer of bubbles.  Aroma is caramel malt, with, of course, boatloads of hops.  Flavor is a bit like Oaked AB, but I think there is a heavier malt flavor to this one.  Hops are obviously American flavors... grapefruit, some pine.  I¬ím not sure what I like better, Stone beers, or the insults they print on the bottle.

I have to admit that after having the Arrogant Bastard, which I didn¬ít really care for, I wasn¬ít sure that I would like the Double Bastard, as I have never considered myself a real hop-head. 

Well, many thanks to Matt at the beer store for talking me into trying this gem. 

This poured a gorgeous garnet color into a chalice. Great, creamy and sticky lace which lasted forever. Huge aromas of hops and malts. Incredible hop flavor balanced by incredible malt flavor. And the ABV was so well hidden that I couldn¬ít even taste it! This went down easier than probably any beer I¬íve head 

A truly great beer. Don¬ít pass this by. You¬íll love it even if you, like me, aren¬ít a hophead!

Bottle. Aroma of grapefruit hops, floral/pine hops, with nougat, fig, sweetness arising from the malt. Flavor continues along the same lines, and while it was far from "punishingly unforgiving" as stone claims, I actually preferred the fact that it stayed in very admirable balance. I found this very comparable to Yulesmith winter, which I had just a few nights ago, but while the sweetness in the Yulesmith I felt grew into near oppressiveness by the end, I found this brew to stay balanced, smooth, drinkable, etc. throughout. I hate the word "balanced" and I can¬ít believe I just used it for a Stone brew. But word. There it is. Good stuff.

Bottle, 2007.  Pours a deep red/amber/brown color with a small white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of caramel malt, some floral hops.  Flavor mainly of malt, some floral and piney hops, faint grapefruit notes.  Delicious!  Thick mouthfeel, so this is a sipper, but is one of the most balanced American strong ales.  Sweet, but not too sweet and thick, but not too thick.  Excellent, best ASA I¬íve had to date.  I love this beer! (Oh yeah, also the label is awesome!)

...the bigger, badder brother of satan himself.  This shit is really hardcore, and will give you super human strength.  Massively complex, dark and roasty, yet sweet to mask the high alcohol content. I would like to drink this again, but you can¬ít get it in Florida.  This will make you a true badass just by drinking it.

Bottle at Oldsmar Tap House.  Pours a rich red-amber with a smattering of white foam on top.  Very thick palate, with rich, chewy malts and a slight woodiness.  This is counterbalanced by a monster hoppiness loaded with pine and grapefruit.  The alcohol is noticeable as well.  Very big and bold.  Awesome!

on tap at 1702 nice chestnut color with whie lasting head.  aroma of sweet and almost a little spice.  flavor is sweet and malty and young.  slight alcohol.  well rounded sweet and bitter. really nice fresh on tap.
Bottle.  Pours a deep ruby red with little head.  Sweet barleywine aroma with a thick alcohol prescence.  Thick, malty, sweet, alcohol taste.  Thick full bodied palate.  A delectable brew.

Cloudy orange beer with a tight orange-cream head. Massive sweet cookie malt and resinous hop aroma. Huge hop attack bolstered by thick chewy matls, something vaguely spicy in there, gargantuan flavour and heavy mouthfeel. Intense but not overbearing, big alcohol is almost undetectable. A gorgeous beer!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a thick creamy, foamy light brown/beige head. Aromas of hops and flavors of sweet dark fruit, alot of hops with a nice lingering finish.... One of the best ive ever had.

Bottle. Pours ruby brown with a beige head. The first sniff was all hops, which quickly gave way to caramel, brown sugar, and fruit (berry, plum). Medium/full body. Flavor starts with sweet malt, caramel, just a hint of chocolate, and plum. Then a slight roasted flavor emerges, followed by floral and piny hops. The finish is long , dry, and pleasantly bitter. Very good.

Beer pours dark caramel brown with solid two fingered head and immense lacing.  Strong aroma of piney hops.  Flavor was lots of piney hops with super loads of caramel and some fruitiness (apples?).  A pretty high level of bitterness, reminiscent of the regular AB, but with a much higher sweetness level as well.  Pretty well balanced.  A HUGE beer of immense proportions.
This beer just has way too much malt sweetness and not enough hops to balance it.....super cloyingly sweet....this is gross...I can¬ít belive it got a 99%.....but hey I can¬ít like everything right?

Poured a very dark with light head. It smelled very strongly of hops. It felt slightly bitter with minimal bubbles in his mouth and tasted very hoppy yet smooth. It wasn¬ít quite as amazingly smooth as the regular Arrogant Bastard, but it was close. Still remained pretty drinkable despite how heavy and high in alcohol it was. Good, but still liked the original Bastard the best.

Bottle. Pours coppery orange, with a very thin, lacy off-white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, citrus and pine hops, hint of alcohol. Flavor is more big malt and caramel up front, followed by a big pine and resin hoppiness, with a very sweet back end before a fairly high bitterness, lasting hops finish. Mouthfeel is very big, a bit sticky, moderate carbonation, not too thick. Chewy, as the previous reviewer noted. Good beer, very interesting balance.

Dark reddish brown color in my snifter. Head is tan and thick, with a full 2 fingers of height. The lacing is enormous.

Aroma is hugely hoppy with tons of west-coast citrus and pine, but there¬ís also a big caramel sweetness.

Flavor follows the nose pretty closely, as malty sweetness fills your mouth, nearly inducing chewing. Hops then rip through the palate with a massive dose of oily grapefruit rind. Alcohol is quite apparent but not in a yucky way. It¬ís more peppery and sweet.

Mouthfeel is thick and well-carbonated. The booziness gets to be intrusive with some warmth and the drinkability takes a dip for this. Killer beer overall though.

Its Big, I¬íll give it that.  Pours clear amber with a pretty big head.  Very Hoppy aroma, which is matched by the big malty flavor.  The massive hops ans malts provide a bizzaro balance to this off balance beer.  Its really good and memorable, always a good combo.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 A lot of hops on the nose, mostly floral hops.  Some maltiness as well.  Very attractive in appearance, a ruby/brown color, clear, with a medium white head.  Flavor is sticky-sweet, malty, slight alcohol.  The finish has a wicked hop bite that lingers for quite some time.  The mouthfeel of this beer medium to thick.  Enjoyable.  Definitely better than the regular Bastard.  Note:  Revisit on 6/16/2010 with a 2007 release bottle.  Much more chocolatey and less hoppy on the nose.  Fruity as well.  Closer to a barley wine.  Flavor is malty, fruity.  The finish still has a lingering hop presence, piney, resiny.  Interesting!

Sampled from a large, novelty size 70 dollar bottle.  Intense, almost overwhelming, but just right to keep coming back.  Flavor of all things natural.  A relentless brew that lives up to its name, logo, and story.
Eh, pretty good beer. This is not really my style of beer so I may rerate eventually.

Bottle. Pours a reddish orange with a small off white head. The aroma is quiet sweet with lots of molasses and some bubble gum. The flavor is dominated by the hops. Lots of bitterness and strong Alcohol rule here. FInish is heavily bitter and lasts forever. Tasted this with the arrogant bastard also and to me it was just to much. The Arrogant bastard was so much nicer.

Bottled. Poured clear, tawny with a tan, foamy head. Nose was caramel and hop resin. Flavor was sweet, caramel malt, alcohol. Finish was slightly hoppy. Mouthfeel was medium, sticky, with alcohol in the finish. A fine big beer.

2002 thanks to Atlanta group.  Poured into snifter glass.  Pours medium brown.  Malty, sour nose.  Smells pretty sharp.  Rich malt, very full.  Alcohol is there, but not in the front, noticed only in the aftertaste really.  Very, very delicious beer.  Could drink this for quite a while.
Bottle. Reddish amber colour with a nice head. Nice aroma of caramel and hops. Flavour of caramel and hops. Ends up nicely and bitter.

Double wow! Talk about a hefty beer. the great thing is, you don¬ít even realize its so massive until halfway through it. goes down nice and smooth, not too hoppy. Goes down as one of brewing¬ís great achievements.
What a heavy beer. Thick luscious head for a 10% beer. Pours a heavy amber hue with ruby hints. Very hoppy yet balanced.
Powerful, intense, malty.  Pours really nice into a deep amber color with a nice head.  Taste is intense of well balanced malts, and alcohol.
Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle: Complex and big, sweet malty notes with fruit, hops and caramel touches. The body is heavy, oily and thick. Lives up to expectations.

Thanks to Geoff from Firehouse for hooking me up with these bottles in LV.  Pours a nice robust caramel red, and the lacing head is chino, spidery and fine.  An excellent nose, with a spicy hop bouquet and a firm malt twist.  It¬ís a very creamy beer in the mouth, almost feels like a steam beer in that respect.  Excellent hop translucence mixes with the malt bop and finishes with a clean, refreshing albeit exceedingly alcoholic zing.  Not for the novice beer drinker!!

Orange translucent color. minimal head. Malty nose with hint of spiciness.Initial flavor is malty with high alcohol notes and somewhat yeasty followed by Intense and complex hopiness that lasts for a while
Pours cloudy carmel with a redish head, flavor is a lot of malt and a lot of hops, slightly bitter finish, really tasty beer
Pours hazy, caramel red. Head is reddish. Tons of malt up front, hops even a little earthiness in this one. Creamy, good body. Great beer.

Bottle. Clear red-brown with a creamy bubbly beige rather short lasting head leaving a good creamy lacing. Aroma of roasty malt, chocolate, caramel. Great mouthfeel. Sweet nice malty alco bombing hoppy flavour.
Dark red-brown color. Creamy head. Fruit and malt aroma. Strong apricot candy flavor. A bitter finish but not overpowering. Hint of smoke. Lots of hops. Massive beer.

bottle: pours a beautiful  crimsonbrown with a good sized tan head. aroma is a good bitter smelling hops, very sticky caramel malts. both the hops and malts are pretty extreme but balance each other out very nicely. good amount of fruit also. a very nice aroma that i really enjoy. the flavour is pretty strong upfront with a good hard bitter hop that goen into a nice amount of deep caramel malt. the finish is a sticky malt with a great hop bitterness again, with some raisiny taste, very enjoyable for 10%

Pours like a thick toffee into the glass, the carbonation swirling around the 2-finger tan head nicely.  The nose is wonderfully malty, with caramel and candi sugar.  Big malt upfront, with strong bitters coming through mid-palate and lathering more boldly through the back pull.  The sweetness contains some caramel, ripened peaches (definitely fruit, but not overbearing), and hints of roasted peat.  The ABV is nicely integrated.  The mouthfeel is thick, almost creamy without being "chewy".  There is plenty going on here, nicely complex.  A nice contrast presents, with a totally different ending than beginning.  Sweet vs. bitter is definitely explored in this strong brew!  I wonder if this exploration was "full force", or if was approached in a linear, progressive continuity.  (The only downside is that it feels a little "balls to the wall" all the way through.... maybe that¬ís the appeal.)

Trappist Glass.  Pours Reddish brown with a frothy head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of sweet malts and hops.  Huge tatse.  The bitterness takes over fairly quickly.  Pretty gigantic beer.  Has a barley wine feel.
Reddish brown pour.  Aroma of hops and caramel.  Taste of malt and smoke with a nice finish.  Smooth for the higher alcohol content.

Bottle @ Yespr tasting.[thank you, Storm]
Pours a wonderful red with a small creamy yellowish head. Aroma is packed with American hops and a light caramel background. Fine, creamy mouthfeel. The flavour nearly burns with all those hops. Light caramel and chocolate behind it. Some woody tartness as well. A bit too unbalanced.

[Courtesy of Storm, session @ yespr] Deep amber with tiny short lasting head. Sweet hoppy aroma with caramel notes. Sweet vinious flavor with hops, caramel, ripe fruits and caramel. Strong alcohol notes. Ends bitter.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark, red-hued amber color with a bit of head.  It smells like a juniper tree, very hop-dominated with some fruit and alcohol.  The taste starts out with malts and fruits and then quickly turns to the hop flavor and alcohol presence.  Finishes dry, bitter and earthy.  It¬ís a very thick, complex beer.  Far too hop-dominated and bitter for my tastes, but fans of that style will love this beer.

very nice aroma of caramel malt/yeast esters/spicy hops, very malty and bittery (grapefruit pithy bitter) - i can¬ít decide if I like it or not though, it¬ís almost like drinking hopped pancake syrup - over-rated as are most ¬íextreme¬í beers

Bomber. Pours a dark red/amber with a thin white head. The aroma is mostly hops and fruits. The taste starts out being quite fruity with a sweet full malt. It also has a strong alcohol presence that kicks. Later I found the hops to really stand out. So strong and yet somehow drinkable and easy. Great. If this is evil I don¬ít want to be good.

75 cl bottle, thanks to Storm. pours clear and golden red with a little lacing white head. hoppy and fruity aroma. Flavour is nice hoppy and with a light liqourice and peppery note. Dry almost woody finish. Ends dy hoppy and with a lingering caramel malt flavour. Solid and hoppy - great.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Thanks to Hellbilly for this!  Pours mahogany with tan head and thick lacing.  Caramel malts on the nose.  Big malty backbone with a blast of hops. Nice lingering pomegranate finish. in my opinion this is the best in the bastard series

This is some dank shit. I consider it mothers milk. Strong and in your face with a big nose a full flavor. At 10% this beer can get on quite quick but is still very drinkable. Good combo of hops and malt, very thick beer that punches you in the mouth. Great beer overall. You¬íre Not Worthy!!!!
Different from the original arrogant bastard. Nice aroma. Much more maltyness than the regular bastard. Much less hops as well. Good drink overall with just a bit of alcohol bite.

overrated,  sure it has 2% more ethanol, which only detracts from the experience,  double what else?  not as solid a malt base as the plain ol¬í ordinary bastard.  It has a clear orange red appearance and a foamy head than slowly bubbles up and can be restored with a swirl.  another example where double does not translate into better -

Courtesy of Dragonstout. Pours a murky copper color with a foamy white head. Aroma is mostly hop and booze. Tastes of caramel, hops, grain, honey, dark sweet fruit, some spice. Finishes with a slight hop presence. Mouth feel is mostly solid bodied with a sweet and tart finish.
Bottle Dark amber pour with decent head. Floral hop aroma and flavor. Decently complex. Honestly, I¬ím kinda disappointed as the AB seemed to be much more complex, perhaps I need to try the AB again.

Not a big fan of double bastard.  One AB is enough let alone double .  Has a big double alcohol taste for it being 10%.  I have had double beers that are 10% and I couldn¬ít tell at all.  Not so with this.  It¬ís just not a very enjoyable double drink.  Double the arrogance.  Double the terribleness. 

Double your pleasure. Double your fun.  Try it all with Double mint...Gum... eh never mind.
WOW! pours an amber orange color. aroma of hops and alcohol. Tastes of pineapple, extremely biter hops and alcohol. Drinking this is like taking a punch in the face.

Well. This beer is exactly what the desciprtionn says on the bottle. A Beast. Alchohol is not hidden at all, with a massive hop content to balance. Burns in the stomach once it¬ís there. Beautiful burnt orange, amber color when held to a light. As rugged and viscuous as this beer is, it is still somewhat balanced, and I reccommend to all.

Aroma is deep citrus and dark berries and a slight alcholoic bourbon sweetness. Pours a thick tan head.  Color is dark honey.  Mouthfeel is perfect-thick but just sparkly enough.   Taste and aroma are very similar to DFH 90 Min, but it¬ís all a little better and more sophisticated.  The flavor is the same as the aroma, but you get a refined bitter that is dry and very fresh - like a nose full of fresh hops.  The bitter makes this beer.  All the rest is good but the bitter is unique and very well balanced with it¬ís sweetness.  And that play masks the alcohol very very well.
This is a real joy.  Superb!
Thanks miketd.  The color was medium amber.  The head was creamy and off-white.  The aroma was sweet malt, alcohol, and candy.  The flavor was

My 666th rating, appropriately enough. Thanks to miketd for this sweetass .....extra! Pours a dark hazy orange amber with a two finger creamy orange head. The aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, citrusy hops, a little alcohol, mellow. The flavor is strong, sweet, caramel, a little alcohol, waxy grapefruit peel, mellow. The palate is full and smooth the malt adding quite the mouthfeel with the hops contributing a waxy backbone. Nice strong ale.

Bottle from dkachur, thanks Dan! Reddish brown color. Raisin and some flowery hops in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with raisin, pepper, nutmeg, blackcurrant, banana, plums and flowery and oily hops. Good complexity, full bodied, heavy on the tongue, well hidden alcohol. Satisfyingly balanced. Oily hopbitter aftertaste, almost vinous. Syrupy mouthfeel. A huge beer!
A nice sweet hoppy nose.Lots of hoppiness in this beer.Hops and caramel sweetness with a bitter swwet finish.The alcohol was hidden well.

nose of sweet malt and alcohol.  color is dark red with a slight white head and mild carbonation.  very full mouthfeel.  flavor is huge with hints of plum, raisons, toffee with a nice alcohol-induced complexity at the end.  where does a barley wine begin and an american strong ale end?  this definitely is reminiscent of a barley wine and a very good one.  this beer could probably age forever, but the malt wasn¬ít overpowering here and allowed for some subtle flavors to arise

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2008 one of a kind beer pour a nice very dark amber color with a small head oaky taste and smelll i can taste and feel the 10% alcohol in the bottom of you stomach but still enjoyed it

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2008 Pours a dark reddish brown color with a lingering head and decent lacing. Smelled of malt and citrus hops. Flavor was a nice malty character, brown sugar and dried fruits. Thick body with a lingering dryness and a l could barely taste the alcohol. It was super smooth and quite scary that it was that drinkable. Awesome brew! *****Update***** Just had a fresh 08. More bitter hops then I remember, the alcohol is noticable but still easy to drink. Another good brew by stone!

Unbelievable beer.... Stone is incapable of making a bad beer. 

Bottle courtesy of Overlord.  Poured a nice reddish brown with a small head but some impressive lacing. 

Smells hoppy and malty, fruity and dark as well.  Definite presence of alcohol as well. 

Loads of sweet malt on the taste with a wonderful hoppiness in the background.  I love Arrogant Bastard and Oaked Arrogant Bastard but this is a different animal altogether.  

Loved everything about this brew.  Probably my favorite American Strong.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2008 Side by side vertical of the 05, 06 and 07 releases done on 11/26/07. The 05 was in a growler poured at the brewery that day, and the 06 and 07 were in 22oz. bottles. I drank all three out of the same exact style of glasses, beginning with the youngest release.  Appearance: All three years pour almost exactly the same color, the 05 may be a touch lighter in color. Vibrant brown/red color with a thin off-white head. The head on the 06 lasts the longest by far, followed second by the 05.  Aroma: 07: Hoppy and spicy, not much maltiness, and there¬ís a touch of alcohol in the background. 06: Smells much sweeter, hops are much more subdued and sweet smelling rather than spicy. Still some alcohol but not as much.
05: Even more sweet and subdued than the previous two.  Flavor: 07: Hoppy, almost like a dark IPA, but not. Hops are spicy up front and finish sweet. The malts in there also contribute a bit to the sweetness but the hops are the star of this show. 06: My first impression is earthy. Still hoppy of course, but the hops have mellowed &#40;sorry for the cliche¬í&#41;. A little citrus in there as well, grapefruit. To me, the alcohol bite on the finish is much more than on the 07. 05: Mellow, and the most mellow part is the booze, just a hint in the aftertaste, smooth otherwise. Hops are faint and sweet up front and spicy towards the finish.  Palate: I refilled my glasses for the mouthfeel portion and again the head on the 06 totally showed up the head on the other two years. 07: It¬ís actually thick, but it¬ís crisp enough that it feels much thinner. Nice carbonation.
06: Thicker, not quite as crisp. Smooth though, the carbonation has mellowed.
05: The thickest, not by a ton of course, but it is the thickest. Carbonation has smoothed out some, still nice, but not as crisp.  Overall: Of course, all of these releases are still drinking nicely. I¬íll be honest, I like the hops in the fresh stuff an

1-27-08 bottle shared thanks to Mike on BA 

Caramel amber in color with a decent off white head.  So much better than the other two Bastards I¬íve had!  One of the first American Strong Ales that I have really enjoyed.  Caramel alcohol flavor.  Hot, heavy finish.  Smooth on the palate and warming as well.  Very impressed overall - I didn¬ít expect to enjoy this at all.
Bottle (Thanks Puzzl) at home - club tasting. Clear red/brown - white head. malty sweetness, high hoppy, high bitterness, resin, caramel, cookies. Dryu finish. Fantastic !!

Big thanks to MiguelMandingo on BA for sharing this bottle!  Wasn¬ít expecting too much from this as I wasn¬ít a terribly big fan of the Arrogant Bastard, but was very pleasantly surprised.  Pours a dark maroon color, a bit murky, and a nice beige head atop.  Taste is rich, sweet maltiness in the form of dark toasty caramel and nicely and appropriately hopped.  Smooth with no rough edges, yet crisp and with a nice mild bitterness.  Creamy caramelly, hopped flavor and much superior to Arrogant Bastard, I thought.  Thanks again Mike!

Not really sure what is "double" here...most guess the ABV, but its only 2.5% higher.  Doesnt taste like double the hops either. I wasn¬ít impressed either way. Just seems like Stone turned everything up to the max on this one just for $#!ts and giggles, and this is what they ended up with. Another user said it best..."Made to be offensive to your palate just to be offensive and say they are cool."  That is exactly what I thought as well.

Pours a mildly hazy dark amber with a thick fizzy head that dissipates rapidly Strong lacing. First taste assaults the senses with a complexity of hops and malt. Very pleasant. If you need an ale for breakfast, this would be the one. Nice, smooth mouthfeel, complex aftertaste that subtly hints at the potent alcohol content.

Bottle. Dark reddish-brown with a light head that dissipates. Sweet, hoppy aroma with lemons and spices. Strong sweet and bitter flavor of hops, dates and citrus. The hops linger nicely. Tasty and drinkable.

Light brown amber color. Caramel malty aroma and super strong hoppy smell. Big hop bomb taste, to asaualting of a beer. Made to be offensive to your palate just to be offensive and say they are cool, not my style. Good notes would be it hides the alc completey, drinking a whole bottle will most likely get you a buzz.

Reddish hue with super minimal head.  Sweet smelling with clovers and spices.  Sweet tasting, fruity and smooth with a spicy aftertaste.  It certainly is a "bastard" ale, it¬ís strong and bitter, overpowering (in a good way).

Bastard the Double is a harsh but forgiving boss.  If you can withstand the matly onslought, you are rewarded with notes of grape, apple and roast.  Not the rough-housing I was expecting, but still not a fruit juice.

Bomber. This one pours amber with an off-white head. The aroma is earthy, malty, and of course somewhat hoppy. The flavor is big, as expected with huge hop flavor citrus and resin, although there is some toffee/nutty maltiness in this one.Medium body that hides the alcohal fairly well. Big bitter hop finish.  A strong bitter beer that is not for the faint of heart. A fun hoppy beer that is not quite balanced enough to be considered outstanding. Still very good.
Nice powerful beer.  Strong in every way.  Sip it guys - not a chugger...lol

From a 22 oz bottle.  Pours a deep amber color with frothy white head.  Aromas of piney hops, some caramel malts, and brown sugar.  Taste is big.  This is definetely the big brother to the arrogant bastard or at least his evil twin.  Big hops and big malts hits your taste buds.  Great mouthfeel, bitter dry finish, and some warmth from the alcohol.
Beautiful looking beer. Big bold flavor. A little to strong on the aftertaste. A serious sipping beer. Noe that I know what to expect my next time around with this brew will be even more pleasurable.

From a 22oz. bottle--Poured a deep brown-amber body with a one-finger whitish head.  Thick, cloudy, sweet, and sticky.  Lots of hops and gripping sugars.  Full-bodied might be an understatement.  This beer is an asault on the palate.  Finishes quite bitter.  Aptly named brew!

Great beer for the hop heads. Of course a big bottle at 10% without someone to share it with is a bit much. Stone has a wonderful knack of using the best qualities of yeastiness and caramel malt to lead you into a hop attack. A full beer with great bitterness.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, roasted, nutty and caramel for the malt, orange and a little orange for the hops, dough and earth for the yeast, with raisin, cherry, toffee, brown sugar and alcohol in the background. head is creamy with some larger bubbles, off-white, with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is almost clear and reddish brown. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start, then the long finish is lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy bordering on syrupy, and has a soft carbonation. It finishes with a nice alcohol burn. One of the best tasting beers I¬íve ever tried. Superb.
Pours out amber with tan head. Sweet and malty. Caramel taste with hoppy bitter goodness. Dry after taste no alcohol burn.Very good.

(bottle from AJ¬ís Glendale, AZ-2007 release): Pours a reddish brown color body, clearish. Big tan head, lasting. Sweet caramel aroma, not as hoppy as the original. Somewhat grapey, effervescent. Caramel taste, not as hoppy. Sweet & malty. Caustic taste, some hops. Dry.

Thanks to miketd for the bottle.  Dark brown color.  Smell of hops, malt, citrus, pine, caramel, some plums and alcohol.  .  Taste of caramel, hops, alcohol, citrus, pine, toffee and nuts.  Very good beer.

Bottle. Pours lazily a thick, deep reddish brown, hazy with thin beige head. Aroma has vanilla, raspberries, pineapple, peach, caramel with slightly floral hints, as well. Flavor is thick raw caramel, citrus peel hop notes, slight smokiness and pungent alcohol. Palate is resiny, oily, thick. Alcohol and light citrus hop flavors, and a very mild bitterness coat the mouth in the finish. Very full, resiny, oily mouthfeel. Intense and warming.

Nothing special here. Enjoyable, and generally well-made, with well-masked alcohol. Not sure why this is so highly rated - maybe my beer lost something during the plane trip - anyone know anything about that?
I tried this beer on tap at Stone Brewery.  In my opionion it is one of the best beers around.
OH YEAH!!!! this is what I am talking about. Truly caramel malts with deep grassy hops. This beer comes at you and just stick with you all the way. a real winner

The aroma is full of citrus hops and caramel malt. The appearance is deep amber with a foamy head. The flavor is like the aroma meaning that it¬ís simple but effective. The hops and caramel are strong! The palate is very smooth. Overall I like it a lot.
great aroma better than bastard.  pours very dark amber.  i would say you do get more of a alcohol after taste with this beer.  accidenly rated this beer a .5???

22oz. Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Smells of malts, piney hops, caramel, dough, alcohol, and bread.  Poured dark orange/amber in color with a small tan head that diminished quickly.  Hazy.  Sweet flavor.  Tastes of malts, pine hops, resin hops, caramel, alcohol, and toffee.  Medium body.  Oily, then sticky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Hoppy, sweet, sticky finish.  Very drinkable.

Bottle, bought in some liquor store in MD.  Fairly thin head, dark red-brown color, clear.  Aroma is GOOD GOD.  Excellent blend of floral hops and malt.  I smell pine mixed with caramel, with a slight winish quality, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is similar, very caramel, and has a good mellow-bitter hop infusion at end, somewhat sweet and slightly fruity, almost tastes like a barleywine.  Has a warming alcohol aftertaste, and is truly delicious.  Although, I am not sure I like it as much as Arrogant Bastard.

NOTE TO STONE:  PLEASE SELL YOUR BEERS IN NC!!!!

This beer really wants to try to kick the crap out of you, it says so right on the bottle. Haha! Looks and smells similar to the Bastard Ale, but the taste takes it a step stronger. More malts, more hops, more alcohol, fewer apologies and even less balance. This is highly recommended for people who have liked Bastard Ale in the past.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2008 22 oz bomber at 2nd Houston Tasting, thanks to TexasJeep.  Pours a dark, reddish-amber with an off-white head.  Irregular lacing.  Wow, when they say double they aren¬ít kidding.  It¬ís like they put double the malt and double the hops in this bad boy!  The aromas of sweet malt and hops are pronounced.  The flavor was also sweet malt with citrus hops and some spices.  Mouthfeel was thick and creamy with nice bitterness in the aftertaste.  Really enjoyed the sample.  Will definitely have to get a whole bottle for myself.  Blows Arrogant Bastard away!  Addition after buying and drinking a whole bottle myself:  this was like a barleywine more than a strong ale.  Texture was melded into that sort of peach nectar sweet creaminess one sometimes gets from a barleywine whose hops are past fresh.  Love this brew.

This was a bastard of a beer like the name implies, with a hilarious message on the bottle.  It had a strong bitter finish, even more then it¬ís "little brother" the Arrogant Bastard Ale.  It was enjoyable, but not for the faint of heart.
Bottle: A hop came over to my house last night, grew arms and legs, and punched me in the face.  What a great beer.  Hops of an imperial IPA without the thickness.

22oz bottle.   I had the pleasure of trying this during the same session as Arrogant Bastard, and I think the comparison helped me understand there beers much more.   DB has a very similar appearance, with maybe a little more honey in the body, and a slightly darker and fluffier head.   The aroma is malty and pretty hoppy with lots of candied citrus; richer and more balanced than AB.   The flavor is similarly balanced with massive malts, citrus hopps and a little alcohol.   The way it all blends into one smooth experience really sets it above.   All the flavors work well together, over a thick and slightly syrupy body.   Lots of intense flavors, and you definitely can¬ít drink a lot of it, but the balance and smoothness hold it all together beautifully.

Somewhat overrated, in my opinion.  A solid strong ale, but a little unrefined.  The fruit notes are underdeveloped, where you¬íd hope to have a little identifiable character rather than just an impression of fruitiness.  An enjoyable brew, but not exceptional.  

I¬íve had this a few times.  I drink it more often than this review would indicate though, so perhaps there¬ís magic in that bastard.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2009 April 20th 2009 - Well just had a 2005 to celebrate my annual 4:20.  Smoked a bowl and drank a DB, doesn¬ít get much better than that!

Janurary 9th 2008 - This is my favorite beer of all time, every year I look forward to its release.¬† Stone Brewing freakin rocks!¬† I guess I¬íll just wait for the IRS instead!  

April, 5th 2008 - Ok well I just picked up another 7 bottles of this and 6 of them are gone.  This is by far the best session brew of all time.  I drink 3 of these and I start walking funny.  I drank an 06 vintage and got a huge malt bomb!!!  It was freakin delcious.  The fresh stuff stings your tastes buds with refreshing hops and super malt.  This beer is on steriods or something.  It is the most unique beer I have ever drank and impresses me more and more everytime I drink it(which is atleast once a week).  I have drained New Jersey of this beer completely, I am always on the prowl for more.  Next release I¬ím buying 5 cases, hopefully it will last me the winter, but who really knows.  This beer needs to move into the top 1 for sure.  For my 24th birthday I had a 1/2 keg of Oaked Bastard which was delicious just not as good as the Double.  This year to celebrate my quarter century of living, I¬ím getting a 1/2 barrel of Double Bastard.  If you want to come send me a Beermail.  All are welcome to come enjoy this masterpiece on tap.  Maybe I¬íll write a letter to the president of Stone Brewing Co. and ask for a 1/2 barrel of some kind of barrel aged Double Bastard.  That would freakin rock!!!!  

April 20th, 2007 (420) Yesterday my wife, little broski, and I went to a tattoo convention in Philly and had a great time.  On our way home there was a Canal¬ís liquor store I had never been in.  So we had to stop to check out thier beer selection.  It was very limited, but they did have nine bottles of Double Bastard on the shelf.  So I grabbed all of them with joy and my wife rolled her eyes at me.  I took the nine bottles to the counter and asked the young lady running the register if they had any more.  Sure enough the beer manager comes running up with a whole case that was sitting in the back!!!!  So I bought the whole case and left with a huge grin on my face knowing I have some Double Bastard once again to ration out over the next couple weeks.  I¬ím in the dog-house with my wife though, but that¬ís okay because I have 12 delicious Double Bastards sitting in my living room.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 08 22oz. Poured into mug. pour is muddy red/murky brown with frothy copper colord head. Tons of lacing here. Aromas of sweet fruits and malt, piney hops, and a small bit of alcohol. Nice smooth body with nice malty presence and finishing up with hops in the finish. One of my favorite beers and this years is far the best.
06 Growler. Pour is deep ruby with two fingers of toffee colored head. Aromas strong of sweet malt, apricots, alcohol, and caramel. This brew seemed to almost condense itself. Almost all hop presence is gone and a more thick, syrupy bastard has emerged. It is much smoother and finishes warming. Wow, what a treat!
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: The beer was copper with some plum and had a head that dissipated quickly.  The nose showed sweet caramal, plum, stewing raisins, spice and orange.  In the mouth it was medium to full-bodied with good malt richness with balancing hops.  The palate was not as dilineated as the nose and showed more chocolate and coffee than the nose.  It was also sweeter as the malt showed stronger.  This should age well but is great now if in the mood for a sweet malty beer.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2015 Best word to describe this one is probably AGGRESSIVE.  Everything about this beer is BIG...from the enormous malt and hop aroma to the billowing head that is perched high above the beer itself.  It rich mahogany glow and buttery mouthfeel makes this a clear favorite amongst beer enthusiasts...CHEERS!!!

22oz bottle.  Red amber, medium haze.  Tan head.  Big aroma of the greatest beer ever made!  Big malts, sticky sweet.  Pleasant hop bitterness.  This is a big beer.  Yellow beer is for wussies!  This beer is not for the faint hearted.

Bottle - pours deep mahogany with tan head and beautiful lace.  Nose was sweet and inviting, citrusy with maybe even a hint of cherry.  Very smooth and creamy.  Front end is sweet and malty, but back end is very hoppy and spicy, and the flavors transition very seamlessly.  Clean with a somewhat dry finish. An absolute blast to drink, and an experience in itself.  Definitely made for the serious beer drinker.

Bottle - clear beep mahogany color with lasting tan head and lace. Initial hop aroma. Medium body with gripping hop bitterness. Big malty flavor matched with building hop flavors. Creamy mouthfeel. Rich flavors blend well and finish clean and slightly dry.
Bomber.  Call me a masochist, but I can¬ít get enough hops.  Hoppier, Maltier, and all around bigger than the Arrogant Bastard.  Delicious.

I love stone, and this is no different.  Drank next to the regular Arrogant Bastard, and this is a little better in every way.  Just seemed like everything was a little more pronounced in this than the original.  Stronger malts, better stronger hops and nice and sweet.  I need to get a few of these.

Bottle. Very strong aromas of roasted malt, pine and perhaps citrus. Luminous mahogany color (under halogen) with a tannish head that went up and down quite quickly. Medium to full body with very smooth carbonation.  The flavor starts very malty, but there is an awful lot of hop to nearly balance it. The finish is rather sweet, but the hop continues to build. There¬ís a lot of malt and hop, but it could stand more bitter. Heat was hardly noticeable, and didn¬ít interfere with the flavor.

From bottle (Courtesy secret santa) : Pours a dark, tough to see through brown color with some red highlights, not a very impressive head, and what it does have dies pretty quick, but leaves a nice offwhite ring around the edges.  Aroma seems a little faint, but once i finally get a whiff, its pretty good.  Sweet malts, some hints of sweet fruits too, and small amounts of hops present themselves.  Taste is very interesting.....but i really like it!  Sweet on the outset, then turns very hoppy.  The end is again very sweet and some alcohol, like a barleywine, but like Zinister said, still very drinkable.  Aftertaste is very hoppy and has a slight alcohol burn as it goes down.  Nice full body on this one, it is quite nice to sip on.

Bottle from South Bay D&L. Pours a dirty, mean reddish brown. Strong sweet malt and hops on the nose. Flavor is very hoppy and full bodied with a sweetness bordering on barley wine...but is very drinkable. Ornery little beer that is right up my alley.

Pours a medium amber with smallish head. Sweet aroma of caramel and hops. Strong bitterness.
copyright grimreeser.
Pours a medium amber with smallish head. Sweet aroma of caramel and hops. Strong bitterness.

too much bluster and bravado on the bottle.  my local micro brew produces much hoppier beers on a daily basis, and doesn¬ít feel the need to insult my manhood.   good beer, fairly well balanced, but definately does not live up to the hype...
For all the machismo on the bottle, this was a disappointing effort.  Poured a copper/caramel with little head.  Too sweet and sugary for my palate.  Hops and malt as expected.

2007 release - 22oz from 
Stone bistro.  darkish auburn color with little head.  hoppy, hoppy aroma. big maltiness, big bitterness, long finish -- little acidic for me.  but a pretty great sipping beer overall.

Bomber from 2006.  Poured a red amber with a relatively thick head.  Sweet smell of caramel and some fruit.  Since the beer is over a year old a lot of the hop flavor and smell has disappeared and I didn¬ít think it was as good without that obviously.  The beer tasted surprisingly sweet.
