bomber poured a red amber in color fairly thick looking with a one finger head on the pour leaving a nice layer with good lacing at the surface. aroma is caramel malt, sweet fruit, citrus peel, and hops. definitely a big brew. taste is medium mouth feel, good dose of malt with some sweetness, hops come in strong with citrus and fruit, finishes with some alcohol and sharp hop bite. really a heavy hitter, has a great deal of malt giving it a bitter side and a huge wallop of hops providing fruit and citrus combined well. being a 10% brew the alcohol is noticeable but not dominating, sweet but not over the top, and hopped but not too bitter. bottle and labeling are pretty good as an extra.

22oz bomber shared with ealdent. Pours a dark, clear brown/copper with highlights of dark amber and a large tan head. The aroma is strong - quite hoppy with some citrus/pine, but also very malty (lots of caramel) with a good bit of alcohol. The taste starts complex with a two-edged bitterness: a hint of roasted grains with a dark chocolate or coffee-like bitterness and a large presence of hops. The flavor is quite reminiscent of the "weaker" version - but sweeter and more alcohol. The middle of the palate detects more roasted grains, some biscuity malts, subtle touches of fruity esters, and hops. The finish isn¬ít as long as its lowly "arrogant" brethren and is much more warming. The mouthfeel is heavily carbonated (pour vigorously or swirl in glass to release it and to add creaminess to the texture) and medium- to-full in body. Overall, a good beer that is exactly what its name implies.

Poured from tap an amberish brown with off-white foam head.  Aroma pounds at you with hops and a caramel maltiness.  The taste is a blend of smooth sweetness and hop madness followed by the alcohol warming.  This beer held its own. I drank this one after a St Bernardus abt 12 and although completely different the DB has a great taste all to itself.
Wow, what a beer. Pours a mediun brown with small amount of lacing. Taste is sweet and hoppy with a hint of caramel. Very complex. Well done stone.

bottle. pours clear dark brown with one finger eggshell head. faint aroma of caramel and hops. taste is sweet mollases with a healthy bitter hop finish. alcohol is warming but hidden behind the sugary palate. some citrus elements in there but doesn¬ít taste like a standard double ipa.  struck me more as a mix between a belgian double and an ipa.  the dark malts are dominant but it definitely has a strong bitter finish. its a bit too sweet and syrupy for my tastes.  interesting to try.  not what i was expecting.

Head pours out a little thin and there¬ís a little bit of lacing, but it¬ís not a real ring.  Smell is very good.  Sweet, and very hoppy...grapefruity hops, Stone hops ;)  Smell has some sweet brown sugar.  A blast of floral grapefruity hops that have really great bitterness.

Pours a muddy bronze with a cream head that retains and only gives way to thick sheets of lace. Smells of citrus, hops, caramel, alcohol and spice. Tastes syrupy, dark and dried fruit, caramel, sweet malt, spice and alcohol. Mouthfeel is tremendously smoooth. Wow this brew is a delight and killer at the same time. Hop bitterness lingers on the palate. ABV is present but well hidden behind complexities. What can I say, such an original brew that is a must try. Has barleywine characteristics with strong ale drinkability. Beware.

maroon with a medium dense khaki head. rich cherry orange malt aroma. medium bodied that is creamy and syrupy. maple oak malt flavors with a light chocolate note to it. nice bold citrus fruit and grass hoppiness to it. bitter, ofcourse, and strong but not overpowering

Pours a deep red-brown with a thick lasting cream head.  Aroma is sweet, and malty with a strong peach scent.  It tastes sweet and slightly fruity which gives way to a grapefruit citrus bitterness from the hops at the finish.  Delicious.
Overwhelmingly hoppy in all departments.  So much so that it¬ís hardly bitter.  Instead it taste like sweet sweet nectar from the Gods.  Perfection.

650 ml, 2007 release. Clear, dark copper with a large head that settles down to a smallish ring. Chocolate and earthy, fruity nose. Big chocolate-citrus front turns to orange-brandied molasses, then to pine-alcohol, and finishes bitter with mostly herbs and evergreen resin, accompanied by orange and alcohol. Medium-heavy palate is smooth and almost syrupy, but has lots of hop tingle at the end to finish dry. Nice beer, but there are better and more complex ASAs out there that don¬ít taste like an uber-hopped DIPA.

22 oz. bottle received from both Zinister and MrBendo in separate trades.  Pour is a slightly hazed ruby brown with a decent tan head on top.  Aroma of sweet malt grain (rye?) and a bunch of resiny bitter hops.  The taste is a nice combo of the sweet caramel malt, the resin hops and a nice finish with the graininess.  The body of this one is huge, almost chewy.  Initially served at about 50 degrees.  When this warmed to about 65 or so, it really took on the nose of a hoppy Barley Wine.  I really enjoyed this beer a lot, thanks fellas!  (I look forward to the second one!)

This is indeed a Double Bastard!  Its one massive beer.  The body is a thick, syrupy, cloudy, dark reddish brown color.  A large, foamy, light tan colored head settles slowly to a wispy film, leaving intricate patterns of lacing etched onto the glass.  The aroma is fruitier than I expected, a surprising dose of peaches intermingling with the requisite grapefruit and orange hops.  Big, heavy caramel and toffee malts are kissed with huge, oaky vanilla scents.  The flavor is comprised of the same components, though the fruitiness takes a bit of a backseat to the huge, oaked toffee malts.  Expertly blended for supreme balance, despite its enormity.  The body is downright thick and syrupy, a slight negative in my book, though its a minor flaw I am willing to overlook.  This one reminds me of a more refined, more realistic, more drinkable version of DFH 120.  There¬ís just so much complexity going on here in such a massive package.  Not something I could drink often, but impressive as hell nonetheless.

Poured from a 22oz bomber and served in a snifter.  This brew poured a cloudy, reddish brown hue with a one-finger thick head of beige foam that quickly faded away.  A decent amount of sticky lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of sugary caramel and  grapefruit notes.  The flavor included chewy caramel malt, brown sugar, grapefruit rind, and a sweet, warming alcoholic note.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and filling, also lightly sticky and syrupy.  Minimal carbonation.  Really nicely done!  Aggressive hopping and large quantities of malt make this a super tasty big beer!

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 Bomber from the brewery.  Murky brown/red color with tan/beige head.  Aroma is strong orange and candy malt.  Strong orange flavor with large malt sweetness, caramel and brown sugar though surprisingly well balanced, it being such a big alc beer.  Full bodied and creamy, this beer is very nice! 7 4 8 4 16 = 3.9
------- through ¬í08 vertical.  Thanks to Drewbeerme for supplying so many of the bottles and for everyone else for coming.

¬í02- Red cloudy body with small beige head.  Aroma is slight with oxidized cookie.  Flavor is bitter oxidized dough with some maple syrup and some weird hoppiness, maybe alc.  Medium to light carbonation.  Solid even after this many years.  8 4 6 3 15 =3.6

¬í03 - Similar appearance.  Very fresh aroma of red fruit, juicy.  Flavor is alc, oily, mape syrup, oxidation.  Medium to light carbonation. I really enjoyed this aroma more than any of the others. 8 4 6 3 15 = 3.8

¬í04- once again similar appearance.  Cookie aroma with some red fruit, all very light though.  Flavor was red fruit and nice dough oxidation with pretty distinct alc and dry.  Medium with light carbonation.  Intereting flavor with some maple syrup.  7 4 6 3 14  = 3.4

¬í05 - Similar appearance.  Maple syrup aroma with some fresh hop notes, weird in that way, I can enjoy the light citru notes.  Big malty flavored barleywine with alc and maple syrup, some resin but a little unbalanced and sweet.  Medium to light body with light carbonation.  Boozy but nice nice at the same time. 8 4 7 3 16 =  3.8

¬í06 - Similar appearance.  A lot citrus in the aroma but some alc and port.  Flavor is paper, cardboard, alc, some citrus, hot.  Medium body and light.  Oh man is this a bad vintage! 7 4 5 3 13 = 3.2

¬í07 - Appearance is the same again.  Fresh red fruit aroma, big malt with some hops.  Flavor is hops with red fruit and grapefruit, resiny, I can dig it after the rest of the line u

Pours a nice brown red with just a little head.

Malty, hoppy and flavor is balanced well with grapefruit bitterness. Just bitter enough buit not too bitter. Very good beer, so good that  I must have purchased and drank 12 or so bombers in the last 2 weeks. :D
This beer was really dark and really heavy. For me it left sort of a bitter after taste. also a def sense of carmel in there. i would def have again

Bottle huge thanks to secret santa. Aroma is hugly peachy, grassy, not much malt character, piney grassyness. Taste is more malt based, toffee but with a huge bitter backing, sort of passes me by without thinking about it. Annoyign as its a great beer but i was expecting more, like a yulesmith or something. Still one id love to have again.

Dark, almost opaque body topped off with light brown head.  The aroma of caramel was the most dominant with a light orange scent.  The flavor was a great combination of the hoppy citrus flavors that we expect from Amer. Strong Ales.  There was a lot of lime, orange, and the tartness of grapefruit.  On tap at Tria, Philadelphia.

aggressively hoppy on the nose, followed by heat and caramel malt aromas.  Very pretty in the glass, translucent amber.  Hops once again on the palate, crisp and pine-y followed once again by the alcohol and an almost candied malt finish.

22 oz  bottle.  I had this along with samples of Arrogant Bastard and the Oaked Bastard.  Aroma is hoppy, with a roasted malt hint to it as well.  Flavor is pretty distinct, without any real defined flavor sticking out.  Alcohol is pretty well masked compared to what you¬íd expect in a 10 percent beer.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2008 Poured a deep auburn copper with a tan head into a half yard. The aroma was piney hops. The first taste, the hops hit you, then the warm mouthfeel and the malts. It¬ís striking at first, leaving an impression. Very good!
2008 Vintage: This one is really fresh, and fresh this beer is amazing. Full of pine and citrus

Bomber. Pours a wonderful dark ruby red with nearly no head. Aromas whole hop flowers, resinous notes, grapefruit, caramel and sugar malts, and more citrus hops! Full mouthfeel, little carbonation. Full out assault on my taste buds. Hops, malts, hoppy malts, malty hops! Flavor is tough to decipher. No real flavor coming from the generous amount of hops, just bitterness. Starts off hoppy with a sweet bread like maltiness. Quick to follow is a certain sweetness I can¬ít quite put my finger on (maybe caramel) mixed with a grapefruit west coast hop bitterness. Long bitter finish with slight alcohol warming in the stomach. After taste of citrus hops lingers on your tongue and gums. Good, I really like Arrogant Bastard better. Sipper of a beer, with what is surely to be a ton of IBU¬ís! Had to come back, towards the end of the bottle the alcohol really comes through, changing the after taste to a fine liquor. I guess I just had to become acclimated with the IBU¬ís. Love this after taste.

Poured a beautiful, glowing swirl of copper, brown and red.  An ample off-white head developed and sat stubbornly atop the beer.  Creamy and slow to dissipate the head produced average lacing.  I just love the look of this beer.  The aroma was sugar cookie, malts and some caramel maltiness.  The citrus makes an appearance as does some alcohol.  The flavor was dominated by caramelly sweet malts and a noticeable, but not at all unpleasant, alcohol heat.  The citrus hops are quite mild and the pine and floral hoppiness is present, but basically overwhelmed by the sweet malts and alcohol.  The mouthfeel is very nice and overall this beer a thick, hot brew that lacks balance but not personality.  A great beer to sit and sip while reading a book on a cold winter¬ís night.

Bomber, courtesy of Russells in Amherst, MA.
:::APPEARANCE::: dark reddish brown, just like maple syrup, head was very minimal but was a nice thick creamy texture::: AROMA::: I could smell it from 3 ft. away, cherries, sweet and malty, berries, grapes, and citrus hops:::TASTE:::bread-like malt and bitterness up front, then sweet malts followed by a slowly developing hop bitterness that lasts for awhile, despite the citrus hops in the aroma, there were none in the taste:::MOUTH-FEEL:::medium/thin body, syrupy, modest carbonation_____Honestly, I expected better. The aroma was the best thing about DB. I like bitterness, but something throws me off in this one. I think maybe the bitterness persists too long, after the first taste it just wouldn¬ít leave and ruined other flavors. Forget Ruination, this one is far more ruinous to your palate........IMHO, Double Bastard is best enjoyed in spaced-apart sips.

A really massive beer. I am a huge fan of Stone, it is probably pound for pound my favorite brewery. This beer adds to the mystique that is Stone. Small head that sticks around for the party. Hopsy nose with a bit of caramel for spice. The taste is, surprise surprise, intensely hopsy, but also a nice sweetness that balances nicely.

22oz Bottle: 2007 Release, Pours a hazy dark copper with a small but lingering tan head. The nose is sweet with some caramel but citrusy hops are very noticeable. The taste is malt driven which surprised me based on the aroma. Alcohol shows itself in the taste and finish. The mouth feel is medium to heavy. Some lingering bitterness on the finish as well. I think this beer improves with age. But I still remember more from it when it was fresh.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2007 I had this on tap.  It is a sweet, strong, hoppy ale that seems to fit well with the early winter and the upcoming holidays.  I wish I could say I liked it as much as other Stone ales I have tried, but the malty sweetness and high alcohol were just a little too powerful.  Still, when those first snowflakes start falling, this is a nice mug to reach for.  Maybe they could call it Double Elf or Double Santa instead of Double Bastard.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2008 Pours a great cloudy red color with a khaki head.  Smells of sweet malts and tastes the same.  Lots of hops  balanced by huge sweet malt taste.  I think it¬ís too sweet for its own good.  i can¬ít get into beers that have huge thick bodies and tons of sweet malt flavor.  it also gave me some hardcore shits the next day.
Very bitter, but very malty.  Makes for a well-balanced taste explosion.  Relatively heavy body with subtle fruit notes.  Alcohol is clear in both the nose and the flavor.

22oz. bomber. Pours a clear, dark copper color with a thin, white head that dissipates quickly. Heavy aromas of citrus fruit, hops, grass and some hints of apple. Flavor is of bitter fruits and hops, but has hints of sweet caramel and some spicey notes. Mouthfeel is very soft and smooth. Better then Arrogant Bastard and one of the best Stone brews I have tried.

Pours mahogany color with frothy head. Nose is very sweet, with malt and bread influence, and a bit sugary. Flavor is complex with malt, sugar, dried fruit. Creamy mouthfeel and clean finish. Great beer!

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 old rating:
7/3/7/3/14 - 3.4

pour is a cloudy dark copper with a red tint, a small tan head, and good lacing.

smell is caramel, hops, malts, some pear, and earthly.

taste is creamy, somewhat sour, light grapefruit, caramel, bitterness that grows as you drink, and dry leaves, end is nicely bitter and thick.

Bottle. Ah, the Double Bastard. I¬íve been looking forward to this since I started to get into craft beer. One of my first craft beers was the Arrogant Bastard. And now, having obtained this, I¬ím quite ecstatic. As I pour this, it¬ís a dark ruby/amber with a really nice, velvety light tan head. As I swirl this beer, a cloud of bubbles engulfs the beer about one inch from the surface. The aroma is very intense in grapefruit and hops with subtle hints of banana. There are a darker fruit aroma to it, but I can¬ít exactly pinpoint what fruit it resembles. As I start to quaff this beer, the pine and sharp grapefruit citrus qualities becomes very evident. More subtle notes, such as banana and darker fruits start to appear as the brew starts to pass the tongue. The finish is dry, much like a grainy bread, and a hopsy bitter. The alochol in it is a little noticeable as it warms the chest. This is amazing. This has lived up to my anticipation.

tangy candy like nose, almost peach nose. This has a massive malty sweetness.  it has a hint of caramel.  The bottom line is this just haves a lot of malt.  There is a bitterness at the end but it is not as aggressive as I thought this was going to be.  It iis actually more balanced than regular
Arrogant Bastard.  I actually like it more than the original.

bottle.  pours a hazy dark reddish brown, with a thin off-white head that quickly recedes to a film.  smell of caramel malt, citrusy hops, dark fruits, a bit of wood, and strong alcohol.  a hint of cherry in the taste, with a bit less alcohol as was in the nose, but plenty nonetheless.  light spice and a touch of floral/citrus hop, as well.  finishes with a bit of alcohol bitterness, and a decent sweetness to balance it.  fairly full-bodied, with a good coating mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  not my favorite offering from stone.  the alcohol taste nearly overwhelms what would otherwise be a pretty tasty beer.

I love Arrogant Bastard, but I loved this one even more. Oddly, I thought it was a little more subdued than the Arrogant, which really attacks your taste buds. Pours a deep brown color with little head or lacing. Sweet malt, caramel flavor, hops are not overly done here, surprisingly. Mouthfeel is fantastic. Awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Bottled.  Pours a deep mahogany hue with ruby red highlights.  Small tan head settles into a film with no lacing.  HUGE aroma: pine resin, green apples, and mandarin oranges.  Flavour is crushing hops of sweet pink grapefruit.  Bitterness is nice but holds a little long.  Very unique beer.

22 oz. Bottle. Pours dark amber with very little head, lacing around the edges. Little bubbles slowly rise from the depths of this brew. The nose is a wonderful sweet sour with a familiar memory invoking component that I can¬ít put my finger on but it smells great. Its like candied apple and raisins mixed with sour malt. When you take a sip the first thing you notice is strong sweet malts as it washes to the back of your throat you notice the alcohol warmth and the hoppy bite. The hops are well integrated and don¬ít come through much on the tongue but they are definitely there at the back of the tongue and they mean business. The hops bite lingers for 30 seconds or more after the drink. The mouthfeel is very full and thick with low carbonation. The entire mouth is well coated taking the sensation to every square inch of mouth surface. Very, very good beer. 
P.S. That smell reminds me of the smell of Unibroue brews must be a yeast thing.
UPDATED: APR 10, 2009 Bottle. Body is dark amber color. Aroma is some hops and just a little soapiness.  Taste is not as bitter as I would have thought, hops and citrus. 10% hidden well.
Great. The flavor is dominated by bitter, grapefruit hops. No sweetness anywhere. Smooth, light carbonation. Full bodied. Bitter, slightly alcoholic finish.

Smells strongly of nice sour hops, some dark malt notes. pours a deep dark red with a nice creamy tan head. Taste is rich with a nice bite. Nice bitter sour hops with very earthy notes, some caramel. Very nice.

Smells like strait hops homie. Stars with Carmel hints , ends slightsly harsh.. alcohol very eminent in finish. Deep amber color. niceley carbinated for a ipa style. Very thick on the palate. Extremely hoppy.

Vintage 2004 courtesy of santoslhalper.  Pours copper-red w/small, off-white head.  Nose of big carmel and toffee.  Sweet, sweet McLovin¬í.  Tastes of Pure Carmel malt w/ bitterness at the end.  The big hop nose that frequents Stone Brews is gone, but this is really friggin¬í good, still.  ¬í07 rating to come.

After recovering from the insults on the back of the bottle, i poured a 22oz into two pint glasses. It has a rich brown color with a healthy two finger off white head that laces nicely. I smell very strong pineapple and grapefruit aromas. This beer is heavily hopped and that is the primary flavor, but there is malt to attempt to balance the piney and pineapplely flavor of the hops. This is a strong beer and it has a full body to accompany the 10% alcohol. Perhaps I¬ím unworthy, but the drinkability on this isn¬ít too high for me.
Awesome.  Very hoppy on aroma and the hops swim around your mouth and hang on for dear life.  Thank you dpjuart!
this beer is not only horible but its tast is beond horible it tasted like bad terioky chicken and bbq thats been siting there for 2 weeks please stop makeing this beer it horable

aroma of sweet malt and hops...thick with a heavily pronounced alcohol start to finish...hop bitterness pick up in the aftertaste...2nd sip brings out the sharp pine taste in the hops and the sweet malts..alcohol still dominates....a lot going on here

Bottle.  Poured a dark ruby, almost coke color, with a thin white head.  Interesting malt and hop nose that seems well balanced.  Flavor is grapefruit, malt and hops, an odd mix.  I dont particularly like the citrus flavor, but this is an excellent beer.  Finishes sweet, citrusy, and smooth.

Wow, hoppy beer.  Pours a murky light brown with a small head and little lacing.  The flavor is of strong bitter hops and grapefruit, it finishes bitter and clean.  A bit over the top for my tastes, I¬íll reached for an Oaked Bastard any day over this one.

22oz 2007 version.  Not quite as menacing as I expected, I would venture to say it is less menacing than the arrogant bastard.  Clear dark amber pour.  Mostly sweet malt, citrus and a waft of pine in the nose.  Pretty sweet on the palate, fairly soft carbonation with some complex hops, a bit of roast, and loads of sweet citrus fruit.  This tends towards a warming beer, sweet hops linger forever!

Bottle.  Deep amber in color, with some purple when held to the light.  Minimal head.  Aromas included grapes and berries with some malt; the alcohol came through, too.  It tasted crisp with a gin-like character.  The malt and alcohol showed themselves.  This would be a good after-dinner drink.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2009 Poured from a bomber.  Poured a deep amber color with a soft beige head.  Sweet malt aroma with a hint of hops.  After the first sip, I am surprised how relatively mellow it is.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a hint of fruit (apple, perhaps?) that leads into a healthy dose of hops that dry the palate out.  Somewhat chewy but not overpowering.   Another good beer from Stone.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2007 Very powerful.  Lots of sweet malt flavor, balanced with an extreme amount of bitter hop flavor.  Not a floral/herbal taste, but just straight bitter.  Strong malts remind me of a barley wine.  No shortage of flavor in this beer.  Delicious and strong.  Only complaint is the bitterness is perhaps a bit too overpowering.
Bottle. Dark brown amber with some ruby highlights. Medium tan head. Flavor is incredibly smooth. Bitterness balanced very well with complex malt presence. Subtle alcohol notes will warm you up.

Had this beer on 2/11/2007.  Aroma is a dry scent with a faint citrus to it.  Color is a deep amber with light carbonation and a tight head.  Taste is rich sweet and hoppy.  Starting with a full body it goes down with a rich sweet feel and a slight sharpness.  Finish comes out of this with a smooth feel, and sweet malty flavor that is backed by a citrus hop flavor and nice yet bold bitterness.  This is one of the best beers I have ever had. I think its better then the regular Bastard.  The only down fall to it is the citrus taste, I am not a big fan of citrusy beer.
Bottle. A heavy malty character with a mild hop profile. A light head with a heavy malt and roasted barley finish.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted maltiness and hops.  Up front there is a lucious maltiness that is perfectly balanced by a huge bitter hoppy finish.  I love this beer.

Courtesy of who else, Ibrew2or3. 2006 vintage, cellared one year. Curious to see if this is more like an IIPA or a BW at this point. Dark amber body, edges of brown. Foamy, dirty looking white head. Nice retention and only slight lacing. Nose is VERY hoppy still, wow, this is a huge hop bomb. Citrus rinds, hops, pine, grass and a very light toffee backing. Flavor is busting with the hops also, very juicy, with only a hint of backing from the malts. Still good carbonation after the aging, very fun and exciting to drink. Heavily astringent. Medium-full bodied, resin coats the tongue. Lengthy, bitter, dry, spicy, citrus finish. A masterpiece.

poured a dark red with a nice creamy head.  Lots of hops and sweet malts and cantaloupe in the nose.  Tasted similar,  very malty and not nearly as bitter as I suspected.  Finished strong,  with a long lasting blast of flavor.  I was almost angry I had to share the bottle.

Tap@ David Copperfields. Pours a clear deep copper/ambered colour ( not cloudy like some of the bottle descrips.)w/ quickly diminishing eggshell brown head, very little/no lacing. Aroma was a slightly toasted hop sweetness. Alcohol vapours were almost eye-watering! Medium carbonation suspended in a heavy feeling almost barleywine like way. Nice and bitter but the super strong alcohol presence cuts that and substitutes a decent malty candy sugar thing until swallowed then  the bitterness returns. Not much "hoppiness" like in a IIPA but they¬íre definitely ( & defiantly! ) there ¬ítil the end.

Very disappointed with this beer.  I enjoyed the "single" bastard, although not blown away.  The beer poured an orange with very little head - appeared cloudy.  The best way I can describe my impression was old fashioned medicine - very bitter and syrupy.  I very rarely dump out a beer, but I finished my pint and poured out the rest of the bomber.  I¬ím a big fan of Stone Brewing - the smoked porter is one ofy my stand-bys - this one just did nothing for me.  I could tell there was a lot of flavor and complexity but it was overcome by the pure bitterness.  I guess I¬ím not worthy.  This review is for the 2007 vintage.

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of citrus ( grapefruit) and malt. Taste is sweet and fruity, citrus. Has a big hop taste with a bitter finish.
I¬ím disapointed in this. Not one of my favorites. Maybe the bottle is skunked?
Coudy red without head. Sharp smell of sweet hops. Citrusy fruit taste. Astringent finish with a sting at the tip of your tongue.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Bottle from xmarcnolanx. Yep... it¬ís an ASA. Aroma of sweet, rich malt with lots of sticky pine resin. Pours rich, full mahogany with bright ruby highlights. Frotli khaki head leaving lots of sticky lacing. Flavor is quite malty with the dry piney hops interwoven throughout. Creamy and mostly full bodied with lively carbonation. Finishes with a big burst of dry, lingering hops.

Big citrus and pine aroma with asweet fruity malt as well. It smells amazing. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a lingering head and decent lacing. Flavor was a sweet light roast, candied sweetness, brown sugar and dried fruits all balanced by some huge hop bitterness.. Thick body with a lingering dryness and a little alcohol. Scary drinkable at 10% wow!

bottle (2006 vintage)....pours a reddish caramel brown with a thin off-white head....nose was of strong/rich sweet caramel malt with very little hop presence if at all....flavors of sweet caramel malt which then gives way to some assertive piney bitter hops which would be even more prevalent if drunken fresh.......pretty good.
2007 bottle. i drank a bunch of em. i bought the store out of it and then im keeping one to age. its really freaking good stuff.

Bottled.  Medium-sized, beige-hued head that lasts quite well, sheets and splotches of lace, and becomes a ring towards the end.  Bubbles are rather creamy and nice looking.  The liquid is a rather blah amber color.  Aroma is malt and hop heaven!  Smells like dry-hopped with pine, pollen, and grapefruit--mellow, smoothe stuff mostly with a touch of astringence--with dark, rich malts of dark fruits, brown sugar, honey.  Body is full with almost no carbonation: a touch syrupy, enough hops to dry things out suitably with a mouthwatering finish.  Flavor is lovely with lots of hops, lots of malts, and well-blended alcohol.  I taste honey, pollen, roasted malts, pine wood (not sap), grapefruit and milder varieties of citrus as well.  There is some yeastiness that is also in the aroma, a floral bread dough.  Not the best in the style, but one of them.  Reminds me of the Yulesmith ales, but nowhere near as smoothe and wonderful.  Mmmm...good.

2007 Bottle. Pours dark amber, cola colored with little head. Aroma is heavy malt iwith a hoppy undertone. Brown sugar. Taste is phenomenal. Strong hop taste, balanced with strong brown sugar, caramel taste. Mouthfeel is very creamy and a little thicker, maybe like a barleywine. Absolutely delicious. This is not an intimidating beer in the slightest, but it is very, very good.

2006 bottle, shared, nice tasting and very smooth even for 10% abv. i get some sweetness vanilla type flavor ontop of the traditional AB, much more flavor and almost no bitterness probably due to the aging.
Bottle.  Dark amber color with a strong floral aroma.  Complex flavor on the palate of juniper, apricots with a syrupy mouth feel.  The alcohol is cleverly concealed behind the wall of complexity.

Fresh 2007 bomber.  Pours dark, clear, syrupy looking red with a compact white head.  Aroma is oak, vanilla, strong maltiness, spicy hops, herbal, more vanilla, and something that reminds me of cola.  Smells like a better version of the oak aged Arrogant Bastard.  The hops are more subdued than I would have thought, in the aroma at least.  There is a tiny bit of syrupy malt sweetness in the smell but it is not cloying.  It kind of reminds me of cough syrup but not in a bad way, if that makes sense.  Taste is remarkably drinkable for something that I imagined would be harsh and bitter, etc.  I¬íd even say it¬ís smooth.  I had to check the bomber to make sure this was in fact the 2007 release and not an earlier version that¬ís been mellowing for awhile.  Bitterness is fairly low compared to what I expected.  Flavor of sweet, sticky malts.  Medium to full bodied.  Alcohol hidden well.  I think it¬ís important to note that the people I was drinking this with said the exact opposite thing as me with respect to everything so it is a major possibility that my palate was shot or something while drinking this and it is a harsh, hoppy, green, young bitter beer.

Pours a gorgeous red-orange color with a thick bubbly off-white head. Sweet aroma, fresh citrus and resiny pine hops. Yum. Taste is extremely hoppy and bitter. Kind of sticky mouthfeel, with an unexpectedly dry finish.  This is good, but a little strong for my tastes. Definitely not something to drink everyday, but worth a try.

Honestly, I couldn¬ít wait to try this beer and I wasn¬ít disappointed--not even remotely. Stone never fails to disappoint. The alcohol content is remarkably well-hidden in this considering that it¬ís 10%. What I like most is that it seems to be a fusion of the Ruination IPA and their normal Arrogant Bastard--a very interesting hybrid. It leaves a very strong aftertaste, reeking of hops just like Ruination, which is definitely a plus--if you enjoy that sort of thing. So delicious. I can¬ít wait to grab another one.

22 oz bomber. Pours a deep dark red almost mahoganey with a cremy very light tan beige head. Aroma of spruce, pineapple and alcohol. Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and noticable carbonation yet only slight alcohol warming from this ten percent monster. Flavor is lots of hops, imagine an IIPA, yet balacned with lots of caramel malt and smooth alcohol.  This is the kamikaze of full bodied alcohol bombs, strong yet smooth. If you don¬ít like this beer reach down between your legs where your balls used to be and pull your thong out of your ass Nancy Boy!!!!!

This pours a dark ruby with a thick tan head.  Aroma of pine, caramel, hints of vanilla, and hints of alcohol.  Wonderful thick mouthfeel, well balanced pine and caramel flavor.  Very well hidden alcohol.  Simply an amazing beer, and one I¬ím glad to have opened my first one of the season.
Pours cloudy, brown, with a moderate, fluffy head. Aroma is very hoppy. Mouth feel is very full. Flavor is amazingly hoppy with a mild alcoholic warmth. Holy crap!

Poured from a bomber.  Very deep rustic copper color, with a crazy depth of colors and aromas.  Full of sweet, sweet caramel, molasses, citrus, pine, and even grapefruit.  The head, which was nice on the pour, turned nonexistant, I mean completely disappeared even with vigorous swirling.  Nice carbonation, fizziness to it though, as I¬ím guessing from the flavors that this is aged considerably.  It has crazy depth of maltiness, not quite cloying (almost) but extremely complex and well balanced.  Rediculous full flavor of well rounded malts, caramel, biscuit, roasted nuts, molasses, burned creme brulee, pine, grapefruit, and pine...did I mention a large alcohol feel, tingle, and taste.  I really think this is the craziest most complex beer I¬íve had to date, almost if I wasn¬ít quite ready for it.  The biggest beer in range of flavor...breathtakingly maticulated complexity.

bottled, consumed 11/13/07.  Pours a deep golden brown with a plentitude of swirling tiny bubbles.  The head is modest and dissipates quickly to a thin off-white skin.  Big hoppy aroma of grapefruit with some molasses notes, too.   Thick, slick mouthfeel with a cola-like carbonation/mild burn.  Sweet and malty in the front and cleanly bitter and lingering in the back.  Alcohol flavor is there, but not as noticeable as you¬íd expect a 10% beer to be.  Man, this is a good, well-balanced beer.

This is a good one from Stone-Poured from a 22oz bottle-amber with a nice beige head.Aromas of hops,malt and sugar and pine,all the usual suspects.It is really surprising how sweet this was,not overwhelming,but nicely balanced.

smells like this was aged in wood, deep and heavy, but not very potent.  poured dark brown, looked red/orange through the light and produced a small amount of head that left quickly.  the taste however, is superb!  it¬ís everything i want, if i had more bottles i¬íd ruin my evening and clean criminal record.  creamy throughout, deep dark ripe plum and nectarine with figs and caramel adding to the malt side, but bitter, oily, resiny hops throughout the entire taste.  this is how i like beer to be balanced.  hops have a sweet side to them too, as if they¬íre bursting with oil and aroma, picked fresh at the peak of the season.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 650 ml bottle from Henry‚Äôs Market. This is the winter 2007 release. Pours a translucent dark reddish brown with an off-white head that lasts a fair time and shows some lacing. The aroma is strong and complex with caramel, cola, citrus and hops. The flavor is hops forward with biter hops being the first taste sensation you notice, rounding out the sides are caramel, toffee and cola. The mouthfeel is full, creamy and satisfying from start to end; the carbonation is lively and prickly. The alcohol is well hidden, perhaps a touch shows on finish, but because of effective use of hops it is not distracting. The finish is dominated by more lingering biter hops and caramel. Overall: I love this beer. Gotta‚Äô stock up the cellar, this is a great year and it should age very well. Recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 2004 release @ Najas. Caramel hoppy plum flavor. Very chewy sticky mouthfeel. Thick brew. Beautiful lacing. Definetely a sipping beer. Very flavorful. I await to try a fresh bottle to compare. 2007 rls comes out Nov 5th!
Just had the 2007 release. Fresh batch is not as thick and chewy, Very hoppy and malty. Caramel and plum flavors. Sweet floral hoppy aroma. Very delicious beer.

Pours a deep ruby red that in spite of showing it¬ís color, is surprisingly opaque, only letting light through on the extreme edges. The aroma is brutally dominated by burnt caramel with just a hint of hops lingering in the background. The taste is an almost indescribable balance of abundant sticky caramel malts and delicious sticky pine hops with just enough citrus to mellow the whole thing out into almost complete perfection. The beer is certainly medium to heavy bodied, but the absolutely wonderful taste fully compensates for any heaviness. I am ready to say without any hesitation that this is now hands down my absolute favorite beer. I have reviewed 400 beers now and this is my first perfect 5. This one is now doubt a sipper, but each sip is so spectacular, the taste compensates for any and all of the factors of a beer of this strength that usually gets in the way of drinkability.

Draft sampled. Pours ruby in color with a off-white head. Aroma of caramel, sweet malt, dark fruit, and floral hops. Flavor is smooth and well balanced with sweet malt, dark fruit, warm alcohol, and a strong hop presence. Awesome american strong.

2006 Bomber....Pours a brilliant ruby red color into the tulip glass.  There was a huge off white fluffy head and a quick ringlet of lacing.  The scent was strong alcohol with some malt and hops fading in the back.  Very strong alcohol and hops up front with a smoother, malty finish.  This one has a barley wine like feel to it, best to be sipped and enjoyed.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 Lacerative is about right. I picked up several 2006 bottles, which was not surprisingly hot while fresh. After almost a year I decided it was time to crack another. Still hot! What¬ís here so far is AB on steroids, with the same aggressive profile but with less depth than the original. At times it even seemed to border on the one-dimensional, since the alcohol was in danger of occluding the beer¬ís other characteristics. Obviously from my rating, I still rate this as enjoyable. But we¬íll see what some more time does to this one.

22 oz. Nov. 2003 bottling. Pours a rust color with an off white head that fades to a smattering of sheen. Smells bready, yeasty, with plums and spicy alcohol. Lightly carbonated with a sticky, syrupy mouthfeel. Has a fruit juice bittersweet caramel flavor with a strong grapefruit hop and alcohol taste to finish. 
 The Bastard is best quaffed in it¬ís original ( and more drinkable ) formula. 
Maybe a couple years of cellaring will help. Jan 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: This is a great beer, but its just not my thing. It is too much I think. However, thats what Stone was going for, and they certainly achieved that. It¬ís better on-tap than from the bomber I think. The alcohol is very apparent and I think it could be balanced out better.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

I love, I gotta have more of it.  Dark, yet bright orange-tinged red with a firm fortress of a white foam head.  The thick aroma, I swear, reminds me of pepperoni pizza ... full, earthy, forest-like.  As expected, this assaults my palate with a full-on artillery blast of rich alcohol-laced, dirt-laden hoppiness with an accompanying  huge malty crossfire.  This would go great with a nice meaty chili or a pepperjack cheese burger.  (#3109, 9/24/2007)
I know this beer is supposed to be a monster, but i don¬ít feel the alcohol was balanced out enough. Hops balance the malt well, but on the whole, perhaps too strong for its own good.

Very very rich, dark, elxplosive flavor. Gives a completly welcome kick in the taste buds. The finish has to be my favorite part of this beer, it just lingers for so long that you never lose the tase of great beer in your mouth, even while eating.

2006 Release 

Pours ruby with a sizeable head. I look at it and think that it looks like a gem. Nose is more subdued than I would have thought, but certainly isn¬ít lacking. Sweet like a navel orange or tangerine, with some alcohol and hops on the edge. I also get something like cotton candy. Flavor is smooth and rich. Complexities continue for some time. The hops are there in a mature way, but do not overpower. After a few seconds, the softer sweeter side of the Bastard comes out and you get that warming alcohol feeling on your tongue. To me that is where the Double Bastard shows most. There are two sides to the brew that are different, but come together perfectly. Feel is terrific. Smooth. Very drinkable. Even at 10%. Killer brew, man.

Malted beyond reason. Hopped beyond expectations. Seems like Condensed Stone Ale; add 3 bottles of water to dilute to normal concentration. Lots of influence from belgian styles with an uncompromising malt backbone. Some pine, tart apple, caramel malt, witha  slight alcohol finish - too much to try and decipher it all out. This is exactaly what I expected but still was unprepared.
Oh, so nice. So rich. So intense in flavors. You are truly not worthy if you don¬ít like tis intense beer. How I miss Stone.

Bottle.  Sampled @ BCTC 2007 at RateBeer tent.  Cider-brown coloring with ample head.  Overly sweet, cinnamony, spicy.  Malty, tangy, tart - a little too harsh assault on the senses with an out-of-place alcohol on the roof of mouth ending.  Feels like the guy at the party who tries too hard to be liked . . . if they backed it down a notch, everyone would flock.
Amber colour, withe fluffy head. Aroma is hoppy, some pine. Flavour: lots of hops as well, bitter, dry malts. Softer aftertaste.

Aroma is relative weak, pine, quite hoppy and malty. Clear, dark red coloured with an off-white, thin head. Taste is bitter, strongly hopped with pine hops, but with a nice malty smoothness in it. Good stuff. Thanks to Jerohen for the import.
Ruby coloured, lasting off-white head. Hoppy and fruity nose, not very strong. Very bitter flavour, almost astringent, but very nice. Lasting finish. Nice brew.
Clear redbrown color, short head. Aroma is quite hoppy, bit fruity, some caramel malt. Taste is very bitter, some pine and grapefruit, quite malty. Nice one.

Aquired via trade with Hogtown Harry. I¬íve been wanting to get my hands on this for a long time, so I am very excited! Pours out quite dark and cloudier than the regular ABA. Nose is hops, hops and more hops. First sip- wow. Its like getting hit in the head with a shovel. You scrape yourself off the floor and ask for more. One of the most bitter beers I¬íve had. Booze tast is fairly evident and it has quite a dry finish. Its tough to describe the malt due to the massive hop bill. I would love to get my hands on more of these- however this is the poster child of ¬íenjoy in moderation¬í!

2006 bomber, with a big THANKS to adrian910ss, pours a clear dark ruby amber, like a strong iced tea, with a nice orangish tan head, good lacing.  Interesting sweet malt aroma of candied fruits, caramel, dark fruits, some hops citrus too, but seems to sit behind the malts.  Flavor brings the hops in, but are well balanced against the sweeter malts.  I¬ím not a fan of syrupy sweet, and this takes it to the brink until those hops jump into play.  Well balanced, unique and interesting, another great one from Stone.

Heavy  toasted caramel malt flavor.  Very bitter and tons of citrusy hop flavor.  The malts and hops are very well balanced.  There is a slight alcohol finish.  The body is full with a creamy and syrupy texture along with soft carbonation.
Another awesome brew from Stone, real big hop aroma and great malt flavor and thicvk palate. Not too bitter due to large malt balance,,,great BREW

Thank you stegosaurus !!! I have searched for this one every where. Medium amber pour with an alcohol and sweet malt aroma. Bitter after taste but not to over whelming. I enjoyed it as I do most of Stone beers.

Bottle sampled with Mad_idian, purchased @ Once Upon a Vine in Richmond. Pours deep amber brown with a decent size beige head. Aroma of citrus, fruit, floral hops, and caramel. The flavor is citrus, fruit, caramel, floral bitterness, and a big alcohol kick near the finish.
Draught pint. Dark mahogany with foamy head.  Big hoppy aroma.  Big maltiness, big bitterness, finish that lasted forever.  On a warm day, one sipped is quite enough.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Poured dark amber with off white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, and sweet malt. Flavor of citrus and hops to start. Finished with a sweet malt kick. Good balance that packs a punch.

¬í06 bottle.  Dark auburn with little head.  Aroma of floral hops, candied sugar, malt, and citrus.  Very sweet malty flavor with mild floral hop notes throughout.  This thing is ridiculous it¬ís so good.  Will be seeking out a couple more bottles today.

very dark copper/mahogany color. 
Aroma is quite malty, and lots of floral hops, and citrus, with a really nie brown sugar/caramel sweetness. Flavour has some really nice caramel maltiness to it. Loads of floral hops, and a really awesome bitterness to finish. The alcohol is there, and gives a nice warming to your throat, but other than that the 10% is hidden VERY well. Wow. best american stone i¬íve ever had, hands down!

(05 vintage aged 2 years)  Poured a murky copper with a dirty tan head. Had a rather potent aroma of malts, floral, pine, and hops. The flavor was a little strong up front but, because it was aged it had a mellow finish. There was notes of malts, fruits, citrus, pine and a golden brown sugar. OUTSTANDING ASA!!!

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 My 100th rating!  Woohoo!  A 2005 growler of Double Bastard purchased at Stone Brewery (actually got two growlers, one for trading). This beer is hard to find.  It is sold in $60 huge bottles, or at special Stone tastings.  Nice clean malty aroma.  Should I give it a 9 or 10?  Very little carbonation, so little head or lacing.  The combination of trying a 2yr old year, from tap probably makes the carbonation low.  Very little hops in the aroma.  Nice deep reddish caramel color.  Mild sweet flavor.  Medium to mild hop bitterness.  I wonder if the aging has transformed this into more of a barleywine.  Slight alchohol after taste.  Well balanced.  I gave it a 4.3, but should I go higher?  Hmmm, probably should rerate with an unaged version.

Tried the 2000 and 2003 versions on 11/28/07 at Double Bastard day on tap at Stone.  2000:  Very little oxidation. Little head but some small bubble carbonation around the edge.  Mild aroma.  Some malty caramel goodness.  very dark amber. 8,4,9,4,18: 4.3.
2003:  More oxidation than 2000?!  Lighter color than 2000?! 8,4,9,4,18:4.3

Rated 11/3/06:  Amazing offering by one of my favorite brewers. The Arrogant Bastard was the brew that really started me off on the journey for great beer, and almost a year later I find myself sipping on the Double during an already great Friday Night. The aroma is original and awesome, if I could create a flavor of incense or an air freshener I would want this. Very aromatic throwing malts, hops, dark fruits, citrus notes, with a powerful alcohol kick bringing up the rear. Nice pour looks like the local fermented apple cider with a pencil thin head and minimal lacing, but hey it¬ís a strong one so you can¬ít be too upset. Take a sip and it bites you strong and fast a very aggressive mouthfeel with a smoooooth subtle burn. Flavor is right on and then some, hoppy enough to combat the huge malt content. This is American Barleywine at it¬ís peak. Thank you Stone again and again, thanks!

Bottle.  The aroma is very nice on this one.  It is a mixture of sweet malt, pine hops, citrus/tropical fruit hops.  Very good mouthfeel and full body.  The flavor is good also; mostly sweet malt and piney bittering hops.

2006. Bouteille, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur ambr√©e rouge et transparente. Nez malt√© de caramel toffee sucr√©, fruit√© (cerises, l√©ger de raisins et d¬íagrumes, notes de prunes), de houblon r√©sineux, moyennement citrique et l√©g√®rement terreux, l√©ger d¬íalcool et bois√© (f√ªt de ch√™ne) ainsi que des notes de vanille et de chocolat noir. Post-go√ªt long et un peu sec, amer de houblon citrique, r√©sineux, l√©g√®rement terreux et herbeux, d¬íalcool moyen et l√©g√®rement fruit√© (mo√ªt de raisins et de cerises, zest d¬íagrumes) et bois√© (traces de fum√©e de cigarette).

Duane shared a bomber of this with me.  Aged somewhere around 6 months I believe.  Thanks dad!  Poured reddish/brown with a beige head.  Let it warm up a bit before I drank it.  Aroma was sweet malts, caramel, sugar and some piney hops as well.  Flavor was very well balanced.  Caramel, slightly roasted malt, brown sugar, and a toned down hop finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  I¬íd like to try this fresh, but I have a feeling it¬ís a bit better and more well balanced once its been aged.  Awesome stuff.

Pours hazy dark amber with a off-white head.  Aroma is cookies and carmel, heavy grapefruit, and lightly of broth and hints of vinilla.  Flavor starts well balanced and moderate, nice malt backbone, carmel and dark fruit, with grapefruit juice again.  Alcohol warming in the finish.  Medium to full bodied, creamy and a bit oily, lively carbonated.
A lot more malt  flavor  than I was expecting.  Great hops though.  A little thick for me as well.

Reddish color.  A bit hoppier than the AB, but I enjoyed their IPA better.
A bit of sweetness in this one, perhaps fruit?
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2007 Much better than the arrogant bastard.  Great hops and alcohol flavors.  Pours red with great hops aroma.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009 Bottle, 2004 Vintage; Tasted May 7, 2007.  Pitch red color (if that makes sense) with a large head that collapses quickly.  Monster aroma of sweet malts, tempered by some wicked earthy and slightly piney hops.  Wow... tons of caramel, sugar, slight rum and alcohol.  Raisins, cherries, oak.  The hops seem to have almost vanished in 2+ years, but I really like this.  I¬ím sure a fresh bottle would be a massive hop bomb, but there is nothing wrong with this fine aged specimen.

I have been saving this beer for a special occasion for a few years, and though I thought it should be savored on a celebratory basis, tonight it is in memoriam.  To my friend, Dean.  You were a riot while you were here, a jokester to the end.  You lived a hell of a life and any of us would have been lucky to live half of it.  You are gone far too soon.  I hope God has a tuned up Gibson waiting for you.  He¬ís in for a hell of a concert.  Rest well.  I hope to see you again.  Cheers, friend.

Re-ratings; MN Ratebeer Winter Gathering, January 10, 2009.  2004 Vintage:  Courtesy of MilkmanDan.  Orange color with no head.  Strong caramel malt aroma.  More caramel malts in the flavor.  Lots of toast and biscut.  A bit of chocolate.  Almost no hops left.  7/4/7/3/16  2008 Vintage:  Dark red color with no head.  Very light caramel malt aroma.  Strong, very strong hop flavor.  Heavy on the citrus with some pine in the background.  Caramel malt balances is it out a bit.
Even better than the arrogant bastard,  nice red pour with hops and alcohol flavor all around. Another must have from stone

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 22oz bomber, 2006 batch. Poured a dark, semi-clear bronze/mohogany color with a small beige head that dissipated quickly. Thick aroma of sweet dark malts, lots of caramel, butterscotch and alcohol. Nice initial flavors of vanilla, caramel and lots of sugar, ending in heavy hops bitterness and lots of dry alcohol. Definitely one of my more favorite strong ales!

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2009 bomber, 2005 vintage (aged 21 months). pours hazy amber-copper with off white head. i last sampled this vintage at 1 year next to fresh 2006 bottle and the hops were still live and kicking in it, it was a little subdued but no aged characteristics were taking place. however, with 21 months of age it¬ís noticed instantly in the nose and flavor.....nose has classic BW oxidation characteristics but it¬ís not too much, sherry, dull caramel, plums, and cherries. hops have suffiently faded at this point. flavor has more upfront caramel than when fresh, some vegetable notes of beets, hint of smoke, and prunes. alcohol is hidden much better then when fresh. like assumed, aging this thing 18months+ really turns it into an aged barleywine. i like this hoppy mess of a beer fresh but i think i prefer it toned down and with more complex malt/aged notes.4.0.  12/2/07, 2007 vintage, released a month ago. pours dense reddish brown with small white head. nose has lots of hop notes of bubblegum, grapefruit, and tangerine with some sweet alcohol notes. flavor is pretty bitter with piney, grapefruity hop notes along with some caramelized dark fruits and tabacco. not med body and alcohol is well hidden. this vintage seems less sticky and more drinkable when fresh than previous ones. pretty tasty but not the most refined and sophisticated beer. i prefer this beer aged. 3.7. 

5/12/08, 2005 vintage, about 34 months of age on it. this is tasting great right now, low oxidation, very creamy pour, sweet caramel body with hints of hop flavors still holding on. hops have really faded out but this isn¬ít oxidized or past its prime. just right if you ask me. really tasty and could hold up another few year but this may be peaking. good stuff. 4.0. 

1/2/09 - 7 year vertical 2002-2008. Everyone pretty agreed that the 2003 was the best on the lot, DB aged 5 years. The ‚Äô03 had the best aged character with mild bals

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2007 2005 vintage on tap at Stone.  Aroma of toasted nuts, yeast, and malt.  Caramel and toffee tastes transitioning to a toasty alcoholic flavor and finishing with an intense bitterness and lingering sweetness,  An amazingly good beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear red color with an off-white head. Sweet malty hoppy aroma with some hints of citrus and caramel. Dry malty bitter flavor with lots of hoppy hints and also citrus hints. Slightly sweetish malty and bitter finish with a long hoppy aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 22 oz. bottle.  Poured dark copper, medium white head.  Aroma is filled with citrusy hops, slightly sweetened with malts, alcohol present.  Flavor is full, bursting with bitter hops, eventually rounded out with malty sweetness and alcohol.  Surprisingly smooth for its ABV.  Easily on par with Arrogant Bastard.  Re-rated 5.20.10.  Bomber from 2010.  Poured deep orange with a small tan head.  Aromas of sugar cane, floral hops, citrus, plum, raisins, and a ton of malt.  Flavor is sweet dark fruit initially, moving to a very bitter and astringent hop bite.  Warming alcohol present.  Aftertaste is sweet roasty malt with some sweet citrus.  Bitter, warming, thick, and sticky.  This is seriously good, it¬ís almost like a hopped-up barleywine.  8/4/8/4//17.
Pours a hazy red color with a tan head.  Aroma is of caramel and citrus hops.  Flavor is malty caramel, with a nice bitter hoppy finish.

3L bottle. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber with a large off white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt and caramel with tons of piney hops. Taste is sweet malt and caramel balanced by a piney and resiny hop bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden but lets it self be known when you stand up. Full mouth feel with a perfectly balanced bitterness. Even for a beer of such strength I found it to be very drinkable. One of the best American Strong Ales ever.
Bottled. Semi clear amber coloured with a small head. Round bodied with notes of pines, hops , caramel, grass and alcohol.

Courtesy dsnowden. Gorgeous deep ruby with 3cm  of dense, frothy, off white head. Full of resinous pine tree hops and sweet caramel malt. Big, rich, and hoppy. Full body, balanced carbonation. Lightly syrupy. Very good brew, but I prefer AB.

Pours a deep orange/red.  Looks thick.  Smell of malt/caramel and hops.  taste is much the same with some dark fruits thrown in.  I really like the balance of this beer.  I think this beer has a nice rich flavor but is still drinkable.  One of the best american strong ales I¬íve had.

$4.39/22 oz. seems like a deal.  sweet grain aroma. flavors are sweet, malty and orange then hoppy and dry.  hops stay in the mouth for a very long time.sweetness subdues the alcohol.  taste reminds me of the time i ate beer mixed with cheerios...too sweet to drink alone

Bottle at Chris_O bottlefest 2007.  Attractive red/amber colour with lasting cream coloured head.  Fresh hop grapefruit aroma.  Vanilla, syrupy in mouth and then really aggressive hop on end.  It¬ís unsubtle.  I prefered the standard Arrogant Bastard.  Sticky.  A bit like emery paper over the tongue.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2010 Bomber. Clear dark amber, short yellow head with fine carbonation, fades quickly to a medium-light lace. Marked alcohol aroma (10% ABV) mixed with dark fruits. Heavy body with faintly oily mouth feel. Grapes/raisins/dates to start, slight whisky tones in the middle, and mildly sweet - like baking chocolate from middle to finish. There is a moderate hoppiness which isn‚Äôt too complex. Very enjoyable, but prefer Old Guardian.

Pours a darkish orangy-red, slightly hazy, with a medium-small head persistent with very fine bubbles. Smells of caramel and hop resin.  Reminds me very much of the smell that assaults you as soon as you step into the Stone brewery.  Tastes of thick chewy malts and sweet fruits; raspberries and blueberries laced with chocolate. .. good bitterness throughout.  Mouth feel is also thick and somewhat sticky.The hop bitterness stays with you throughout the alcohol burn, but doesn¬ít quite manage to suppress it, which can only be expected at 10%.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2007 On tap as Turbo Bastard at the 10th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Festival: Pours an effervescent bright copper with a large, dense frothy tan head that coats the glass with lacing as it subsides.  Has a floral buttery popcorn and grapefruity hoppy aroma.  Body starts full and lightly sweet with a huge bitter hoppy bite with some floral, soapy grapefruit flavor.  This has a strange hop character and some off-flavors that I¬ím not too fond of.Earlier Rating: 3/18/2003 Total Score: 4.22002 bottle rated on 8/25/05: The aroma seems to have picked up some more dark fruity complexity as a result of the age and lost some of its hoppiness.  Lots of sweet dark caramel is also noticeable.  The body is still full and malty with the hoppy bitterness still quite strong, especially toward the sticky, dry finish.  I think this stuff would probably age well for a very long time.

2004 Bottle rated on 5/9/05: Has a very rich, malty, caramel, butterscotch aroma well balanced with fresh piney hops.  NIce viscous sweetness throughout with a powerful bitter balance.  Quite enjoyable.  This might be my favorite vintage to date.

2003 Bottle rated on 6/24/2004: Very bitter, yet sweet and somehow balanced.  Goes down refreshingly complex.  A sure bastard of a beer that I can¬ít help but try and try over again.  Thanks TChrome!  


Rerate of 2002 on 4/3/2004: Pours a murky dark brown with a thick cream-colored head.  Strong powerful aroma of pungent hops and thick caramel malt.  The aroma smacked me around and took some getting used to but kinda grew on me.  Nice, thick sweet body with good complexity, very reminiscent of a barleywine.  Even after aging for over a year, this is still a bit over the top and could use some more balance to make it smoother.  Overall a nice bastard of a brew.

2002 bottle rated on 3/18/2003: Sweet caramel aroma with some alcoholic notes.  Smooth caramely butterscotch flavor with a medium bitter finish and a definite warming effect.  Relatively complex and very reminiscent of the arrogant bastard.  A decent brew, but I was expecting a little more.

(Bottle 65 cl) Hazy, orangey brown with a dense, stable, beige head that leaves some laces. Fat aroma of caramel and overripe fruit. Fairly full body with lots of sweet caramel, overripe fruit and cinnamon. A fairly hoppy finish. Lovely. 030407
pretty intense. strong and bitter citrus slam throughout your entire mouth. and it camps there for awhile. smooth palate and moderate body. i like the little brother better. alcohol over the top.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 22 oz bomber - ¬í07 batch.  Re-rate time.  This is way different than I remember - an evident sign of a palate changing over the course of a year.  Able to much better appreciate this beer now....being big and complex.  Starts rather sweet but ends with a killer bitter punch.  Very well rounded; yet cut throat at the same time.  I like this.  Plenty of subtle fruity characteristics hiding behind everything going on up front - wood, caramel, resiny hops.  A great beer if you like em big and bold!
Wonderful hop bitterness with hints of oak.  With out a doubt one of the best beers in the world.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 2006 22oz. bottle $5.99.  Aroma is heavy on the malt and hops with a slightly sweet/spicey undertone but also some alcohol.  Appearance is a murky, dark, red/brown body with a mostly diminishing off-white frothy head with virtually no lasting  lace.  Flavor starts off kinda sweet with moderate bitters and finishes mostly bitter.  Duration is average.  Palate is medium to full bodied with a Oily texture, flat carbonation and a moderate alcoholic finish.  This is a re-rate on a  2007 vintage from BOLTZ7555.  Wow, completely different animal.  The malty caramel and sweet malts are up front but still a very bitter brew.  Much better with some age on it.
You¬íd better be a hop lover! No malt here. This is Stone¬ís frontman beer. No fizzy yellow wussies allowed.

Aroma: sweet malts, citrus hops & some sourish water, vanilla...a bit too sweet for me. 
Apperance: rust-/currant-red...slightly dim...white beige, fluffy head w/ thin lacing. 
Flavour: initial hop flavour...hops remain, hmm... is this just hops? Well well, some full-bodied malts are there. A sweetness is present but disappears leaving a very nice, dry aftertaste. 
Palate: quite nice...slightly slimy...ehm...I don¬ít quite get this

ChrisFest  Aroma is a bit cardboard and lacks fresh fragrance - something I have noticed with other beers strongly dosed with American or citric hops: an intensity of such hops can result in cardboard notes. The beer is warm and relaxed with a growing burn in the mouth. Malt and hops are agreeably balanced and though strong are not offensive. Enjoyable. Buttery and bitter.
extremely bitter, definitely a DOUBLE BASTARD, not a beer you can chug, packed with flavor, strong aroma of hops

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 A Mes rate: Some random sized american bottle at Chris O¬ís extravaganza. Amber colour with a tan head. Heavy on the hops in the nose backed up by the alcohol and some malt. More of the same in the flavour. Big stacks of hops, chunky malt and for me just too much alcohol showing. Oddly enough there was something chocolatey in there too. Palate is very good. Fine beer but probably a little over rated, but hey it¬ís american so it must be better than everything else, right?***rerate*** Tap at the Rake. Jesus. This. Is. Fantastic. Aroma score stays the same, the appearance goes up one thanks to the excellent lace and beautiful colour. The flavour, palate and sheer drinkability are utterly excellent. Having this on tap is a whole different experience to the bottle. The alcohol is well hidden, the chunky malt base is fantastic and the unusually thick biting bitterness is just a thing of joy. Mitch, you got me mate. This is superb.

Bottle 22oz courtesy of MrRomero, Color, was medium amber color with a nice beige head. Plenty of grass and grapefruit in the nose. Taste was slightly sweet with medium malts, nice hops, fairly agrressive, alcohol was present and warming. Palate was medium, nothing oily or cloying. Pretty damn tasty beer, and the label provided a good read.

Bottled - Chris_O Fest March 07.  An amber coloured beer with beige bubbles.  The aroma is inviting and has well balanced malts,hops and alcohol.  The taste is very flavourful.  Moussey hops and tons of malt.  Fruity and full of big alcohol.  Tasty.

Bottle.  [Blind tasting session @ Sk8viking]  #23 Average fizzy white head that was mostly diminishing. Good lacing. Body was clear and flat looking with an amber hue. Good balance between the hoppy and malty notes. Grass, pine, grapefruit, caramel, bread, grain, toffee, toasted. Full bodied with a soft carbonation and a light alcoholic texture. Flavor was balanced between moderated bitter and sweet notes. Nice dry and crisp finish. Another fantastic beer at this tasting.

I tried this beer because, for the most part, I¬íve been really impressed with your product.  But this one was simply TOO MUCH!! for me.  I found it hard to really enjoy because everything about it was so overwhelming!  I commend you because if your goal was to create a totaly over-the-top product then, gentlemen, you have succeded.
Poured muddy brown with a light brown head. Aroma was iced tea and herbal hops. Flavor was light, sweet tea, hops, crisp, bitter, and dry. Not amazing.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 Beautiful deep purple pour with small head. Aroma is slight cherry, pine, dark fruit. Flavor is berries, pine, grapefruit, and floral. Finish is loaded with bitterness and it leaves a mild alcohol burn in the back of the throat. I also get notes of burnt cigarettes in finish. A bit too much of an assault on the senses in my opinion. I¬ím not worthy!

22 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy copper with a very slight off-white head.  Aroma is hops, raspberries, grapefruit and pine.  Taste is VERY bitter with a carbonated bitter pine grapefruit finish.  Very nice.

Thanks to axilla for this trade. Blind rating at sk8viking¬¥s. Pours a light copper with a dark off -white head. Smells of pine, grapefruit and alcohol. Tastes of hops and forest berries. Low carbonation. Sugary. Bitter and sweet finish. ¬¥guess I¬¥m worthy.

Courtesy dsnowden.  2006 bottle.  Pours a gorgeous ruby red with 2cm of off white head.  Smells of floral hops and grapefruit, but not overwhemling.  Somewhat subtle.  Some grapes as well.  Very sweet taste, some molasses, sweet fruits, hops, sweet malts, and raisins.  Hop characters really come out in the beginning, then turn into malts and sweet raisins.  Leaves a pretty bitter aftertaste in the back of the mouth.  Damn good.

poured into tall tulip.  after an arrogant.  pours a dark clear amber with full frothy head.  looks and pours a lot like the arrogant, slightly darker.  it is sweeter, smoother, maltier, and the hops are less present in comparison to the arrogant.  On initial compared to the arrogant it has less hops and more malts, it seems to be fruitier/yeastier, sediment was noticed at the bottom pours of the bottle....  has a whisky type aged/oak presence.... darn good, less afront than the arrogant, sweeter, still I would say they are on par, one is not better than the other....

thanks cmubeerman.  immediately my favorite stone beer.  really malty.  deep brown red and totally clear.  very heady.  actually has a bunch of dark fruit in the aroma.  this could be barleywine.  reasonably chewy.

not a strong showing from stone this year at the SD Strong Ale Fest (Dec 06).  i think consensus was that this tasted like they dumped a batch of Ruination and a batch of Arrogant Bastard together.  It was thick but had more IPA flavors coming through, over top of some hints of chocolate and carmel... weird weird brew.    Earlier Rating: 4/3/2005 Total Score: 4.4damn this was amazing.  seriously.  tasted of choclate and malt and was creamy, nothing bad about this whatsoever.  YAY!!

Rich brown amber in color. Aroma full of pineapple , lemon, citrus wafts. Sweet rich caramel flavors intermixed with bitter hoppiness and alcohol. Smooth and lengthy on the palate revealing a true mouthful to savor and enjoy with each sip. Truly an outstanding tantalizing beer to be sure!!!
A huge beer, lots of hops, caramel malts, dried fruits.  I chill this a bit to cut the alcohol character, which can be obvious.  Definitely hangs with the best "double IPA" beers.

The aroma was deeply nutty and malty with a strong, strong caramel presence. Citrusy hops tickled the nasal passages as did light wafts of alcohol. The biscuity malt presence was deep and interesting. The appearance was lightly hazy medium amber with a tan head which never grew, but did last at the edges of the surface enough to trace the glass. The flavor was malty with a strong biscuity and nutty presence. The hop bittering was excellent and balanced the malt almost perfectly. The toast and caramel coupled with the citrusy hops were well done and had aged very well, very, very well! The body was full and viscous with a moderate level of carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. The malt impression stayed till the very end and the beer ended finally in a dry citrusy malt character long in the aftertaste. Warming from alcohol was present and well done. An excellent beer! 22 ounce bottle. 2002 Release.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle.  I¬íd been saving this one since November and was underwhelmed when I finally tried it. Malty with good hops but too much strong alcohol dominating this beer.  Not upto the standard of other highly ranked beers on this site.

2006 bomber.  Almost opaque ruby brown color, lasting khaki head.  Strong aroma that I could smell from a yard away of wheat, brown sugar, strawberry, lots of stuff -- insert aroma here, this beer probably had it.  Bracing bitterness the whole way through but also extremely smooth and drinkable.  Starts sweet before the "punishing" (sorry Stone, it ain¬ít that bad) attack on the palate.  Taste of berries, brown sugar, creamy mouthfeel.  Awesome beer!

Sampled the 2006 Release. Great aroma full of malty hoppy goodness. Very thick in aroma. The pour is great wit a thick head that slowly disintegrates. Very bubbly as well and has a dark brown hue. Mouthfeel is smooth but has a lingering malty aftertaste. Flavor is packed full of strong hops and a great winter brew.

¬í03 vintage.  

Dark orange pour.  Sweet hoppy smell.  Not too hoppy with a fruity malt body.
Off the charts!!!! Strong alcohol, balanced. Had the 2006 realease in a 22oz bomber.
Pours a nice orangish-brown, foamy head, malty aroma, taste is very malty and of dried dark fruits.  Bitter aftertaste.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2009 2003 Vintage:  3L bottle enjoyed at the "IPA/Porter Brewout" on 2/10/2007...  Wow!  This beer looks at tastes great after a few years in the bottle!  It pours a deep amber/copper color with a large, foamy ivory head.  The carbonation is plentiful and the bubbles are extremely small and look like gold flecks as they shimmer to the surface.  Simply beautiful!  The aroma is rich caramel malt, citrus (candied orange), and sticky pine hops.  The flavor is extremely deep and rich and has tons of thick, sweet caramel malt, aged fruit, and heaps of citrus, pine, and resin hop flavors.  No oxidation at all (somewhat surprising since this was one of the big flip-tops and is just over 3 years old now).  The body is heavy and full, thick and sticky.  Extremely smooth and creamy on the palate.  Overall, this must be Stone Double Bastard at its best.  What a treat!  Thank you so much to whoever brought this.  Hopefully I¬íll be invited when they open the second 2003 3L bottle!
2004 Vintage:  22 oz bottle shared by Lance at the "IPA/Porter Brewout" on 2/10/2007...  I consider myself lucky that I was fortunate enough to be invited to this brewout.  Not only did I get to partake in the 2003 Double Bastard, but I has also able to try the 2004 Double Bastard!  Surprisingly, the 2004 hasn¬ít come along nearly as far as the 2003.  It has the same gorgeous appearance, but isn¬ít nearly as sooth and creamy on the palate and the flavors haven¬ít melded and mellowed quite as well yet.  Overall, it is still quite stong, bitter, and abrasive.  Needless to say, Double Bastard is still holding to its namesake!  It¬ís amazing how much difference one more year can make...
2006 Vintage:  Draught at Dilly Deli on 12/12/2006...  This was the first time I ever had Double Bastard.  It has the same dark amber/brown color and beige/tan head as the bottled version.  However, this beer is somewhat offensive in its youth.  It is quite bitter (not necessarily in a good way) and the alcohol seems a bit too dominant.  The rich maltiness and nice hop flavors seem to be underdevelped.  Nearly full bodied and heavy in the mouth.  Smooth and creamy on the palate.
This beer is wonderful after several (3+) years of age.  It is a bit too harsh when it¬ís still young!  Currently aging in the basement (as of Feb 2007):  1 x 2005 bottle (22 fl oz) and 1 x 2006 bottle (22 fl oz)...
. . . . . . . . . .
2006 Release - "Ye Shall Know the Bastard, and the Bastard Shall Set You Free."
11/06/2009:  Double Bastard Ale...  Aroma:  Vanilla toffee; brown sugar; aged, dried citrus (orange, grapefruit) peel.  Appearance:  Murky, dull brown color; waves of very small, sparkling carbonation bubbles; a growing ivory-colored, dense, foamy head; nearly solid, detailed lacing from the top to bottom of the glass.  Flavor:  Moderately sugar and toffee malt punch in the front; growing dried bitter citrus peel in the middle; ample grapefruit in the spicy and dry finish; the alcohol is definitely obvious in the flavor, burns a bit, and doesn¬ít mix well with the finish; warming sensation; bitterness sticks around for quite awhile.  Palate:  Medium to medium-full body; smooth; creamy texture.  Overall:  Bitterness has subsided, but that was to be expected; this vintage/bottle definitely didn¬ít hold up nearly as well as the 3L bottle had; I am somewhat disappointed overall.
1 Pt. 6 Fl. Oz. bottle ( 10% Alc. Vol.) from my sister. Thanks Eryn!  Score:  7/3/7/3/14 = 3.4
Had on tap at brew pub as part of sampler. Brown/amber color. Tasted up front of fruit and brown sugar, finishing with the hop bitterness. Pretty good beer all and all.

2006 bottle.  Very drinkable.  I would like to taste a fresh bottle and taste the laceration, I mean really taste it.  With the 2006 bottle the taste of the beer goes from sweet to bitter and over-all it makes a nice transition, but again, I think this beer is probably (better) and made for drinking it fresh.  I would buy again.

Tasted the 03 and 04 vintages at MilkmanDan¬ís tasting.  Thanks for these special brews.  These are monster beers!  Strong and very complex with dark fruit, candied sugar, plenty of hops, the whole gammet.  Very enjoyable beers.  Stone delivers once again!

On the doorstep of 300, we poured the Double Bastard on an evening filled with friends and family. It pours a caramel amber color with a beautiful golden, creamy, cascading head. Fair lacing despite the heads ability to last and last. With 13 people participating in this review, we had all varieties of aroma¬ís being noted. Despite the wide spread of scents, we agreed that this is a balanced aroma. Noted aromas were brown sugar, wheat, berries, floral hops, peach/pineapple, cinammon, honey, and alcohol. Initially, the beer is moderately sweet up front, and finishes up with a heavy bitter end which is dominated by the alcohol. Moderate weight in the mouth, it has an oily texture that changes to dry with an alcohol tinge. Overall, this beer is more balanced than the Arrogant Bastard.

Reviewed on February 3, 2007.

this is a knockout beer. bottle from international beverage in GR, came highly recommended and did not disappoint. full flavor, and surprisingly the alcohol content does not overpower like most microbrewery offerings of same nature do.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Rerate.  11th Beer of the Beer Spot Tasting Sunday March 30th, 2008.  Bottle 2004 Vintage provided by King G.  Pours cloudy with a reddish tan ring.  Nose is sweet and malty with an edge of hops.  Taste is sweet, malty with muted hops very nice.  

2005 Bomber.  I¬íve been aging this at home since its release.  I remeber it being a bit too strong, but thought I¬íd see how well it ages.    Pours cloudy brownish orange with a nice large puffy tan head.  The aroma is hoppy and sweet and slightly sour.  The taste is strong, with a hoppy front end, and sweet as it pushes through.  The bitterness of normal AB has been lost to some degree and replaced by a balance between the hopiness and the sweetness.  This is certainly better than I remembered it initially.  I¬íll look forward to aging the rest of my 05 bottles.

Dark, cloudy orange appearance. Aroma is surprisingly sweet but it is more of a citrus, pine hop sweetness rather than from malt.  There is a solid malt body but the aroma is more citrus hops and florals.  This is still very good but I don¬ít think age has done it any favors.

03 vintage pours a hazy orange.  Nice piney hop presence accompanied by a sweet candi sugar sweetness, and citrus.  The flavor is very well balanced with a light hop punch filling in the alcohol and dark fruit candi sugar sweetness.
04 vintage  similiar color, but gives a slight sourness to it, maybe from the piney flavor.  The hops are more intense, but still well balanced by the floral character and dark fruit.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Vintage 2003 pours to an electric shade of fiery orange.  Nose of slight pine, bigger cedar, and dominant pleasant-smelling cleaning products.  Woods, paper, hay, and caramel in the flavor - not immensely intense or intimidating, seeming to have settled into somewhat colorless territory over the years.  Retains a forceful alcoholic undercurrent.

Bottle.  Deep copper, brown, with a thick tan head.  Despite the slight head cold, the hops are impressive.  The aroma is fruit, flowers and pine.  There must be five types of hops in this beer.
  While there is a bitterness there, it¬ís not as scary as the label would make it out to be.  In fact, this beer is rather sweet and heavy, which cuts the bitterness.  What comes through is the alcohol.  The only points lost are for the alcohol in the aroma and flavor.  I¬íd think this fits more as an Imperial IPA. But, what do I know.
user_location: People¬ís Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
[22oz Bomber] 
Deep ark amber color with a nice head.  A great araom of hops and a malt balance that was very good.  Some sweet flavors and the beer was easy and nice to drink  Great stuff.
Fruity aroma with apricot, hops, sweet malt, and vanilla. strong and powerfull taste with a lot of hops sweet fruit, toffee and herbs. A long bitter fruity aftertaste.

It¬ís surprising that a beer so full-bodied can also have such a heavy amount of viscosity.  This is a cookie malted, cheesecake with berries drink to start, then it obliterates all sense of taste.  It¬ís an impressive foray into an ASA with alot of typical character found in Imperial Stout territory.
