Wow this Bastard is doubled! This beer is not for the weak and brittle. Give this to a macro Pale Lager drinker and watch him/her writhe in pain. Aroma of citrus and hops. Taste is STRONG! Strong hops and alcohol with a little malt swirling around in the beginning but don¬ít expect it to stay for dinner. The hops run the gamut here. The mouthfeel was syrupy and thick with little carbonation. Thanks for the trade Dirty_Martini!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: i thought the arrogant bastard was great but this one tops it.  like the name says its twice as good

Bottle.  Good sweet and earthy hoppy nose, with strong alcohol, a strong bitter character on the tongue and lovely finish.  Pours a nice deep ruby red.  Almost like a hoppy barley wine, strong alcohol flavour there.  And it has a definite barleywine kick.  It¬ís deceptively good, and you will get very drunk very quickly if you don¬ít take care (or if you do take care!).  I¬ím not sure if I like it more than the Arrogant Bastard, though.  The AB is a hop kick in the teeth, and this one also cuffs you around the ears.  Hurt me, you nasty bastard.

Bottle, 2006 release.  Pours a very deep clear conceit color with a extremely thick head, almost overcarbed (this beer seems to overdue a lot of things).  Aromas of arrogance and ego trip-esque.  Similar flavors of pride and superiority.  Nice mouthfeel of overconfidence.  Overall, a self indulgent asshole of a beer.  I would have another.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text:
Double Bastard Ale
3 Liter bottle
Medium pour in a tulip glass
Brewed winter 06, consumed 01/07

Poured a clear ruddy brown and amber with a yellowish beige fizzy somewhat diminishing head with good lacing.

Smelt of canned pineapple, citrus grapefruit with moderate tutti frutti , sucre d¬íorge, and light spruce, pear and banana.

Taste was upfront strong bittersweet pineapple and light gelatin and barley sugar followed by a strong/harsh bitter sweaty spruce and pine with light cinnamon and clove spiciness on a long finish.  Palate was medium bodied, softly carbonated, oily, moderately alcoholic and strongly astringent.

Overall, opening a bottle of this size is an occasion itself, and the contents do not disappoint with great bold flavors and aromas.

If this is related to arrogant bastard, this is its distant cousin the MMA fighter.  It kicks you in the mouth, in a good way.  Coppery color with a pleasant tan head.  Very hoppy and well balanced.  Great sipper.  The malt profile isn¬ít incredibly accessible, but its understandable as that certainly wasn¬ít the attempt.

Just had this one and wow, what a great beer. Like taking the Arrogant Bastard and just smoothing it out. Pours a copperish color with a light tan head. The smell great, very hoppy with the alcohol smell. The taste, as I just mentioned is th AB, just smoother and slightly more alcohol taste. Very drinkable and very good.

pours a nice and clear ruby brown, topped by more than an inch of frothy tan foam. Good head retention, spotty lacing. I think the beer is too intimidating for little clingy bubbles to stick around. I smell pine and citrus hops in the aroma - and lots of ¬íem.

I taste very dark malts, toffee and caramel, and more toffee and more caramel, then chocolate, and lots of dark honey, and dry buckwheat pancakes (like they make at The Original Pancake House in Southfield, MI). Then a bit of licorice in the finish. The hops? Abundant citrus and abundant pine and a zesty spicy bitterness that lingers. As does the pine. Did I mention the spiciness...? White Pepper!

Very full beer. Lots of malt, lots of hops, lots of balance. Gentle but very full fantastic carbonation.

Wow! this motherload packs some flavor, smell and appearance. Smell is of pinaepple, oaked wood, spiced aged cheese, and toast. Taste is piny, high hoped and bourban flavored with a dry woody taste. The head is thick and packs a tight lacing that last throughout the glass.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2007 Pours a Dark amber with a dense off white head.  Aromas of Citrus and pine hops.  Laces very well. Tastes of hops, citrus, raisins and slight alcohol.  Slight malty aftertaste with a good amount of hops. I like it!!!

2006 release, from a 22 oz. bottle with a blurb on the back, sampled at a cool cellar temperature in a Arrogant Bastard pint glass.

Poured a clear, deep reddish amber with a fluffy, creamy off-white/pale tan head that settled into a thin sudsy, creamy lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Aromas of citrus, pine, a subtle dark berry fruitiness, caramel, cocoa and clear grainy alcohol.

Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, dry, slick, full bodied, but also a bit airy light mouthfeel, pretty close to perfect for a strong ale.

Some barley wine characteristics, but with a strong ale punch, grapefruit and pine, rind and oily, earthy, fruity, sweet caramelized sugar and roast malts, caramel with a subtle coffee and cocoa, the alcohol is a spicy fusel flavor and provides a nice warming presence in the palate and throat, and a dry grainy, sweet malty, hoppy finish.

Definitely a double bastard, a sipper for sure, but also dangerously quaffable, the alcohol is upfront, but also sneaks up on you towards the end of bomber.

Read somewhere that this beer was considered to be a barleywine and have let it sit in my fridge because I¬íve had some imperfect barleywines lately. I was going to bring about five large bottles to an art opening tomorrow night and I assumed this would be too extreme for the masses.  But the pour indicated it wasn¬ít a bw, too much lovely  froth and a nose very similar to Arrogant Bastard. I had Arrogant Bastard once and was pleased and surprised by it, finding it to be a slightly improved version of SN Celebration Ale (I¬ím always curious about my "beer memory" but  afraid to test its accuracy). This is another notch up from Arrogant Bastard and a truly delicious beer. Maybe I can find another bottle for tomorrow.
Amber to brown, haazee, bitter/sweet like cake cholcolate. could not disern when amt comes through and the hop bitterness, excellent creeemeee mouth feel. could only do one bottle

Double Bastard pours a rich sienna with a creamy, frothy tan head which is fully lasting and has great lacing.  When held to the light, with the glass at an angle, the beer is crystal clear and becomes a yellow-- almost olive color at its thinnest point.  The aroma provides a bit of bread, hibiscus, raisin, cherry, tar, and alcohol.  It is recognized as a Stone beer from the cement-like smell of the yeast.  The body is quite full and has an oily texture that slides right down.  The carbonation is soft and small.  It has a heavily bitter flavor with a moderately sweet aftertaste.  The flavor of grapefruit and medicine lingers for a good while.

Bottle. Pours red-brown, heavy tan head. Reeks of alcohol and... something... unidentifiable. One sip: GAH!!!! It¬ís like swallowing a mouthfull of rusty razor blades, complete with noxious bitter aftertaste that we could taste for 20 minutes after one sip. And it¬ís worse when "repeated". 
Straight down the drain as an offering for the demons of the privy.

Deep copper with a thick frothy light tan head.  Friuty, almost wine-like nose.  Huge malt backbone with a bit of hops.  Great mouthfeel.  Not thick or cloying like some high ABV beers.  Carbonation is right on.  Flavor starts maltly, but not too sweet, and finishes with great hop bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Bomber. Cloudy copper with a medium head. Some lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, toffee, candied oranges and earthy hops. Full body, syrupy texture. 
A lot of earth and perfume hops and caramel sweetness trying to cover the alcohol. (they come close) Long finish. Heavily sweet and moderately bitter.

I¬íve had this beer several times before, but never rated so I grabbed a 2006 release and fired away. Over the past several years, this has been one of the best barleywines I could think of. If I ever wanted to show someone what a great American Barleywine could be, this was it. Now, I opened this bottle at my brothers house and it was received very well, An aroma of huge grapefruits, big alcohol, and sweet malts. Smelling it is like listening to your favorite AC/DC 3-chord riff. Only this is hops, alcohol and malt instead of Back in Black. The pour is a dark burnt orange, crystal clear with a great off=white head. Mouthfeel is full and round, biting with the alcohol and instantly warming. Flavors are excellently blended with the hops, alcohol and malts all coming together in a manner that kicks you in the head and let¬ís you know that you really, really aren¬ít worthy of consuming it¬ís goodness.
Bottle, 22oz. This beer is incredibly full flavored. I thought that the alcohol content was just right for such a stong tasting beer. If you see it, buy it... I miss it already.

(Bottle, thanks to Degarth and hopscotch) Pours beautiful clear, deep dark red. Flowery, citrusy aroma with rasin and a pretty massive malty backdrop.Undertones of cherries, pine, caramel, sweet red apples and some warming alcohol. Flavour is a mix of the above mentioned hop tones with a good malty body. Lingring, bitter aftertaste with some alcohol. Tiny notes of saffron. Big body.

22 oz.  Very flavorful.  Has the subtlety of a jack-hammer, but if you¬íre in the mood, that¬ís just fine.  I enjoyed it very much; would have even more if the alcohol were masked a little bit better.
22oz. Thanks to Styles. Poured a reddish tanish color with a tan head. Aroma of hops and and malt. Taste of coffe and chocolate is good.

I agree with others that this is pretty much a barley wine. I am actually amazed that this is rated as high as it is, since in my opinion this isn¬ít a very well balanced beer. It definately didn¬ít earn the lofty above 4 rating that so many of you have given it. It poured a deep copper color with an eggshell colored head that dissapated quickly but with nice lacing. Aroma was of honey cookies, buttersotch and allspice. Flavor was good, with a fair bit of sweetness and pronounced alcohol. In my batch hops took a backseat to the malt and alcohol profiles. It had nice mouthfeel, but I am not going crazy to try this one again. Thanks to Andrew Crawford for bringing this down from the OC.

22oz bottle-pours a foamy tan head that laces and red color.  Aroma is medium malt-sweet, medium fruit.  Taste is medium malt-caramel, nutty, medium fruit-cherry immediately followed by hops bitterness.  By mid beer the alcohol aftertaste becomes more pronounced.  Big beer.  Occasional.  OK carbonation.

This is a much heavier version of the Arrogant Bastard ale.  Double is so strong it is almost like drinking a barleywine.  I felt the alcohol flavor took away from the rest of what the beer has to offer, which is a lot of complexity.  Overall, I like the original bastard better, although this is a nice sipper.

Pours dark amber with a large beige head. The aroma is heavy with caramel, some hops, slightly fruity and alcohol. The flavor is loaded with fusel alcohol, caramel and citrus. Medium/light body is thin, finish is all hot alcohol burn.

A hazed brown pour with a hell of a head. An aroma that hints of malt but is ruled by an excellent hop hammer. A lot of hops but enough malt to make the balance right down my alley. The 10% was just the right warm not hot at all. Almost hidden. An extra smooth palate that was just excellent. This beer was an excellent hoppy adventure. BTW I had to drink all 22 on NY Eve by myself:((:

So much beer, so much alcohol, so much body.  Pours a deep amber color that isn¬ít as dark as you may imagine.  Lots of hop up front, malty while in mouth and sticky aftertaste after swallowing.  Lots of standard ale taste just jacked up out of what might be a good idea.  Good beer, but unbalanced, sticky and maybe just too much to be enjoyable.  Liked it, but definately a sipping beer.
Tastier and better balanced than the single bastard.  Extremely flavorful.  At the risk of sounding like a wuss, a tiny bit less hops might improve the balance even more.  Either that or more malt.

22oz bomber.  brownish haze pour yields a tremendously styrofoam-looking, dense foamy head that just sits on the brew and doesn¬ít go anywhere.  the lacing is perfection.  my nose is overtaken with the roasted, toasted, caramel malts and the burnt toast hops radiating from my glass.  dark fruits are also noticable on the nose, as is a touch of grapefruit and campfire pine.  effin aye!  hoppy and stout.  this seems to be the culmination of everything on the darkside of brewing rolled up into one lump sum.  there¬ís almost too much going on in the glass.  the finsh is quite long here, ending in bittesweetness.  it needs an intermission and a second act. truly the most unique of damn good beers that i have tasted in many a day.  my hat is off, Stone.  the classification is american strong ale, but i believe stout i2pa about covers it too.

I had the extreme luck to try both the 2005 and the 2006 versions on draft at the Brewery, and of course both versions were fantastic.  The aged version was a more mellowed, but still orangy-bitter concoction than the rougher, but almost as enjoyable 2006 version is.  Just a fantastic beer.
Simply put this is the perfect beer!!!!!!!

Draft at 3Floyds brewpub. Incredible that I¬íve taken this long to find a Stone beer.Pours dark brown, but still lets a nice red light shine through. Thin head with a clingy lace. Big hoppy taste all right. I catch some pine, but it doesn¬ít try to take over the bitterness, and it¬ís matched by a big burly malt taste. Nice and sweet, with plenty of alcohol warmth.
Dark amber pour with small head and sticky lace.  Astringent aroma.  Definite alcohol presence.  Good, but not a 100 percentile.

2004 bomber shared with ross. This stuff is awesome. I got this through Secret Santa, so who ever you are thanks a ton. Pours a dark brown with a thin but respectable head. Aroma is hoppy but it is balanced by some semi-sweetness as well. Taste is freakin amazing it is the perfect mesh of hops and sweet wonderful malty goodness. The double bastard is amazing.

Over-hopped?  I don¬ít understand what that means.  This ale rocks!  It¬ís rich color, flavor and texture are a great compliment to the wonderful hops used to create it.  Anyone who thinks it¬ís over-hopped is not worthy to drink it and should stick with fizzy yellow beers.  If this beer were available all year I would drink it every day.

Fresh 2006 bottle.  Looks nice... clear ruby color with thick off-white head.  This beer certainly is punishing on the palatte... I find it way too over-hopped.  Aroma contains mostly piney hops but some caramel and vanilla malt character.   The flavor, however, is completely unbalanced towards the bitter piney hops.  Palette is soapy and sticky and alcohol content is very noticeable.  Not sure why this is a 100th percentile beer... maybe it¬ís better aged.
Ruby red color with white head. A good taste and smell of hops. It is sweet to the taste, that of fruits and caramel. It has just a small bitter taste that is very pleasant in your mouth.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Amber. Alcoholic taste that is still smooth with a slight bitterness to it. Anniversary gift from my wife.

2006 Bomber.  Finally - the Double Bastard.  Deep ruby/brown color with frothy white head.  Aroma is of big citrus hops & sweet malts, caramel, & more massive sweetness.  Taste starts with massive caramel-malts and big piney-citrus hops tastes.  Dances on the tongue and really satisfies.  I really want to see how this baby ages.  As usual, Stone delivers with a great brew.

Aahhh. The Bastards big brother! This is an explosion of thick chewy flavor. Pours a dark amber with a small head. Nice carbonation also. Flavor is very rich. Heavy candied malts and hops. Good pineapple sweetness mixed in. I loved it.

the reading material on the back of this bottle is pretty good, almost as good as the brew itself, has a really really good aroma of sweet chocolate, caramel, and hops.  has a strong full-bodied taste.  Caramelish with malts, lingering bitter/dry aftertaste.

clear mahogany color with a huge thick creamy off white head, huge lacing. The intial flavor is a Strong blast with a slight sweetness and the finish is long and ends up on the bitter side following the overflowing citrus. I will likely have to set a few of these down with my previous years bigfoots for follow on tastings

Pours a beautiful burboney brown with a medium layer of foamy offwhite head.  Aroma is earthy and hoppy.  Flavor, is pretty much the same.  Starts with a rich earthy malt flavor then quickly kicks into a very dominating piney hop flavor.  Masks the alcohol very well.  Overall, very good.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2010 The aroma is of malts and slight citrus hops. The head is creamy, light brown with excellant lacing and a mostly diminishing head. The hue is amber/brown and clear. The intial flavor is a blast with a slight sweetness and the finish is long and ends up on the bitter side. The body is medium, the texture is creamy and the carbonation is soft. Second time having it and it is still a damn good beer.
9/21/2010 - 2007 Edition; The aroma is malty, caramel, figs/dates and a touch of citrus. The body is cloudy, a golden brown amber. The head is fully diminishing with good lacing. The taste is sweet then bitter. The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation average the finish long. The creaminess sits at the back of the mouth, excellent, held up very well - glad I have a couple more and a few for every year since 2007.

Poured from a 22 oz. bomber.Minimal head with a bouquet of malts and hops. Dark amber color, nice appearance. Big and bold taste filled with hops, but well balanced with caramel malt. I also got a hint of some fruit and pine.  Alcohol is mildly detected, but definitely packs a punch. This is one good bastard!
#300 Bottle 22oz Pours out a crisp amber topped with a nice tall head. Great hop nose and tast as well. A very nice caramel tast. WOW this was GREAT
This had a biting aroma of malt and hops.dark amber color.It had good body and tasted better than the regular Arrogant Bastard ale.Had a sticky finish.Good beer!

Bomber from Liquorama.

Aroma is huge with caramel, toast, sweet bread, citrus and white fruit. Intense aromatics!

Body is dark orange/nrown and holds a very lasting two finger thick tan head that is fluffy and inviting.

Pine, orange zest, tons of caramel, toasty fruit cake notes and a very substantial mouthfeel. It¬ís pretty narrow, but extremely concentrated. A bit too hopped for my personal atstes, but a well made beer and you can taste and feel how costly the grain bill must have been.
22oz - 2006 Release.  Cloudy, ruddy liquid supporting a light tan head.  Oranges and pine on nose.  Piney, boozy blast with crushing bitterness on finish.  This is a good one, but not for me.

Bottle.   Pours a clear mahogany color with a huge thick creamy off white head, huge lacing.   Aroma is dense pine forest, grapefruit gove, dried fruits, malt.   Flavor is gigantic sweet malt, caramel, floral hops, spicy pepper, alcohol.   Palate is full, full, full, medium to high carbonation, dry finish.   Whopper of a beer, and damn good.
On tap @ Pizza Plant Walker Plaza. Great F@#%&n beer. Prefer on draft over the 22oz bottle. Alcohol is present but not overly dominent. Very jealous I didn¬ít get this @ Coles
I love it.  This is a very tasty beer.  Sweeter and smoother than the original Arrogant Bastard.  But the extra alcohol is hidden perfectly and this is a perfectly drinkable brew.
Bottle. Pours hazy caramel with off-white head. Aroma is hops, peach, caramel. Flavor is hops, caramel, malt, apricot, floral, and quite bitter.

Big log cabin pine and citrus hop aroma.  Dense cherry mahogany looks with a tight and sponge right beige head.  Powerful spicy supercharged hops underlayed by a wild game malt.  Plenty of alcohol detectable which only reinforces its character and powers the hops through a strong finish.  Big heavy chewy beer, comes on with a dash of fruity and leaves you nothing but bitter, like a whirlwind infatuation gone wrong.  I love and hate it, and I¬íll keep wanting it when its gone.

this is a hairy beer!!!!, amazing nose, , amber cherry colour lotsa bitter bitter hops , and some sour cherries some malts amd dare i say a little dog shit on the nose. the taste was super bitter hops, some alcohol just extremly earthy nasty bitters.  really odd mouth feel... like i said HAIRY.crazy beer

Nice malty aroma with some earthy hops.  Pours a nice ruby, with a large-off-white head.  Flavor hits sweetish, but then has this nice bitter twang with a beautiful alcohol finish.  Thick.  My sweet lord, high alcohol is already hitting me . . . yum.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2006 Faint aroma. 5 for the Beautiful dark ruby/amber color with very small head. Burns in the throat so it must be good... Feels soapy on the tongue. 5 is generous for Flavor- it¬ís strong but very alcoholic...just okay. 

Not the best tasting beer. If it¬ís high rating is for the 10% abv...i¬íd rather take a shot of liquor than try to force a pint of this down.

#500 for me.  I¬íve been saving this for the past month to be my 500th rating.  Maybe I should have saved it alot longer to have it mellow out more.  It¬ís stated correctly that it¬ís abusive.  Much more than the reg. bastard that I liked better.  I had this 12/10/06 while watching the Cowboys lose to NO.
Bottle.  Heavenly.  Big-time brew.  Full body and loaded with flavor.  Great hop profile.  A true assault.  Beautiful appearence.  High alcohol content has you feeling warm in no time.  My full rec.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2008 Bomber, poured dark red with a off white head, aroma of sweet malt, caramel, faint chocolate, little hop fragrance, faint vanilla, roasted malt flavor with caramel and hops, touch of alcohol, this is a full bodied beer.
This is one heck of a beer.  Very hoppy with a strongly alcoholic burning taste.  Colorwise and headwise, it¬ís a nice beer to look at.  I just would not recommend putting it in your mouth.

Brown body that pretty cloudy.  Head is about two fingers of tan/orange froth.  Aromas are strong and sweet.  Pinapple and oranges with a caramel background.  Mouthfeel is sticky and viscous with a bit of an antiseptic quality if the alcohol catches you just wrong... it doesn¬ít happen every sip and isn¬ít horrible.  Flavor is a nicely balanced version of the aroma... caramel like malt body that holds up a pineapple hops presence and gives way to a warm and bitter bite left by alcohol and hops in the finish.  Very well balanced, but makes little effort to hide the fact that it is probably stronger than you are and will whoop your butt.  The sweetness can be a bit cloying.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Beer-bottle brown stream cascades into a dense, yeast-colored merengue. Blood red liquid in the glass, as limpid and luminous a s a laser beam. Upfront aromatic assault of grapefruit zest and pinesol, caramel, and unripe pineapple is followed hestianitly by baby powder and sawn 2x4s. Brash, staggeringly sweet, maple-y, pecan-y malt flavor barely has time to register before a punishing pinesap/orange/pineapple trainload of hops derails on the tongue¬Ö adrenaline rush! Finishes with and intense smokey, herbal bitterness and an ethanol impact as savage as a cat-o-nine-tails. Mouthfeel begins syrupy, creamy, just short of cloying¬Ö ever so slowly fading to off-dryiness and a tenacious aftertaste of swisher sweets, rasins, orange juice, and shoe polish. Except for the disappointly trite aroma, the beer is actually quite balanced¬Ö huge and turbulent and scary in all respects, like a mosh pit of fat goth chicks. However, in pursuit of sheer strength, it forsakes finesse and complexity.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2009 Traded with Jason from Knightly Spirits back in April for this fool, 2005 Release.  Pours a cloudy orange caramel with a one finger yellow beige head.  Aroma is big chewy malts--raisins, brown sugar, some nuts and toasty grain--and some resiny earthy hops.  This actually smells quite a bit like the Old Guardian, but better.  The flavor seems to lead much more to the malts, though there is a bit of earthy hops again.  I¬ím sure there¬íd be more if this was a newer bottle.  Dry alcoholic finish, with some lingering bitterness.Full bodied, creamy moderate carbonation.   I would like to try a fresher version of this to see how differently the hops would¬íve played out.  Rerate from Hollingshead Deli, draught.  Hops are definitely more assertive, piny, pineappley, and lightly grapefruity.  Same in the flavor.  Finishes with some alcohol, but still well-hidden @ 10%.  Bitterness was at a 5-6 and dry.  Creamy full body.  I like it both fresh and aged, though I think I prefer the livelier hops. No change in the rating.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Wow! Pretty hoppy stuff. Arrogant Bastard is pretty good. Not as hoppy as I¬íd expect the high IBU to be so when I saw Double Bastard Alr it peaked my interest! Hops come out in the flavor. LOTS OF HOPS!! Beautiful ruby red color. Decent head at pour, which falls in a short bit after starting to drink. Hops stay on pallate for quite some time. Aroma reminds me of Bigfoot, though the hop profile sure tastes different. If you don¬ít like a hoppy beer, pass this one by.

It was nothing like I expected it to be.  Much more well balanced than its twin brew.  The caramel flavor seemed to cut the edge and make it more enjoyable than plain bastard.  Great finish kicked with the right amount of bitterness.

bottle.  Arogant Bastard might be my favorite and this is double the goodness.  well maybe not double the goodness but very nice.  dark brown./red pour with thin tan head.  very nice aroma of big caramel malts and floral hops.  lively palate.  big caramel malt and citrus hops.  sugar is a bit strong but mellows as the beer warms.  bitter finish.  I love this bastard.

2006 bottle.  Pours a dark deep ruby red, clear, with a healthy light reddish tan head.  The nose is vague, not quite overpowering in any particular sense.  It does smell strong, with liberal malt, hops, and a touch of alcohol.  Some fruity flavors peak through, but nothing obvious.  the nose is balanced.  The palate is near perfect.  viscous, low in carbonation.  A bit slippery, mouthwarming, and yet still easy drinking.  The flavor on this brew is truly powerful!  I was worried by the aroma, but this really is a bit more than just an amped up Arrogant Bastard.  Big round full malt, but like an Arrogant Bastard, but sweeter and deeper, with hints of toastiness, and other specialty malt sort of flavors, but none in particular obvious.  The hops are huge on this beer.  As big as I¬íve seen in a non IPA.  Big piney flowery, and even hints of grapefruit sort of hops, combines well with the malt, and a less detectable than I thought it would be alcohol.  The finish brings out a truly bitter flavor, a tart tangy pine and grapefruit seed only amplified by the alcohol.  The aftertaste is more of this.  I¬íd think this would get unclean tasting, but the flavor is so distinct, that it¬ís still quite nice on the palate.  As it warmed, the flavors became bolder, dominated by woody and earth flavors, blending well with the incredible malt and and hops.  I am extremely hesitant about handing out perfect scores in any category, but I really truly enjoyed this flavor.  I enjoyed this beer thorough, and I think I¬ím going to buy a few bottles to sit on.

(2006 bottling) This is unique but I am not sure what differentiates this beer from a Barleywine.  Very deep fruit flavors, caramel and bittersweet finish.  Malt, chocolate, currants, sherry and alcohol dominate the flavor.  Very nice considering the 10% ABV.  Not a bad beer, but probably not a repeat buy.

Well, I thought I might like this because I always wanted arrogant bastard to be maltier, but I think there is too much bitterness and alcohol in the flavor.  I love the aroma, which is super malty with some fruits like apples and maybe even papaya, some hops, and bread/yeast.  Similar flavor and very rich but the hops go way up.  I think this beer is good, it certainly has a lot going on and even looks very nice, but maybe just a bit too intense for me!

this is a double rating sort of a blind test I poured the beer into 2 duvel glasses not knowing which year was which. 1st is for the 2006 and the 2nd is for 2004. what a difference between these 2 bottles. the 06 was just loaded with hops and the o4 was more malty. 06  poured a clear garnet, with a tan head. aroma, citrus, orange, grapefruit, grassy with a touch of lemon than a bit of alcohol, sugar. flavor, dry hop  semisweet grapefruit with a squirt of orange on it, with nice alcohol bite at the finish. now the 04 pored a cloudy garnet with a big tan head. aroma honey, malt, brown sugar,dark fruits, with a hint of yeast, and alcohol molasses . flavor, wow the alcohol jumps right out there in the for front followed by some roasted malts, dark honey with raisins. this is so much smoother and easy to drink than the 06. my ratings for these 2 different but the same beers would be the same even though I like the 04 better.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Bottle. Via trade with cbkschubert. Thanks Craig! A little wiff of bubblegum in the aroma at first. Nice foamy head and dark amber body. Good flavor but not as flavorfull as the regular bastard. Still a good beer.

Update: 2006 bottle. has really mellowed down here but in a good way. The hops have become tamed and smooth. The bubblegum aroma has disappeared with a light citrus feel to it.

Update: 2005 Draft. Beautiful body. Great aroma and flavor. Old rating - 4.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2007 Really nice malty caramel aroma with a reddish brown hue and a small head, mostly diminishing.  Flavor is somewhat bittersweet, medium body with an average finish, just a little bit alcoholic, soft carbonation.

Poured from an 06 bomber, this brew poured a beautiful very dark amber.  The nose was powerfully full of hop bitterness and a generall fruity sweetness.  Interestingly the flavor was not as bitter as one might expect given the name and provenance of this beer.  There was a great deal of mixed hop flavors (Chinook was the only one I could pick out) balanced with a fruity maltiness that was almost completely unaffected by the high alcohol content.  Incredibly easy to drink despite the 10% ABV.  Great beer, period.  Wish it was more widely available and bottled in 12 oz 6 pcks.

Poured from bottle into a tulip glass.  The aroma astounded me with its intense fruitiness.  Initially  it burst out with lime and kiwi, and then mellowed into some grapefruity hops.  The first sip will really set you back!  Prominant alcohol burn and aggressive citrusy hops smack you around a bt until your palate acclimates.  Afterwards you can detect the malty subtleties, but they¬íre mostly overwhelmed.  This  is one beautiful beer, with deep a red-ish brown body and a lasting tan head.  Nice lacing too.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a terrific bubbly, thick head.  The head reminds me of the head that develops if you proof yeast in a small bowl before baking bread. Aroma of plums, grapefruit, malt, citrus and pine. These same qualities also come through in the flavor in varying amounts. Really nice, full bodied mouthfeel. The 10% alcohol was not in your face and I thought fairly well hidden. This was really good stuff and I¬ím glad I¬íve got a few more put away to enjoy on a cold winter¬ís night!

Pours reddish amber with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of very fragrant citric hops, notes of grapefruit and melon. Taste is sweet, grapefruit, sticky pine resin, and finishes with an enjoyable alcohol burn. Mouthfeel is full to heavy bodied with lively carbonation. Not as aggressive as expected. Can we expect a Triple Bastard in the future?

Many kudos to Ron for helping me acquire this.  Ron called our local beer store quite often in 2005.  Don¬ít have, don¬ít have, we¬íre out.  This year we upped the calls and got there right after they stocked the shelves.  It was worth the trouble.  Interesting fruity nose - apricot, melon, pine.  Not much of a head but a nice cloudy dark orange.  Comes into your mouth with a lot of gusto.  Mucho hops and malts all in one almost too heavy helping.   But not too much.  Then, amazingly, the hops fade out and don¬ít overpower you.  Well crafted and enjoyable.

great scent, pine, color, is a rich near chocalate brown, little sediment floating around at bottom...Excellent, rich and heavy, not much in the way of bite, near balanced, but defintely bitter and hoppy, Hides alcohol very well, great sweet finish

I have to admit, I was a little intimidated of this beer. 2006 Bomber. Poured a deep ruby/red body with some small floaties. Large, suprisingly short lasting, foamy biege head. Grapefruit, alcohol, fruity/piney aromas. Bittersweet, hoppy, fruity malt flavor with a lingering bitter aftertaste. Alcohol is quite prevalent throughout but not horrible. Full-bodied mouthfeel. This beer is a real great sipper with flavor not for the weak for-sure. I felt,  as with some beers with such hype , that it didn¬ít live up to expectations. I¬ím not saying this beer is very good, I would like to see how this ages and sample again. Great brew!

the best of the "bastards"...deep mahogany body with substantial tan head..aroma of grapefruit, pine, sweet malts, cherry, dates and figs...flavor is a heap of sugary malts, mild grapefruit and floral hops, herbal additives, dark fruits...there is a sort of medicinal quality to the flavor as well...perfect mouthfeel...as Borat would say, "Very Nice!"
Really an amazing beer.  I drank this one and slept like a baby.  Beautiful beer to look at and drink.

Bottle:  poured probably as nice as any beer I have see.  A reddish brown copper color with a nice creamy vanilla head that was most presentable.  Flavor was mostly bitter alcohol that lasted throughout.  The aroma was sweet.  Thanks to Mrs.600ish Edden for the treat, don¬ít know if I was worthy of such a beer at such an early stage, however I think I proved them wrong.  Only one regret, has to be drank with someone whom you enjoy hanging with.  I did a George Thorogood.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a meduim sized off white head that disappears quickly. Aroma of caramel, toffee and pine. Taste of slightly bitter of hops, toasty malt and citrus round out the flavor. The alcohol is up front and personal. A good and interesting beer.

22 oz bottle, 2006 release.  Pours reddish-brown with a small beige head that disappears quickly.  Lots of pine in the aroma, along with grapefruit and alcohol.  Full mouthfeel, the alcohol definitely makes itself known.  Hoppy, fruit, grapefruit, and lots of alcohol.  Very good, but loses points due to the alcohol presence.
It¬ís better than the bastard which is saying something.  Only topped by Stone¬ís standard IPA in my opinion.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 Mini vertical with drewbeerme between a freshly bottled 06 vintage and a 05 vintage.  Both pour a reddish amber with a beige head that fades.  The 06 aroma is so fresh, lots of PNW hops pine grapefruit and a heavy malt aroma underneath that.  The 05 lost lots of that hop aroma leaving a strong malty nose that was very reminiscent of a barley wine, very bigfoot like.  Slick and full mouthfeel where you can really feel the alcohol.  The 06 is bitter and hoppy, camel, thick malts, toffee, fruit, alcohol and a piney grapefruit bitterness.  The 05 is similar but all of those malt flavors come to the front, syruppy barley wine like and much of the hop bitterness is lost.  I prefer the fresh to the aged, with out the hops its a barley wine and it needs that bitterness to counteract that heavy malt.  Though I would like to revist this after about six months and see how those hops have toned down and balanced out this beer.

Vertical from ¬í02 to ¬í08. Thanks to drewbeerme as well as pantanap for making this possible. 
¬í02 pours an amber brown with a beige head that laces down the glass.  Aged malts in the aroma with slight paper.  Fruity malt flavors, alcohol, red fruit, and paper.  Drinkable.  6/4/5/3/12 = 3.0 
¬í03   pours an amber brown with a beige head that laces down the glass.  Nose of fruit, cherries, brown sugar, dough, light but really nice.  Red fruit, citrus, sweet malts balanced with charred flavors are lighter but tasty.  Alcohol is hardly noticeable.  Well balanced, excellent.  9/4/8/4/16 = 4.1  
¬í04  pours an amber brown with a beige head.  Light aromas of malt, fruit, caramel, that are sweet and candied.  Red fruit and charred flavors with noticeable alcohol.  Smooth, but a little sweet and boozy.  7/4/6/4/13 = 3.4 
¬í05  pours an amber brown with a beige head.  Sweet malt juicy nose with prune, dough, sour notes, and oxidation.  Sweeter than the others.  malts, citrus, red fruit, grassy notes, slightly biter and oxidized.  6/4/6/3/12 = 3.2    
¬í06  pours an amber brown with a beige head.  Light aroma of malt and hairspray.  Fruity boozy flavors, green, ah, not good.  5/4/5/3/11 = 2.8 
¬í07  pours an amber brown with a beige head that laces down the glass.  Frutiy citrus nose that¬ís bready and sweet.  Citrus fruit and bready flavors.  Slight grass, bitterness with a slight earthy finish.  Fresh compared to the last samples but super grassy.  7/4/7/4/15 = 3.6 
¬í08  pours an amber brown with a beige head that laces down the glass.  Light malt aromas with citrus fruit and fresh hops.  Oh how its nice to see a strong showing with the hops after the last 6 years.  Red fruit and citrus flavors.  Bitter, fresh and refreshing with a cleansing palate of citrus and grapefruit.  7/4/8/4/15 = 3.9
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2007 Ruby amber color. Bitter flavor from beginning to end. Some fruit taste and sweetness balance the hops. Would be rated higher except that I smell and taste too much alcohol.

Singular aroma of chocolate-like Balsam-fir branch. There could possibly be an edge of chinese food in there. Tempered candy. Pour of ruby with creamy rim. Highlu scorching ten percent, keeping this low. Again, mainly a singular balsam-fir orangey hop presentation, one dimensional and really all not that different from Arrogant. I don¬ít appreciate this as much, because I feel that the extra alcohol throws this out of balance with the malt and that at this level the hop characters pigeonhole¬ís itself.
Another Hall Of Famer from Stone.   I am a masochist and damn proud of my roots.  Stone, press on!

Had on tap at Mad Mex.Aroma is of swet malts,dark fruits and alcohol.Pours dark copper with a reddish tint.Medium off white head.Tastes of sweet malts,citrus and hops.Mouthfeel is medium to full with a smooth bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 Fresh 2006 bottle. Pours deep orange-brown amber with a modest head. Absolutely enormous aroma of orange peel and some peach; lots of caramel. The flavor is powerful - vast amount of malt in this one - and well hopped with plenty of bite to balance the powerful caramel malts and keep this one on the aggressively hopped side of most barley wines.

It¬ís very good, but not exceptional for a 10% beer. I¬ím happy to have another four bottles in the cellar, but I don¬ít particularly regret not buying more.

2006 bottle sampled Nov 2007. 
The beer is oxidizing some, but it¬ís also blending, not so hot as before, not so edged with hops, bringing out plums and brown sugars that weave in with the orange peel hops that are now fading somewhat. Not bad at all, again about a 3.9. We¬íll see what another year does.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2008 Bottle.  Poured with a medium head.  Color was a rich red-auburn.  Initial reaction was wow this is strong.  An assault on the palate.  Ends with a strong hop flavor, but present from the beginning.  A general sweet taste.  Alcohol very present.  Caramel malt flavors.  Complex.  Dry finish.  Liked the 10th anniversary better, but still damn good.    (Rerate; general impressions were the same, but liked it a bit more.  Raise from 3.9 to 4 on January 11th)

Very strong and complex.  Pours a reddish brown with small ring of head. Mostly hop aroma. Tastes syrupy, malty and sweet. Notes of caramel, toffee. Hop flavors come out towards the end. Dry, slightly bitter finish.  The best I¬íve had from Stone.

22 oz bottle: 2006 version.   Nice caramel malts intermingled with a wonderfully balanced hop aroma some light citrus notes and a bit nutty.  Pours a clear maroon with a creamy tan head that lingers around for quite a while.  A complex hop texture comes to the forefront in the taste.  Somewhat sweet, lightly bitter, alcohol is very prevalent.  A sour fruitiness lingers around the palate after the initial sips, going back again it is quite spicy and the alcohol kicks you in the butt.  Palate is nicely bitter, with a sour citrus note, and very interesting.  Overall, This was a very nice pickup for a discounted price.  I love getting good deals on good beers.  It makes them taste that much better.  Cheers!!!

2006 Release, Rated 11/21/06. Pours a deep mahogany red-brown with a medium light brown head. There¬ís a nice piney, herbal hop aroma to start with, and then some grapefruit citrus kicks in. There¬ís good malt presence in the nose, mostly caramel, and sweet at that. 

Double Bastard is big and full bodied. Lots of malts, lots of alcohol, and above average bitterness. There is quite a bit of sweetness to this beer, and at times you¬íre reminded of a flat cola. 

As time goes on, I¬ím noticing more and more spiciness. There¬ís definite pepperiness from the alcohol. There¬ís something similar to the aftertaste of a good cigar. Maybe something like nutmeg or even a bit of cinnamon. 

The beer is smooth drinking for its alcohol, and it passes with a fairly long bitter finish. Given the current sweetness and alcohol, I can only imagine what might happen to this beer after aging a few years. You could be looking at an American competitor to the likes of J.W. Lees.

looks and smells great. Very intensely hopped and very malty.  A little too sweet and the bitterness is nice, but the flavor seems a little one-dimensional and doesn¬ít really evolve like I hoped it would.
2006 Edition.  Reddish, copper color, with off white head.  Fruity aroma with hints of citrus. Overall very smooth with a moderately bitter finish.
22 oz. bottle.  Copper color with off white head.  Medium full exceptionally smooth  body.  Initial sweetness give way to strong hop bitterness.  Extremely well balanced.  One of Stone¬ís best.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 Bomber. Thanks, AbusedGoat! Believe it might be an ¬í03 but none of us is really sure. Pours deep mahogany brown with a big, thick, moussy, lacy, bubble off-white head. You can tell there¬ís an awful lot of unfermented sugar just from the nose--big, thick, cloying toffee-caramel-butterscotch business hits you as soon as you pop that cap. It¬ís really too sweet. By a long shot. The attack is mild, a little velvety on the body, even. Sticky sugars, bitey booze; how much malt did they put in here with this much booze and this much booze food left over? The booze bite is probably sharper than the hop bitterness at the end. I can honestly say I won¬ít finish this one. Too bad.
Draft at Collins Pub. Numbers apply to the draft rating (bottle had merited a 3). Dark ruby amber, crystal clear, thick moussy white head that fades. Huge chocolate, caramel, and vanilla nose. Big thick oily body, minimal carb, super-forward flavors right from the attack. Thick and complicated layers of woody, fruity, sugary, and piney goings-on thoughout the mid-palate, culminating in a dense and clingy finish of pine and caramel.
I remember this stuff being pretty phenomenal when we split a double magnum for the Seahawks Super Bowl, but I have no other bottled comparison and I wasn¬ít rating beer that day. Safe to say the draft rocks.
22 oz Bottle, 2006 Release. Clear copper color with a Lite Brown head.  Aroma of hops and oranges, taste of malt, hops and bitter with bitter after taste

22oz bottleI. love it, wonderfully hoppy aroma: poured a goldish red with a good head. Surprisingly smooth. Definately only for the worthy. It¬ís my 21st birthday and so far this is the best beer of the day, but it¬ís only 5:00.

Aroma: A prominent to intense hop aromaAppearance: Color medium reddish copper;clear, Good head stand
Flavor: Hop flavor is strong and complex, High bitterness, although the malt backbone generally supports the strong hop character and provide the best balance.  A clean, smooth alcohol flavor is  present. Mouthfeel: Smooth, medium-light to medium-full body.  Smooth alcohol warming.    
Overall Impression: An intensely hoppy, very strong pale ale without the big maltiness and/or deeper malt flavors of an American barleywine.  Strongly hopped, but malt balasnced

22oz. bottle.  Fruity, caramel aroma.   Hazy brown/orange color with a thin tan head.   Flavor starts very sweet with candy, and fruit and has a nice bitter hop finish.  Decently thick palate.  A very different brew than what I expected - really surprised me considering Arrogant Bastard is one of my favorites.  Not bad, but I¬ím not sure I would get it again.

From 22oz. 2006 edition.  Pours an orange brown with bubling tan head that quickly subsides.  Nose is large, bready malts, some citrus notes burried underneath.  Sweet, thick malts abound in the flavor, covering up a nice bitterness throughout.  Medium thick palate.  Nice.

Bottle. Pours ruby with a beige head. The aroma is tons of citrus/piney hops, with some sweet notes. The flavor is very aggressive, lots of grapefruit, pineapple, and wine-like characteristics up front, followed by sweet maltiness, and finishing like a candied apple.
22 oz bottle. I wish I could find the Oaked big bottle ... Hoppy, strong alcohol. A truely arrogant beer. One of my favorites. But yeah, Id probably not recommend it to many people..

2006 Bottle:  Pours a deep reddish copper with a bountiful head.  Aroma is purely hops - citrus and florals.  Taste is packed with...  gee, let me think - HOPS!  However, the dominating hops are backed with fruity wine tones and some sweet malt.  Has a silky and rich feel througout the entire glass and will remain one of my favorites from Stone.

Bottle via trade with cbkschubert. Beautiful ruby color.  Floral hop aroma. The flavor was out of this world. Complex malt/hop taste. Sweet but not too sweet,Hoppy but not too hoppy(is that possible??) This is a great beer. Big, aggressive,  rich, sticky, AND with a smooth warming alcohol finish. Thanks, Craig

2006 bottle.  Color is a nice gleaming dark red.  Pretty nice looking with a little creamy toffee colored head.  The aroma is of course similar to arrogant bastard...but on steroids.  Aroma of sweet syrupy candied apples, sweet malts, and not much hop aroma to speak of at all.  The taste i very smooth upfront with malty sweetness coming through, followed by an almost over the top bitterness for a strong ale...but it works well for this beer.  I wouldnt mind trying an older bottle to see if the malt shines through over the bitterness after a couple years.  Good stuff!!!

Pours mahogany/amber with a small creamy reddish/tan head. Dark fruit, caramel, toffee, a bit of alcohol,  and of course, wonderful resiny/piney hop aromas. Flavor is even more complex. Malty sweetness with that same caramel  and toffee, notes of dark fruit undertones, and very forward piny hops. Guess that¬ís a little redundant. Either way, another fantastic ale from Stone.

22oz bottle, 2006 release.  Pours a clear reddish amber; light tan head with attractive lacing.  Huge, hoppy aroma: piney and floral hops, brown sugar.  Full, chewy mouthfeel: piney hops, maple syrup, some red fruits; nicely-balanced (especially for an american strong ale); alcohol remains hidden.  Remarkably balanced finished considering the amount of hops in there.

Dark mahogany pour, ruby highlights, and a small dense tan head.  Smells of dark fruit, citrus, caramel malt, a hint of spice, and a little alcohol.  Very complex flavor with lots of intermingling of figs, caramel and and in your face hop bitterness.  Nice full body but slightly sticky.

From a 22oz Bottle, 2060 Vintage.  Pours a deep cherry wood color with a well sustaining layer of foamy cream head.  Semi-transparent, beautiful coloring.  Gripping aroma.  A load of citrusy hops bites the nose instantly while drifting in for the first whiff.  Creeping in more slowly gets past the somewhat harsh hops and moves on the reveal some soft white apricot fruits.  Full bodied, heavy mouthfeel with a mild, soothing carbonation.  A touch of caramelly sweetness starts out on the tongue before ending with the expected whallop of hop bitterness.  Lots of malt, lots of body, but the complexity seems to be missing.  Just a lot of crystal malt and piney spruce hop resin bitterness going on.  On the plus side, the craftsmanship is excellent - great body, great head retention, and the alcohol is masked frighteningly well.  Good overall, but the malt and hop characters strike me as rich, but not complex overall.  For my money, I would rather simply drink the standard AB, as the flavors are practically the same, and take advantage of the lighter, less chewy body and increased drinkability.

Lots of hops on the nose as well as a molasses sweetness, dried fruits, caramel, and toffee.  Big maltiness and a thin, light carbonation on the body.  Definitely some alcohol burn on the end but at 10% its still well masked.

I was surprised to see this on the shelf...what a nice warming treat for a cold day.  This is a great big ale that has a strong hop flavor and biterness.  There¬ís a sweet fruity charachter to this that is complimented well by the bitter aftertaste...ummmm, hop candy.  The ABV is hidden well but is finding it¬ís way to my head quickly.  Cheers.

Twenty-two-ounce bottle. Poured a redish brown with a thin quickly disolving head with some carbination bubbles visible on the glass. Strong smell of citrus (grapefruit) hops and some malt sweetness. It¬ís been a while since I had an original Bastard, so it is hard to compare but this beer I think it is safe to say has the best balance between malt and hops out of any of the Bastard variations. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel with a bit of alcohol in the throat as it warms but not overdone. Also it becomes more malty as it warms but still has a hoppy aftertaste that last just about the right amount of time.

Finally! I am able to get my hands on this beer! Bottle. Pours a beautiful mahogany with a nice off-white head on top that is leaving nice lacing. Aroma is fruit, malts, hops, caramel, the aroma is huge in this beer. Definitely a complex aroma. Flavor is a hard smack to the face. Lots of flavors within this beer. At first sip you get hit with tons of grapefruit/hops/pine hitting the palate. Fruit and caramel come in after to help sweeten the beer but not too much. The beer is definitely bitter but it is a very nice bitterness, one that makes the beer extremely enjoyable. You can easily tell from the first sip this is the evil big brother of Arrogant Bastard Ale. This beer is simply delicious!

22 oz from mail order.  Description on bottle had me hesitant, but first taste blew me away.  Hops aroma is very strong as is hops taste, but in a very pleasing way.  Poured amber/copper with virtually no head.  Strong aftertaste, but again, if the taste is good, the aftertaste is as well.  This is the best beer I have ever tasted and will be the benchmark I use for future beers.

Smelled hoppy and fruity, but more like an Imperial IPA than a Strong Ale.  Poured a copper amber with a frothy, creamy off white head.  Malty flavor, floral, hoppy.  Finish is far too harsh to make this beer pleasing, too much palatable alcohol.  Good, but better beers are smoother.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2008 Bottle. Wonderful aromas of fruit, flowers and alcohol. The flavors are more of the same. A very dominant hops component with some pronounced alcohol. Additionally there is some floweriness. Pours copper with a small head. Most satisfying and excellent beer.

Smells of hops and alcohol...malts are very apparent...whew!....powerful aroma...color is same as regular bastard dark amber except with burnt orange hues...a very unusual beer...amazed that a 10% brew is this easy to drink...this beer is: "The Essence of Autumn"

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2011 2006 bottle.  Pours similar to the original, dark, deep, opaque, red-brown; head is average, creamy, and somewhat lasting with a canvas color and minimal lacing.  Similar nose but fruitier and stronger; a caramelly, cookie sweetness, dark fruits (maybe plums or prunes), and noticeable piney, resinous, and citrus hops with slight alcohol warming.  Flavor is definitely in your face!  Pine and resin hit first, followed by a nice caramel, cookie-like sweetness with some fruitiness (grapefruit, plum) and vanilla & cinnamon.  Bitterness is high and really takes over by the finish, which contains some alcohol warming and pine and resin which lasts forever.  Palate is soft, creamy and chewy, and full.  Flavors get more complex as it warms.  Interesting and like no other; a strong American with plenty of hops and a slight Belgian strong influence with the fruitiness.  Such a well done beer from such a great brewery and will buy more to age; this is by far my highest rating for a ¬ístrong¬í ale.  The newer vintages seem to have changed the hops, which clash a bit with the malt backbone.  I aged a 2010 bottle for almost a year and it is more like the older versions with a high bitterness, nice malt complexity and hop notes all over.  Looking forward to this year¬ís vintage.

(2006) 22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquor - Opened with a big hiss.  Pours a deep amber color with a good size light tan head.  Nice thick stringy lacing left as the head settles.  Has a sweet, floral, resiny aroma.  Flavor is sweet with a nice hop/malt balance and light esters.  Slight alcohol warming.  A suprisingly smooth, full bodied beer.  An excellent beer.

Bomber.  Aroma:  Lots of sweetness, some dark fruits, grapefruit, caramel and malt, pine and resin, and lots of alcohol.  Big aroma.  Appearance:  Murky reddish-brown.  Light beige head was full and creamy with decent retention.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Lots of sweetness and malt up front.  Sticky sweetness, that if it stuck around I would not like it.  Fortunatly, A ton of hop flavor and bitterness comes in to scrub it away.  Hops are a tasty grapefruit juciness, pineiness, and earthy resin.  Bitterness comes on strong.  But it¬ís needed, and welcome.  Some spice, honey, dark fruit, and caramel also of note.  Lots of alcohol in the finish.  Palate:  Full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Some significant alcohol warming in rear of mouth.  Overall:  Not something I would drink regularly.  I¬ím even glad I shared this bottle, because a whole bottle might be too much.  Bigness is the name of the game here.  Big aroma.  Big flavors.  Big bitterness.  Big alcohol.

Another Milestone...500.  22oz bottle.  Lively hiss upon opening.  First pour shows a filtered deep purple reddish hue.  A mix between red wine and iced tea.  Sweet sugary candy sugar malt nose.  Cocoa and dark fruity notes.  A little cinnamon and cookie mixed within a peppery anise spice rack.  Body is full and strong.  Hmm, let me think...Full and sweet, then the bitter alcohol then the sticky dry alcohol burn then citrusy bitter dry hop finish, then cloying effervescent big burpin¬í lingering aftertaste.  It¬ís a kicker!  Initial cocoa and cinnamon malt sweetness, then the pruny dry bitter middle stands out.  Still get a vanilla oaky, smokey flavor.  Finish is still sweet, but it is played out to a bitter long, coating the tongue piney hop finish.  Which, of course, melds perfectly with the whisky burn and the sticky cooked sugar flavors.  They are arrogant and correct, my palate has been worked over.  Ever angle and flavor was smacked around.  And I still have half the bottle left.  Second glass...More spice in the nose.  More caramel and cinnamon notes.  Maybe not more, but more overt.  More pronounced smokey flavor.  Sticky.  Dry medium roasted coffee notes start to shine through.  Dried fruits.  Slight hint of tart cherries.  This has lived up to the hype.  The flavor is great.  The complexity is there.  The burn is trace.  The finish is lasting.  The effects are blurry.  And the glass is still half full.  Job well done!  Well...done writting, gonna enjoy this.

Rating #200.  This is damn good.  Pours a deep red with an good head.  Very hoppy grapefruit aroma, as well as fruit and malt.  Strong flavor of delicious fruit, sweet malt, very bitter, and pine.  Juicy, bitter, and fairly thick.

22 oz. 2006 release.  Pours a thick creamy dark maroon with a thick head and big slow moving bubbles. Aroma has a strong alcohol presence, sweet toasted carmel notes, and subtle hints of fruit and raisin.  Taste is just as complex.  Medium to heavy mouthfeel, with a nice warming feel from the alcohol.  This bastard freakin¬í rocks!

Now this is what I imagined it would be.  This was an awsome expirence.  I really liked the dark cloudy color of this beer.  It was nice and thick and it warmed as it went down, I could taste the alcohol in this one for sure.  I would love to have more of these.
06 version.  An absolute monster of a beer.  More barleywine than I recall of the 05 and in my mind a lesser beer but still, yet again a staggering achievement.

Oh yeah, double yer pleasure with this !  NOT for novice beer drinkers. Those who want  experience a rich and hearty beer. On the heavy side; some alcohol overtones but smooth. A nice change-of-pace  drink.

slightly souring malt aroma, acrid unripe pineapple with some powdered sugar on it. nice roasty brow with a modest head. slides through the mouth. what impresses me is the smoothness, the balance. my tingling tongue knows there¬ís hops a plenty, but the balancing sweetness is almost honeyed, with some dark cherry and almost an orange taste.

2006 bottle.  Poured a deep copper/amber with a small to medium off white head.  Aroma is dark malts, some dark fruit, a touch of chocolate, and complimentary alcohol.  Taste is about the same as the aroma, with a touch of hops.  I was very impressed by this beer, tastes actually much like the darker belgian beers with a neutral yeast strain.

Bottle: Poured amber in color with a small white head. Smell is full of malt, which seems to hide any hops that are in this beer. I also note a bit of grapefruit. Beer taste is a bit bitter, with a bunch of malt to compliment. I notice a nice grapefruit in this one. Tastes sort of like some barley wines I have had, but with more hop. Interesting, but good.

excellent beer

the alcohol is very present and has a devastating effect.

not for the faint of heart.

Very pleasantly bitter aftertaste, not unlike Campari, but not as sweet

strong hop presence
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2006 Lighlty hoppy and perfume smell.  Medium amber color with decent head.  Flavor is medium hoppy and slighlty sweet/acetic, good complexity and finish.

Good beer 2006 version. One of Stone¬ís better creations than in the past. Alcohol is is present but not as overbarring as in the 10th aniversary. The caramel and hops balance nicely. A l get a slight odd aftertaste that I can¬ít put my finger on. Good beer not bad for teh price either (3.99 for a bomber).

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2006 The sweet caramel aroma hit me in the face from a foot away.  Very strong, and the flavor doesn¬ít disappoint.  Textured malts a plenty, with some hops, although not as much as I expected form Stone.  Extremely well balanced.  Detectable alcohol, although not too much for 10%.  After two I was smiling and couldn¬ít stop.  I tried.  I had one a year ago that was good, and then bought two today from a local beer shop (The Bottle Shoppe, Bellingham, WA) that had been cellared for a year.  Aged very, very well.......Highly recommended!!!
Man...This stuff is rough.  Almost undrinkable, but somehow delicious.  Mind boggling...

Pours much like regular Bastard. Aroma is noticeably maltier. Damn does this smell good. Huge aromas of dark fruit and sugar malts with a lot of citrusy hops to boot. Flavor is much he same with a big hit of malt followed by lots of bitterness. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Medium bodied and very drinkable.
on tap. i rated this but i think it got deleted cuz i said it sucked too hard. not as good as the arrogant bastard. kinda of butthole tasting

An excellent malty like Bonds like brother of the original.  Its almost too much to handle but the boys at Stone Brewery do it right.  There is a surprising malty aroma to the normal Stone metallic aroma goodness.  The inital taste impressions are deep and vast with malt, hops and a heavy freaking note of citrus.  the second thing to go is the malt, being 10% you had to expect is somewhere.  It finishes surprisingly smooth.  a great beer!
big sticky, citrusy and strong.  what else do want in a beer.  similar to arrogant but not as grapfruity and far more sticky sweet. excellent beer.

this is my favorite stone beer so far.  i had this out of the huge three liter bottle that was about a year old.  great huge beer!  citrus taste but had a great maltiness to back it up.  better than arrogant, easily.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 2005 finallly found one of these. Aroma was of light alcohol and a lot of breadiness. The flavor had a lot of sweetness, caramel, breadiness, and some hope bite. I was expecting this to be a lot hoppier but i guess my bottle was a year old. I will have to try a new bottle when it comes out. This was still very good, but should be listed as a barleywine i think.

Rerate: 2006 bottleAbout the same rating on a lot fresher and better stored bottle. A lot more hop presence. Not so much in the aroma but a lot of flavoring and bittering hops. Alcohol was pretty prominate in aroma. Intense beer, very good.
wow, this is a strong brew. Very strong malt and hop flavors. Had a somewhat fruity smell to it. very nice.

Have damn mercy.  If this beer isn¬ít enough to satisfy your taste buds then your and alien.  It has enough flavor and alcohol to make this a one beer wonder.  Strong malt, hop, and alcohol flavors.  One of the ultimate brews.

Bomber, 2005 release.  Clear dark copper-ruby with a light tan frothy head, leaving sheets of lacing.  Aroma of deep caramel malt, brown sugar, a bit of chocolate even.  Fruity notes as well- black cherry, plum, raisin.  Very complex flavor- dark rich maltiness and alcohol, nice warmth, hops come through now and then.  Some charred oak and vanilla on the finish.  This would make a perfect fireside beer on a snowy night.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 Bottle.  Pours a dark amber/reddish-orange color with a fine, almost frothy cream colored head.  Aroma is rather pungent; sweet and malty with citrusy sweetness and hints of alcohol, bourbon especially, and vanilla (with other spices that I can¬ít really pick out specifically).  Also some nice earthy notes and pineyness.  Flavor has a nice balanced bitterness with a chewy hoppiness that I didn¬ít expect from the aroma.  Nice alcohol notes at the end that pairs nicely with the dry finish.  I do wish there was some of that spice and citrus I picked up in the aroma, but still a very nice tasting beer.  Palate is nice; good carbonation, but a tad syrupy.  Great beer, one of Stone¬ís better offerings.  Rerate - brewed 10/07 - boozier than I remember.  I¬ím not sure what keeps them from calling this a barley wine.
Scary beer.. grapefruit flavor lingers and very carbonated. i got the half gallon bottle for $70.00 with the chain and lock on it

Bottle: Poured a deep amber color ale with a small foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of heavy sweet malt with a strong dose of bitter hops. Taste is really sweet with a heavy dose of sweet malt plus a strong bitter hops presence. Body is above average with no discernable trace of alcohol. Very good try at bringing a lot of extreme side to a beer while conserving some balance.

Pours a hazy brown with an inch-thick fluffy head. Strong, rich aroma of malt, hops and spice, maybe a touch of dried fruit. Flavor is a complex bittersweet mixture of sweet malt, dried fruit, warm alcohol and malt with a strong hop presence. Freaking excellent beer. very comparable/similar to the best barleywines I¬íve had, despite being labeled as an American strong ale.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2008 Holy Schnikes! Wow, I have been drinking alot of beer lately (hey, its hot summer!). One of these bombers is kickin me hard.  Very full over the top flavor. NOT for the faint hearted lite beer sipper. Thick, chewy, lots of alcohol. Mama call me a cab! Oh wait, I¬ím at home......This beer will kick you in the keister. 

Updated from 4.2 to 4.5 on 12/25/08. This years batch is phenomenal.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2008 Nice beer. Hazy brown with thick light brown head. Aroma is roasted chocolate with a citrusey background. Strong malt character with a roasted chocolatey dry character. Has a bit of grapefruit bitterness and a firm but balanced hoppy finish.
This Ale just about knocked me over.  Way too strong for my liking, but full of flavour.  Freakin Frog well done.

The Double Bastard is one bad mother. I really loved this beer. The pour was dark reddish brown with a nice head on top. The aromas pour from the glass as soon as you get it out of the bottle. The aroma is of sweet malt and hops. The mouthfeel is one of the best I¬íve experienced. It is thick and creamy--perfect, I would say. The flavors are rich and thick as well. You get plenty of citrusy hops parked right next to lots of sweet satisfying caramel-like malt. This is a rich satisfying brew. The best barleywine I¬íve had. Reminds me quite a bit of Victory Old Horizontal."

(Bottle a bonus from ABUSEDGOAT trade) 2005 release.  Nose of caramel malts with a hint of raisins.  Deep dark amber,semi hazy, with only a tiny beige head; flavor shows caramel malts, with a plummy note, a molasses note, and alcohol present (not surprizing at 10%), and an alcohol and light hop bitterness in the finish, almost halfway between an imperial porter and barleywine.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2007 In the bomber bottle from Roof Bros. I shared this with some pals on Memorial Day. I wish I had been more like Daffy Duck and exclaimed, "Mine, mine, it¬ís all mine!" Pours dark brown, mahoganey blood red. Has a yellow-beige head of sizeable retention. There¬ís all sorts of things going on with the aroma: juniper pine, flower water and grapfruits. This would best be described as an Imperial Porter, if I had to categorize it beyond the broad, catch-all setting of "strong ale." It cleanses the palate with fire. This defininitely lives up to the hype. UPDATE 1/2007: Reddish purple dark amber. Thick beige head. Candy sweet raspberry jolly rancher aroma. Such a burn, not quite as much as a barleywine. Big hops cling to the tongue. hard bitch from hell bitterness. Big acidity.

Hazed red amber ale with a good off white head. Coniferous, resinous hops with floral complexity. In mouth, a pinhous and complex  ale with good floral hops, caramel, light molasse notes, raisinous quality, like a barley wine. Smooth and delicious. Post-Mondial 2006 tasting at Goldorak.

pours thick copper body. small off white head. fantastic aroma. sweet molasses and spicy hops. very balanced flavor. sweet molasses malty backbone with fantastic nutty hop profile. full bodied nice carbonation. long bittersweet finish.

2004 Bottle: Murky soft brown color with a tan dense head.  Sweet aromas, almost like a sweeter barley wine.  Brown sugar, alcohol, something similar to a lot of the brews that were aged in bourbon barrels.  WOW!!  Ok, the flavor is great and then it expands throughout your mouth and into the nasal cavities, yea, all the way into the brain.  It is a virtual "Hello Dolly" to the oral region.  Sweet flavors abound in the midst of this high alcohol fest.  It has a great finish -- smooth and leaves much flavor lingering and eventually . . . a slight burning sensation in the back of the throat.  Thanks Indiana_Red for sharing this treasure.

Rating #500! 2005 vintage. Tap sample from The Freakin¬í Frog. Brown in colour with hints of amber. Low carbonation. Powerful sweet malt aroma with a nice light hoppy citrus fruit (although not Cascade or Centennial, from what I could tell) overlay. More of the same in the mouth with a bit of an alcohol presence, but what surprised me was the lighter than expected body of this beer. Solid bitterness that kept everything in check too. A very drinkable beer for its size. Well done Stone!

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2006 Marketing 101: ¬ìThe customer must identify with the product¬î.  Works for me, this beer is twice what I am.  Cloudy red-wine color with a medium white head.  Smells barley-wine-ish.  Brutal taste of earthy malts, liquorice, burning alcohol, out-of-this-world hops.  Extreme!!  Sampled from a 2 year old impressive 3L bottle that made it look even more scary.

Poured from a bomber a brownish orange with a smal tan head and great lacing. Aroma was of malts and caramel with hop rising in the background. Syrupy body worked well with the taste buds. Flavor started out as brown sugar and malt but just as the tastebuds were getting used to that, the hops kick in and take over. As this brew goes down the alcohol kicks in a bit just to let you know it¬ís there. Another winner for Stone.

This stuff will mess you up.Tastes great and cant taste the alcohol too much. Much better than Arrogant Bastard ale.
But not even close to IPA

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2008 Bottled in 2003. Poured a nice ruby orange to brown color with a very nice head that sustained itself well. The lacing provided was very nice. Aroma was resinous and citrusey, no alcohol at all. The flavor was excellent, probably all the better that it was aged. No pine trees to kill things. Just caramel malts, resinous hops, and citrus fruits (grapefruits probably most prominent). This aged barleywine became a very nice double IPA, my favorite of the "hoppy" styles. Mouthfeel was moderate, not too thick, not too heavy. The dog LOVED the few teaspoons he got and rolled around on his back, while wagging his tail. Re-rate on drafts in Arizona and at SL provided similar experiences. This is perhaps my favorite barleywine out there.

This beer was a bit confusing for my palate as it had an initially sweet taste to it with a bitter kick at the end.  Had a very nice clear caramel color to it and a strong aroma giving a hint of the flavors to come.  As one rater mentioned before, it does leave the mouth feeling quite dehydrated but thats not surprising with a 10% alcohol beer.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 22oz bomber 2004 Release-An aroma of alcohol, malt and hops. Brown reddish with a small head that dissipates even quicker. A heavy body with an alcohol taste and malt. A complex brew that is very tasty.
22oz bottle &quot06 Release-An aroma of hops and malt on a reddish body with a small tan head. Tast of this big boddied brew is og hops, malt, and alcohol. Very tasty and drinkable. 8/4/8/4/17
Post-mondial Tasting (3 litres). Rousse d√©lissieuse, tr√®s beau collet. Arome super de fruit sucr√© cuite. Go√ªt r√©chaufant pr√®sque parfait.

Reddish brown liquid with large light tan head. Plenty of thick lacing.

Complex smells of caramel malt, honey, apples, and alcohol balanced well with some citrusy hops.

The fun continues with some light fruit taste maybe pineapple and a little apple. Lots more caramel malt taste followed by a roasted malt taste. The transitions continue from sweet to spicy. Good spicy hops with plenty of pleasant alcohol warming.

Smooth thick syrupy feel. The only thing that keeps this beer from being a perfect five is the overly dry spicy feel left ten minutes later that leaves my mouth feeling like I just woke up (yeah you know that feeling). Other than that, this is one of the most complex and delicious beers I¬íve had. Thank you again Greg Koch/Stone Brewing.

2005 bomber. Deep copper-orange pour with a thin yellowy tan head. Nose hits you immediately - brown sugary malt and citrusy hops. The strength of the malt in the nose is suprising. Initially, the sweet maltiness is there, but is bludgeoned into submission by the bitter flower. Still, the strength of the two flavors is remarkable. Slightly syrupy body, and the alcohol is hidden well - you only know it is there by the warming down your gullet. Niiice.

Despite supposedly being more "evil" than its smaller brother, it is actually much more balanced and better, even if the hops are more assertive.   Big thick malty palate that is right at the line between being nice and being syrupy.  Loads of American hop aroma and taste, well balanced by carame;ly malt flavors.  Nice.

2005 bottle courtesy of Naven.  Good overall, but I just don¬ít like the hops here.  They come across to me as being very bitter and cloying.  I love hops, but the combination here just doesn¬ít work for me.

2005 bomber - The bastard was taunting me from my fridge, telling me that sure I could handle an Arrogant Bastard, but I didn¬ít have what it takes to down the unruly big brother, double bastard.  So I had no choice but to drink up.  This cocky SOB pours dark brown with a thin head.  The aroma is surprisingly malty given the huge IBUs.  My first sip revealed that though I hadn¬ít smelled them much, there were huge mountains of hops hiding in this dark brew.  The malts I¬íd smelled were completely hammered down by the hops overload.  With 10% ABV well masked, the thick body coats the tongue and leads to a long, bitter finish.  Double Bastard put me in mind of a barley wine that¬ís been hopped all to hell and back.  It¬ís good and I do like big, aggressive beers, but the description is very right about it being "lacerative".   It¬ís very harsh on the palate, much moreso than their comparably hopped Ruination, which I love.  My bottle was about 7 months old.  I¬íd suggest waiting two years or more instead.  Give this biggest of bastards some time to settle down a little bit.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 Pours copper-amber color. Sweet malty aroma with some strong hoppiness- cherry, oranges, cotton candy, maple syrup, caramel, vanilla, pineapple.  Flavor is ultra-hoppy, with tons of citrusy hops on a oaky caramel base; maple syrup, dried cherries and apricots.  Sticky, thick palate.

After tasting the Arrogant, or Single Bastard, I wondered for long what made the Double Bastard indeed double. I was hoping for a second helping of malts rather than hops as I found the original somewhat bitter for my taste. The pour produced a clear but deep ruby body topped of a creamy custard head that rapidly disappeared to yield a central column of carbonation. At the nose I found my inquiries to be answered by a straightforward but complex aroma. Sweet rich malts are well balanced by the alcohol and a fruity blend of cherry, apple, berries, and syrupy orange scents mingles with a creamy coffee note. The flavor was a bit more reminiscent of the single Bastard with its strong grapefruit tonalities accompanied by slightly green coffee and chocolate notes. Some flowery bitterness is also noticeable as it joins the finishing bloom of grape juice leading to a smooth creamy aftertaste. A terrific effort from Stone, and my favorite so far.

Thanks to TannerTavernBoys for sharing this monster.  Aroma is sweet caramel with heavy alcohol presence and piney hops.  Nice brown color to the beer with a white head that forms a halo around the glass.  Flavor is very sweet with caramel malt and toffee.  The finish is lots of piney hops and even more alcohol flavor.  It is a bit thick and syrupy.  A nice beer, but I prefer the Arrogant Bastard.  The alcohol was not at all hidden in this.  Definitely worth trying though.
Dark brown appearance ¬ñ little head -  Molasses, brown sugar with alcohol nose- sweet and dry hoppy taste (raisin?)- texture slightly rough ¬ñ sour/sweet after taste

Pours a very reddish amber with a small white head that laces the glass.  Sweet, floral aroma, it definitely tells the tale of the road ahead.  Big, sweet, and sticky malt blast up front is met with a lesser hop finish, with a trace of burning alcohol.  Mouthfeel is certainly thick and sticky, but it¬ís balanced enough to make the 22oz bottle enjoyable, not a chore.
this is a strong thick ale.sweet and little fruit tones.would drink again but will stick to my stouts.something this thick and strong should be a stout but was good anyway

Stop.  Hammer Time.  Violence in a bottle.  This will turn the baddest mofo¬ís into little piteous heaps of blood and tears.  It¬íll send shivers down your spine and decrease your fertility by 23%.  This stuff is too good for a puny mortal like myself.  In short:  Awesome.

Pours a syrupy deep amber color, kind of brownish, with a thick crop of tan foam. Nose is thick and sweet, with hints of caramel and citrus. Flavor is thick as well. Heavy sweet malts give way to an overpowering alcohol vibe, has a heavy heat on it. Again with stone, you get a beer that isn¬ít terribly good, It¬ís just a kick in the mouth.

Dark copper with a nice tan head and great lacing. Big dark fruit aroma of plum/raisin. Lots of malts upfront with a great bitter kick at the end. Lots of lingering bitterness at the finish.  I prefer the regular bastard but this ones a winner too.
Had a friend bring be a 3 Litre of DB for  Super Bowl weekend. It didn¬ít last one day! Another huge beer by Stone, actually easier to drink than Arrogant Bastard.......
A great beer that I thoroughly enjoyed drinking. Great color, aroma, minimal head, and a taste that was both sweet and a bit fruity at the same time.

I brought a HUGE bottle to a board meeting to celebrate the launch of a startup; I brought it to make the point that a truly unique product can sell at a premium price and does not need to competet with commodities like Budweiser solely on retail price.  Appearance is good ...  a striking copper gold, crystal clear, with a frothy tan head.  Nose is sweet toffee, sweet fruits, and alcohol.  Taste is sweet toffee, dried fruit, cherries, and an alcohol burn; the strong bitterness is not quite sufficien t to compensate for the alcohol.  Mouth is syruppy.  The pieces are all ok, the total package is a little better than ok, but with a bit more carbonation to cut the syrup and less of an alcohol presence this would be much better.  I strongly prefer Arrogant Bastard, Ruination, Smoked Porter, and a few others from Stone.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 A well timed trip to Seattle allowed me to score one precious bottle of this stuff.  I checked 7 places that had some, at least at some point, and one bottle is all I could I find.  Not bad considering I live in helplessly Stone-less Florida.  Very good beer.  The beer poured out of the 22oz bottle with little head.  There wasn¬ít much in the way of aroma.  Being a Double Bastard I was anticipating double everything you¬íll find in a single Bastard.  Not the case.  Still I found it a very smooth and balanced beer. The only fault I find in this beer, other than its availability, is that it was a little too smooth and subdued.  Not a bad thing at all.  Just not what I had expected after waiting so long to finally get a bottle.  I thought I¬íd get run over by the ¬ìIn your face¬î taste I was expecting.  Great beer.  I¬íd love another.

2005 release. Pours a reddish brown with a thin tan head. Sweet aromas of dark fruits and caramel.
